webTitle: England all washed up with somewhere else to go

fields.headline: England all washed up with somewhere else to go
fields.standfirst: The one-day final is moved to tomorrow - or maybe to Monday
fields.trailText: The country that gave cricket a timeless Test has now produced the timeless one-day game. The final of the triangular one-day series between South Africa and England, scheduled to be played at the Wanderers today, has been moved to tomorrow.
fields.body:
The country that gave cricket a timeless Test has now produced the timeless one-day game. The final of the triangular one-day series between South Africa and England, scheduled to be played at the Wanderers today, has been moved to tomorrow.

Sunday always was a reserve day. Now Monday has been opened up as a last option if the match cannot be completed tomorrow. Tomorrow's game is a day-night affair, starting at 2.30, but Monday's would be a day game, from 10.00am. If tomorrow's match is only part-played a completely new game would be staged the following day.

Ali Bacher is perhaps the only cricket executive who could rip up the playing conditions of a tournament. He has even arranged a special charter to take everyone to Bulawayo on Monday night if necessary: Ali Bacher's magic carpet ride.

Pitching the importance of tomorrow's game has become as difficult as pitching the ball in the right place was for Devon Malcolm here.

Even the England captain, Nasser Hussain, hinted at a little ennui yesterday when he was asked to gauge the public reaction back home in the event of a famous victory. "I'd say people back home have probably forgotten all about us after this week," he said.

A number of supporters have flown in recently but it is a little difficult to bang the drum for England given the circumstances of their qualification. They have won only two of their scheduled six round-robin matches and sneaked past Zimbabwe and into the final only on net run-rate after their match at Centurion Park on Wednesday was washed out.

This might be a minor event but it could still represent England's first victory in eight attempts at winning a one-day tournament.

Hussain added: "We used to look forward to our days off. Now we are looking forward to our days on. Even nets are welcome at the moment because it gets us out of our hotel rooms. Both sides are doing a lot of hanging around. The important thing is which side will be more switched on and prepared on the day.

"This will be a big day, with a big crowd and the more of these key games we can win the more confidence we can take into future tournaments."

South Africa have won eight of their 10 one-day internationals against England in this country. "When you play South Africa their batting is so deep the game is never over," Hussain said.

South Africa's captain Hansie Cronje said yesterday: "Whatever happens now I think this summer has erased the memories of the 1998 tour to England. We have now proved we are the better side.

"We have come a long way with our Test cricket and now the side is beginning to settle. The fact that we have four batsmen in the top 10 of the latest ratings proves that. We also have two bowlers in the top 10, which says to me that we are beginning to become a good, all-round Test team.

"For England, Andrew Caddick has made a big difference. He really is a fine cricketer and Nasser Hussain has been a much tougher and more aggressive captain. England are a better side than they were two years ago. Having said that they have won only two of their round-robin matches, so they clearly are beatable."

The rain is proving a little harder to defeat. Yesterday morning, when it had stopped raining for an hour or more, people could still be seen walking around with umbrellas through sheer force of habit. A local weather bureau spokesman said: "These are freak weather conditions."

There is a 30% chance of rain today and the same on Sunday. If the match does not take place the prize money and whatever remaining kudos there is will be shared between the two sides. This is contrary to the announcement this week that South Africa would be adjudged the winners because of their superior record in the round-robin.

 The International Cricket Council has approved the idea of portable pitches following a recent trial "cricket max" game between New Zealand and the West Indies in Christchurch.

webTitle: The Spurs fan who refused to be written off

fields.headline: The Spurs fan who refused to be written off
fields.standfirst: A tale of two Harrises, lots of letters to Sugar and co, and now lawsuits
fields.trailText: Vivek Chaudhary on a tale of one anorak, two Harrises, lots of letters to Sugar and co and now lawsuits.
fields.body:
Like most Tottenham fans, Steven Harris long ago became frustrated at the stuttering progress of his team. Not for him, though, chants of "get your wallet out" directed at the Spurs chairman Alan Sugar. Instead he wrote him a letter. And then another.

Three-and-a-half years and a whole lot of ink later, he had enough correspondence to publish a book, entitled Dear Alan, Dear Harry.

The Harry in the title is the Mirror's football journalist Harry Harris (no relation), whom Steven Harris drew into the web for his coverage of Tottenham, particularly his stories about potential transfer activity.

Harry Harris is now threat ening to sue his namesake over the book, claiming Steven Harris has written defamatory material. Harry Harris is also reported to have called Sportspages, the well-known bookshop, asking it to withdraw the book from its shelves. Unfortunately it had already sold its few copies by the time the call was made.

Harris the Tottenham fan is threatening to counter-sue, claiming Harris the journalist has no right to demand the book be withdrawn. The outcome is an entertaining spat between the two camps, as rival lawyers prepare to exchange writs.

Martin Cruddace, the Mirror's solicitor, said: "We are not over-reacting. The book contains defamatory material about Harry Harris and he is entitled to protect his reputation. Steven Harris can write as many books as he wants criticising Harry Harris but the line has to be drawn somewhere."

In fact, the book - which Harris published himself and now sells via e-mail from his north London home - offers a useful reminder of how an obsessive fan hungry for success can become a thorn in the side of a big club simply by demanding answers. Tottenham's letters to Harris, which are all published in the book, also give an insight into the way some of the country's leading clubs treat their paying customers.

Harris's first letter to Sugar, in August 1996, raised issues such as the future of Spurs, the effects of the Bosman ruling, plans to sign players and even Bruce Rioch's recent sacking from Arsenal. "I was getting very frustrated," he recalls. "I just needed some answers. I really couldn't figure out the direction Sugar wanted to take the club."

The reply, when it came a few days later from Tottenham's then chief executive Claude Littner, was hardly enlightening and somewhat contemptuous, given that Harris is a season-ticket holder and lifelong supporter.

Littner informed Harris in the last paragraph: "Your analyses of football... are not in line with our view and your interpretation of Bosman may not work out that way. Similarly your analysis of, and regard for, Bruce Rioch are based on... well nothing - a bit like the rest of your letter."

It was a red rag to a bull. For Harris the club's off-hand response would prove to be the start of an obsessive, detailed and persistent letter-writing campaign to Sugar in which he sought to find answers to the team's demise during one of the most troublesome periods in its history.

Prior to the start of the 1996-97 season Spurs - then managed by Gerry Francis - had sold Jürgen Klinsmann, the Romanian pair Gica Popescu and Ilie Dumitrescu, and Nick Barmby, replacing them with Ruel Fox, Chris Armstrong, Clive Wilson and Andy Sinton. Steven Harris wanted to know what was going on at his beloved club and admits he became obsessed with firing off letters to Sugar about the decline of his team.

Harris never once received a reply from Harry Harris while Tottenham irregularly replied but that did not put him off from writing more and more inquiring letters, and the anorak extraordinaire did not stop at team issues.

He also wrote letters to Sugar about ticket allocation for an away match against Chelsea, and the location of the seat allocated to the club's former manager Bill Nicholson's seat for last season's Worthington Cup final.

The former Spurs striker Teddy Sheringham was also sent a letter, asking him why he left the club. He never replied. Says Harris: "The letters took up quite a lot of my time. I'm self-employed and the fact that I sometimes never received a reply never put me off.

"I suppose it became a bit like having a pen pal that you don't really like. My friends have been very patient with me and some of them did think it was a bit strange, that I was becoming a bit obsessive. I have been the butt of a lot of jokes but I couldn't stop writing letters because I wanted answers to what was happening at Tottenham."

Spurs fans will, of course, empathise with Harris's frustration, and the book also provides a painful summary of the upheavals at the club over the past few years.

As for Harris, he is enduring another unhappy Tottenham season, and is preparing to express his anger - by letter, of course.

fields.headline: Referee Reed reprimanded
fields.standfirst: Premier League puts the official on probation over his clenched-fist guesture at Anfield
fields.trailText: The Premier League has put referee Mike Reed on probation over his clenched-fist guesture at Anfield last Saturday.
fields.body:
Mike Reed will spend the remainder of his days as a Premiership referee on probation after being severely reprimanded by the Premier League for making a celebratory gesture after Liverpool scored against Leeds United last Saturday.

In a move designed to remind Premiership referees that they must remain detached during the course of matches under their control, the Birmingham official was warned that he would face further action if there was any repeat of such behaviour and he was also censured for commenting on the incident.

The Premier League also announced that Reed would not now be in charge of the televised league match between Everton and Newcastle United at Goodison Park on March 19.

Reed was upset by yesterday's verdict. "I am glad this is my final season," he said.

"I am disappointed by the reaction of the league. I felt I was right awarding the advantage rule but instead I have got a rollicking for it. I had already received a letter telling me to keep my emotions in check but then I was told the incident would be brought up at a meeting. The upshot of that meeting was that the chairman of the board wanted me to be suspended for three games."

Reed was seen to clench his fist in apparent delight after Patrik Berger had scored Liverpool's second goal in a 3-1 win. The official insisted he was congratulating himself for waving play on after Vladimir Smicer had been fouled in the build-up to the goal.

However, Reed's explanation was not convincing enough for the Premier League. "Having considered the available information, we have issued a reprimand and a warning to Mike Reed," said the Premier League spokesman Mike Lee.

"It is essential match officials do not make gestures which could lead to misinterpretation. The impartiality of our officials must not be open to question.

"It does not help when public comments are made by an official while the matter is still under consideration. Mr Reed has been warned to keep his emotions under control in future or face further action."

Reed is the second Premiership referee to be disciplined this year. Rob Harris is serving a one-month suspension after permitting Tranmere Rovers to play on with 11 men after hav ing a player sent off during an FA Cup tie against Sunderland.

With Arsenal far from flying, it is appropriate that Dennis Bergkamp is ready to start for the first time in 2 months against Liverpool tomorrow in a game that will have a crucial bearing on the Champions League shake-up.

Arsène Wenger yesterday stopped short of accepting that Bergkamp's absence had cost his side the title. But he knows the Dutchman, who scored in a friendly against Tottenham in midweek, has been sorely missed, particularly with Nwankwo Kanu at the African Nations Cup.

"We miss that kind of player at the moment," said the Arsenal manager, who also has Tony Adams available again. "He's a link between midfield and the strikers. To have him back is very important."

Terry Cooke has asked for a transfer from Manchester City. The former Manchester United winger has been a peripheral figure there this season.

The former Hull manager Terry Dolan has taken charge at York City. He replaces Neil Thompson, who left the club on Wednesday.

webTitle: Harley street paved with blue and gold

fields.headline: Harley street paved with blue and gold
fields.standfirst: He is young, gifted, left-footed and English. Even more remarkably he is holding a place among Chelsea's foreign legion
fields.trailText: He is young, gifted, left-footed and English. Even more remarkably he is holding a place among Chelsea's foreign legion. Jon Brodkin meets Jon Harley.
fields.body:
Jon Harley is hardly a typical Chelsea player. It is not just that he was born in Maidstone rather than Marseille and is only 20. He still lives in club digs and has a Chelsea-supporting father who is as excited as he is. "The morning after a game he's straight down the newsagent getting all the papers," Harley says. Just like the Desailly family, presumably.

Yet Harley Sr must fear he will need a magnifying glass or a local rag to find any trace of his son after today's game against Wimbledon. Celestine Babayaro is back from the African Nations Cup next week; Graeme le Saux should return from injury in a fortnight.

Despite his excellent form as an emergency left-back, Harley will surely be relegated to third choice and shoved back in the reserves to play with nobodies like Gianfranco Zola. Apparently not.

"I think Jon Harley's done enough," says the assistant manager at Stamford Bridge, Graham Rix. "If he carries on the way he's been playing and retains his attitude and level-headedness there's no reason he shouldn't stay in the team.

"The fact that he's 20 and Le Saux's 31 doesn't make any difference. If they deserve to be in the team they will be. Otherwise it knocks every youngster in the club. They think 'What chance have I got?' It has given everyone in the youth development side a boost to see Jon Harley and John Terry get in a very good team."

Listening to Harley destroys the notion that Chelsea's home-grown starlets are banished to a corner wearing dunces' caps, left to curse the imports, clean their cars and feel that because they carry a British passport they will never get a chance.

Terry, a 19-year-old centre-back, has also played more regularly this season and, although Chelsea recognise the need to bring down the age of their squad, Harley believes talent - not a change of managerial plan - has been decisive.

"If you're good enough you will get your chance," he says. "I don't think it's a different approach. It just shows that, if young players are ready, they will come through. Before I don't know if the players were ready. Now they are."

No question of resenting the foreign bodies then? "Everyone we've bought we've learned from," he retorts. "The foreigners we've had have been world class. It might be an issue if they were buying players who aren't that great and were blocking English players just as good. But I don't think it's a problem."

Almost inevitably, though, Harley will be rested soon. It is hard to imagine his manager, Gianluca Vialli, playing him in Marseille on February 29. And then the worry is that the wheel will turn back to him at the speed of turnstiles at the Dome.

Despite three appearances in his more natural left midfield slot in April 1998, he played only one minute of first-team football in the next 16 months. "I didn't even touch the ball," he says. Frustration set in.

"All I wanted to do was play in the first team. I felt I was ready. Also it was the last year of my contract, so I didn't know what was going to happen." A new 3-year deal answered that. Vialli has high hopes.

"I'm sure that very soon he will be the complete player," says Vialli. "He's got fresh legs, he's quick, he's fearless, he's got a lovely left foot and plenty of enthusiasm. He's got to work on his personality on the pitch; the way he behaves, the way he talks to his team-mates. But that's linked with experience."

All this is good news for Kevin Keegan. The dearth of left-sided players is well documented but in Harley and Manchester United's Danny Higginbotham he has two with potential. Harley is confident yet comfortingly down-to-earth. He lives in digs in Northolt, where his dinner is cooked for him, and visits his parents at weekends. Last month he was earning £250 a week, marginally more than George Weah gets an hour. He also thinks players are overpaid, not that he is complaining.

Today will be his seventh straight start (what Zola would give for that). And, although he now knows he can match the best, he is no big-head. He acknowledges the need to improve his heading and strength and is visiting the gym unprompted. "I've been pushed off the ball a few times," he says.

On occasion one senses Harley cannot believe the sudden turnaround. When the Chelsea fans first chanted "Jon Harley" he heard it as "Vialli". No matter, the chants have continued as the fans appreciate not only his youth and talent but also his Englishness. He is a Chelsea fan himself.

It is hard to believe that until this season he had never played left-back and was pushed there only to prepare for Babayaro's absence after Le Saux hurt an ankle. Playing alongside Marcel Desailly and Frank Leboeuf helps.

"It seems I get more time on the ball than in the reserves," he says. "But the movement of the forwards is much better than I've been used to. Marcel and Frank tell me what to do. They're constantly talking but Wise is the one. How he comes off without losing his voice I don't know."

Harley seems a quieter type, though steely determined, not unlike the person he roomed with at the FA's Lilleshall school of excellence: the England striker Michael Owen. "Everyone knew Michael was ready for stardom. Our tactics were get the ball to him and he'd score," recalls Harley.

Owen has proved his worth at the top. Now Harley must do the same. "He's done well," says Vialli, "but the test will come. At the moment nobody's expecting anything because he's young. In a few months we will see if he can cope with the pressure. I hope he can." Put your lire on it.

"I've been pushed off the ball a few times," he says. On occasion one senses Harley cannot believe the sudden turnaround. When the Chelsea fans first chanted "Jon Harley" he heard it as "Vialli". No matter, the chants have continued as the fans appreciate not only his youth and talent but also his Englishness. He is a Chelsea fan himself. It is hard to believe that until this season he had never played left-back and was pushed there only to prepare for Babayaro's absence after Le Saux hurt an ankle. Playing alongside Marcel Desailly and Frank Leboeuf helps. "It seems I get more time on the ball than in the reserves," he says. "But the movement of the forwards is much better than I've been used to. Marcel and Frank tell me what to do. They're constantly talking but Wise is the one. How he comes off without losing his voice I don't know." Harley seems a quieter type, though steely determined, not unlike the person he roomed with at the FA's Lilleshall school of excellence: the England striker Michael Owen. "Everyone knew Michael was ready for stardom. Our tactics were get the ball to him and he'd score," recalls Harley. Owen has proved his worth at the top. Now Harley must do the same. "He's done well," says Vialli, "but the test will come. At the moment nobody's expecting anything because he's young. In a few months we will see if he can cope with the pressure. I hope he can." Put your lire on it.

webTitle: Busst the boss is alive - and kicking

fields.headline: Busst the boss is alive - and kicking
fields.standfirst: After a horrific leg fracture and 17 operations, the old Sky Blue is doing just fine
fields.trailText: Roy Collins catches up on the recuperation of former Coventry defender David Busst who, after suffering a horrific leg fracture that put Peter Schmeichel into counselling, has had to endure 17 operations to repair the damage.
fields.body:
David Busst is so matter of fact describing the 17th, and last, operation that has finally allowed him to kick a ball again that he could be a mechanic explaining how he has changed the spark plugs in your car and tightened up the fan belt.

Busst, the former Coventry defender who is now managing Solihull Borough, had 15 operations in 12 months following the leg break at Old Trafford four years ago that was so horrific it sent the then Manchester United goalkeeper Peter Schmeichel into counselling.

There were operations to put pins in, operations to take them out, skin grafts, muscle flaps. But it was an operation in May 1998 that restored his ability to kick with his right foot and got his hopes of re turning to football as a coach up and running, so to speak.

"It wasn't the break that stopped me playing", he explains, "but the damage to all my tendons and a dropped foot. So the last operation I had was a tendon transfer, where they move all the tendons about and tighten them up."

He still walks with a limp and cannot raise his foot above the horizontal but it is now held in a firm position, a little like the head of a golf club. "The only thing I can't do is chip a ball," he says, "but then I never could."

It is impossible to prevent your teeth grinding as you recall the details of the career-ending injury on April 8, 1996 - Busst's leg bent back at a 90-degree angle after a challenge for the ball following a corner; the game held up for almost 10 minutes as they mopped up his blood; and Busst in so much pain as he was carried off that "I couldn't hear 50,000 fans applauding me above the noise of my own screams". Schmeichel was so affected that he had a brief spell of counselling to get over it.

Busst was 28 then. Now 32, he has seen the inside of more hospitals and clinics than Elizabeth Taylor. But he never once contemplated the Priory clinic because he is not, he says, a man given to depression. In any case, the hundreds of interviews he gave in the months after leaving hospital proved more therapeutic than years of counselling.

He says: "I never had any media attention as a player. But for six months after the injury, I was on Sky Sports, down to London all the time to do TV and radio, and every paper was phoning for interviews. Only when it all stopped and no one was interested any more did I think, 'Oh God, that's it now.' "

The thought he found most difficult to cope with was not the loss of his playing career and the likelihood he would not be able to coach, but that he would not be able to kick a ball in the garden or on the beach with his children, Leah, 13, and three-year-old Cobi.

Thanks to that final operation, Leah and Cobi have a fully functioning daddy and Coventry have a popular assistant community officer who organises after-school coaching sessions for local kids and sets up half-term courses. He is also the newly appointed manager of Solihull Borough in the Dr Martens League Western Division, one of his former clubs.

Busst was coaching their under-18s as part of his practical for the Uefa A badge when he was asked to take over from the sacked Paul Dyson a month ago. He has since steered the team to four successive wins, including a Worcester Cup success against the Dr Martens Premier Division side Redditch in midweek.

That encounter, like today's league match against the runaway leaders Moor Green, the club from whom Coventry signed him, is both a home and away match. Solihull flogged their ground 10 years ago and have since been sharing with Redditch and Moor Green. Next season, however, they will move into a new, 3,000-seat stadium, which should improve attendances that are currently under 200.

Having had only four years and 50 games in the Premiership, after signing for Coventry at 24, Busst empathises more closely with the non-league player. He says: "I appreciate where these lads are coming from. I know what it's like to come to Monday night training feeling exhausted after a full day's work, particularly the ones who work in the building trade. The last thing they need is me shouting at them, which can only make them ask, 'Why am I doing this?' "

He has found himself doing a bit of a Gordon Strachan on the touchline, but he is trying to curb that, too. "You can't really change things and I remember when managers used to bawl at me and you'd pretend you couldn't hear. Shouting can have a positive effect but it can have a negative one, making a player scared to even want the ball."

Solihull, he says, are a family club that extended to full-blown nepotism when he appointed his dad John, former manager of Evesham, as scout. Premiership stars would cringe at the players' workload - if they are successful in the league and the four cups, they can play 60 games a season. And most of them also turn out for Sunday morning teams.

Busst, who hopes to get his A badge this summer, has no long-term plans. Having never considered management before it was thrust upon him, he is just seeing whether he likes it. And he is literally happy just to be alive - and kicking.

fields.headline: Boro chairman's patience wears thin
fields.trailText: The pressure on Bryan Robson increased yesterday when, for the first time, his chairman Steve Gibson said that Middlesbrough's showing this season was "not acceptable".
fields.body:
The pressure on Bryan Robson increased yesterday when, for the first time, his chairman Steve Gibson said that Middlesbrough's showing this season was "not acceptable".

Gibson has steadfastly backed Robson but his patience is finally wearing thin with a man whose status far outweighs his managerial achievements.

Middlesbrough are only four points off the relegation zone and have been knocked out of both cups by Wrexham and Tranmere in a torrid four-day spell before Christmas.

"We are not satisfied with where we are. We need to win our first major trophy and we need to win our first place in Europe; that has to be our next step," said Gibson.

"This season we have been knocked out of both cup competitions by lower-league sides and we are in the bottom half of the Premiership. That is not acceptable.

"I did not expect us to be looking over our shoulders at this stage of the season and I did not expect to be knocked out of the cups by lesser teams. We have the right to look for a much better and productive season next year."

Whether Robson will be around to oversee matters remains debatable. After vitriolic criticism from Boro's supporters in recent weeks, the 43-year-old displayed the first chinks of vulnerability by conceding he would assess his situation depending on the club's position at the end of the season.

In 5 years on Teesside he has spent £63m, only for Mid dlesbrough to become embroiled in their second relegation fight in three seasons after winning one of their last 10 Premiership matches, scoring just seven goals in the process.

However, Gibson qualified his comments by saying: "There are one or two clubs who may be out of reach, such as Barcelona and Manchester United, but provided we all stick together, the fans and the club, we can go forward. The next five or six years can be the most successful in our history.

"What has been achieved in the past is only mediocrity and this club, with its fan base and the support we enjoy, are ready to go forward."

Robson suffered another disappointment yesterday when he received a fax from Atletico Madrid saying that the former Leeds striker Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink was not for sale.

Meanwhile, Danny Wilson's season took another turn for the worse yesterday when, in a Belgian newspaper interview, Sheffield Wednesday's striker Gilles de Bilde was quoted as heavily criticising his team-mates, their style of play and the English game in general.

"People say how brilliant it is, but it's only the foreign players who make the difference," said the Belgian. "Manchester United are the only exception. In all the other teams the strikers and attacking midfielders all come from abroad, especially at Wednesday.

"All the good balls are from Wim Jonk. He gives you passes to feet; passes from the other players go over your head. The players just give it a long kick and it is up to me and Gerald Sibon to do something about it."

webTitle: Myopic vision sees fashion victims stack up

fields.headline: Myopic vision sees fashion victims stack up
fields.standfirst: Barnes the victim of fashion to turn top players into managers
fields.trailText: John Barnes has been the victim of a fashion to turn top players into managers, and those who appointed him should shoulder the blame for Celtic's continued demise.
fields.body:
John Barnes has always been a sharp dresser off the field. For a time, when a player, he wore a natty jacket with convicts' arrows which owed more to Sing-Sing than Saville Row.

Yet at Celtic Barnes proved himself singularly ill-suited to football management. No, maybe that is not quite fair. After all he was voted the Scottish manager of the month for December - just three weeks before Thursday's dismissal.

What Barnes singularly failed to do, however, was turn a losing team around and for that he was arguably less to blame than those who appointed him. The managerial casualty list is littered with the names of famous footballers who have been handed the reins at big clubs and promptly headed for the nearest canyon.

Barnes's playing career, and in particular his 10 years at Liverpool, may have left him with a profound knowledge of the game and clearly Kenny Dalglish, having been appointed Celtic's technical director last summer, felt that this experience justified making him head coach. But whatever his title there was bound to come a time when Barnes would be required to manage, rather than instruct or organise, and this is where his lack of experience became exposed.

The sign of good coaching is when a plan is working, the set-pieces are coming off and the players are comfortable with the chosen system. Good management, on the other hand, is when things begin to go wrong and the players have sufficient character and motivation to put it right and this is a quality rarely achieved without a solid learning process.

There has to be a kernel of natural managerial ability in a person's make-up to begin with. Brian Clough had it when he went into management at Hartlepool. David O'Leary has it at Leeds and owes much to his apprenticeship under George Graham, who in turn had a good grounding at Millwall.

The lofty reigns of Ruud Gullit at Chelsea and Newcastle were not noted for their handling of the diverse personalities that make up a professional football team. And the jury is still out on Bryan Robson, who has now been in charge at Boro for six years but has yet to acquire a master's ticket when it comes to arresting the seasonal drift.

Then there is Dalglish himself. To look at his managerial record, with championships won at Liverpool and Blackburn Rovers, not to mention a league and FA Cup double, Dalglish's credentials might seem impeccable. Look closer, however, and flaws start to appear.

His success at Anfield, backed by 25 years of honours under Bill Shankly and Bob Paisley, stalled when it came to rebuilding an ageing side and was followed by a stressful departure, which admittedly owed something to the Hillsborough tragedy. At Ewood Park, supported by Jack Walker's millions, he created a title-winning team only to step aside the following season when, for a time, he became director of football.

Having taken over from Kevin Keegan at Newcastle Dalglish contrived to make the Premier League's most entertaining side as dull as a Victorian Sunday.

Now, in the short term, he has to run the Celtic team as a hands-on manager. Publicly blaming the players for Barnes's departure, however justifiably, might not have been the most tactful of starts.

Dalglish has a seven-year contract at Parkhead, said to be worth £5m, which may be a measure of the high regard in which, as one of the best British footballers of all time, he is held at Celtic. But given the uncertainties of not only football but the stock market, which saw £4m wiped off the share value of Celtic plc following Tuesday's Scottish FA Cup defeat by Inverness Caledonian Thistle, it still seems a remarkably generous appointment.

Maybe Celtic were hoping that a strong presence of former Liverpool players - Terry McDermott was one of Dalglish's assistants at Parkhead - would spark the sort of revival achieved at Rangers under Graeme Souness. But once Souness left Ibrox for Anfield his limitations as a manager became more apparent.

The lingering belief that outstanding deeds on the field automatically confer on a retired player the gifts of motivation, inspiration and a deep understanding of the human psyche gets less credible as the financial side of the game becomes increasingly tied up with big business.

There, the managers are products of a hard school of learning which much of British football, unlike other European countries with their courses and coaching diplomas, still ignores.

There is still no substitute for knowledge and experience in dealing with players, who are often as perverse as racehorses. Bobby Robson, who will be 67 on Friday, has wasted little time proving the point at St James' Park and his experience includes a spell on the dole.

Some may feel that the Celtic job has become a poisoned chalice, what with the current dominance of Rangers, the influence of the plc and leading investors and the possibility that the meltdown at Parkhead is far from complete. Perhaps nobody in his right mind would want Barnes's job but in football the prospect of glory, however distant, always did far outweigh common sense.

fields.headline: Soccer diary
fields.standfirst: Joachim suffers Chinese whispers
fields.trailText: Gut-busting players, hackneyed headlines, food of giants, and official oddities.
fields.body:
When Aston Villa's Julian Joachim lost half a stone in four days because of a bout of flu, he knew exactly where to go to put the weight back on - his own Chinese restaurant, the Happy Valley in Leicester.

"Fortunately all the food came free," he says with a footballer's sense of priority. Now Villa fans are hoping that the next time Joachim scores, he will feel like another one 20 minutes later.

 Plaudits were widespread and resounding for the Sun's back-page headline on Celtic's Scottish Cup defeat: Super Caley Go Ballistic, Celtic Are Atrocious. But nothing is new. The Daily Star more than 20 years ago had: Super Caley Are Fantastic, Airdrie Quite Atrocious.

 Eating disorder: A letter in the official Manchester United magazine. "Sometimes I look at my evening meal and think of United. The meat on my plate is the heart of the team, Jaap, Keano and Becks; the potatoes are the honest footsoldiers like Gary Neville and Denis Irwin; and the peas are those vital squad players, Ole Gunnar and Teddy. It all adds up to a delicious meal."

 It is easy to sympathise with Stan Collymore. "I never felt I was wanted. I can only remember receiving praise three times. If they'd have given me more encouragement they could have got 20% more out of me." Leicester's Martin O'Neill on his time as a Nottingham Forest player.

 Never mind David Beckham's sarong. Dwight Yorke admits on a soon-to-be-aired ITV2 programme that he used to play netball in Tobago and then completes the challenge of ironing 15 pleats in a netball skirt in 30 seconds.

 Look, it is simply not true that Celtic are thinking of signing Everton's David Weir so that they can have a back line of Weir, Tebily, Scheidt.

 Everybody knows that the referee is blind, but what about the assistants? Peter Rhoden was running the line during a recent cup game in Seaton Carew when the ref called off the match because of high winds and hail.

However, Rhoden failed to hear the call or notice the exodus and remained in position for a full five minutes before realising he was the only one left. "I thought play was held up at the far end," he pleaded in mitigation.

 Talking of match officials, a very poorly ref asks a priest if he thinks there will be football in heaven. "Well, there's good news and bad news," replies the priest. "The good news is that there is football in heaven. The bad news is that you've got a game next Saturday."

And before anyone complains, that was taken from the Reading Referees' Association web page.

 Last Saturday's failure to beat the old enemy has not stopped Sunderland fans from posing this quiz question: name three Newcastles in England. Newcastle under-Lyme, Newcastle-upon-Tyne and Newcastle under Sunderland.

 Following the story of the supporter who could not access Scunthorpe on the internet because his company computer had been blocked from recognising obscene words, comes news that a Sunderland fan has experienced similar problems raising the site for the club's fanzine 'Sex and Chocolate Aren't As Good As Football'.

 Apparently, when asked if he was having trouble up front, Martin O'Neill replied: "Where else would I play Collymore?"

webTitle: Babangida gears up for final flourish

fields.headline: Babangida gears up for final flourish
fields.trailText: As unbeaten runs go, Nigeria's record of 19 years without losing at home is impressive, yet tomorrow it will come under severe pressure as Cameroon travel to Lagos for the African Nations Cup final.
fields.body:
As unbeaten runs go, Nigeria's record of 19 years without losing at home is impressive, yet tomorrow it will come under severe pressure as Cameroon travel to Lagos for the African Nations Cup final.

Algeria, in a World Cup qualifier in 1981, were the last side to beat the Super Eagles in the Surulere Stadium and the size of Cameroon's task was illustrated when Nigeria swept aside the tournament favourites South Africa 2-0 in Thursday's semi-final.

Nigeria's players are already claiming to be Africa's best and have been lauded as such by the defeated South Africans. Yet Cameroon can at least claim that history is on their side.

Twice in the 1980s Cameroon beat Nigeria in the final of the Nations Cup, 3-1 in 1984 and 1-0 four years later. The teams have not met in a competitive match since Nigeria's 2-0 win in the third-place play-off in 1992.

Should Cameroon upset the odds and take the lead then Nigeria's volatile supporters could turn on their team yet. Though Cameroon's coach Pierre Lechantre would welcome such an outcome, he was concerned yesterday to take the heat out of the potentially explosive clash.

"I want it to be limited to a match of soccer," Lechantre said. "It should be a confrontation between players and no more. There is tension between the two countries and if it reaches the limit of a soccer match I might get worried."

Like Cameroon, Nigeria are seeking a third African title, having won the cup at the Surulere Stadium in 1980 and in Tunisia in 1994. They are rightful favourites having come through a tough group ahead of Morocco and Tunisia, and coming from behind to beat Senegal in the quarter-final.

Their players have certainly decided that any victory would be justified. "You can't dispute the fact that we've got better-quality players and the best team in Africa," said the midfielder Mutiu Adepoju.

"If people say we have the best team in Africa then we accept, and it's true anyway," said Tijani Babangida after scoring both goals in the semi-final. "This victory and others we've achieved in this tournament show we can beat any team."

It was a view shared by the South Africans, the defender Pierre Issa declaring Nigeria "truly African champions in every respect".

But Nigeria's captain Sunday Oliseh was concerned about premature elation. "I don't know about our being African champions right now," he said. "We'll see after the final against Cameroon."

 South Africa's coach Trott Moloto is expected to lose his job once his contract expires at the end of the African Nations Cup following their defeat in the semi-final. The president of the South African FA Molefi Oliphant said a decision would be taken after South Africa's third-place play-off match against Tunisia tomorrow.

Nigeria (probable):Sharunmu; Babayaro, Okpara, Iyenemi, West; George, Adepoju, Babangida, Oliseh; Kanu, Ndukwe.

Cameroon (probable): Alioum; Song, Njanka, Kalla, Olembe; Foé, Wome, Mayer, Njitap; Mboma, Eto'o.

webTitle: Never mind the score, clock the Italian motor, the wage packet and the Emmerdale actress

fields.headline: Never mind the score, clock the Italian motor, the wage packet and the Emmerdale actress
fields.trailText: Darren Tackle puts giantkilling minnows in their place before suggesting areas in which his contract fails to match up with players of equal talent and notoriety.
fields.body:
Wednesday

Every time it happens, the press, the media and that gets hold of the shitty end of the stick. Super Caley Go Ballistic Celtic Are Atrocious: can anyone explain to yours truly why that is funny? What is it that the media thinks is so bleedin' entertaining about giantkilling?

What - apart from the look on Kenny Dalglish's face after he was summoned back from his 24/7 on a Spanish golf course to do some actual graft for his 15 long 'uns a week - was there to laugh about at Celtic's humiliation? Aside from Barnesey getting the chance to spend more quality time with his wardrobe, obviously.

Take it from someone what knows: giantkilling is no smirking matter. Here's how it happens: you turns up to the match in your sparkling new engine - something Italian with a discreet spoiler that only lifts from the bodywork when you hit 120mph - and you see them coming off the coach, clocking the motor and starting to scowl, knowing all they've got is a three-year-old Mondeo or worse, a club Rover 75.

As you line up before the game, you mention how you earn more in a fortnight than they pick up in a year and instead of respecting you for reaching the pinnacle of your profession, they start foaming at the mouth. They play like banshees, kick everything in sight, and fluke a score, then celebrate like they've won summat worthwhile.

So on their way back to the centre circle you point out that while they may have scored today, tonight it is unlikely they will be going to the Majestick on River Street and scoring with that actress what plays the barmaid in Emmerdale like you will be. Next thing you know, they've declared all-out thermonuclear war on your shins.

Then, afterwards, when they've got their precious win that means so much - it's only a game, lads - they're desperate for your shirt so they can take it home and frame it.

All right, the last bit's never happened to me, but only because they is trampling all over each other in the rush for Carmine's, as if your Paraguayan sweat is worth taking home.

Then you wake up next morning and there they are, the sad little muppets, all over the papers as if they is national heroes. And you know what the so-called media will concentrate on don't you? Dustman earning £36 a week from football bins superstar on 28 gees.

This, it cannot be stressed enough, is not news what should reach the ears of club chairmen, who need to understand that the only thing what motivates a professional is a wheelbarrow load of sponds. Play for the love of it? Behave. Personally, I reckon the only thing Inver Caley Doo-Dah should be done for this week is bringing the game into disrepute.

Thursday

Things is not going well on the Rodney front. With it being revealed in the papers that me old mate Stan the Man earned exactly £500,000 per goal in 1999, it is time to re-assess what this agent of mine actually achieves. Basically, this is what he got me in the last season:

1. One exclusive glimpse of me recently re-decorated snooker room for OK magazine, which was dropped for space reasons to accommodate an 18-page spread on Dennis Wise's new garage.

2. Two photo-sessions for FHM magazine, neither of which featured semi-clad supermodels writhing at my feet, though I know for a fact Les Ferdinand has a clause in his contract insisting on just that.

3. Three charity film premieres, which, for reasons known best to himself, Rodders says involve no fee. And not much glamour either. This week, for instance, he sent me to the charity premiere of The Beach. I was expecting an intimate night with Leonardo di Caprio, that French bint and 4,000 screaming adolescent girls and it turned out to be the launch of a corporate video for the Morecambe Bay tourist board.

4. Two appearances on Martin "you're bonkers you" Kelner's Radio Leeds phone-in.

5. A year of protracted negotiations for an extension to me current contract which culminated in Mr Chairman offering a wage cut of eight long 'uns a week, plus a slice of the catering profits. "A slice of the catering profits?" I says to Rodds when he reveals this latest twist. "What's that mean?" To which Rodders replies: "I think he'll pay you for doing the washing-up in the executive suite after home games."

Note no shampoo ads, no mobile phone endorsements, and no appearance on Zoe Ball's The Priory. Worse, no checking into the real The Priory followed by an exclusive interview with the Observer's Ian Ridley detailing my continuing battle with the disease of uselessness either.

Questions, I think you'll agree, need to be asked. Urgent.

fields.headline: Football stewards to get makeover
fields.trailText: After years of being labelled mini dictators or accused of not being interested in their jobs, stewards at the country's football grounds are the latest recipients of the game's makeover.
fields.body:
After years of being labelled mini dictators or accused of not being interested in their jobs, stewards at the country's football grounds are the latest recipients of the game's makeover.

A groundbreaking training scheme being run by football clubs has been teaching stewards how to politely throw troublesome fans out of grounds, how to treat fans as customers and how they can polish up on their communication skills when talking to fans in stadiums.

The course, which lasts up to a year culminating in a written examination, also teaches potential stewards first aid, emergency evacuation procedures, ground regulations, how to detect trouble before it arises and how to deal with racist fans.

Many of the country's large clubs now refuse to employ their fans as stewards and a lack of football knowledge is seen by some as an advantage not a disadvantage.

Three clubs, Leeds United, Blackburn Rovers and Shrewsbury Town will today be rewarded for their pioneering steward training courses as other clubs around the country attempt to improve standards at grounds.

Clive Warne, a sports safety consultant who is overseeing the course organised by the Premier and Football League and the Football Association, said: "In the past stewards have either just been fans or over zealous officials who deal badly with the crowd."

He added: "That is all changing now. We want stewards to watch the crowd not the game and deal with fans as if they are customers. Clubs are realising that they can no longer employ fans as stewards. They are also becoming much younger and fitter."

Around 25,000 people work as match day stewards each weekend at Premier and Football League clubs.

With costs for the policing of games increasing, clubs are also keen to save money by employing efficient, well trained stewards.

fields.headline: White' s week
fields.standfirst: Jim White explores the wider, weirder world of sport :  Will Colly throw a wobbly over the Leicester work ethic?
fields.trailText: Will Colly throw a wobbly over the Leicester work ethic? Will Curcic get his priorities right? Will Scottish football fans have so much to cheer about ever again?
fields.body:
As ever, Stan Collymore did himself no favours this week. It may not have been his fault - agents had their say, Aston Villa did their best to extract some sort of adequate compensation, Leicester were keen not to pay over the odds for damaged goods - but the protracted transfer saga of Stan the Man seemed somehow symptomatic of a player whose grasp on reality disappeared some time ago.

After the embarrassment of his last year at Villa Collymore needed to make a clean, quick and apologetic escape. Instead the negotiations on personal terms dragged on, the rumour factory went on overtime and his reputation for being capable of knuckling down and getting on with it sunk even lower.

Worse, his press conference to announce the move on Thursday suggested he had learnt little. By casting the blame on Aston Villa - I did my best but they consistently let me down was the gist of his remarks - Collymore came across as unrepentant and self-pitying. Moreover, for students of his sad decline, there was a familiar pattern to his remarks. As his former manager Frank Clark puts it, for Stan the grass is always greener on the other side.

When the player first arrived at Nottingham Forest he announced he was glad to be out of Southend; when he then transferred to Liverpool he belittled Forest; when he arrived at Villa Park he told everyone he was glad to be home. Two and a half years later his time in Birmingham is dismissed as a "nightmare".

Great actors do not blame the theatre in which they were performing for their flops or, as Paul Merson put it this week: "It might be a new club but it's the same you."

And the welcome Collymore receives at his new place of work will depend, as Steve Walsh explained, not on his potential but on his performances. On the surface Leicester is the last place a player like him will find conducive. It is a dressing-room forged on a one-for-all, all-for-one philosophy, it is a dressing- room without stars, it is a dressing- room, one suspects, that is ruthless in weeding out those who do not share a commitment to the cause. Tea and sympathy will be in short supply.

So why did a manager as shrewd as Martin O'Neill buy him? Well, for a start, he is desperate. Leicester have a shortage of strikers and Collymore is potentially a class act. He has everything physically required to be the greatest and might just score a few goals. If he doesn't, well, thanks to John Gregory's desperation to be rid of him, O'Neill is not taking any financial risk; if it all goes pear-shaped, Collymore can be on his way with limited damage to Leicester's bottom line.

Then there is the Cantona factor. Barry Fry, one of Collymore's small army of previous managers, alluded to the Frenchman when he suggested that O'Neill might have the bargain of the century on his hands. Cantona, after all, had a reputation as shot as Collymore's when he arrived at Old Trafford and look what he achieved there. Yet Cantona's problems were caused by a surfeit, rather than a lack, of commitment, which manifested itself as a volcanic temper. If anything, he took the game too seriously. It was not until he met up with someone as dedicated to the cause as him that it all clicked.

Nevertheless, as O'Neill has gambled, it might just work for Collymore this time. But it will work only if he has changed, if he is determined to achieve something with his talent before it is too late, if he is ready to resist the temptation to retreat the moment anything goes wrong. Because football won't change to meet him halfway. Dressing-rooms will remain places which treat the unorthodox brutally. Footballers will continue to live under a code of collective responsibility; whingeing, skiving, aloofness will not be tolerated. It may be neanderthal but it is a fact of team games: players need to be able to rely on their team-mates.

Which is probably Collymore's tragedy. In retrospect his undoubted physical prowess would have been better used in a sport that suited his mental proclivities, an individual pursuit like sprinting. It is too late for that now. And, if he excuses away this opportunity with Leicester, it will be too late also for Stan Collymore to become the footballer he might have been.

Curcic has a great deal on his mind

It is heartening to discover a footballer whose priorities go beyond the financial. Sasa Curcic, the former Bolton, Aston Villa and Crystal Palace midfielder, whose last appearance in Britain was carrying a placard round Selhurst Park asking Nato to stop bombing his Yugoslav homeland, has more pressing needs.

"Some chairman might have to pay £10m for me but I would not want that. But if they offered me 15 women from around the world, then I might play."

Curcic adds that he has "given up football for sex". Dwight Yorke is said to be in shock at the revelation that the two pursuits are, apparently, mutually exclusive.

The prickling of Celtic that gives hope to thistles everywhere

The reaction to Celtic's defeat by Inverness Caledonian Thistle was extraordinary this week: John Barnes hustled out of his job, Kenny Dalglish furious that he is obliged to abandon the golf course and do some work, the Sun praised by the Independent for producing a literary masterpiece of a headline ("Super Caley Go Ballistic Celtic Are Atrocious").

But the most intriguing aspect of the affair was the way in which Scottish football fans with no particular brief for either side were so enthused by the result. It was not just in Inverness (and in the blue half of Glasgow) that they were dancing in the streets. The grins were evident everywhere on Wednesday morning - everywhere, that is, except in the environs of Celtic Park.

The reason was not just the inevitable pleasure that comes from seeing the mighty fall from a roof. It was also because such is the growing domination of the Old Firm that nobody thought such a result would ever happen again. Everyone simply assumed that the increasing concentration of wealth in the coffers of the big two would ensure that the Glasgow clubs would continue to hoover up all the trophies until such time as they decided to take their ball with them and go off and play in an Atlantic League.

Of course, with Celtic in the semi-finals of the League Cup and with Rangers still in the Scottish Cup (and with a space already allocated for the Premier League trophy in the Ibrox boardroom display cabinet), it is likely that the hegemony will be intact again at the end of the season. But in the meantime Inverness's mighty achievement reminded everybody that it is still possible to challenge the orthodoxy. Just for a week it brought a sense of optimism back to an increasingly predictable world.

fields.headline: Canary carve-up
fields.standfirst: A unique site of scientific and cultural importance faces destruction in the name of art.  George Monbiot reports
fields.trailText: A unique site of scientific and cultural importance faces destruction in the name of art. George Monbiot reports.
fields.body:
To the list of human activities threatening the world's wild places we can now add a new item: art. This, at any rate, is the official definition of a scheme which, if it goes ahead, will leave one of the most beautiful mountains on earth blasted by monumental graffiti.

Mount Tindaya, on Fuerteventura in the Canary Islands, is an ancient volcanic plug of international geological importance. It is the home of cacti, lizards and flightless birds that have become extinct everywhere else on earth. Perhaps most importantly, the mountain was the holy shrine of the Guanches, indigenous people eliminated soon after the Spanish arrived in the islands. They appear to have used it as an astronomical observatory. In some places, there are elaborate funeral sites.

Most remarkable are the 200 "podomorphs" they left on the rocks: bizarre engravings which look like pairs of feet. Nothing like them has been found anywhere else. Tindaya is still regarded as holy by many people in the islands.

Eduardo Chillida is one of Spain's most celebrated sculptors. He is the winner of the Carnegie Prize and the International Grand Prize for Sculpture. His works are found in public places all over the world. But for years he has been searching for a site on which to leave a vast and lasting testament. He wants to hollow out a mountain, carving an empty cube so big that it would leave a person standing at the bottom speechless with astonishment and awe.

When the Canary Islands government heard about his plan, it got in touch with Chillida: he could have Tindaya. The scheme, officials insisted, would attract tourists and enhance the prestige of their island. The land would become a vast natural gallery for the work of a great man. That the rock this "sculpture" would excavate is worth some £150 million, that government officials have been closely associated with people trying to quarry the mountain and that there is no other earthly way in which they would be able to get away with digging a hole this big are, of course, entirely incidental concerns. This is, the authorities would have us believe, art for art's sake.

The mountain, if this scheme is executed, will be devastated. Geologists have warned that its summit could collapse into Chillida's cube. The dust, disturbance and immediate damage caused by the quarrying could destroy or drive away some of the mountain's rare species. The government has previously sought to restrict access to Tindaya, in order to protect the Guanches' carvings. It could not justify the project without encouraging thousands of people to visit it. Land speculators have moved in already, buying up the endangered scrubland on and around the mountain in the hope that it will become valuable building land once the sculpture has been completed. The government has commissioned neither environmental nor archaeological assessments of its plan.

But the volcanic porphyry from which the mountain is made is in great demand. It is of a particularly beautiful variety, much sought after for facing prestigious buildings. Its value has risen significantly over the past few years. The "sculpture" is, in other words, a brilliant and audacious scam. Government officials have spotted in Chillida's grandiose dreams the means of realising their own.

This is not to suggest that Chillida himself is party to this artful dodge. He is just a vain old man who wants to build a monument that will be impossible to ignore: his egocentricity is being exploited by people who have recognised a perfect convergence of interests. But despite numerous attempts by the islanders opposed to the project to tell him what he is putting his name to, Chillida refuses to acknowledge the problems. He appears to believe that his sculpture is a matter of destiny.

"I went up and found those footprints left by the Guanches and it turned out that they are identical to my signature, but with a few more fingers," he recalls. "Strange, no?"

The opponents of his scheme are, he says, making a fuss about nothing. "I only want to create something for man, a great space where we would feel smaller than we think we are, and more tolerant to one another, a place of tolerance: marvellous."

The problem is that if this project goes ahead, the tolerance it will commemorate will be the tolerance of corruption. A complex, extraordinary place, whose archaeology and wildlife are represented nowhere else will give way to a sheer-sided quarry, impressive but bleak, whose lines echo those of every urban environment on earth. This is how the world loses its wonders: through the venality of officials and the vanity of famous men.

webTitle: I lost my heart in ... Indonesia

fields.headline: I lost my heart in ... Indonesia
fields.standfirst: Craig Nelson
fields.trailText: Craig Nelson.
fields.body:
Going to Indonesia means island-hopping, and each island is a completely different experience. You can visit an orangutang reserve in Borneo or Sumatra, see 1,000-year-old Hindu temples in Java that are very different from the ones in India, and end up staying in probably the best hotels in the world in Bali.

The maps fool you - Indonesia is squeezed to fit, so it's much larger than you imagine. The diversity is incredible - I didn't expect such huge differences as a moved around, but some islands are Muslim and very conservative while others, like Bali, are tourist paradises. On Java, which is predominantly Muslim, you catch little glimpses of other religions - churches or Hindu flower shrines by the side of the road where someone has died. There are even Buddhists.

I visited more than a dozen islands, yet there are thousands, some of which are uninhabited. You can travel very luxuriously or go cheaply; you can stay at the most modern hotels and then visit people whose way of life has hardly been touched by western lifestyles.

Bali was one of the biggest surprises. I was expecting the marble- lined bathrooms, but I did not realise how easy it was to escape the tourist areas - the hordes of drunken Australians touring the bars - and end up being the only westerner in a village. I was impressed by the way Bali has managed tourism.

I got a ticket that allowed me to fly anywhere very cheaply. I kept having stop-overs on my way to somewhere else and I wanted to explore each place I landed in but, unfortunately, time was limited, so I know I have to go back and see more.

European temperatures are dropping. Heavy fresh snow expected.

Andorra
The best skiing is on the north-facing slopes of Soldeu and Pas de la Casa. Austria
Good skiing on well-prepared upper pistes at Obergurgl. Mayrhofen is in need of snow. France

fields.headline: Guiding lights
fields.standfirst: Nicky Holford only ventured off piste by mistake until a Flaine guide opened up a new world
fields.trailText: Nicky Holford only ventured off piste by mistake until a Flaine guide opened up a new world.
fields.body:
The snow began to fall the night we arrived in the French resort of Flaine, and it continued until dawn, softening the harsh edges of the often-criticised 1960s architecture. Our Scottish instructor could not wait to get started. These sorts of days only happen a handful of times in a season, he told us.

The first day's agenda - a gentle warm up - was scrapped, and soon we were lined up like soldiers at the top of a small bowl of new snow. Our guide went first, the snow flying over his head. It looked fun.

None of us had skied powder before, and, as we soon found out, we lacked the basic skills needed to turn in the stuff. Like kamikaze pilots, we set off, quickly nose-diving into the snow and creating huge craters. In no time, the small bowl was dotted about with buried figures trying to dig themselves out - an exhausting process. But those few minutes before the crash were enough to get a taste and develop a determination to crack it.

Until then, my annual ski holidays had followed a similar pattern. The resorts, companions and restaurants varied, but the first couple of days would always be spent limbering up on a few gentle cruisers, graduating later to more challenging terrain and black runs. Off piste was something that happened by mistake.

The week in Flaine changed all that. We were whipped into shape, given confidence and taught tips that transformed our skiing. While we never grasped the rhythm that infuses the most fluid skiers, we made great progress. Enough for us to venture off the beaten piste with a mountain guide and discover a new world.

What clinched it was an unforgettable off-piste descent of the 23km Vallée Blanche. Any intermediate can ski this stunningly beautiful run that begins from the Aiguille du Midi cable car in the Chamonix valley. After a rather alarming start along the " arrê t ", a narrow path bordered on one side by a steep drop, the route is a simple meander with magical views and scenery in the shadow of Mont Blanc.

Nearly all skiers will follow the single piste, which is often crowded. But we left the piste far behind and made our own way across the snowy wilderness with no other skier ever in sight.

With a few basic off-piste skills and a guide, your skiing possibilities instantly multiply. Small resorts become unlimited, crowded slopes become avoidable.

If you want to explore a large ski area, such as the Trois Vallées or L'Espace Killy, hiring a guide and splitting the cost between a few of you is an excellent way to discover the many linked villages without wasting time stopping to look at the piste map. Your guide will know where the best snow is and the best route for the weather conditions of the day. And, if he or she is a ski instructor, you will be able to jump the lift queues as well.

Any ski instructor with the highest qualifications (in the case of British instructors, this is BASI I) is qualified to guide you around a resort and take you off piste. But they are not qualified or insured to take skiers on a glacier. For more extensive off-piste skiing, you will need to hire a qualified mountain guide.

To become a member of the International Union of Mountain Guides (UIAGM), you must already be an established mountaineer, and the training takes a further three to five years. Mountain guides are easily recognisable, not so much by the blue UIAGM badge, but by the size of their rucksacks. The essential tools of the trade include avalanche transceivers, a shovel, probe, first-aid kit, tools for adjusting skis, and extra clothing. Many will also have other items, such as a rope for crevasse rescue or for climbing up or down a cliff, and a bivi pack if someone is injured or stranded.

Any level of skier can enjoy the expertise of a guide and discover parts of the mountain they would be unwise to explore alone. Every resort has its couloirs and itineraires (off-piste routes). Many are tracked and easy to ski as long as you have someone qualified to show you the way.

It can become addictive. Since those first inexperienced days in Flaine, I have found myself skiing off the back of the Valluga in St Anton, which descends the Pazieltal into Zürs, putting skins on my skis to climb up Argentière's Col du Chardonnay, and being roped down the steep start of a run called the Pyramide in the Grandes Rousses near Alpe d'Huez.

· Spread your weight evenly between both feet - both legs have to act as one unit.
· On turns, apply exaggerated up-unweighted movement using pole plants to set the rhythm.
· Weight must be over the middle of the skis. Do not sit back, but push your heels down into the snow on each turn to bring the tips up to the surface.

Pack leaders 1 St Anton . Jens Borgnaes, 00 43 54 46 35 63
2 Chamonix. Roland Stieger, 00 33 450 54 43 53
3 Val d'Isère, Chamonix. Nick Parks, 01492 650267
4 Courchevel 1850. Sebastien Figliolini, 00 33 479 08 43 45

The practicals

Hiring a guide costs £100 - £185 pre day for 1-6 people. Fresh Tracks holidays from the Ski Club of Great Britain (020 8410 2022) hasfour levels of off-piste weeks with the guides. Seven nights in Flaine in the Hotel Aujon start at £695 plus half-price membership for £22.50. Ski Weekend (01367 241636) offers two levels of off piste in Chamonix and Alagna/Monte Rosa for £599 for four days with guide.

fields.headline: Ski briefs
fields.trailText: The political crisis in Austria will create a moral dilemma for skiers and a headache for tour operators.
fields.body:
 The political crisis in Austria will create a moral dilemma for skiers and a headache for tour operators. Publicly at least, operators say they do not expect much impact, but many will be casting anxious glances at early bookings for next season. "Over the next couple of weeks, we would expect to take 500-1,000 bookings," says First Choice marketing director Adrian Harwood. "But if there's a sharp downturn, it will give a pretty clear indication that politics is having an impact."

 St Anton, in Austria, is having a facelift. By October, the railway line running through the town will have been shifted to the periphery, leaving a huge new area for development next to the foot of the slopes. A new station and a new gondola will be built, relieving pressure on existing lifts, cutting queues and diverting traffic from the centre.

 Inghams' (0181-780 4444) programme for next winter features two Canadian resorts unfamiliar to British skiers. Stoneham and Mont Ste Anne. Both are close to Quebec City and customers can even stay downtown and buy a newly-introduced area lift pass. This includes the price of a shuttle bus to the slopes and allows you to ski Le Massif , which claims the largest vertical drop in eastern Canada. One-week package prices start from £305 if you stay in town, from £316 in Stoneham and £339 in Mont Ste Anne.

 Self-catering specialist Interhome (020-8891 1294)still has accommodation available during the half-term holidays. Most of it is in Switzerland, where a week in Zermatt or Verbier costs £177 and £137 per person respectively, accommodation only, based on four people sharing two-room apartments. It also has apartments left in the French resort of Chamonix , Italy's Bormio and Austria's Kirchberg .

 Wearing a helmet on the slopes reduces severe head injuries by 44% among adults and 53% among children under 15, according to a study by the US Consumer Product Safety Commission. It estimates that the number of US skiers receiving hospital treatment dropped from 114,400 in 1993 to 84,200 in 1997, due mainly to technical advances in bindings preventing leg damage. The number of head injuries also fell, but nowhere near so sharply.

fields.headline: Dark passions
fields.standfirst: Forget sprouts, haute cuisine and the EU gravy train. For Valentine's Day lovers, Brussels means chocs.  Veronica Horwell goes on a pilgrimage
fields.trailText: Forget sprouts, haute cuisine and the EU gravy train. For Valentine's Day lovers, Brussels means chocs. Veronica Horwell goes on a pilgrimage.
fields.body:
Eurostar hurried through the mist. The dining car advertised hot chocolate in three languages and three currencies, including the euro. But it wasn't chocolate, just a sachet of powder, rehydrated. I was on a pilgrimage to Brussels in search of the real thing, rich, dark and bitter, the drink of the Mayans and Aztecs. For them, the cacao pod symbolised the human heart torn out in sacrifice: they "were the repositories of precious liquid, blood and chocolate".

In the Grand Place, the sign of a trumpeting golden angel advertises the "museum of chocolate", an idea that promised much but failed to deliver. A small greenhouse in the garden sheltered some coffee bushes, but sadly no cacao trees. In Guatemala, they look like alien life forms, pods protruding from their trunk. They depend for fertilisation on midges breeding in forest rot. Probably against EU regulations.

The landmark branch of Godiva is just across the square: the firm, now 75 years old, made Belgian chocolate famous. It was a clever marketing ploy to use a naked lady on horseback as a logo - sex and chocolate, the perfect serotonin combo.

In the glass-roofed Galeries Royales St Hubert, I found the Neuhaus shop, established by an emigrant Swiss pharmacist in 1857 to dispense liquorice and chocolate to take away the taste of medicine. When British and Swiss technology transformed the drink into something smooth, solid and edible, Neuhaus became a confiseur - a confectioner. Britain's Richard Cadbury created the first chocolate box, with Victorian art (ringlets and kittens) printed on the lid. Neuhaus's boxes were confections in silk and ribbons, gifts for sweethearts, wives and mothers.

The Neuhaus shop has marble outside, chandeliers within. For Valentine's Day, its window is filled with cherubs and chocolate hearts on velvet cushions.

I returned to my hotel somewhat nauseous and ignored the goodnight choc left on my pillow. (Are you supposed to eat it in bed, then get up to brush your teeth again?) I fell asleep reading about that notorious chocaholic, the Marquis de Sade. When imprisoned in the Bastille, he demanded his wife bring him cake "black from chocolate as the devil's arse is black from smoke" and cacao-butter suppositories for his piles.

Consuming more than a couple of squares of brut grand cru 70% cocoa solids in a morning is much like chain-smoking Havana cigars, so next day I passed up on Leonidas in Rue au Buerre in favour of the Dandoy bakery opposite. Dandoy predates the era of chocolate bars for the masses and still trades in spiced speculoos biscuits, the Flemish descendants of medieval gingerbread. Wooden moulds hang on the walls, carved with crude figures - the giant biscuits they turn out are like edible cartoons or thin tombstones.

I burnt off the calories with a walk to Musée Horta, up past the art-nouveau houses in St Gilles. They look like tins of quality cocoa, with their mosaics and Liberty-style wriggly lettering. Perhaps the roofs hinge off. Inside Horta's museum, the art-nouveau designs swirled like chocolate dribbling from a spatula.

On the way back, I sorted through acres of plastic crates in Les Marolles flea market, looking for the bowls formerly so common for breakfast chocolate. The dealers spoke as much Arabic as French or Flemish, the hoods of their djellabahs raised against the cold. A chocolate-free zone: Godiva boasts customers in Saudi Arabia, but cacao never really displaced the ancient nut sweetmeats in Islam.

You can't follow chocolate with haute cuisine - earthy tastes are more compatible -so I went for cabbage soup, rabbit in gravy and black bread in a Marolles backstreet bar. Chocolate and wine don't go either - better are the naturally-fermented Belgian fruit beers.

In Place du Grand Sablon, the window of Wittamer Chocolatier had a tiered cake piled with chocolate hearts. I stocked up for the cold, lonely Eurostar home. Love at last bite.

5 romantic things to do

1 Choose beautiful postcards with your lover's initials, reproduced from medieval manuscripts, Flammarion, Galleries, St Hubert.
2 Breakfast at the table in front of the (fake) fire at La Brouette, Grand Place, as the sun rises over the gilt pediment opposite and backlights your lover.
3 Get surreal on 9% Blue Chimay ale in Magritte's former local, La Fleur en Papier Dore in the Rue des Alexians: it needs visiting lovers for atmosphere.
4 Stand hand-in-hand in the twilight of the Eglise St Nicholas, Rue au Buerre.
5 Feed each other Marcolini's Java bars (coffee/chocolate blend) in the formal and silly little park of Le Petit Sablon.

The practicals

Kirker (020 7231 3333) offers two-night B&B breaks at the 4star Le Meridien from £221 pp, inc return travel to the hotel and a copy of Kirker's city guide notes to Brussels. Two-night breaks at the Embassy Hotel start from £189pp.

fields.headline: 3 minute guide
fields.standfirst: Life in the slow lane
fields.trailText: Life in the slow lane
fields.body:
Have horse, will travel - but slowly?
Life doesn't come more languid than a weekend's clop in a rented gypsy caravan. I have little experience of horses.
But these horses have plenty of experience with people. One quiet puller?
Most of Slattery's (0800 515900) horses are the Irish Draught type - strong, powerful but trusted to obey the wishes of the smallest child. I'm not sure I'd trust my life in my child's hands?
Don't worry, all feeding, grooming and harnessing instruction is supplied before you're given the reins. Free to go where I want, stop where I fancy?
Sadly, not quite. Your suggested route will keep to roads with room for cars to pass and avoid gradients too steep for the horse. Are the caravans traditional Romany style?
Those belonging to Slattery's, Acorn Activities (01432 830083, www.acornactivities.co.uk) and Cresta (0161-926 9999) are all modelled on original gypsy lines.
For Romany, read basic?
Cramped but cosy; generally four-berth with a two-person tent sometimes provided. What about meals?
Folding chairs and a table, cutlery and cooking utensils, a wash basin and two-ring-plus-grillgas burner are included. It can't be the most expensive of holidays?
Acorn asks £200 per weekend, £250 for Monday to Friday, £400 for a full week in July and August. Children are in heaven. Adults require resource?
Not necessarily. Overnight stopovers on farms or alongside beaches are never far from pubs and restaurants. Where do we clop?
Cresta offers Counties Kerry, Galway and Wicklow; Slattery's goes to County Kerry; and Acorn leads you through the Brecon Beacons in Wales. How much ground would I cover in a weekend?
About 50 miles at most. Any more do's and don'ts?
Do return the caravan to base. And don't let your horse roam in search of greener grass while still tethered to the caravan. What if I do?
Thank God for mobile phones. And dial the back-up vehicle.
