fields.headline: Stormy exchange
fields.standfirst: Where do celebrities go to get away from it all? In the first of our series on walks around Britain,  John Humphrys  pounds the Pembrokeshire Coast Path
fields.trailText: Where do celebrities go to get away from it all? In the first of our series on walks around Britain, John Humphrys pounds the Pembrokeshire Coast Path.
fields.body:
John Humphrys gets passionate about wind. Not the sort he has to deal with when grilling evasive politicians on Radio 4's Today programme, but the kind that sweeps across Cardigan Bay and tries to blow him off his favourite stretch of the Pembrokeshire Coast Path.

"In Cape Town, the wind is known as the Cape Doctor, and I think of it in those terms," he says. "A really strong wind beating against you is the most energising and wonderful sensation - 10, 12 or 20 miles of that really sets you up. I'm basically out for a good walk with a lot of wind in my face and the smell of the sea."

Well, you'd hardly expect to find Humphrys pottering round the park on a calm day with an ageing Labrador, would you? The small farm he owns in Wales gives him a jumping-off point for the Path, which winds and plunges along one of the country's most spectacular coastlines.

The Met Office says the wind here is above gale force for more than 31 days a year, so you can see why it suits him.

The stretch he likes best is the 12 miles from Cardigan down to the village of Newport. "You have farmland on the left, there's birdlife all around and, on the right, there's glorious Cardigan Bay with its sensational cliffs and coves. Outside the Isle of Skye, I can't think of anything to match it. I remember one fantastic September day when I walked 18 miles along the path and only saw two other couples - and you're not passing fish and chip shops all the time."

He often goes with two friends, one a mine of information about wildlife and the environment, the other a route-finding enthusiast who's had them desperately climbing cliffs to escape the incoming tide. Much of time they walk in silence, relishing the scenery and the exertion of the path's ups and downs.

Humphrys tries to end the day at the Golden Lion in Newport, a tired walkers' paradise he found by chance: "It gives you something special to aim for - it's got some of the best bar meals and one of the best pints of beer I've ever come across."

The path that's not a promenade

Anyone walking the full length of the Pembrokeshire Coast Path is certain to end up with a deep tan - from the wind, if not the sun - and calf muscles like Popeye.

The route covers 186 winding, undulating miles - 100 of them on spectacular clifftops - and a total ascent and descent of 35,000ft, which is a bit like climbing Everest. The terrain is so rough that when the path was made in the 1960s, they used a small bulldozer to cut through the gorse and blackthorn that cling to the slopes. Even a hardened walker will need 10 days or more to get from Cardigan at the northern end to Amroth in the south.

It's not clear how many people do the whole thing, but about 150 a year are serious enough to register at checkpoints and get a signed certifi cate from the Pembrokeshire Coast National Park Authority. A recent survey showed that 300,000 people a year set foot on the path and 12,000 cover "a significant distance".

The reward is a rich diet of 500ft cliffs, crashing surf, seal-covered rocks, smugglers' coves, gleaming beaches and multiple relics of the early Celtic church. The only blots are the refineries of Milford Haven and Pembroke power station, but you can dodge these by bus.

Anthony Richards, access officer for the national park authority, says the most popular part is round the cathedral town of St David's and the westernmost tip of Wales. His nominations for best cliff, best beach and best fishing village are Stackpole Head on the southern section, Marloes Sands, and Porth gain, between Fishguard and St David's.

"I must stress the challenging nature of this path," he says. "It's not a promenade, it's a mountain along a coast. We can give advice about the gentler sections, and there are some places accesssible by wheelchair. The path is safe, but not the coast itself."

Every spring, when the coastal flowers are at their best, the authority organises a guided walk along the entire route, with naturalists, ornithologists, archaeologists and geologists. It costs £120, excluding accommodation, and this year runs from May 27 to June 9.

fields.headline: Ring of fire
fields.standfirst: First there were storm chasers, but now tourists are looking for a more explosive thrill - volcanoes that belch smoke and spew rivers of molten lava.  Matthew Brace reports from fuming Arenal in Costa Rica
fields.trailText: First there were storm chasers, but now tourists are looking for a more explosive thrill - volcanoes that belch smoke and spew rivers of molten lava. Matthew Brace reports from fuming Arenal in Costa Rica
fields.body:
There's something about volcanoes that brings out the child in otherwise mature travellers. It is impossible not to be thrilled when standing at the foot of a cone spitting flaming boulders and belching plumes of ash, especially at night when you can see the magma's fiery red colours.

The heart beats fast as the ground shudders before an eruption. One belch from a smoker is never enough. Even with ultra-sensitive, multimillion-pound seismic equipment, there is still enough element of chance about volcanoes to make being in their presence exhilarating. Lately, people have been getting addicted and have begun organising their travels around hot-spots where the earth's crust is fluid and prone to violence.

The world has about 500 active volcanoes. More than half are in the Pacific Ocean, in what is known as the Ring of Fire - Indonesia has about 70, Central America roughly 60 and Japan around 45. A search on the internet will bring up a healthy-looking list of tours and accommodation from Hawaii to Indonesia and Iceland to Costa Rica.

The Costa Ricans are deeply proud of their most famous volcano, Arenal, a shapely cinder cone that rises into the clouds from t he rainforest around its base. Climbing it is forbidden and only the truly foolhardy would try. My guide spared no detail when telling me about four German tourists who ventured up a few years ago and were killed instantly when they were struck by a still-burning giant boulder blown from deep within the crater. Visitors can, however, get quite close in relative safety by taking a trail from the Tabacon Resort near the pretty town of La Fortuna.

The trek would not look out of place in an Indiana Jones film: the opening shot would be the security sign - beyond here your travel insurance runs out. The path leads through a cutting in a snake-infested forest. Miniature motorways of leaf-cutter ants cross the path and howler monkeys whoop it up in the trees on either side. Towering over everything is Arenal.

The trail leads to a clearing and a small beach of fine grey rock and sand - crushed particles from an old lava flow. A rock thrown in the air thuds on the sand and echoes underground. This is the roof of a giant subterranean complex of caverns leading to the central magma chamber bubbling at ferocious temperatures and, on occasion, pumping its bile up the volcano's oesophagus.

Beyond this lies an almost vertical 60ft wall of loose lava and boulders - this is as far as the last lava flow reached. The wall is climbable with great care but, once on top, walking is near impossible. From here, the eruptions (mainly ash plumes) are clearly visible and accompanied by great booms that shudder through the valley and resound in the pit of the stomach.

Seconds later, a clatter and rush of rocks down the cone signals the fall of boulders. The rocks leave puffs of smoke as they bounce down the mountain towards you. Their final resting-place is still several thousand yards away but, as these boulders measure up to 50ft across and travel at about 70mph, it seems like spitting distance.

At night, the view from the hot spring-water pools at the Tabacon Resort is spectacular, but the place does get crowded and you will have to share it with noisy, boozy American tourists bawling every time the mountain spits fire. Just repeat loudly enough that a full eruption would see a river of lava sprint down the valley and vaporise their margaritas in about a minute and a half. That should shut them up.

True volcano addicts watch in silent awe, then retire to their room at the nearby Tilajari Resort to celebrate with an ice-cold beer and plan which of the planet's smokers to head to next year.

The practicals

Matthew Brace travelled with Valle Dorado Tours (00 506 228 9932, e-mail: vdorado@sol.racsa.co. cr.)
He stayed at the Grano de Oro (255 3322, granoro@ sol. racsa.co.cr) and San Jose Palacio (220 2034,palacio@sol. racsa.co.cr) in San Jose, and the Tilajari Resort (details from Valle Dorado) near Arenal.
Travel agents offer fares with BA (0345 222111) from £580. Also American Airlines (0345 789789) from £560, and Continental (0800 776464) from £698.

Burnt offerings . . . . volcanoes around the world

Emma Owen

Many of the Caribbean islands (Martinique, St Lucia, St Vincent, ) promote their volcanoes as day-trip destinations. If you want to go independently, contact the relevant tourist boards. The Caribbean Tourism Organisation is on 0171-222 4335.

In Hawaii, it is possible to fly over Kilauea volcano by helicopter. Hilo Wings, e-mail: info@hilowings.com.

The Philippines has 37 volcanoes, 18 of them active. Mount Mayon in Legaspi, South Luzon, is one of the more famous ones, along with Mount Pinatubo in central Luzon. Both Blue Horizons Travel and Tours (00 632 893 6071), and Interisland Travel and Tours (00 632 522 1405) organise sightseeing trips. Over here, the Philippine Department of Tourism is on 0171-835 1100.

Japan has more than its fair share of volcanoes, with a major eruption every 20 years or so. Mount Fuji is an obvious and busy destination, but a hike through the Kirishima National Park allows you to stroll through 15km of lunar landscape, volcanic lakes, hot springs and waterfalls. Maps for the various walks can be collected at the tourist offices in Ebino-kogen and Takachihogawara, or contact the main tourist information office in Tokyo on 00 813 34 31 13 51. Here, the Japan National Tourist Organisation is on 0171-734 9638.

In Indonesia , the mountains' eruptions are seen as a sign of anger from the gods. Gunung Bromo, on Java, has an annual festival when offerings are thrown into the crater in an attempt to pacify the gods. Organised tours can be arranged from the main tourist centres in Bali and Java. The Indonesian Tourist Office is on 0900 1600180.

Mount Etna, in Italy, is Europe's largest active volcano. Tourist visits to the craters are restricted - when it blew in 1983, it took the tourist centre with it. Vesuvius is potentially the most dangerous, as the surrounding area is densely populated - emergency plans recommend the evacuation of 600,000 people in the event of rumblings. The tourist centre at Linguaglossa (for Etna) is on 00 39 095 64 30 94 and at Pompeii (for Vesuvius) on 00 39 081 850 72 55. The Italian tourist office in Britain is on 0900 1600280.

Iceland sits precariously on top of the mid-Atlantic rift, and some 11% of the country is made up of lava fields. Active volcanoes include Eldfell on the Isle of Heimaey, Surtsey, Grimsvötn and Krafla. The tourist office in the UK is on 0171-590 1100.

The trek would not look out of place in an Indiana Jones film: the opening shot would be the security sign - beyond here your travel insurance runs out. The path leads through a cutting in a snake-infested forest. Miniature motorways of leaf-cutter ants cross the path and howler monkeys whoop it up in the trees on either side. Towering over everything is Arenal. The trail leads to a clearing and a small beach of fine grey rock and sand - crushed particles from an old lava flow. A rock thrown in the air thuds on the sand and echoes underground. This is the roof of a giant subterranean complex of caverns leading to the central magma chamber bubbling at ferocious temperatures and, on occasion, pumping its bile up the volcano's oesophagus. Beyond this lies an almost vertical 60ft wall of loose lava and boulders - this is as far as the last lava flow reached. The wall is climbable with great care but, once on top, walking is near impossible. From here, the eruptions (mainly ash plumes) are clearly visible and accompanied by great booms that shudder through the valley and resound in the pit of the stomach. Seconds later, a clatter and rush of rocks down the cone signals the fall of boulders. The rocks leave puffs of smoke as they bounce down the mountain towards you. Their final resting-place is still several thousand yards away but, as these boulders measure up to 50ft across and travel at about 70mph, it seems like spitting distance. At night, the view from the hot spring-water pools at the Tabacon Resort is spectacular, but the place does get crowded and you will have to share it with noisy, boozy American tourists bawling every time the mountain spits fire. Just repeat loudly enough that a full eruption would see a river of lava sprint down the valley and vaporise their margaritas in about a minute and a half. That should shut them up. True volcano addicts watch in silent awe, then retire to their room at the nearby Tilajari Resort to celebrate with an ice-cold beer and plan which of the planet's smokers to head to next year. The practicals Matthew Brace travelled with Valle Dorado Tours (00 506 228 9932, e-mail: vdorado@sol.racsa.co. cr.) He stayed at the Grano de Oro (255 3322, granoro@ sol. racsa.co.cr) and San Jose Palacio (220 2034,palacio@sol. racsa.co.cr) in San Jose, and the Tilajari Resort (details from Valle Dorado) near Arenal. Travel agents offer fares with BA (0345 222111) from £580. Also American Airlines (0345 789789) from £560, and Continental (0800 776464) from £698. Burnt offerings . . . . volcanoes around the world Emma Owen Many of the Caribbean islands (Martinique, St Lucia, St Vincent, ) promote their volcanoes as day-trip destinations. If you want to go independently, contact the relevant tourist boards. The Caribbean Tourism Organisation is on 0171-222 4335. In Hawaii, it is possible to fly over Kilauea volcano by helicopter. Hilo Wings, e-mail: info@hilowings.com. The Philippines has 37 volcanoes, 18 of them active. Mount Mayon in Legaspi, South Luzon, is one of the more famous ones, along with Mount Pinatubo in central Luzon. Both Blue Horizons Travel and Tours (00 632 893 6071), and Interisland Travel and Tours (00 632 522 1405) organise sightseeing trips. Over here, the Philippine Department of Tourism is on 0171-835 1100. Japan has more than its fair share of volcanoes, with a major eruption every 20 years or so. Mount Fuji is an obvious and busy destination, but a hike through the Kirishima National Park allows you to stroll through 15km of lunar landscape, volcanic lakes, hot springs and waterfalls. Maps for the various walks can be collected at the tourist offices in Ebino-kogen and Takachihogawara, or contact the main tourist information office in Tokyo on 00 813 34 31 13 51. Here, the Japan National Tourist Organisation is on 0171-734 9638. In Indonesia , the mountains' eruptions are seen as a sign of anger from the gods. Gunung Bromo, on Java, has an annual festival when offerings are thrown into the crater in an attempt to pacify the gods. Organised tours can be arranged from the main tourist centres in Bali and Java. The Indonesian Tourist Office is on 0900 1600180. Mount Etna, in Italy, is Europe's largest active volcano. Tourist visits to the craters are restricted - when it blew in 1983, it took the tourist centre with it. Vesuvius is potentially the most dangerous, as the surrounding area is densely populated - emergency plans recommend the evacuation of 600,000 people in the event of rumblings. The tourist centre at Linguaglossa (for Etna) is on 00 39 095 64 30 94 and at Pompeii (for Vesuvius) on 00 39 081 850 72 55. The Italian tourist office in Britain is on 0900 1600280. Iceland sits precariously on top of the mid-Atlantic rift, and some 11% of the country is made up of lava fields. Active volcanoes include Eldfell on the Isle of Heimaey, Surtsey, Grimsvötn and Krafla. The tourist office in the UK is on 0171-590 1100.

fields.headline: Mrs Slocombe's Pussy
fields.standfirst: It was the early 80s, Brideshead Revisited was on television and Stuart Jeffries had arrived at Oxford University. It seemed the most dismal, class-ridden place on earth, and the ghost of Sebastian and his teddy made it worse...
fields.trailText: It was the early 80s, Brideshead Revisited was on television and Stuart Jeffries had arrived at Oxford University. It seemed the most dismal, class-ridden place on earth, and the ghost of Sebastian and his teddy made it worse.
fields.body:
I hated Brideshead Revisited when it was first broadcast in 1981. I so thoroughly misunderstood the TV adaptation of Evelyn Waugh's novel that I thought it was about contempt when really it was about love and loss. But who could blame me for that? I'd arrived in Oxford in the same year as Brideshead Revisited was aired and found it the coldest place on earth, cliquey and more class-ridden than anywhere I'd been in my life. I'd returned to England from my gap year in the US, where warm people had befriended me and found my accent entrancing. By contrast, Oxford seemed to be a student city that detested the outside world and many of the students who lived and worked there, especially those with provincial accents. My first memory of Oxford is of sitting at dinner in hall on my first evening in college and asking someone to pass me a glass down the long table. In the long, long silence that followed I waited for a response. "Pass the glass?" said someone eventually, mocking a northern accent. "You mean parse the glarse." No one sent a glass down the table to me.

Later that term, during a tutorial, I asked my tutor to tell me how to pronounce Kant. "Kant or Karnt?" I asked. "Oh, it's Karnt," said my tutor, not unkindly, but authoritatively and yet wrongly. John Mortimer's adaptation of the novel seemed to be in league with these mispronunciations and the class criticism they implied. When Sebastian Flyte (played by Anthony Andrews) comes back from church one morning, he tells Charles, his friend and the narrator of novel and adaptation, that he has been to "marse". Surely nobody in the world spoke with such soft 'a's, not even extremely snooty Catholics? This seemed emblematic of the alienation I felt: I would never be a member of this club, I would never parse. But I felt furious as well as unworthy. This was the time and the place for a neutron bomb, not for an adaptation of a historical novel. I was oblivious to the tenderness and love that coursed through the programme, and instead saw everything in it as an affront to me, an insult that was confirmed by the coldness I felt from most of my fellow students and even from working-class people whose jobs were bound up with serving students.

Charles Ryder first bumps into Sebastian Flyte at the barber's. Sebastian is leaving, carrying his large teddy bear. Charles's friend, who has accompanied him to have his haircut is revolted, but the barber is enchanted. And Charles, too, is preparing himself to be captivated. "That was Lord Sebastian Flyte, a most amusing young gentleman," says the barber, unctuously removing the young men's coats before showing them to their chairs. "He's the Marquis of Marchmain's second boy. His brother, the Earl of Marchmain, went down last term. He was very different." Flyte, says the barber, warming to his theme, had not wanted a haircut, but had come instead for "a hair brush for his teddy bear. It had to have very firm bristles, not to brush him with but to threaten him with a spanking when he was sulky. He bought a very nice one with an ivory back. He's going to have Aloysius engraved on the back. That's the teddy bear's name."

I loathed this speech. "Too much information, you deferential throwback!" I shouted at the screen. And yet, the barber isn't only deferential (though he was surely that, since such an attitude was common among tradespeople in cities such as Oxford in the inter-war years), but he is also, and over- whelmingly, charmed by Flyte, the golden boy with his adorable eccentricities - the lightness of him, his beauty. To all of this I was blind. Instead, I saw only contempt: the contempt of Sebastian Flyte for those who were not part of his charmed and charming circle; and the contempt of the barber for those who spoke with flat vowels and had set aside their teddy bears along with Andy Pandy a decade before. And I felt resentful contempt of my own, for Sebastian and his deferential barber.

I have never been able to waft commandingly into a basement barber's with a camel coat over my shoulders, igniting smiles and happiness, to buy something frivolous. There was a time while I was an undergraduate when I had the double crown at the top of my forehead permed, true, but that was hardly a gesture of supreme decadence, nor did it win the admiration of crabby barbers or, indeed, anyone else. Instead, while I was at university I got my hair cut silently, studied hard, drank bitterly and got the Midland Red coach home, walking across dark allotments into a bright place where people were pleased to see me. It was only 56 miles away, and yet I crossed so many barriers to arrive and to leave. How could the country I lived in be so divided, even then, and how could the barriers be so close to home?

When Sebastian next appears before Charles he is drunk. He is standing outside Charles's open ground-floor window in the quad, poised to throw up through the window and nearly over Charles's feet. He is sick, wipes his mouth and then, mustering the thinnest of smiles, disappears into the night with his rowdy friends. In the morning, Charles's scout (cleaner, servant, personal policeman, moral coach, confidant, all-round flunkey) cleans up the vomit. (Did it not occur to Charles to clean it up himself? How could he bear to sleep with that stench in his rooms overnight, particularly as he had now closed the windows?) The scout then picks up the five shillings, left there for his trouble, and tells Charles that he shouldn't drink so much. By the time Charles has returned from his lectures that same morning, though, the room is filled with flowers, along with an apologetic note from Sebastian. The scout, played by Bill Owen, is even now arranging the last of the bouquets. "A most amusing young gentleman, sir," he says, warmly. "I'm sure it's a pleasure to clean up after him!"

Again, this would never happen to me. It would never be a pleasure for anyone, still less a total stranger, to clean up my sick. No landlord would escort me to the door of his pub, wipe his face with a bar towel and then tell his friends: "That Lord Stuart half drowned me with his own vomit. What a young wag he is, to be sure!"

Most of the friends I cultivated at Oxford were state-school pupils revolted by this dynamic which we saw on screen and which we thought was transposed into reality. From this culture of deference, though, we received no bounty since it was not offered to us. Still less, had we been accorded such deference, could we have stooped charmingly to pick it up with the grace of a Sebastian Flyte or the diffidence of a Charles Ryder. We had neither the skills, nor the temperament. This dynamic was a curious legacy from an earlier, more exclusive era that had to be stamped out; it was part of what, in the past, had kept the likes of us out. Most of us, obviously enough, took Jude The Obscure as our text: Jude's had been the fate of our ancestors - to build the walls that kept us out. Now, though, we were inside the walls, and it would be different - if only we didn't have to contend with working-class Judases conspiring against us. Or so it then seemed.

For many of us, after all, attending university felt as though it was a huge responsibility, both to ourselves and to the generations before us who never dreamt of studying at a college, least of all at Oxford. Few of our parents had reached any form of tertiary education - though my father had, as his 30s turned into 40s, studied for a production engineering degree at Aston University. In the front room, which was off-limits to his children, my father had wrestled with mathematics and metallurgy, while I sat in the other room watching Andy Pandy, Dad's Army or the 1970 World Cup. Then he went to lectures where he sat amid long-haired youngsters with whom he had next to nothing in common. It wasn't, so far as I could judge, a time of strawberries and punting; he never had occasion to buy a hairbrush with which to admonish his recalcitrant teddy bear.

When I learned I'd won a place to Oxford, I phoned my dad at work and remember him being really touched in a way that I'd not experienced before. "You're cleverer than all of us," he said fondly, a remark that has danced happily around my head ever since. But I also took that remark as a responsibility: my cleverness, if that's what it was, shouldn't be thrown away when I went to Oxford. None of my forebears had had the chance to exhibit their cleverness or anything else at such a place, and so the weight of their exclusion lay heavy on my shoulders.

I remember crying sentimental tears a few years later, in 1992, when I watched on television Neil Kinnock's party political broadcast. It was part of the same shockingly misguided presidential-style campaign that included the Sheffield rally, so I was prepared to be disgusted. But Kinnock asked why he and Glenys were the first people from their respective families in a thousand years to go to university. Why? Because between Sebastian Flyte's days and theirs, and indeed mine, egalitarian governments had established free education for all children and set up the ladder for us to climb. Working-class men who said things such as "Lord Sebastian, such an amusing young man" - they would never get their feet on the first rungs. They were holding themselves down, and they were making things more difficult for us. They made me and my friends angry, and yet we didn't know what to do with that anger, except to sit sullen in barber's chairs.

We were recognisable by our lack of poise, by our uncertainty. These are the words, at least, of Richard Hoggart in The Uses Of Literacy, where he writes about the "uprooted and the anxious", the scholarship boys who leave their homes, first spiritually, through reading and education, then physically, by going away to college. They were the first to leave their societies, their classes, and they never really belonged anywhere again. By contrast, Sebastian Flyte, in the barber's, in the quad, at the lunch party, at mass, belonged everywhere - the world was his and he was comfortable with the arrangement. Who wouldn't be?

Hoggart writes: "I am chiefly concerned with those who are self-conscious and yet not self-aware in any full sense, who are as a result uncertain, dissatisfied, and gnawed by self-doubt. Sometimes they lack will, though they have intelligence, and 'it takes will to cross this waste'." I stood not long ago in a bookshop reading these words in tears, because they were about me - too much about me for comfort when I studied at Oxford. I've always wanted those three years back, so I could live them well, to live them wilfully and to cross the waste that much of that time was for me. I would have walked around with a teddy bear, or a real bear on a chain, or a lobster on a leash, and bought all three of them tailored silk pyjamas to wear when we went out in public. I would have carried my burden more lightly, not been overcome by a spirit of seriousness and of shame.

There was another scene in Brideshead, that only now can I cherish - because the spirit of seriousness has taken flight from me, hopefully for good. Charles's cousin Jasper breaks off from his final exams to chide him about his now-hedonistic lifestyle. He dresses down Charles for his new flashy clothes, his profligacy, his choice of friends, his drinking. Charles smiles, reaches into a cupboard and produces a bottle of champagne which he proceeds to open while he defends himself: "I usually have a glass of champagne, about this time. Will you join me?" There was drinking for me at Oxford, but none of it had these light-hearted and insolent qualities. I wish everything I had done there had had such cheerful insolence.

The characters Charles initially made friends with were academic pedants (one step up from proletarian scholars), who were never given the chance to flourish in our sight. As for the proletarian scholars of 20s' Oxford, we never got to see their kind.

Perhaps now I'm getting nearer to why I hated Brideshead at the time and why I still feel uneasy about the drama, even though now I understand Waugh's novel. It is because the adaptation and the book allow of no other way of being at Oxford than that of Sebastian and his coterie. Near the beginning, Charles divides Oxford students into three classes - the flamboyant aesthetes (like Sebastian, like camp, reptilian Anthony Blanche), the proletarian scholars (whose characterisation is so thin that not one appears, even in the novel) and those, like his first friends and like his first undergraduate self, third-way academics in embryo, who appear as stereotypes rather than flesh and blood individuals.

I felt tyrannised by this taxonomy, since I regarded it as being still true in 1981. There were privileged aesthetes who lived with beauty, and the rest of us who did not. But there was a fundamental difference between Charles's times at Oxford and my own - the flamboyant aesthetes of my day were copyists from whatever old Oxonian texts they could get their hands on, but, as they re-enacted these novels, they lost the books' charm. There were putative Zuleika Dobsons, acting out the adventures of the eponymous heroine of Max Beerbohm's 1911 novel in which a dazzling beauty visits Oxford and is responsible for a mass suicide among the students. And why not? There was in 1981 a dining society called The Dobson Society, which was women-only except for the male guests who were required to throw themselves into the river during Eights Week for the privilege. There was another called The Northey, which was named after Nancy Mitford's young femme fatale (you wouldn't expect an all-woman dining society at Oxford in 1981 to name itself after Sheena Easton, would you?)

But most dining societies were all-male or male-dominated. The Knights of Marchmain, for instance, gallant cavaliers loyal to the aristocratic ethos of Brideshead Revisited, would as a post-dinner feat choose a woman to whom they would present red roses, chocolate and a Marchmain cocktail. That they were not often in a fit state to perform this was evinced by the fact that one of them skewered both feet on the gates of University College after delivering a cocktail to a lucky, lucky woman. The Scruton Society, named after the conservative philosopher Roger Scruton, would meet to discuss such questions as "dealing with the lower orders", though after their evenings few of them would be able to deal with undressing for bed. The Straight Line Society consisted of men who would, after their alcoholic dinners, put two pins in a map of central Oxford and walk the route it described - over roofs, through houses, bushes, theatres, concerts and philosophy lectures. They would walk over books, over my face, down through the basement barber's where men permed my hair silently, up over gables and cupolas, through my nightmares, through the orchestras playing at the Sheldonian Theatre, through libraries, poetry readings, football matches. On and on until they had finished marching.

In such a context, when Charles was invited to a select luncheon in Sebastian's rooms, I was ready to be disgusted at the spectacle. I could take in none of the atmosphere of kindness, nor the beauty of the meal, nor, really, did I have a proper understanding of the exclusivity that is necessary for their kindness to be kind or their beauty beautiful - and so no powerful class analysis of the scene at all, just resentment. They started with plovers' eggs and champagne, and had moved on to lobster Thermidor when the last guest arrived. This guest was Anthony Blanche - poised, certain, catty Anthony - who, during the meal, memorably, or at least memorably to me, referred to a woman as a drab. I'd never heard that adjective become a noun before, and immediately feared that I was such a noun myself - a graceless, flat-vowelled drab. In Brideshead, there was no other story than that of decadents and of aesthetes and their self-righteous nostalgia for another age. Just as the TV adaptation of Brideshead was inspiring a nostalgia for an exclusive age that had died and been reborn in these corpses, I was bringing my hope to Oxford to be born. And the midwives of my hope were Anthony Blanche's pale imitators.

When I saw Brideshead Revisited again in 1998, I felt strongly the words spoken by Captain Charles Ryder in the opening scene of the adaptation, lying awake in his military bunk to find himself 39 and loveless. "Something within me, long sickening, had died," he says. And so it was with me, but what had been sickening in me was not a nostalgia for a charmed youth, still less a thwarted passion for a Catholic heiress, but a self-destructive bitterness concerning Oxford that I've outgrown. Now I am more healthy and stronger, only overtaken by a sense of loss for three years in time that could have been happier, had I had the will, had I not been so embroiled with a resentment for the Brideshead ethos, a resentment which Nietzsche describes thus: "The noble man lives in trust and openness with himself, the man of resentment is neither upright nor naive nor honest and straightforward with himself. His soul squints." I insisted to myself that I would watch Brideshead without squinting.

When I revisited Brideshead Revisited in 1998, I saw love and loss and, in the early episodes, a sort of kindness, which occasionally touched me. In the opening scene, for instance, Captain Charles Ryder fails to stop one of his men, Hooper, having his hair cut under the orders of a brutish colonel. The colonel considers Hooper's hair to be too long and so charges someone to deal with it. It recalls an officially inspired rape, a vulgar affair, a scene unfit to be seen by lords or teddy bears, from which Ryder walks away languidly. In Hooper's world, this is what happened: an unwilling soldier crudely hacks at his hair with scissors not designed for the task; in the other world, to which Hooper is not privy, teddy bears get better treatment.

Afterwards, no one takes it upon themselves to console Hooper for this brutality. He is an unpopular officer, one who doesn't properly belong anywhere, but who is uprooted and anxious everywhere. Only later does Ryder make a point of apologising to Hooper. This was very well dramatised in the adaptation. In the book, the apology is merely reported, thus: "It's not the sort of thing that usually happens in the regiment," I said.

"Oh, no hard feelings," said Hooper. "I can take a bit of sport."

In the TV adaptation, by contrast, this exchange takes place with a lovely rhythm. After the incident, Hooper and his men are marching from the camp. Ryder wheels into step with Hooper and offers him the apology. The rhythm is lovely because the marching comes to symbolise the onward march of history in which Waugh and his Ryder have no faith; the rhythm of the marching men is countered briefly by Ryder's gentility, his voice the last breath of proper kindness from a fast disappearing world.

And yet, now, Ryder's kindness is hard for me to tolerate. The velvet of Ryder's gentility, after all, conceals the iron of his class hostility. This expression of Evelyn Waugh's loathing for the Hoopers of this world - the anxious and the uprooted. For Hooper is uprooted - thrown into the army with little understanding of how it worked; so comprehensively out of joint with his post (he is a platoon commander and Ryder's subordinate officer) that he addresses the men who are contemptuous of him by their first names, and yet receives no compensating solidarity from the officers around him since he is not one of their clarse: so much a wafer-thin character that he can be presented as a thoroughgoing professional incompetent without the viewer or the reader wondering why. We know next to nothing about Hooper, except that he is Charles Ryder's lustreless symbol of the Youth of England. He only exists in relation to Ryder's, and by extension Waugh's, lugubrious loathing for what the future held. But I at least wanted Hooper to become more than just Waugh's symbol. I wanted him to have a lustre all of his own. I should have made Brideshead Revisited a trilogy - the extant novel would have been flanked by a prequel about Hooper's early years and the sequel would have been called Hooper: The Radiant Years.

The Hooper who exists in Brideshead Revisited, though, bears all the weight of Waugh's opprobrium. At the end of the TV series, as in the novel, Ryder rounds on Hooper in his thoughts. He is reflecting on the beauty of Brideshead, its august history, and its destruction by soldiers billeted in the house. "The builders did not know the uses to which their work would descend; they made a new house with the stones of the old castle; year by year, generation after generation, they enriched and extended it; year by year, the great harvest of timber grew to ripeness; until, in the sudden frost, came the age of Hooper; the place was desolate and the work all brought to nothing; Quomodo sedet sola civitas . Vanity of vanities, all is vanities."

Poor Hooper to have to bear all this. "He was a sallow youth, with hair combed back, without parting, from his forehead, and a flat, Midland accent," reported Ryder early on. Poor Hooper, poor Stuart. Pictures of me at the time show me to have my hair combed back, without parting, from my forehead. Memories of the time show me to have had a flat, Midland accent that would never quite parse muster in Oxonian society, to my initial incredulity and continuing anger.

Perhaps it is good that Hooper did not take Charles's kindness, but instead played down the significance of the incident. Ryder's gesture to Hooper was only one of politeness, of good form; it shows his breeding, not his empathy for or understanding of the affront to Hooper. Hooper may have been Waugh's unfeeling symbol of the rise of cultural materialism, his index of the shabbiness of Britain to come, but I would have comforted him with a better quality than Ryder could have attempted. Better than that, I wouldn't have allowed a public-school twit of a colonel to order that his hair be cut; unlike Ryder, who seemed incapable of even protesting against the incident, I would have rebelled in the name of Hooper. The likes of Hooper and his ancestors have suffered too much, unimagined by Waugh; and out of anger, and kindness, I would not have let the latest Hooper suffer another moment's indignity at the hands of someone who had not suffered enough.

The rest of Brideshead has many such episodes of kindness that did not revolt me so. One, in particular, stayed with me. After the luncheon, Sebastian and Charles are the only ones left in the room. Sebastian suggests they go to the Botanical Gardens to look at the ivy. As they walk through the gardens, arm in arm, I take this - perhaps against the grain of the director's or, indeed, the author's intentions - as a gesture of tenderness and of consolation in a cruel world. No wonder Charles loves Sebastian and chooses his world above the cold ones that surround him at Oxford. I, too, would have liked someone to take me by the arm and show me the ivy.

That tender love recalls Charles's reflection, years later, on that meeting with reproving Jasper. As Jasper leaves Charles's room, Jeremy Irons' languorous narration as the older, disaffected Charles Ryder, begins: "Now I could have matched his gamecock maturity. I could have told him that to know and to love another human being is the root of wisdom." And I know now that it is.

But hatred has its place, too. Once, my parents came to see me for the day and I took them on a walk around Oxford. We wound up standing at the side of the lake at Worcester College. Across the lake from us, and inaccessible, was a group of young, flamboyant aesthetes, drunk on Pimm's. The men wore boaters and blazers, the women summer dresses. It could have been a lovely scene for my parents to see, an English idyll, a costume drama as winningly fanciful as Brideshead Revisited or Inspector Morse. But it didn't belong to my parents or to me. It was ruined. "Oh, look out those common people over there," yelled one to his friends, in a deliberately affected bray. My mother's face was furious, and my father's revolted: the likes of them still didn't belong here. We walked away, back to a cafe where there weren't many students. Now, I wish I had dived into that lake, swum across and killed them with an ivory-backed hairbrush, and stuffed teddy bears into their mouths. That's how I should have left Oxford - with blood on the blazers and boaters floating on the lake

7#169; Stuart Jeffries, published by Flamingo, 2000

It had to have very firm bristles, not to brush him with but to threaten him with a spanking when he was sulky. He bought a very nice one with an ivory back. He's going to have Aloysius engraved on the back. That's the teddy bear's name." I loathed this speech. "Too much information, you deferential throwback!" I shouted at the screen. And yet, the barber isn't only deferential (though he was surely that, since such an attitude was common among tradespeople in cities such as Oxford in the inter-war years), but he is also, and over- whelmingly, charmed by Flyte, the golden boy with his adorable eccentricities - the lightness of him, his beauty. To all of this I was blind. Instead, I saw only contempt: the contempt of Sebastian Flyte for those who were not part of his charmed and charming circle; and the contempt of the barber for those who spoke with flat vowels and had set aside their teddy bears along with Andy Pandy a decade before. And I felt resentful contempt of my own, for Sebastian and his deferential barber. I have never been able to waft commandingly into a basement barber's with a camel coat over my shoulders, igniting smiles and happiness, to buy something frivolous. There was a time while I was an undergraduate when I had the double crown at the top of my forehead permed, true, but that was hardly a gesture of supreme decadence, nor did it win the admiration of crabby barbers or, indeed, anyone else. Instead, while I was at university I got my hair cut silently, studied hard, drank bitterly and got the Midland Red coach home, walking across dark allotments into a bright place where people were pleased to see me. It was only 56 miles away, and yet I crossed so many barriers to arrive and to leave. How could the country I lived in be so divided, even then, and how could the barriers be so close to home? When Sebastian next appears before Charles he is drunk. He is standing outside Charles's open ground-floor window in the quad, poised to throw up through the window and nearly over Charles's feet. He is sick, wipes his mouth and then, mustering the thinnest of smiles, disappears into the night with his rowdy friends. In the morning, Charles's scout (cleaner, servant, personal policeman, moral coach, confidant, all-round flunkey) cleans up the vomit. (Did it not occur to Charles to clean it up himself? How could he bear to sleep with that stench in his rooms overnight, particularly as he had now closed the windows?) The scout then picks up the five shillings, left there for his trouble, and tells Charles that he shouldn't drink so much. By the time Charles has returned from his lectures that same morning, though, the room is filled with flowers, along with an apologetic note from Sebastian. The scout, played by Bill Owen, is even now arranging the last of the bouquets. "A most amusing young gentleman, sir," he says, warmly. "I'm sure it's a pleasure to clean up after him!" Again, this would never happen to me. It would never be a pleasure for anyone, still less a total stranger, to clean up my sick. No landlord would escort me to the door of his pub, wipe his face with a bar towel and then tell his friends: "That Lord Stuart half drowned me with his own vomit. What a young wag he is, to be sure!" Most of the friends I cultivated at Oxford were state-school pupils revolted by this dynamic which we saw on screen and which we thought was transposed into reality. From this culture of deference, though, we received no bounty since it was not offered to us. Still less, had we been accorded such deference, could we have stooped charmingly to pick it up with the grace of a Sebastian Flyte or the diffidence of a Charles Ryder. We had neither the skills, nor the temperament. This dynamic was a curious legacy from an earlier, more exclusive era that had to be stamped out; it was part of what, in the past, had kept the likes of us out. Most of us, obviously enough, took Jude The Obscure as our text: Jude's had been the fate of our ancestors - to build the walls that kept us out. Now, though, we were inside the walls, and it would be different - if only we didn't have to contend with working-class Judases conspiring against us. Or so it then seemed. For many of us, after all, attending university felt as though it was a huge responsibility, both to ourselves and to the generations before us who never dreamt of studying at a college, least of all at Oxford. Few of our parents had reached any form of tertiary education - though my father had, as his 30s turned into 40s, studied for a production engineering degree at Aston University. In the front room, which was off-limits to his children, my father had wrestled with mathematics and metallurgy, while I sat in the other room watching Andy Pandy, Dad's Army or the 1970 World Cup. Then he went to lectures where he sat amid long-haired youngsters with whom he had next to nothing in common. It wasn't, so far as I could judge, a time of strawberries and punting; he never had occasion to buy a hairbrush with which to admonish his recalcitrant teddy bear. When I learned I'd won a place to Oxford, I phoned my dad at work and remember him being really touched in a way that I'd not experienced before. "You're cleverer than all of us," he said fondly, a remark that has danced happily around my head ever since. But I also took that remark as a responsibility: my cleverness, if that's what it was, shouldn't be thrown away when I went to Oxford. None of my forebears had had the chance to exhibit their cleverness or anything else at such a place, and so the weight of their exclusion lay heavy on my shoulders. I remember crying sentimental tears a few years later, in 1992, when I watched on television Neil Kinnock's party political broadcast. It was part of the same shockingly misguided presidential-style campaign that included the Sheffield rally, so I was prepared to be disgusted. But Kinnock asked why he and Glenys were the first people from their respective families in a thousand years to go to university. Why? Because between Sebastian Flyte's days and theirs, and indeed mine, egalitarian governments had established free education for all children and set up the ladder for us to climb. Working-class men who said things such as "Lord Sebastian, such an amusing young man" - they would never get their feet on the first rungs. They were holding themselves down, and they were making things more difficult for us. They made me and my friends angry, and yet we didn't know what to do with that anger, except to sit sullen in barber's chairs. We were recognisable by our lack of poise, by our uncertainty. These are the words, at least, of Richard Hoggart in The Uses Of Literacy, where he writes about the "uprooted and the anxious", the scholarship boys who leave their homes, first spiritually, through reading and education, then physically, by going away to college. They were the first to leave their societies, their classes, and they never really belonged anywhere again. By contrast, Sebastian Flyte, in the barber's, in the quad, at the lunch party, at mass, belonged everywhere - the world was his and he was comfortable with the arrangement. Who wouldn't be? Hoggart writes: "I am chiefly concerned with those who are self-conscious and yet not self-aware in any full sense, who are as a result uncertain, dissatisfied, and gnawed by self-doubt. Sometimes they lack will, though they have intelligence, and 'it takes will to cross this waste'." I stood not long ago in a bookshop reading these words in tears, because they were about me - too much about me for comfort when I studied at Oxford. I've always wanted those three years back, so I could live them well, to live them wilfully and to cross the waste that much of that time was for me. I would have walked around with a teddy bear, or a real bear on a chain, or a lobster on a leash, and bought all three of them tailored silk pyjamas to wear when we went out in public. I would have carried my burden more lightly, not been overcome by a spirit of seriousness and of shame. There was another scene in Brideshead, that only now can I cherish - because the spirit of seriousness has taken flight from me, hopefully for good. Charles's cousin Jasper breaks off from his final exams to chide him about his now-hedonistic lifestyle. He dresses down Charles for his new flashy clothes, his profligacy, his choice of friends, his drinking. Charles smiles, reaches into a cupboard and produces a bottle of champagne which he proceeds to open while he defends himself: "I usually have a glass of champagne, about this time. Will you join me?" There was drinking for me at Oxford, but none of it had these light-hearted and insolent qualities. I wish everything I had done there had had such cheerful insolence. The characters Charles initially made friends with were academic pedants (one step up from proletarian scholars), who were never given the chance to flourish in our sight. As for the proletarian scholars of 20s' Oxford, we never got to see their kind. Perhaps now I'm getting nearer to why I hated Brideshead at the time and why I still feel uneasy about the drama, even though now I understand Waugh's novel. It is because the adaptation and the book allow of no other way of being at Oxford than that of Sebastian and his coterie. Near the beginning, Charles divides Oxford students into three classes - the flamboyant aesthetes (like Sebastian, like camp, reptilian Anthony Blanche), the proletarian scholars (whose characterisation is so thin that not one appears, even in the novel) and those, like his first friends and like his first undergraduate self, third-way academics in embryo, who appear as stereotypes rather than flesh and blood individuals. I felt tyrannised by this taxonomy, since I regarded it as being still true in 1981. There were privileged aesthetes who lived with beauty, and the rest of us who did not. But there was a fundamental difference between Charles's times at Oxford and my own - the flamboyant aesthetes of my day were copyists from whatever old Oxonian texts they could get their hands on, but, as they re-enacted these novels, they lost the books' charm. There were putative Zuleika Dobsons, acting out the adventures of the eponymous heroine of Max Beerbohm's 1911 novel in which a dazzling beauty visits Oxford and is responsible for a mass suicide among the students. And why not? There was in 1981 a dining society called The Dobson Society, which was women-only except for the male guests who were required to throw themselves into the river during Eights Week for the privilege. There was another called The Northey, which was named after Nancy Mitford's young femme fatale (you wouldn't expect an all-woman dining society at Oxford in 1981 to name itself after Sheena Easton, would you?) But most dining societies were all-male or male-dominated. The Knights of Marchmain, for instance, gallant cavaliers loyal to the aristocratic ethos of Brideshead Revisited, would as a post-dinner feat choose a woman to whom they would present red roses, chocolate and a Marchmain cocktail. That they were not often in a fit state to perform this was evinced by the fact that one of them skewered both feet on the gates of University College after delivering a cocktail to a lucky, lucky woman. The Scruton Society, named after the conservative philosopher Roger Scruton, would meet to discuss such questions as "dealing with the lower orders", though after their evenings few of them would be able to deal with undressing for bed. The Straight Line Society consisted of men who would, after their alcoholic dinners, put two pins in a map of central Oxford and walk the route it described - over roofs, through houses, bushes, theatres, concerts and philosophy lectures. They would walk over books, over my face, down through the basement barber's where men permed my hair silently, up over gables and cupolas, through my nightmares, through the orchestras playing at the Sheldonian Theatre, through libraries, poetry readings, football matches. On and on until they had finished marching. In such a context, when Charles was invited to a select luncheon in Sebastian's rooms, I was ready to be disgusted at the spectacle. I could take in none of the atmosphere of kindness, nor the beauty of the meal, nor, really, did I have a proper understanding of the exclusivity that is necessary for their kindness to be kind or their beauty beautiful - and so no powerful class analysis of the scene at all, just resentment. They started with plovers' eggs and champagne, and had moved on to lobster Thermidor when the last guest arrived. This guest was Anthony Blanche - poised, certain, catty Anthony - who, during the meal, memorably, or at least memorably to me, referred to a woman as a drab. I'd never heard that adjective become a noun before, and immediately feared that I was such a noun myself - a graceless, flat-vowelled drab. In Brideshead, there was no other story than that of decadents and of aesthetes and their self-righteous nostalgia for another age. Just as the TV adaptation of Brideshead was inspiring a nostalgia for an exclusive age that had died and been reborn in these corpses, I was bringing my hope to Oxford to be born. And the midwives of my hope were Anthony Blanche's pale imitators. When I saw Brideshead Revisited again in 1998, I felt strongly the words spoken by Captain Charles Ryder in the opening scene of the adaptation, lying awake in his military bunk to find himself 39 and loveless. "Something within me, long sickening, had died," he says. And so it was with me, but what had been sickening in me was not a nostalgia for a charmed youth, still less a thwarted passion for a Catholic heiress, but a self-destructive bitterness concerning Oxford that I've outgrown. Now I am more healthy and stronger, only overtaken by a sense of loss for three years in time that could have been happier, had I had the will, had I not been so embroiled with a resentment for the Brideshead ethos, a resentment which Nietzsche describes thus: "The noble man lives in trust and openness with himself, the man of resentment is neither upright nor naive nor honest and straightforward with himself. His soul squints." I insisted to myself that I would watch Brideshead without squinting. When I revisited Brideshead Revisited in 1998, I saw love and loss and, in the early episodes, a sort of kindness, which occasionally touched me. In the opening scene, for instance, Captain Charles Ryder fails to stop one of his men, Hooper, having his hair cut under the orders of a brutish colonel. The colonel considers Hooper's hair to be too long and so charges someone to deal with it. It recalls an officially inspired rape, a vulgar affair, a scene unfit to be seen by lords or teddy bears, from which Ryder walks away languidly. In Hooper's world, this is what happened: an unwilling soldier crudely hacks at his hair with scissors not designed for the task; in the other world, to which Hooper is not privy, teddy bears get better treatment. Afterwards, no one takes it upon themselves to console Hooper for this brutality. He is an unpopular officer, one who doesn't properly belong anywhere, but who is uprooted and anxious everywhere. Only later does Ryder make a point of apologising to Hooper. This was very well dramatised in the adaptation. In the book, the apology is merely reported, thus: "It's not the sort of thing that usually happens in the regiment," I said. "Oh, no hard feelings," said Hooper. "I can take a bit of sport." In the TV adaptation, by contrast, this exchange takes place with a lovely rhythm. After the incident, Hooper and his men are marching from the camp. Ryder wheels into step with Hooper and offers him the apology. The rhythm is lovely because the marching comes to symbolise the onward march of history in which Waugh and his Ryder have no faith; the rhythm of the marching men is countered briefly by Ryder's gentility, his voice the last breath of proper kindness from a fast disappearing world. And yet, now, Ryder's kindness is hard for me to tolerate. The velvet of Ryder's gentility, after all, conceals the iron of his class hostility. This expression of Evelyn Waugh's loathing for the Hoopers of this world - the anxious and the uprooted. For Hooper is uprooted - thrown into the army with little understanding of how it worked; so comprehensively out of joint with his post (he is a platoon commander and Ryder's subordinate officer) that he addresses the men who are contemptuous of him by their first names, and yet receives no compensating solidarity from the officers around him since he is not one of their clarse: so much a wafer-thin character that he can be presented as a thoroughgoing professional incompetent without the viewer or the reader wondering why. We know next to nothing about Hooper, except that he is Charles Ryder's lustreless symbol of the Youth of England. He only exists in relation to Ryder's, and by extension Waugh's, lugubrious loathing for what the future held. But I at least wanted Hooper to become more than just Waugh's symbol. I wanted him to have a lustre all of his own. I should have made Brideshead Revisited a trilogy - the extant novel would have been flanked by a prequel about Hooper's early years and the sequel would have been called Hooper: The Radiant Years. The Hooper who exists in Brideshead Revisited, though, bears all the weight of Waugh's opprobrium. At the end of the TV series, as in the novel, Ryder rounds on Hooper in his thoughts. He is reflecting on the beauty of Brideshead, its august history, and its destruction by soldiers billeted in the house. "The builders did not know the uses to which their work would descend; they made a new house with the stones of the old castle; year by year, generation after generation, they enriched and extended it; year by year, the great harvest of timber grew to ripeness; until, in the sudden frost, came the age of Hooper; the place was desolate and the work all brought to nothing; Quomodo sedet sola civitas . Vanity of vanities, all is vanities." Poor Hooper to have to bear all this. "He was a sallow youth, with hair combed back, without parting, from his forehead, and a flat, Midland accent," reported Ryder early on. Poor Hooper, poor Stuart. Pictures of me at the time show me to have my hair combed back, without parting, from my forehead. Memories of the time show me to have had a flat, Midland accent that would never quite parse muster in Oxonian society, to my initial incredulity and continuing anger. Perhaps it is good that Hooper did not take Charles's kindness, but instead played down the significance of the incident. Ryder's gesture to Hooper was only one of politeness, of good form; it shows his breeding, not his empathy for or understanding of the affront to Hooper. Hooper may have been Waugh's unfeeling symbol of the rise of cultural materialism, his index of the shabbiness of Britain to come, but I would have comforted him with a better quality than Ryder could have attempted. Better than that, I wouldn't have allowed a public-school twit of a colonel to order that his hair be cut; unlike Ryder, who seemed incapable of even protesting against the incident, I would have rebelled in the name of Hooper. The likes of Hooper and his ancestors have suffered too much, unimagined by Waugh; and out of anger, and kindness, I would not have let the latest Hooper suffer another moment's indignity at the hands of someone who had not suffered enough. The rest of Brideshead has many such episodes of kindness that did not revolt me so. One, in particular, stayed with me. After the luncheon, Sebastian and Charles are the only ones left in the room. Sebastian suggests they go to the Botanical Gardens to look at the ivy. As they walk through the gardens, arm in arm, I take this - perhaps against the grain of the director's or, indeed, the author's intentions - as a gesture of tenderness and of consolation in a cruel world. No wonder Charles loves Sebastian and chooses his world above the cold ones that surround him at Oxford. I, too, would have liked someone to take me by the arm and show me the ivy. That tender love recalls Charles's reflection, years later, on that meeting with reproving Jasper. As Jasper leaves Charles's room, Jeremy Irons' languorous narration as the older, disaffected Charles Ryder, begins: "Now I could have matched his gamecock maturity. I could have told him that to know and to love another human being is the root of wisdom." And I know now that it is. But hatred has its place, too. Once, my parents came to see me for the day and I took them on a walk around Oxford. We wound up standing at the side of the lake at Worcester College. Across the lake from us, and inaccessible, was a group of young, flamboyant aesthetes, drunk on Pimm's. The men wore boaters and blazers, the women summer dresses. It could have been a lovely scene for my parents to see, an English idyll, a costume drama as winningly fanciful as Brideshead Revisited or Inspector Morse. But it didn't belong to my parents or to me. It was ruined. "Oh, look out those common people over there," yelled one to his friends, in a deliberately affected bray. My mother's face was furious, and my father's revolted: the likes of them still didn't belong here. We walked away, back to a cafe where there weren't many students. Now, I wish I had dived into that lake, swum across and killed them with an ivory-backed hairbrush, and stuffed teddy bears into their mouths. That's how I should have left Oxford - with blood on the blazers and boaters floating on the lake 7#169; Stuart Jeffries, published by Flamingo, 2000

fields.headline: NatWest runs up white flag
fields.standfirst: 18,000 jobs to go as 342 years of independence ends after marathon struggle
fields.trailText: NatWest gave up its marathon fight to retain independence yesterday, advising its bruised shareholders to back Royal Bank of Scotland's £21bn bid.
fields.body:
NatWest gave up its marathon fight to retain independence yesterday, advising its bruised shareholders to back Royal Bank of Scotland's £21bn bid. After one of the hardest fought and closest run three-way contests ever staged in the City, Royal Bank will be the eighth largest bank in Europe and, at home, bigger than Barclays.

While the NatWest brand will be retained on the high street, it is unclear what name the combined entity will take on the stock market. It ends NatWest's 342 years of independence.

The process of combining the two banks will cost 18,000 jobs - a fifth of their combined workforce - and require Sir George Mathewson, the chief executive of Royal Bank, to prevent culture clashes between the two staffs.

Finance union, Unifi, called for a meeting with the Royal Bank, which refused to comment on where jobs will be shed last night other than to say it had a"clear plan for appointments on the basis of merit".

Royal Bank said it was still working hard to canvass support from shareholders yesterday in the final hours before the battle draws to its offical close on St Valentine's Day. Sir George will not be able to claim an emphatic victory until Monday, by which time all the votes from shareholders will be counted, although it is expected he will surpass the crucial 50% with ease after a roller-coaster week.

He also faces a two-week wait before his own shareholders ratify the deal, a gap which could leave the door open for a possible takeover bid against the Royal Bank itself, some corporate finance experts believe.

Bid speculation about Bank of Scotland, which on Thursday gave up the battle it initiated, subsided as Peter Burt, its chief executive, admitted to feeling disappointed at losing out in the four-month saga.

"We will carry on. We saw NatWest as a huge opportunity. We don't need NatWest. We never needed NatWest. It was an opportunity pure and simple that we're very sorry we lost - but too bad," he said.

BoS shares fell nearly 10% to 614p while Royal Bank's continued their slide, ending at 871p and reducing its offer for NatWest to around £12.50, above the target's £11.73 close last night.

While Mr Burt said he had no intention of resigning after losing the contest, NatWest's Sir David Rowland, the defeated chairman and chief executive, and Ron Sandler, the chief operating officer, will not take on new roles in Royal Bank.

Richard Delbridge, the NatWest finance director, is also expected to leave although it was unclear where Gordon Pell, lured from Lloyds TSB only 11 days, ago would be offered, or take on, another role.

Mr Sandler, speaking from his south London home, said his role now was to ensure a "smooth process" in the handover to Royal Bank. He and Sir David will meet with their counterparts at Royal Bank on Monday to hammer out the way forward.

NatWest finally admitted defeat to the stock exchange just after 9am yesterday morning, prompting a statement from Royal Bank in which chairman Viscount Younger said: "Together we will build the pre-eminent UK financial institution to the benefit of staff, customers and shareholders".

The takeover by Royal Bank - which is almost half the size of NatWest - was clouded by comments by Sir Brian Pitman, chairman of Lloyds TSB, who is credited with executing successful takeovers.

"It will be very interesting to see how they manage to deliver," Sir Brian said.

fields.headline: Linda Greenlaw never travels without...
fields.trailText: Books | Chocolate | T-shirt
fields.body:
A necessity: Books, because I spend up to 30 days at sea each fishing trip. We travel for five or six days out to the fishing grounds, so you need something to occupy that time. I read anything except science fiction.

A luxury: Chocolate. I always ask the cook to buy me my own supply of chocolate, which I keep in the wheelhouse. If it was kept in the galley, the crew would probably eat it all in a couple of days. I ration myself to a little bit each day.

A good-luck charm: Sailors are very superstitious and I have a lucky purple T-shirt, which I have had for 17 years. I wear it most days. I always take my lucky pen-knife as well.

If only: If I could go straight to the fishing grounds, either by magic or by helicopter, that would be fantastic.

 The Hungry Ocean, Linda Greenlaw's account of life as a swordfish captain, is published by Sceptre at £7.99.

fields.headline: The path to eternal happiness
fields.standfirst: The Langtang is far less trekked than Everest. Just the place to start out on a life adventure, says newly-engaged  Emily Barr
fields.trailText: The Langtang is far less trekked than Everest. Just the place to start out on a life adventure, says newly-engaged Emily Barr.
fields.body:
As the first rays of sun of the new millennium hit the mountains around us, James produced the ring he had secretly carried all the way from home to Kyangjin and asked me to marry him. We were sitting on a rock, on the flat grassy land by the Langtang river, and we were wearing every piece of clothing we had. The air was freezing, but clear. The nearest road was several days' brisk walk away. Neither of us had washed all week. We were happy.

Walking in the Langtang region, even without the added surprise of a proposal, is sublime.

We began in the small town of Dhunche, around eight hours' drive from Kathmandu. People sat in the sun, picking lice out of each other's hair. A toddler played a solemn game, digging a hole in the earth. Older children rolled bicycle tyres down the road. Every step took us further from the millennium, further from our home in Greenwich, where our local pub was charging £250 for the evening. From here, the West looked like a decadent society, one that had lost touch with what matters.

It may be too easy to idealise Nepal, the world's eighth poorest country, as the calm Other to the frantic west. More than half the people live below the poverty line: its GNP is $190 per capita, little more than 1% of the UK figure. Large areas of the country never see a doctor.

But given the choice between poverty in London and poverty in Nepal, I know which I'd choose. As we turned off the crumbling road on our first day, and took the grassy path uphill, nothing but the immediate moment seemed to matter.

There were few other trekkers: the Langtang is, for some reason, visited far less frequently than the Everest and Annapurna regions, and this was the low season.

The days were crisp and clear; we wore T-shirts in the sun, and fleeces in the shade (at night we froze). Ahead of us was a range of Tibetan peaks; we were only 20km from the border. All the way up the valley, there were yaks and Tibetan settlements. The Tibetan "tashi dele" replaced the Nepalese "namaste" as the usual greeting.

We walked happily by ourselves, stopping at lodges en route, where we were usually the only guests. Lodge owners only ever charge a nominal sum for a bed. In the low season, they are almost always free. They make their money from food, and we did them proud on that score. The bedrooms were unheated, there was no electricity, but every lodge had a big stove in the main room, and we spent each evening sitting around one with the family.

The paths are so well walked, and the locals so helpful, that we didn't feel any need for a guide. We could carry our own bags, so we didn't need a porter.

We spent one night in Ghora Tabela, a small cluster of houses that used to be a summer camp for nomads. Now, because of the trekking trade, it is lived in year round. The name means "grazing place for horses" and, sure enough, a white horse with a bell round its neck jingled comfortingly all night long.

The walk up was hard. On the first day, we misjudged things entirely, and spent the final hour stumbling along by torchlight next to a sheer drop to the rocky river. It took time to adjust to the change of pace, to realise that we were ruled by such basic considerations as the time the sun sets. As James encouraged me up hill after hill, leg muscles made their existence felt for the first time since I did ballet as a child.

On the second day, I realised I had a choice. I could keep muttering: "I can't do it. My feet hurt. My legs ache. But at least I'm losing weight," or I could appreciate the fact that I was in a wide open space, breathing crystal air, surrounded on all sides by snow-capped mountains. The cobwebs blew away.

The only time I seriously doubted finishing the walk was on New Year's Eve, when we contravened accepted wisdom and climbed 1,000m to an altitude of 4,000m. We suffered for it. James put on a brave face, but I couldn't dredge one up. The valley, steep and close all the way up, began to open out. I knew it was beautiful, but I was nauseous, and my head seemed about to explode. When we did arrive, I got straight into the sleeping bag and closed my eyes. James made me eat, but I couldn't stomach anything sophisticated. My last two meals of 1999 consisted of plates of potatoes.

We couldn't stay awake till midnight. During the evening, we heard fireworks nearby: the Nepalese were not particularly impressed with our new year - for them it was already 2056 - but they were happy to go along with it. I wasn't. I held my head and despaired.

But when the alarm went off at 5.30am, I discovered I had acclimatised overnight. It was dark and icy. Teeth chattered and boots clattered, waking everyone else in the wooden building. After we cemented our future together, we went to the dining room and ordered our first meal of the new millennium: a plate of potatoes.

The walk down the valley was a joy. We got to Syrabu Bensi, to catch the bus, in two days. We breathed the air, smiled at the ring, and felt boundlessly energetic. The start of the journey back was petrifying as the ramshackle bus juddered randomly up and down a stony track, inches away from a 1,000ft drop. By lunchtime, we were riding on the roof in the sunshine, ducking branches and, as we got closer to the Kathmandu, electric wires.

We wondered whether we would get back to the city to discover that a huge Y2K catastrophe had hit the planet. If it had, we would never have known.

The practicals

STA Travel (020 7361 6262) offers flights to Kathmandu with Qatar for £535 return, inc tax. A National Park permit, easily obtainable in Kathmandu, is required for trekking in the Langtang region. For more information, see Trekking in Langtang, Helambu and Gosainund by Jamie McGuinness (Trailblazer, £8.95).
