fields.headline: Worth its salt
fields.standfirst: Eilat may not be the most attractive resort, but where else do you get to swim with dolphins, float in the Dead Sea and play at being Indiana Jones in nearby Petra, asks  Andrew Gilchrist
fields.trailText: Eilat may not be the most attractive resort, but where else do you get to swim with dolphins, float in the Dead Sea and play at being Indiana Jones in nearby Petra, asks Andrew Gilchrist.
fields.body:
They came for us the moment we slipped over the netting and into the enclosure, an explosion of fins and grins darting about us in the clear, warm waters of the Red Sea. And what a racket they made. Click! Ping! Chirp! Crackle! Peep! Were these two dolphins talking to each other? Were they talking to me? Should I reply?

Through my snorkel I bellowed a waterlogged "Hello!" and Domino - recognisable from the white mark on her dorsal fin - zipped nearer and presented her back for stroking. In the light of the morning sun, a tapestry of battlescars glistened on her impossibly shiny grey body. This frisky 14-year-old had lived a little.

Domino was one of the six original dolphins (there are now 11) brought from the Black Sea to Eilat, a holiday resort on Israel's southern coast, to form a unique type of nature reserve - a place guided by what you might call the doctrine of "dolphin choice". A giant net stretching into the sea marks out the borders of Dolphin Reef but it's got two gates, always open, so our finned friends can scarper any time. They may nip out now and again to really stretch their dorsals, but they always come back.

This pioneering ethos has bred a pride and confidence at the site best summed up by the name given to the pod's most recent addition: Yampa, the cutest little bottlenose you ever did see, born to Domino last summer and currently the pint-sized star attraction at the reef's four daily shows (sorry, not shows, "interactions"). Previously, the dolphins were given the kind of names you'd give a pony - Cindy, Bungee - but Yampa comes from the Hebrew words yam , meaning sea, and patuach , meaning open. In other words, Open Sea.

We had 25 minutes in the water with the dolphins, every second of it spent marvelling at these creatures that seem equally as fascinated with us. Why do we like them so much? Maybe it's because you don't have to do much to earn their friendship: just turn up in wetsuit and snorkel, splash about clumsily, and they'll come at you with all the eagerness of a puppy bringing the morning paper - only, given their renowned intelligence, they'll probably have read the paper first and got halfway through the crossword. Or maybe it's just the fact that they were lucky enough to be born with broad grins and gentle eyes, and we are suckers for that kind of thing.

Then, of course, there are the tricks. At the 2pm interaction, from a pier extending into the reef, we witnessed a display of synchronised swimming as dazzling as the mid-afternoon sun. We watched three "porpoise", as it's called, in perfect unison, arching in and out of the water at speed, as if trying to sew the sea to the sky - a trick they use in the wild to shake off predators. If they'd suddenly produced canes, top hats and started tap-dancing, no one on the pier - except perhaps the blokes from Berlin University, who have a base there to study these majestic mammals - would have been surprised.

Perhaps most impressive of all was the fact that the dolphins are fed before they do their tricks, not after. So if they don't feel like performing, they don't have to. Again, dolphin choice.

Situated in the sliver of Israeli land between Egypt and Jordan, Eilat made its name as a diving centre, but there's plenty to do above the waves as well. Although it's not the most beautiful resort in the world - colossal hotels all but obscure the surrounding red-tinted mountains - it's a lively place with busy beaches, bars and clubs, and any type of restaurant you want.

Eilat is also an excellent base for daytrips. The ruins of the clifftop settlement of Masada - a place synonymous in Israel with the spirit of defiance, thanks to one horrifying day of mass bloodshed in 73AD - is just a few hours away by coach across the desert. Situated atop a sheer-sided plateau overlooking what were once key trade roads through the desert plains, Masada was a stronghold of great strategic importance. In 70AD, its 1,000 Jewish inhabitants, called the Zealots, found themselves besieged by the Romans, who massed troops in their thousands around the base of the plateau.

The Zealots held out for an incredible three years. But those three years of defiance are not what made Masada so famous. When the Romans finally breached the fortifications, the Zealots, realising all was lost, took an extraordinary decision. Rather than let them fall into enemy hands, they set fire to their houses and their possessions. Then they took their own lives. Ten men were selected by lots and given the job of slaying the rest. Nine of them were then killed by the tenth, who duly took his own life.

We walked after our guide, Asaf, along the dusty remains of thoroughfares that must have run with blood, wondering how it must have felt to be a Roman soldier preparing for battle only to find your foe slain by his own hand. The invaders found only two women and five children alive. They had survived by hiding.

Excavation at Masada began in the 1960s and is still going on. Up at the north end - past the remains of the swimming pool and the bath-house, and near the spot tucked into the side of the cliff that some believe was a cocktail bar - there's a picture of Bill and Hillary Clinton joining in a dig. This is a hint at the wider, political context of these ruins, at the fact that this sobering story of siege and defiance from long ago is seen as having parallels with Israel today. Indeed, the army holds swearing-in ceremonies among these ruins. "Masada shall not fall again," the young soldiers shout.

After all that, it's a relief to take the cablecar back to ground level, switch your brain off, pull on your swimming costume and join the tourist throng in the tiny segment of the Dead Sea that's open to the public. About eight times saltier than your average ocean, the "Sea of the Devil" has to be treated with respect. Thick with magnesium chloride, its water is actually 33% solid, will sting badly if it gets in your eyes and can make you vomit if it gets in your mouth. Such is its level of buoyancy that overweight swimmers have been known to flop over on to their fronts and stay that way, unable to right themselves. Some have drowned. But, all that aside, there's no denying that having an effortless float here is a thrilling, if not entirely comfortable, experience.

Also a few hours' drive from Eilat, in neighbouring Jordan, is the legendary pink city of Petra. Its facades, as ornate and grand as any in Paris or Rome, are made all the more impressive once you know that they were chiselled into existence from the sides of cliffs, by artisans perched on precarious scaffolding.

And, of course, as they never tire of telling you, this is the place where Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade was filmed. Those staying the night in the nearby town will be hard-pushed to find a hotel not showing the movie on video.

Back in Eilat, we set off for what was called "an evening of Israeli folklore" at a local kibbutz, but which could equally have been entitled "a total piss-up with nonsensical singing". Seated in a huge hall with about 200 other guests, we were brought carafe after carafe of wine, glass after glass of beer, and commanded to dig into the superb food laid out on tables at the back. Then a chirpy compere appeared and told us all to shout "Bum" at him.

Actually, it wasn't that simple. In the early days of Israel, when the 1950 Law of Return granted citizenship to any Jew requesting it, there was a sudden influx of people from around the world. On their kibbutzim, or collective farms, they shared a common cause - working the generally barren and inhospitable land to build a country - but they lacked a common language to sing in and build a culture. "But then," explained our compere, "we made a discovery. There is an international language after all."

They composed songs by using the international language of meaningless musical words: la-la-la, dee-dee-dee, bum-bum-bum, and so on. To illustrate his point, he split the room into three and had us all join in with certain parts of the gibberish, until the whole room shook with strangers competing to see who could yell bum the loudest. As the night progressed, the beer flowed faster, the singing got louder and sweaty bodies jostled for space on the dancefloor to perform movements that were as impossible to fathom as the lyrics of the songs.

As cultures go, it seemed a pretty good start.

The practicals

Longwood Holidays (0181-551 4494) offers seven nights' B&B in Eilat, at King Solomon's Palace Hotel, from £427pp, including return flights and transfers. The same package at Edomit Hotel costs £309pp. Dolphin Reef is open all year from 9am to 5pm. The entrance fee for adults is 35NIS (£5.75) and 28NIS for children. For more details, and to hear the signature whistles of each dolphin, visit www.dolphinreef.co.il

fields.headline: Remains of the day
fields.standfirst: This corner of West Africa has changed out of recognition since it gained independence in the 1950s.  Patrick Ensor  returns for the first time in 40 years with his father, a former colonial administrator, who charts his impressions below
fields.trailText: Ghana has changed out of recognition since it gained independence in the 1950s. Patrick Ensor returns for the first time in 40 years with his father, a former colonial administrator, who charts his impressions below.
fields.body:
If ancestral roots in the slave trade are the main draw for American tourists to this corner of West Africa, my visit was also motivated by a sense of history. Personal history. Accra, the capital of Ghana, was where I spent most of the first 10 years of my life, and I was embarked on a journey of rediscovery with my father, Michael, who went out as a colonial administrator during the second world war and stayed for 17 years, till the Gold Coast gained independence in 1957. This was his first return in 40 years.

Ghana's rapidly growing population has put an enormous strain on the country's fragile economy and an education system of which it is justly proud (UN secretary-general Kofi Annan went to school not far from Elmina).

Accra, whose airport is the point of entry for most visitors, is the first surprise. So vast and sprawling - the city covers 10 times the area it did in 1960 and is almost unrecognisable. Every road seems permanently choked with traffic and the fumes of thousands of badly-tuned diesel engines. Every taxi ride, however short, takes at least 40 minutes and leaves your lungs feeling like those of a smoker with a terminal habit. What the pollution does to the hordes of young traders trying to sell bread or chewing gum through car windows scarcely bears thinking about.

All in all, not an attractive place to spend more than a day or two, though the people here, as elsewhere in Ghana, are extraordinarily friendly and good-natured, and there is an endless amount of fun to be had reading the names of the shops and factories as you sit in traffic jams: Charisma Shopping Centre, French Kiss Café and God First Terrazzo Works. Religion touches almost everything in Ghana, a tribute either to the missionaries' zeal or Africans' easy acceptance of the Gospel.

Accra has any number of monuments either created by or dedicated to the late Dr Kwame Nkrumah. Despite the army coup that forced Ghana's founding father into exile and death in neighbouring Guinea, President Jerry Rawlings has seen fit to build a mausoleum for him on the sea front. We choose not to visit it, preferring to admire the two bronze statues of Nkrumah in the gardens of the national museum, one missing its arms after he - and it - were toppled in 1966.

The museum itself is full of fascinating artefacts, including fine examples of kente cloth, historical regalia, wooden carvings and a selection of royal stools with such gnomic inscriptions as "He who follows the elephant encounters no dew". Attached to the museum is a well-run self-service restaurant where, for less than £2.50, you can sample a wide range of Ghanaian cuisine. It's a useful introduction because, in many of the cheaper hotels and restaurants, the local grub is all that's worth eating.

Most meals comprise one course with two main ingredients: a grapefruit-sized ball or two of fufu or banku , depending on whether it's made from pounded cassava, yam or fermented maize, and a fish or chicken stew to add flavour. Scoop a ball of the white starch in your hand, dip it into the peppery stew, and then pop it into your mouth.

Easier said than done. Most food is cooked in the red oil of palm nuts, and all too often I was left looking like a clown whose make-up had slipped. Thank heavens for the bowl of water and washing-up liquid that came with the meal. Then I discovered red-red : fried plantains with black-eyed beans. It rapidly became a favourite, not least because even Africans eat it with a knife and fork.

There are three principal routes out of Accra. To the north-west lies the Ashanti kingdom with its capital in Kumasi, to the west the Cape Coast region, with its string of old European castles and forts. But our trip down nostalgia lane takes us east along the coast through dry savannah country towards the Togo border. With our knuckle-popping young Ghanaian driver at the wheel of a 4WD Toyota Landcruiser, we head for Ada, on the mouth of the Volta river, where my father was a young district commissioner just after the war.

Hotels in Ghana veer from a few expensive establishments along the coast, where everything is priced in US dollars, to mid-range and cheap hotels that have a faintly dilapidated air but where the Ghanaian cedi goes a long way.

The Paradise Beach Hotel at Ada offers all the comforts of an upmarket hotel, with a large swimming pool, a great view across the Volta and an attractive setting for a get-away-from-it-all holiday in Africa. One note of caution: the incidence of bilharzia - a worm infection transmitted by snails in slow-moving water - has risen since the Volta dam was built and slowed the river flow downstream.

The short drive from Ada to the river bridge at Sogakope takes us through the village of Vumë, where large, colourful pots line the roadside. The distinguished English potter Michael Cardew spent several years upgrading and running the local pottery during my father's stint as DC. We stop and are taken to meet the elderly village chief. Of course he remembers Cardew. "He came during the Attlee administration," he recalls.

From Sogakope, we take the dirt road north to Ho, whose large open-air market offers an array of local produce, including trays of tripe and giant snails for those with strong stomachs. From there, we head west to Akosombo and a night at the Volta Hotel. Situated about two hours' drive from Accra, this well-kept hotel offers an attractive weekend escape from the crowded capital. From here, it is possible to take day trips to a small island or longer, more adventurous voyages on the 250-mile-long Volta Lake.

The long cross-country drive to Kumasi follows an escarpment before entering a region of tropical rainforest that I remember well from my childhood. But where are the trees? The answer becomes apparent as we crawl into Kumasi past large wood factories. Timber, along with cocoa, is one of Ghana's chief exports but, at the rate the forests are being felled, we fear there will be little left to log in 20 years' time.

Kumasi is the true cultural heart of Ghana. Although the British made Accra their colonial capital, Kumasi has a king - the Asantehene - and a golden stool that symbolises a proud Ashanti empire that long predates European interest in West Africa. It took many years in the late 19th century for the British to subdue the spirited Ashanti, and it was only with the capture and exile of Prempeh I to Seychelles 100 years ago that British control over the Gold Coast was complete.

Manhyia Palace, built to mark the Asantehene's return from exile in 1926, is open to the public, but no cameras are allowed inside and you must be accompanied by a guide. The two-storey palace is a veritable time capsule filled with the absurd gifts of visiting dignitaries. Cupboards drip with heavy gold ornaments that the king wears on Akan religious days, and alarmingly lifelike effigies of past kings and queen mothers greet you in several of the rooms.

Our two nights at Kumasi are spent at the grand but gloomy City Hotel, built among the spacious bungalows in the old colonial quarter. The state-run hotel appears to have had no money spent on it since it was built in the early 1960s. No one remembers when it last had running hot water. But the staff are more than willing to bring up steaming buckets and cheerfully turn out at all hours to replace broken fittings. This is a cedi hotel, costing the equivalent of £13 a night for a double room.

The road down to the coast to Elmina passes Kakum National Park. Although forest elephants and the fabled bongo are said to inhabit this corner of preserved rainforest, its main attraction is the spectacular rope walk in the forest canopy - one of only four of its kind in the world.

A uniformed guide takes groups through the forest to the first of a series of walk ways suspended between huge tropical trees. It is probably as well that the ground is invisible 50ft below as we take it in turns to bounce along the narrow planks, desperately clutching at the cable handholds for reassurance.

After a reasonably gruelling week on pot-holed roads, the attraction of the beach and a cool sea breeze are almost overwhelming. We spend a couple of nights at the Elmina Beach Resort, still in the process of construction, and our last night before catching the flight home at the top-of-the-range Labadi Beach Hotel, just outside Accra, where my family spent many happy Sundays by the beach.

Ghana hasn't been yet spoilt by tourism, which is still in its infancy. Although conspicuous by our colour, we felt almost invisible in Accra. As visitors, we were everywhere greeted with a friendliness that would put most Brits to shame. When Ghanaians say "You are welcome", they say it as if they really mean it. The country may have changed out of recognition in 40 years, but, as my father and I were pleased to note, the people remain as warm as ever.

'The abandoned fort that was my office stands lapped by the sea'

Michael Ensor

Ghana, well endowed at the time of independence and with a stable currency, soon descended, as the result of reduced earnings from cocoa and other exports and mismanagement, into an economic trough from which it is only now starting to climb. The inflation that its currency underwent is reflected today in the fact that the highest denomination of banknote is worth around £1. As a result, in a country where credit cards are not widely accepted, the traveller is put to the inconvenience of having to carry a thick bundle of notes.

Women used to play a major part in Ghana's retail trade, enjoying a monopoly of the market in foodstuffs and textiles. So much so that when fishermen brought their catch to the beach, it was at once taken over by their women. With the spread of girls' education, women have moved upwards to play an important part in the more complex commercial sector.

After several coups, political stability seems to have returned with a president and legislature elected by a system the revision of whose mechanism was my last task in Ghana. But it is still thought prudent to maintain frequent police road checks, which are not only for the detection of traffic offences, and to restrict photography in unlikely places.

The greatest improvement that I perceived came from the increasingly widespread supply of electricity from the hydro-electric plant below the Volta dam. As well as providing illumination, it powers village water supplies and cornmills, which is a boon for women. How my wife would have appreciated the end of oil lamps during our postings away from headquarters. Now air-conditioning improves the comfort of visitors. There can be few Ghanaians who still feel that the flooding of nearly 10% of the country was too high a price to pay.

Ghana's road network has been greatly extended and this has enabled more outlying farmers to produce food for urban markets as well as subsistence crops. To the east of Accra, a second bridge replacing the ferry across the lower Volta together with improvements to trunk roads have halved many journey times. But secondary roads are as unreliable as I remember them, especially in the rainy season.

A development that saddened me was the harm that had been done to Ghana's palm-fringed coastline by the ravages of a disease of coconut palms that leaves unsightly frond-less trunks. Added to this, marine erosion has washed away much of Keta, where the abandoned remains of the attractive 18th-century Danish fort that was my office and court stand lapped by the sea that has cut the coastal road to the east and is threatening to break through to the lagoon.

webTitle: MPs hit at weapon exports policy and secrecy

fields.headline: MPs hit at weapon exports policy and secrecy
fields.standfirst: Labour's ethical foreign policy: special report
fields.trailText: The government yesterday came under renewed attack over its policy on arms exports as MPs found there had been no radical shift under Labour on weapons sales to Indonesia and serious questions remained over the supply of defence equipment to Zimbabwe and Pakistan.
fields.body:
The government yesterday came under renewed attack over its policy on arms exports as MPs found there had been no radical shift under Labour on weapons sales to Indonesia and serious questions remained over the supply of defence equipment to Zimbabwe and Pakistan.

A joint report from the cross-party defence, foreign affairs, international development, and trade and industry committees also criticised the continuing secrecy surrounding arms sales.

It expressed dismay over the government's failure to implement recommendations made four years ago in the Scott arms-to-Iraq report, specifically the repeal of emergency wartime powers, and allowing parliament to scrutinise arms exports more effectively.

On Indonesia, it says the only change was a "heightened distaste" for arms exports because of human rights abuses under the former Suharto regime. The absence of "any radical or demonstrable change" in government policy meant none of the 125 licences granted by its Conservative predecessor was revoked.

They include licences for Hawk jets - an unidentified number of which have yet to be delivered - as well as armoured combat vehicles delivered despite Labour guidelines stating that arms would not be exported if they were likely to be used in internal repression.

The MPs say the government approved at least one licence that could have led to the upgrading of Indonesia's military capability at a time when its forces were being condemned for their brutality in east Timor.

The MPs disclose that the government has extended existing licences until March 2001 to make up for the period "lost" after the EU imposed a four-month embargo last year. Britain was instrumental in getting the embargo lifted last month.

Reviewing the Tory licences would have been "entirely practicable", they say. Legal advice obtained by the committees suggested that the government could have survived a legal challenge if it had revoked the licences as a result of a change in foreign policy.

The MPs express regret that the government refused to show them its legal advice, or even name the firm of lawyers which gave it, despite repeated requests to do so.

They refer to recent Guardian disclosures that Tony Blair overruled Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, by agreeing to send spare Hawk parts to Zimbabwe, now embroiled in the Congo civil war, and an internal government dispute over arms sales to Pakistan.

These raised "wider issue of public policy" on which they intended to question ministers further.

Earlier this week Mr Blair said he was tightening up arms export controls covering countries involved in the conflict in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The MPs say the government should now draw up and publish guidelines "governing the extent to which the UK feels bound to license spares for existing UK-supplied equipment".

Annual reports covering arms exports should in future give details of the number of items covered by each export licence as well as their total value by country. The MPs call for a "more stringent national policy" on arms brokering and trafficking and say that the problem of licensed production of British-designed arms overseas should be given a far higher priority.

They recognise that the government nevertheless gives more information about arms sales than any of its EU partners. "It is important that we do not damage the competitive position of UK defence exporters in world markets." The EU code of conduct fell "some way short of a system whereby a licence can be refused simply because of pervasive abuse of human rights in the country to which arms are to be exported".

Paul Eavis, director of Saferworld, an independent research body, said yesterday it would be "outrageous" if no legislation on Sir Richard Scott's recommendations was forthcoming before the next election.

The foreign office minister, Peter Hain, said yesterday the government would look seriously at the recommendations and give a detailed response. "But don't lose sight of what we have achieved. We have established tough criteria to prevent the export of arms for internal repression and external aggression. We have banned the export of equipment which can be used for torture."

No new arms export licences to Pakistan had been agreed since the coup on October 12. "There is no evidence that this government has ever licensed any equipment that might be used for internal repression and no evidence that any equipment approved by this government has been used for repression in Indonesia."

Ann Clwyd, a member of the international development committee, said last night that claims that British equipment had not been used for internal repression were "patently untrue". Armoured vehicles had been used on the streets in Indonesia.

Menzies Campbell, Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, said: "What is required is transparency and accountability, proper controls over arms brokers and a select committee with the responsibility to review arms export policy and to monitor individual applications."

fields.headline: Mugabe faces referendum on misrule
fields.standfirst: Despite widespread opposition to Zimbabwe's proposed new constitution, cynicism abounds over this weekend's poll
fields.trailText: The queue to register to vote is long and slow-moving. The room is hot and uncomfortable. Tempers fray.
fields.body:
The queue to register to vote is long and slow-moving. The room is hot and uncomfortable. Tempers fray.

A woman is told that her identification papers are too tattered to be valid and she argues with the official. "This is all rubbish," she says. "You cannot push us around any longer. I have the right to vote and I know it. This new constitution is rubbish and I am going to vote no!"

Others in the queue nod their heads in agreement.

The woman succeeds in getting registered, but those in the queue continue discussing Zimbabwe's draft constitution.

They do not like the fact that it gives President Robert Mugabe virtually all the powers of the state. They do not like the fact that Mr Mugabe can stay in office for another 12 years, although he is 75 and has been in power for 20 years. And they do not believe Mr Mugabe's promises that the new constitution will speed up redistribution of white-owned farming land to poor black people.

"We are fed up with his promises. This constitution is not what the people wanted. We said we wanted less power to the president," said a schoolteacher in the registration queue. "But Mugabe has twisted our words. He has created a constitution which suits him but not the people."

He hands out papers entitled "15 reasons to vote no!" to others in the queue. People pass them around. One leaflet reaches the desk of the argumentative registration official. She puts it in her handbag.

Zimbabwe is palpably tense as the country goes to the polls this weekend to vote on whether or not to accept the draft constitution presented to the people by Mr Mugabe.

Violence has already marred the referendum campaign.

President Robert Mugabe is asking the Zimbabwean people for an endorsement of his rule at a time when discontent has never been higher.

For more than a month the country has been gripped by a fuel shortage. Bus companies have been forced to stop their fleets and many workers have to walk long distances or wait in queues for hours.

Inflation is 60%, unemployment is 50%, corruption is rampant, crime is rising and living standards are falling.

The creation of a new constitution was supposed to unite the nation behind a framework for good governance. But the draft is widely viewed as designed to extend the rule of Mr Mugabe and his Zanu-PF party.

The constitutional referendum is a prelude to parliamentary elections due in April.

Mr Mugabe's party is unlikely to maintain the grip it has on parliament, in which it holds 147 of the 150 seats. But the new constitution will allow the president to continue holding all the reins of power.

"There has been a groundswell of opposition to this draft constitution, particularly in the cities," says Trevor Ncube, editor of the Zimbabwe Independent newspaper.

"This draft constitution is a monumental fraud. It is a misrepresentation of what the people said they wanted. The president has the arrogance to pretend to consult the people and then ignore them."

Twenty years ago Robert Mugabe was credited with bringing peace and racial reconciliation to war-torn Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe).

He was nominated for the Nobel peace prize and hailed as a new-style African leader, who would avoid the misrule of others on the continent.

Today his reputation as an international statesman is long gone. His rule has been marked by vitriolic tirades against white people, and by human rights abuses. Zimbabwe's once-prosperous economy is in tatters.

Harare, Bulawayo and Zimbabwe's other cities are hotbeds of opposition to the new constitution. But Mr Mugabe is counting on support in rural areas, where some 70% of Zimbabwe's 12m people live.

He altered the constitution to say that if Britain does not pay for land seized from Africans during colonial rule, then the state can seize white-owned land without compensation. Rural peasants have been told: "Vote for the constitution, and Comrade Mugabe will give you new land." But Mr Mugabe has promised them land before, and there are signs that many farmers, too, are fed up with his rule.

The government is pulling out all the stops to sell the draft constitution.

It has used its command of the state media to flood the public with beguiling images calling for a yes vote. Advertisements, talk shows, catchy songs and pseudo-documentaries urge people to vote for the new constitution.

Groups campaigning for a no vote have been largely prevented from advertising and have been the targets of a coarse smear campaign.

Opposition workers have been beaten and then arrested by police. But those opposed to the draft constitution are still working to get the word out.

"Vote no" graffiti have sprouted up on strategic bridges and walls. People hand out pamphlets in workplaces. Cars and taxis with "vote no" signs get friendly hoots from other motorists.

However, despite massive opposition, it is almost certain that the constitutional referendum will pass. It is expected that less than 30% of the electorate will vote.

Many believe the vote will be rigged. But even with a small turnout and suspect counting, the referendum will not be a huge mandate for Mr Mugabe.

But the general view is summed up in a bit of graffiti. The government slogan "A new constitution, a new era" has been altered to read: "A new constitution, a new error".

Numerous civic groups are opposed to Zimbabwe's new constitution, including human rights activists, lawyers' groups, women's organisations and churches. Here are some of their complaints:

Increased presidential power

Under the draft, the president has sweeping powers, including the authority to dissolve parliament and declare war. Mr Mugabe will be permitted to run for two more five-year terms.

Women's rights

Women have fewer rights than in the current constitution. The majority of women would not have the right to own property.

Individual rights

Legal experts say the bill of rights is weak. Any right can be overridden in the name of "public morality and public security".

Press censorship

A clause calls for the establishment of a state-controlled media council which would be given the power to regulate the press.

The constitution permits the use of emergency powers which give the government draconian rights of arrest. The draft also allows leaders to ban strikes and demonstrations, along with other powers which resemble measures available under the old Rhodesian regime.

The president has immunity from prosecution while in office, and can grant pardons to anyone convicted of crimes.

A woman is told that her identification papers are too tattered to be valid and she argues with the official. "This is all rubbish," she says. "You cannot push us around any longer. I have the right to vote and I know it. This new constitution is rubbish and I am going to vote no!" Others in the queue nod their heads in agreement. The woman succeeds in getting registered, but those in the queue continue discussing Zimbabwe's draft constitution. They do not like the fact that it gives President Robert Mugabe virtually all the powers of the state. They do not like the fact that Mr Mugabe can stay in office for another 12 years, although he is 75 and has been in power for 20 years. And they do not believe Mr Mugabe's promises that the new constitution will speed up redistribution of white-owned farming land to poor black people. "We are fed up with his promises. This constitution is not what the people wanted. We said we wanted less power to the president," said a schoolteacher in the registration queue. "But Mugabe has twisted our words. He has created a constitution which suits him but not the people." He hands out papers entitled "15 reasons to vote no!" to others in the queue. People pass them around. One leaflet reaches the desk of the argumentative registration official. She puts it in her handbag. Zimbabwe is palpably tense as the country goes to the polls this weekend to vote on whether or not to accept the draft constitution presented to the people by Mr Mugabe. Violence has already marred the referendum campaign. President Robert Mugabe is asking the Zimbabwean people for an endorsement of his rule at a time when discontent has never been higher. For more than a month the country has been gripped by a fuel shortage. Bus companies have been forced to stop their fleets and many workers have to walk long distances or wait in queues for hours. Inflation is 60%, unemployment is 50%, corruption is rampant, crime is rising and living standards are falling. But the draft is widely viewed as designed to extend the rule of Mr Mugabe and his Zanu-PF party. The constitutional referendum is a prelude to parliamentary elections due in April. Mr Mugabe's party is unlikely to maintain the grip it has on parliament, in which it holds 147 of the 150 seats. But the new constitution will allow the president to continue holding all the reins of power. "There has been a groundswell of opposition to this draft constitution, particularly in the cities," says Trevor Ncube, editor of the Zimbabwe Independent newspaper. "This draft constitution is a monumental fraud. It is a misrepresentation of what the people said they wanted. The president has the arrogance to pretend to consult the people and then ignore them." Any right can be overridden in the name of "public morality and public security". fields.headline: Mugabe in the rough
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe is crying out for a fresh start
fields.trailText: The referendum in Zimbabwe this weekend on a new, government-backed constitution which enhances presidential powers seems likely to deepen the country's sense of crisis. If the vote is "yes", President Robert Mugabe and his ruling Zanu-PF party will be accused of rigging the process. On the eve of the ballot, concerns persisted about independent monitoring, the location of polling stations, and increased violence.
fields.body:
The referendum in Zimbabwe this weekend on a new, government-backed constitution which enhances presidential powers seems likely to deepen the country's sense of crisis. If the vote is "yes", President Robert Mugabe and his ruling Zanu-PF party will be accused of rigging the process. On the eve of the ballot, concerns persisted about independent monitoring, the location of polling stations, and increased violence.

The National Constitutional Assembly, comprising politicians, trade unions, church and human rights groups opposed to the draft constitution, has complained of officially condoned intimidation and beatings of its supporters. State-controlled media have refused NCA advertisements. Many believe, with some justice, that the consultation process was manipulated to entrench one-man, one-party rule. Warning of impending "chaos", the government is assuming emergency powers first introduced by Ian Smith after UDI, including detention without trial. But if the result is believed to be a fiddle, popular outrage may prove hard to contain.

If the referendum produces a "no" vote, the pressure on the government ahead of general elections due by April will intensify dramatically. The Movement for Democratic Change, the main opposition, will resurrect proposals, rejected by the government, for a popularly elected, executive prime minister answerable to parliament, full-scale proportional representation, devolution of power to the provinces, and the curtailment of the president's future role to a largely ceremonial one. Mr Mugabe, whose term runs to 2002 and who has ruled almost unchallenged for 20 years, views such levelling ideas with loathing.

Democratic reform apart, the dire state of Zimbabwe's economy will be the key issue in the coming election. With unemployment at record highs and inflation at 60%, with fuel, power, and food shortages biting ever deeper, with services crumbling and with foreign debt and defaults rising, Mr Mugabe and his party acolytes have less and less room for manoeuvre. The president's repeated pledges to expropriate white-owned farmland and redistribute it among the rural poor will win votes (although his demand that Britain compensate dispossessed farmers has already been rejected here). He has underwritten the political loyalties of the military, civil servants, chiefs and headmen, ministers and MPs by printing money, despite the risk of hyper-inflation, and awarding pay rises of up to 300%. And he will rely, as always, on his and Zanu-PF's standing as the freedom fighters of the old Rhodesia and as proud standard-bearers of post-colonial Africa - although he would be wise not to dwell on his own disastrous, neo-colonialist adventure in the Congo.

By conjuring De Gaulle-like spectres of impending deluges, Mr Mugabe and his party may well win an election in which patronage will play an influential role. But if they do, it is likely to be a fleeting, empty victory. For even Mr Mugabe cannot fly from reality indefinitely. His country is on its knees. The longer he resists pressure for change, the more divisive and dangerous will be his efforts to suppress it. His reputation, once high at home and abroad, has suffered badly. By clinging to power regardless, he will only further damage Zimbabwe and himself. The country cries out for a fresh start. It would better all round if Mr Mugabe, now 75, voluntarily heeded that call.

fields.headline: M&S chiefs plough in £2.5m
fields.trailText: The directors of Marks & Spencer yesterday put up £2.5m of their own to demonstrate their faith in their ability to turn round the store.
fields.body:
The directors of Marks & Spencer yesterday put up £2.5m of their own to demonstrate their faith in their ability to turn round the store.

The group's most senior executives, including chief executive Peter Salsbury, finance director Robert Colvill and new marketing supremo Alan McWalter - bought a total of 102,000 shares in the company.

Brian Baldock, M&S's acting chairman who will step aside when his Belgian replacement Luc Vandevelde takes over on February 28, purchased 20,000 shares at 237p, registered in the name of Fielding Nominees.

The move came after Philip Green announced he was ditching his plans to launch a hostile takeover bid for the company and the shares fell to their lowest level in nearly a decade. They rallied but, by the end of the day, the directors' show of support had made no difference and the shares closed down again, off 1.75p on their opening price at 231.25p - meaning the board had lost a combined £14,665. Many analysts believe the shares are heading down further, to 200p.

There has been widespread criticism of the M&S directors' meagre shareholdings, but the chain dismissed suggestions that the directors had taken action only after the group's external public relations advisers had urged them to demonstrate their commitment to the group and belief in its prospects with hard cash.

Potential predator Philip Green, whose wife bought 9.5m shares for £25m just before he announced his interest in bidding, was also a critic of the directors' lack of financial confidence in the company.

However, they still own less than 500,000 shares between them, while Mrs Green is the company's largest private investor.

webTitle: Black man set alight in street

fields.headline: Black man set alight in street
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A black man was fighting for his life last night after being set alight in the street in what Scotland Yard is treating as a racially motivated attack.
fields.body:
A black man was fighting for his life last night after being set alight in the street in what Scotland Yard is treating as a racially motivated attack.

Donovan Lindo, 36, suffered 65% burns when petrol was poured over him in Brixton, south London, on Thursday evening.

Police have arrested a man and a woman in north London and were last night questioning them in connection with the incident.

Mr Lindo was found ablaze in Loughborough park in the heart of Brixton, one of the capital's main Afro-Caribbean districts.

Sources said that it was believed that race was not the prime motive for the attack, which is believed to have followed an argument.

But police were believed to be treating the incident as racially motivated for two reasons: first, race may have been an added dimension in the attack; second, in the wake of revelations of police mistakes in the investigation of the Stephen Lawrence case, Scotland Yard has to be 100% sure before ruling out a racial motive.

Police said that it was highly likely that Mr Lindo knew his attacker, who was white. Chief superintendent Simon Foy, commander for Lambeth borough, which includes Brixton, said: "The suspect in this incident is a white man and by simple definition of the fact that we are dealing with a white suspect and a black victim this matter has been dealt with as a racially motivated attack."

Detective chief inspector Richard Taber, heading the investigation, said witnesses had seen Mr Lindo arguing with a white male in the park before the attack. The argument, in an alley, appeared to involve money and it was highly likely the men had arrived together. Mr Taber said: "I do not believe that this was a chance meeting between Mr Lindo and his assailant."

Police were treating the attack as attempted murder and were actively looking into the relationship between the two men.

Mr Taber added: "It is clear that an accelerant [petrol] has been used to set fire to Mr Lindo. One can only imagine the pain that this poor man went through."

A red plastic petrol can was found nearby, and police checked local garages in a bid to find where petrol used in the attack was bought.

Mr Taber said that the police had arrived as paramedics were treating Mr Lindo. He had extensive burns and was in a "potentially life-threatening position".

A passer-by tried to help the victim tear off his burning clothes, but it was not until ambulance crews arrived with a fire extinguisher that the flames could be put out.

Mr Taber said that medical evidence showed Mr Lindo had also been assaulted. He was being treated at a specialist burns unit outside London.

Arlene Mundle, a member of the Lambeth police consultative committee, said that racial attacks were rare in Brixton. "Except for the bombing, there are not a lot of racial attacks in Brixton or in the borough of Lambeth," she said, referring to a single bomb explosion last year in a suspected hate attack.

"It would be crass stupidity to perpetrate a racial attack in Brixton."

webTitle: Yes, computers spurred growth just as steam engines did

fields.headline: Yes, computers spurred growth just as steam engines did
fields.trailText: Now it's official: this is the longest economic expansion in US history, and there is little sign of an imminent collapse. If we discount the brief recession in 1991, the US economy has been expanding for almost two decades.
fields.body:
Now it's official: this is the longest economic expansion in US history, and there is little sign of an imminent collapse. If we discount the brief recession in 1991, the US economy has been expanding for almost two decades.

This would seem extraordinary, given that only a few years ago economists were fretting that we had reached an Age of Diminished Expectations, and commentators were warning of an "end of affluence".

A reading of history, however, suggests that this long period of growth could have been predicted. It has hap pened every time there has been a major industrial revolution. After the introduction of the steam engine, it took nearly two decades for the new technology to yield a growth premium, because the original steam engines were so inefficient.

Only after years of teaching a generation of mechanics how to use the revolutionary technology, and improving the engine so it could be diffused throughout manufacturing, did the new invention provide for a sustained period of economic growth.

The same kind of lag occurred between the introduction of the electric motor and the long-term growth witnessed at the beginning of the last century.

Now we have the information age, and the computer is finally paying off: it took more than two decades for hardware and software to become so user friendly that it could be diffused to nearly every industry and every use, and to educate a workforce to operate it.

We first saw the productivity premium of this revolutionary technology in US manufacturing in the 1980s. Finally, we are seeing it in the service sector. As a result, productivity is rising economy-wide at more than 2% a year. Tied to labour supply growing at more than 1% annually, we have the potential for 3% or more growth for the foreseeable future.

What could sabotage this era of prosperity? Surely a stock market crash could undermine aggregate demand so America's growth potential goes unrealised. As could a sudden tightening in monetary policy. But it is likely that the stock market will have a soft landing as strong profits continue to fuel the demand for equities. And under the careful guidance of Alan Greenspan, we are unlikely to see a sharp increase in short-term interest rates.

The one serious threat to long-term prosperity is the federal government's new obsession with budget surpluses. Both Democrats and Republicans are so committed to eliminating 165 years of accumulated government debt that no one is willing to spend the money needed for basic research, public infrastructure, or the education and training a continued industrial revolution requires.

This new-found fiscal conservatism may not show up this year or next. But eventually the round of technological progress based on the computer will come to an end. What new technology will take its place if the government fails to provide continuous investment in a science and technology not yet imagined?

Barry Bluestone is professor of political economy at Northeastern university in Boston and co-author of Growing Prosperity, just published by Houghton Mifflin.

webTitle: Who wants to be a dollar millionaire?

fields.headline: Who wants to be a dollar millionaire?
fields.trailText: You don't have to be a rocket scientist to become a millionaire - you just have to be American. Or so the insurers of the hit gameshow Who Wants to be a Millionaire? would have you believe.
fields.body:
You don't have to be a rocket scientist to become a millionaire - you just have to be American. Or so the insurers of the hit gameshow Who Wants to be a Millionaire? would have you believe.

The London-based under writer Goshawk Syndicate has confirmed the suspicion of many British viewers that questions on the US version of the show are easier than those posed here by Chris Tarrant.

The underwriter is going to court to try to end its contract with Buena Vista Entertainment, co-producers of the US show, on the grounds that it has had to pay out too heavily to big-money winners.

The US show, presented by Regis Philbin, regularly pulls in 30m viewers and two of its contestants, a taxman and a lawyer, have won the $1m prize by correctly answering all 15 questions. In the 51 editions broadcast by ABC, there have also been three $500,000 winners - whereas Mr Tarrant has presented just one £500,000 cheque to a winner on ITV in Britain.

A spokeswoman for ABC said there would be no changes to the programme, which has transformed the network's ratings. From being bottom, ABC is number one three nights a week.

fields.headline: Outraged of Lambeth
fields.standfirst: He's not just glad to be gay, he's ecstatic about it, and his campaigning zeal has been employed this week in the Section 28 furore.  Roy Hattersley on the Australian expat, former controversial London Labour candidate, and self-styled shock-trooper of sexual liberation
fields.trailText: He's not just glad to be gay, he's ecstatic about it, and his campaigning zeal has been employed this week in the Section 28 furore.  Roy Hattersley on the Australian expat, former controversial London Labour candidate, and self-styled shock-trooper of sexual liberation
fields.body:
Peter Tatchell is the only man in Britain who is publicly defined by his sexuality. Many public figures are well known to be gay, but it is incidental to their real interest and importance. Tatchell only forces his way into our minds when he is crusading against homophobia. And the passionate intensity with which he fights his holy war leaves no doubt that being what he is happy to call "queer" is his whole life. When he chose to call his jihad OutRage! he was doing more than warning the establishment that he meant to cause offence.

He was expressing his anger at society's rejection of what he believes is a beautiful way of life. It is real emotion - as well as a less attractive exhibitionist streak - which makes him mount his often bizarre campaigns, such as organising a gay crucifixion (complete with transvestite nuns who call themselves the Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence).

His impact has been immense. Last Monday when the House of Lords debated (and defeated) the repeal of Section 28, which prohibits the promotion of homosexuality in schools, peers who were determined that the prohibition should remain quoted Tatchell as an authority on gay life. He had, they claimed, admitted that the disputed clause did not encourage classroom bullying or prevent teachers from protecting persecuted pupils. But on Tuesday he said their action "was a vote for continued censorship and homophobia in schools. It maintains the system of sexual apartheid that treats lesbians and gay men as second-class citizens."

He has pursued his cause so dramatically - demonstrating against Michael Portillo's "hypocrisy" in allowing discrimination against homosexuals in the armed forces, despite the "sexual experiments" of his youth; and attempting a "citizen's arrest" of President Mugabe of Zimbabwe to bring him to trial for actions against two homosexual journalists - that he risks becoming what every homophobe believes all gays to be.

It would be wrong, and deeply offensive to Tatchell himself, to suggest that, as he celebrates 30 years of continuous campaigning, he has begun to mellow. But these days, he argues that his "ideas are at least as important as his activism". If people ignore his plans for creating a world free from sexual inhibitions, he must take some of the blame. There is no doubt that Tatchell would defend heterosexuals who choose to enjoy a parallel pleasure. He chooses to denounce restraint in the language of homosexual liberation because he happens to be gay. But he opposes all forms of personal repression. That is why he condemns "the gay ambition to appropriate every civil right that heterosexuals have".

In his judgment, the inhibitions imposed by society guarantee that not even "straights" are free. That is a view of life which infuriates not only choleric retired colonels and wizened spinsters. Michael Cashman, now a Labour Member of the European Parliament and once a pillar of Stonewall, the most representative gay pressure group, says that if Tatchell is not struggling for equality and parallel civil liberties, "he ought to stop pretending to represent the thousands of gay men and women who are".

But Cashman was anxious to emphasise that Tatchell himself is "utterly sincere". The distinction between the man and his methods was echoed by even the most severe critics of his belief in direct and often scandalous action. The common conclusion was that he is "well intentioned" but "misguided".

The history of his early years in Melbourne seem to confirm that, whatever part of his make-up is the direct product of nature, nurture gave him good cause to be outraged at his treatment by society. Although he describes his early years as containing "moments of great happiness and great sadness", he clearly endured a dismal childhood. His father (a lathe operator) and his mother (a bank clerk who had come down in the world) were divorced when young Peter was four. He remembers - or imagines he remembers - the sorrow he felt at their parting and his subsequent estrangement from his father. But it is his mother ("very talented_ her parents encouraged her to learn recitations and she appeared on radio") for whom he clearly felt most admiration and affection.

"She might have become an actress," but life upon the stage was incompatible with the highly religious views of her family. So she sank back into marriage and the bleak existence of "an ordinary working class, inner city family with no aspiration to anything", and her son was brought up in a house with "no books except an atlas, a bible, a family encyclopedia and two tracts of prophecy from the church".

He had, however, no difficulty in deciding how to spend his spare time. His mother was a chronic asthmatic. "When she was ill, especially when she was in hospital, I looked after my brother and, when my sister was born, her as well. I taught myself how to cook, sew and iron. From the age of eight I was changing nappies and heating up milk." He insists that he has "done enough parenting for one lifetime".

Remarriage did very little to relieve the family's poverty. But the religious intensity of life increased. Tatchell describes his youth, in a desperately poor and fervently Pentecostal household, with real pathos. "By comparison with other kids at school my birthday presents were pitiful. All my clothes were darned or second hand." And he speaks of his taxi-driver stepfather ("didn't own it... just took a percentage of the fare") with near contempt. The family income was "very, very modest". Australia had no health service, so much of his stepfather's wage "small enough in itself", was spent on health care for his mother.

And religion, instead of providing some sort of comfort, only made life harder. "It was a narrow-minded, fundamentalist, fire-and-brimstone sort of Christianity. We never went to the pictures." For years the family did not possess a television set. Then, when they could afford one, his stepfather, fearing that it was a corrupting influence, limited its use to two hours in the early evening. When he was 14, Tatchell left the Pentecostal church and became a Baptist. For a time, he taught Sunday school. He says the faith has gone but the ethic remains, except when it conflicts with his views on personal liberation.

In those early Australian years, he was an enthusiastic athlete; not team games but climbing, surfing and hiking. He was so popular at school that the other pupils elected him head boy, although in that "often brutally macho community" he was recognised as different. He also thought it a compliment when he was adjudged to have better legs than any of the teenagers at a nearby girls' school.

At 15 - "the family needed the wages" - he started work at Meyers, Melbourne's biggest department store. The country is not quite with him on this either; parliament this week was debating reducing the age of consent for homosexual men from 18 to 16. He takes the subject very seriously and promotes the good cause with what he believes to be a talent for inventing a good slogan: "If He Hasn't Got it On, Don't Let Him Have it Off". He actually believes that his argument is strengthened by statistics which show that almost 1,000 men are prosecuted each year for unlawful intercourse with underage girls.

Angela Mason, executive secretary of Stonewall, regards his campaign to lower the age of consent as "a gift to the opponents" and "absolutely counterproductive". She describes Tatchell as "sincere but misguided". Mason at least speculates on the need for a gay advance guard to storm the bastions of prejudice before the more reasonable forces of consensual reform move in to occupy the high ground of principle. But she comes down against the idea. She thinks that, for his own sake and that of the cause for which he campaigns, Tatchell "might be wise to get himself a job" outside the narrow confines of the gay community.

Despite newspaper smears, he "only lived on benefit during the few weeks after the byelection" when he was "getting things back together". If poverty is the cost of keeping up the battle, he pays the price willingly. All Tatchell's liberationist theories are advanced with a piety which makes plain that he is not simply glad to be gay. He is ecstatic about it. He can "remember every detail of that first night" when he decided "if this is what it's like to be gay, I'm gay and it's wonderful".

The campaigns were years away, but sex gave him a new confidence at the same time as work politicised and liberated him. Australia had sent troops to fight alongside the Americans in Vietnam and Tatchell was determined not to be drafted to join them. In the months before he was due to register for conscription in the late 60s he became active in the peace movement. "We were," he says, as if he still cares, "represented in parliament and press as traitors and fifth columnists. Anti-war marches were attacked by baton-wielding police on horseback. We expected to get our heads split open and that is what happened. We went underground and printed leaflets, encouraging young men to refuse the draft, in a printing press hidden in a cellar."

He clearly enjoyed the romance of clandestine subversion, but not enough to make him stay in Australia. In 1971, shortly after his 19th birthday, he emigrated to England. In Melbourne "there was no gay organisation, not even a switchboard or a helpline". It is clear that he felt in desperate need of comfort and support. For he speaks with a combination of gratitude and amazement at the discovery that in the Mother Country, homosexuals banded together to demand recognition and rights.

On his second day in England he passed a lamp-post on which a poster advertising the Gay Liberation Front had been hung. On day five of his new life he attended his first gay rights meeting. Within a month he was beginning to organise the front's campaigns. Despite his instant commitment to the cause, he might have remained just another homosexual dissident had not fate and inclination taken him into the Labour Party.

His instinct was for community politics. And he gave up a good liv ing, as a freelance in design and display, first to obtain some basic qualifications and then to become a social worker with the North Lambeth housing agency in Waterloo. He also began to recruit new members to his local Labour party, an activity which he insists was entirely innocent and, at the time, much welcomed by the old guard.

Of course, he continued his campaigning with the Gay Liberation Front. "In 1979" he says bitterly, "the number of gay men being arrested was higher than before the change in the law" which decriminalised homosexual relations between consenting adults. The outrage is genuine and constantly breaks the surface of his conversation like the bubbles in the lava of a temporarily quiet volcano.

In 1982 Bob Mellish - the MP for Bermondsey and ex-government chief whip - was appointed deputy chairman of the London Docks Corporation and announced that he would not be a candidate at the next general election. Labour was moving left and without the need to organise support, Tatchell was selected to replace him. Tatchell's brand of socialism was not, by the standards of the time, notably extreme. He was neither a Marxist nor a Militant. But he talked incessantly of "mobilising the grassroots".

He also wrote a couple of articles for the extreme-left newsletter Labour Briefing, an activity still regarded as proof of subversive inclinations. Both of them applauded "extra-parliamentary activity", though Tatchell now insists he meant that the marches and demonstrations should augment, rather than replace, the democratic duties of the House of Commons. But his alleged contempt for parliament was the pretext on which the campaign to overturn his selection was based.

No doubt his overt belief that "Gay is Good", helped to mobilise die-hard Labour opinion against him. But his real crime was opposing what he now calls "the old-style mafia," which ran the local party, and exposing what he still insists was inefficiency that bordered on corruption, including "grandiose schemes like spending £50m on a new town hall when council house repairs were years in arrears".

He now makes the improbable claim that he would have survived the strictures and the censure had he responded to the sexual advances of a long dead (and publicly homophobic) Labour hero. But whether or not he was the victim of the animosity which follows rejection, he was certainly made a scape-goat for catastrophes which were not of his making.

Bob Mellish discovered that he would not be paid his Docks Corporation salary while he remained an MP. So he decided to leave parliament at once. Labour therefore had to face the prospect of a gay, draft-dodging, community socialist being caught in the spotlight of a byelection campaign. The "old right" elevated "stopping Tatchell" into a test of Michael Foot's ability to lead the party back to sanity. In the House of Commons, Jim Wellbeloved, (a Labour defector who had joined Shirley Williams, Roy Jenkins and Bill Rodgers in the SDP) challenged the Labour leader to disown the Bermondsey party's choice of candidate.

Foot's response was categoric. Tatchell would not fight the byelection. He now explains. "At the time, I had never met him. But it had been put to me that he was the sort of person who opposes parliament itself. And I had my duties towards the party which I wanted to keep in one piece. A few days later he came to see me and it became clear that he had a real concern for the party as well as himself."

Reinforced by what amounted to a national party uprising against the proposed proscription, Foot suggested a compromise. In the interests of the party, Mellish should abandon the idea of a byelection and Tatchell's candidature should be endorsed in the knowledge that, when the general election came, he would be less conspicuous. In Foot's view, "Tatchell behaved entirely honourably and comes out of the whole thing pretty well", but "Mellish went back on his word" and resigned from the House of Commons.

In the byelection campaign which followed, Tatchell was doomed from the start. Monica Foot, Labour's byelection press officer, says she told Tatchell that he must decide for himself how to deal with the question of his homosexuality. But Tatchell clearly believed the Labour high command expected that, when asked if he was gay, he should categorically refuse to discuss the subject.

Whoever was to blame, Tatchell fell back on a defence which, though reasonable for others, was ridiculous for him. Private lives should remain private. No one else respected that view. John O'Grady, (Mellish's friend, sometime leader of Southwark Council and the Real Labour Candidate) toured the constituency with a loudhailer, singing songs about Tatchell wearing his trousers back to front. Liberal canvassers whispered that the Labour man was gay. A once-safe Labour seat elected Simon Hughes, the Liberal candidate, with a 10,000-vote majority.

Tatchell - forced to prevaricate about the part of his life which gave him most pleasure and pride - was traumatised for weeks after the campaign was over. Mason believes that "Bermondsey changed him". Cashman says "the people who behaved so badly have a lot to answer for", and includes in his condemnation both the newspapers who hounded the Labour candidate and the party officers who persuaded him to hide his homosexuality.

Richard Holloway, the Bishop of Edinburgh, who pleaded for leniency when Tatchell was convicted of "obscene behaviour in church" (interrupting the Archbishop of Canterbury in mid-sermon, at Easter 1998) describes the consequences of the campaign more dramatically: "It was in Bermondsey that the iron entered his soul." Holloway, a man notable for his compassionate and progressive views, began his defence of Tatchell's "undoubted sincerity" with the disclaimer that everyone seems to find necessary before expressing any other opinion. He has "the strongest reservation" about the tactics of a man he says has "many of the positive characteristics of old testament prophets - some of whom were unattractively unforgiving people".

The bishop was referring to the practice of "outing" - the public identification as homosexuals, of men who have denied, or kept secret, their gay inclinations. For a time, Tatchell made a particular habit of outing bishops, justifying the pain he caused on the grounds that they were party to the Anglican Church's discrimination against gay clergy. Bishop Holloway recalls the pain "it caused to good men".

Tatchell is unrepentant and defends himself against the accusation that he always chose soft targets for his exposure with the unheroic explanation that he knows the name of a dozen gay MPs who vote for homophobic laws, but cannot expose their hypocrisy because he does not possess enough evidence to resist a libel case. He does, however, claim that private letters pleading with MPs to reveal their true nature resulted in one or two conversions and subsequent votes (in the House of Commons) in favour of reducing the age of homosexual consent to 16.

He also makes the dubious claim that the most famous attempted exposure - of David Hope, then Bishop of London, in 1995 - was not an outing at all. Then he spoils his unconvincing denial with the added insistence that if it was, he was not responsible for it. Convinced of the Bishop's homosexuality - largely because Dr Hope had been head of a notoriously gay seminary - Tatchell delivered by hand what he still claims was intended to be a private letter. It urged the bishop to be true to what OutRage! believed to be his nature and, by admitting his sexuality, help to convince the church that it was an honourable estate.

The letter, he insists, contained no threat of exposure, but was just a plea for help and understanding. "But a journalist went to see Hope and told him that we were going to out him. So he called a press conference and talked about his sexuality being a grey area." Dr Hope, now Archbishop of York, upstaged Tatchell and his would-be tormentor clearly resents it. "The letter was intended to be private and he gave it to the press without the courtesy of letting me know."

Courtesy has not been a general feature of OutRage! campaigns. The self-righteous certainty makes it easy for some to dislike Peter Tatchell. So does his constant whining about the way he is treated by the press, an unlikely complaint for a man who has tried so hard to heap public contempt on "the closet gays" he calls hypocrites for attempting to keep their private lives private. But the real argument about his 30-year campaign is less concerned with his personal foibles than with the result of his efforts.

When he ran in front of John Major's car in 1996, brandishing a poster which demanded a reduction in the age of consent, he first claimed that his intended victim "dived for cover behind the driver's seat". Tatchell then announced, "We got the prime minister to bend over for gay men for the first time in his life". Asked how he can justify such frivolous treatment of a serious cause, he replies that he believes in "the importance of wit and humour".

Asked if his tactics often denied him support that his cause desperately needed, he dismisses the suggestion with the heroic (but irrelevant) announcement that he would not compromise with homophobia. That is why, last November, he planned to lead a group of gay ex-servicemen who, complete with campaign medals, would lay their wreaths at the Cenotaph. He trusted that the demonstration would cause offence. But he thought of them as the shock troops of gay liberation, breaching the walls of prejudice in the hope that less daring reinforcements would follow.

It would be easier to believe that Tatchell operates in the belief that OutRage! does more good than harm if he showed any sign of understanding the penalties of causing calculated offence. But he refuses even to consider the fears of his gay critics. For Peter Tatchell, the battle seems to have become more important than the victory.

Life at a glance

Born: January 21, 1952 in Footscray, Melbourne, Australia.

Education: Mount Waverley High School; A levels at night school in Melbourne; 1974-1977 Polytechnic of North London (BSc in sociology).

Employment: Department store shop dresser, Melbourne.

Political activities: August 1971, leaves Australia to avoid national service; joins Gay Liberation Front in London; after graduating becomes freelance researcher and journalist, also a social worker; 1978 joins Labour Party;1983 Labour candidate in Bermondsey byelection, loses by 10,000 votes; 1987 founds UK Aids Vigil pressure group; 1989 starts London Act Up (the Aids Coalition To Unleash Power); May 1990 - forms OutRage!.

Publications: 1994 Safer Sexy: the guide to gay sex safely; 1995 We Don't Want To March Straight - Masculinity, Queers & The Military.
