And he gave up a good liv ing, as a freelance in design and display, first to obtain some basic qualifications and then to become a social worker with the North Lambeth housing agency in Waterloo. He also began to recruit new members to his local Labour party, an activity which he insists was entirely innocent and, at the time, much welcomed by the old guard. Of course, he continued his campaigning with the Gay Liberation Front. "In 1979" he says bitterly, "the number of gay men being arrested was higher than before the change in the law" which decriminalised homosexual relations between consenting adults. The outrage is genuine and constantly breaks the surface of his conversation like the bubbles in the lava of a temporarily quiet volcano. In 1982 Bob Mellish - the MP for Bermondsey and ex-government chief whip - was appointed deputy chairman of the London Docks Corporation and announced that he would not be a candidate at the next general election. Labour was moving left and without the need to organise support, Tatchell was selected to replace him. Tatchell's brand of socialism was not, by the standards of the time, notably extreme. He was neither a Marxist nor a Militant. But he talked incessantly of "mobilising the grassroots". He also wrote a couple of articles for the extreme-left newsletter Labour Briefing, an activity still regarded as proof of subversive inclinations. Both of them applauded "extra-parliamentary activity", though Tatchell now insists he meant that the marches and demonstrations should augment, rather than replace, the democratic duties of the House of Commons. But his alleged contempt for parliament was the pretext on which the campaign to overturn his selection was based. No doubt his overt belief that "Gay is Good", helped to mobilise die-hard Labour opinion against him. But his real crime was opposing what he now calls "the old-style mafia," which ran the local party, and exposing what he still insists was inefficiency that bordered on corruption, including "grandiose schemes like spending £50m on a new town hall when council house repairs were years in arrears". He now makes the improbable claim that he would have survived the strictures and the censure had he responded to the sexual advances of a long dead (and publicly homophobic) Labour hero. But whether or not he was the victim of the animosity which follows rejection, he was certainly made a scape-goat for catastrophes which were not of his making. Bob Mellish discovered that he would not be paid his Docks Corporation salary while he remained an MP. So he decided to leave parliament at once. Labour therefore had to face the prospect of a gay, draft-dodging, community socialist being caught in the spotlight of a byelection campaign. The "old right" elevated "stopping Tatchell" into a test of Michael Foot's ability to lead the party back to sanity. In the House of Commons, Jim Wellbeloved, (a Labour defector who had joined Shirley Williams, Roy Jenkins and Bill Rodgers in the SDP) challenged the Labour leader to disown the Bermondsey party's choice of candidate. Foot's response was categoric. Tatchell would not fight the byelection. He now explains. "At the time, I had never met him. But it had been put to me that he was the sort of person who opposes parliament itself. And I had my duties towards the party which I wanted to keep in one piece. A few days later he came to see me and it became clear that he had a real concern for the party as well as himself." Reinforced by what amounted to a national party uprising against the proposed proscription, Foot suggested a compromise. In the interests of the party, Mellish should abandon the idea of a byelection and Tatchell's candidature should be endorsed in the knowledge that, when the general election came, he would be less conspicuous. In Foot's view, "Tatchell behaved entirely honourably and comes out of the whole thing pretty well", but "Mellish went back on his word" and resigned from the House of Commons. In the byelection campaign which followed, Tatchell was doomed from the start. Monica Foot, Labour's byelection press officer, says she told Tatchell that he must decide for himself how to deal with the question of his homosexuality. But Tatchell clearly believed the Labour high command expected that, when asked if he was gay, he should categorically refuse to discuss the subject. Whoever was to blame, Tatchell fell back on a defence which, though reasonable for others, was ridiculous for him. Private lives should remain private. No one else respected that view. John O'Grady, (Mellish's friend, sometime leader of Southwark Council and the Real Labour Candidate) toured the constituency with a loudhailer, singing songs about Tatchell wearing his trousers back to front. Liberal canvassers whispered that the Labour man was gay. A once-safe Labour seat elected Simon Hughes, the Liberal candidate, with a 10,000-vote majority. Tatchell - forced to prevaricate about the part of his life which gave him most pleasure and pride - was traumatised for weeks after the campaign was over. Mason believes that "Bermondsey changed him". Cashman says "the people who behaved so badly have a lot to answer for", and includes in his condemnation both the newspapers who hounded the Labour candidate and the party officers who persuaded him to hide his homosexuality. Richard Holloway, the Bishop of Edinburgh, who pleaded for leniency when Tatchell was convicted of "obscene behaviour in church" (interrupting the Archbishop of Canterbury in mid-sermon, at Easter 1998) describes the consequences of the campaign more dramatically: "It was in Bermondsey that the iron entered his soul." Holloway, a man notable for his compassionate and progressive views, began his defence of Tatchell's "undoubted sincerity" with the disclaimer that everyone seems to find necessary before expressing any other opinion. He has "the strongest reservation" about the tactics of a man he says has "many of the positive characteristics of old testament prophets - some of whom were unattractively unforgiving people". The bishop was referring to the practice of "outing" - the public identification as homosexuals, of men who have denied, or kept secret, their gay inclinations. For a time, Tatchell made a particular habit of outing bishops, justifying the pain he caused on the grounds that they were party to the Anglican Church's discrimination against gay clergy. Bishop Holloway recalls the pain "it caused to good men". Tatchell is unrepentant and defends himself against the accusation that he always chose soft targets for his exposure with the unheroic explanation that he knows the name of a dozen gay MPs who vote for homophobic laws, but cannot expose their hypocrisy because he does not possess enough evidence to resist a libel case. He does, however, claim that private letters pleading with MPs to reveal their true nature resulted in one or two conversions and subsequent votes (in the House of Commons) in favour of reducing the age of homosexual consent to 16. He also makes the dubious claim that the most famous attempted exposure - of David Hope, then Bishop of London, in 1995 - was not an outing at all. Then he spoils his unconvincing denial with the added insistence that if it was, he was not responsible for it. Convinced of the Bishop's homosexuality - largely because Dr Hope had been head of a notoriously gay seminary - Tatchell delivered by hand what he still claims was intended to be a private letter. It urged the bishop to be true to what OutRage! believed to be his nature and, by admitting his sexuality, help to convince the church that it was an honourable estate. The letter, he insists, contained no threat of exposure, but was just a plea for help and understanding. "But a journalist went to see Hope and told him that we were going to out him. So he called a press conference and talked about his sexuality being a grey area." Dr Hope, now Archbishop of York, upstaged Tatchell and his would-be tormentor clearly resents it. "The letter was intended to be private and he gave it to the press without the courtesy of letting me know." Courtesy has not been a general feature of OutRage! campaigns. The self-righteous certainty makes it easy for some to dislike Peter Tatchell. So does his constant whining about the way he is treated by the press, an unlikely complaint for a man who has tried so hard to heap public contempt on "the closet gays" he calls hypocrites for attempting to keep their private lives private. But the real argument about his 30-year campaign is less concerned with his personal foibles than with the result of his efforts. When he ran in front of John Major's car in 1996, brandishing a poster which demanded a reduction in the age of consent, he first claimed that his intended victim "dived for cover behind the driver's seat". Tatchell then announced, "We got the prime minister to bend over for gay men for the first time in his life". Asked how he can justify such frivolous treatment of a serious cause, he replies that he believes in "the importance of wit and humour". Asked if his tactics often denied him support that his cause desperately needed, he dismisses the suggestion with the heroic (but irrelevant) announcement that he would not compromise with homophobia. That is why, last November, he planned to lead a group of gay ex-servicemen who, complete with campaign medals, would lay their wreaths at the Cenotaph. He trusted that the demonstration would cause offence. But he thought of them as the shock troops of gay liberation, breaching the walls of prejudice in the hope that less daring reinforcements would follow. It would be easier to believe that Tatchell operates in the belief that OutRage! does more good than harm if he showed any sign of understanding the penalties of causing calculated offence. But he refuses even to consider the fears of his gay critics. For Peter Tatchell, the battle seems to have become more important than the victory. Life at a glance Born: January 21, 1952 in Footscray, Melbourne, Australia. Education: Mount Waverley High School; A levels at night school in Melbourne; 1974-1977 Polytechnic of North London (BSc in sociology). Employment: Department store shop dresser, Melbourne. Political activities: August 1971, leaves Australia to avoid national service; joins Gay Liberation Front in London; after graduating becomes freelance researcher and journalist, also a social worker; 1978 joins Labour Party;1983 Labour candidate in Bermondsey byelection, loses by 10,000 votes; 1987 founds UK Aids Vigil pressure group; 1989 starts London Act Up (the Aids Coalition To Unleash Power); May 1990 - forms OutRage!. Publications: 1994 Safer Sexy: the guide to gay sex safely; 1995 We Don't Want To March Straight - Masculinity, Queers & The Military.

fields.headline: Late bookings
fields.trailText: On the beach | Atoll story | Channel number | Think finca | Holm from home | Alicante can | Barca mad | Carib sun
fields.body:
On the beach
Follow Leonardo DiCaprio to Thailand and spend seven nights in Phuket, staying at the Bay Inn Hotel. The price of £697 per person includes return flights from Heathrow, seven nights' room-only accommodation, transfers and taxes. Book by February 29 with Bridge the World on 0171-911 0900.

Atoll story
If you can get away before the end of March, the price of holidays to the Maldives has been cut by £180. A six-night, full-board stay at the four-star Taj Lagoon Resort on an island at the northern end of the South Male Atoll costs from £748 per person, twin share, including return flights from Gatwick and speedboat transfer. Cresta Holidays (0870 1610930).

Channel number
Half-term on Jersey. Four-night midweek breaks for two adults and two children cost £177 with Modern Hotels 01534 735511). The price applies to arrivals on February 21 and includes return catamaran crossing from Weymouth, transfers and room-only accommodation at the Mayfair Hotel in St Helier, which has a heated indoor pool and gym.

Think finca
Canter through pine forests and along the dramatic coastline of Andalucia on a week's riding holiday at the English-run Finca los Romeros centre. There is varied riding for all standards. The £724price includes seven nights' full board with wine and drinks, five days' guided riding, return scheduled flights Gatwick-Gibraltar and transfers. Inntravel (01653 629010).

Holm from home
Go to Stockholm for two nights from £299. The price includes return flights, two nights at a three-star hotel and a Stockholm Go There Card, which gives free public transport around the city, free entrance to museums and discounts at shops and restaurants. Bridge Travel (01992 456304).

Alicante can
Seven nights in Alicante cost £149 per person for return flights, transfers and self-catering accommodation, leaving Gatwick on February 26 with Eclipse Holidays (08705 010203).

Barca mad
Breakfast in Barcelona on a two-night city break at the three-star Hotel Lleo. During February, the price is £295 and includes return flights from Gatwick and B&B. Crystal Cities (0870 888 0022).

Carib sun
Save £130 on a seven-night holiday to Barbados. Stay all-inclusive at the Barbados Beach Club on the southern tip of the island for £699 pp. For a fortnight's holiday, you pay £1,079, a saving of £300. Tropical Places (0800 0185256 and www.tropical.co.uk)

webTitle: Ulster goes back to direct rule

fields.headline: Ulster goes back to direct rule
fields.standfirst: Farce as Sinn Fein announces IRA initiative only after power move
fields.trailText: February 12 2000: Farce as Sinn Fein announces IRA initiative only after power move.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland Secretary, yesterday reluctantly announced the restoration of direct rule from midnight last night as Northern Ireland's unique experiment in inclusive government ended in angry farce after 72 days.

Sinn Fein announced a new IRA initiative only after Mr Mandelson had already signed the papers returning power to Westminster.

Government sources were furious. They said that Sinn Fein had earlier refused to divulge all the details of a fresh offer either to General John de Chastelain, chairman of the International Commission on Decommissioning, or to Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble. Mr Mandelson also said last night he was unaware of what it contained.

Minutes before Mr Mandelson's announcement of the suspension, Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, released a statement reporting a "major breakthrough" after frantic negotiations involving London, Dublin and Washington.

He said the IRA was willing to set out the context in which it would decommission. Mr Adams hailed it as a development of "enormous significance".

He believed that taken with the IRA's recent statements conceding that the issue of arms had to be addressed, and that it was no threat to the peace process, it would prompt a positive report from Gen de Chastelain.

That report, produced quickly last night for the governments, was said to give no clear answer to the two key issues: will the IRA decommission and, if so, when? It was still to be released late last night, but Mr Adams called for its publication.

The two governments did publish Gen de Chastelain's report of January 31. It referred to the IRA linkman outlining its ongoing support for the peace process, but the commission said it had received no information as to when IRA decommissioning would start.

It also indicated it would soon be unable to oversee the completion of decommissioning by May 22, the deadline in the Good Friday agreement, if there was no quick beginning.

Mr Adams accused Mr Mandelson of moving pre-emptively to suspend. He said Mr Mandelson had caved in to Ulster Unionist threats, making the situation more difficult.

Mr Adams said: "Peter Mandelson was kept fully informed of all of this. He has signed the papers in the knowledge that there was a major breakthrough. It is ridiculous to suggest that he was not conscious or aware of what was happening."

But Mr Mandelson countered: "I still don't know what the offer was because I haven't seen it. The first I knew of Mr Adams' statement was 20 minutes after I suspended the institutions."

Ulster Unionists suspected Mr Adams was trying to deflect blame. They said that Sinn Fein's statement took them by suprise.

Mr Trimble, who said he was disappointed at the return to direct rule, said: "The best information available to me is there were no significant breakthroughs. Although I had a meeting with Martin McGuinness and a conversa tion on the telephone with Mr Adams, they had nothing to put to me. Suspension became inevitable."

Mr Trimble agreed in November to form the power-sharing executive with Sinn Fein after promising his party's 860-strong ruling council he would quit as first minister before today's reconvened meeting if there was no start by then to IRA decommissioning. He calculated it was the only way to win party backing for the move.

The bitter recriminations underscored the difficulties ahead in resurecting the Good Friday agreement, now 22 months old. Mr Mandelson was unhappy at suspending, but believed allowing Mr Trimble to quit would have meant the end of the agreement.

Dublin, taking the lead in negotiations with the IRA, was unhappy at suspension, and pushed in vain for the institutions to be put on ice for three weeks.

The IRA's offer may be a good starting point to the second review of the agreement. Mr Mandelson said there had been movement, but the IRA had still to confirm it would decommission.

He said: "I regret very much having to do this. But we have got to clear up this issue of decommissioning once and for all. It has dogged the process throughout, and it has sapped confidence in the institutions. Real progress has been made, but not sufficient for me to withold suspension at this stage."

Direct rule was last imposed in May 1974, following the collapse of the five-month Sunningdale executive. It was finally collapsed by the loyalist workers' strike, spearheaded by paramilitaries.

Mr Mandelson said ex-US senator George Mitchell, who chaired the talks leading the the agreement and last autumn's 11-week review, would not be returning.

webTitle: Should the legal age for drivers be raised to 18?

fields.headline: Should the legal age for drivers be raised to 18?
fields.trailText:
Dear Robert,
There has been speculation that the forthcoming road safety review to be published by Lord Whitty will contain proposals to prohibit learner drivers from taking their driving test until they are 18. Stopping 17-year-olds from driving will certainly have an impact on casualty figures in the first year as there will be some 300,000 fewer new drivers on the road. However, in year two, there will be a roll-over effect as these slightly older new drivers qualify.
fields.body:
Dear Robert,
There has been speculation that the forthcoming road safety review to be published by Lord Whitty will contain proposals to prohibit learner drivers from taking their driving test until they are 18. Stopping 17-year-olds from driving will certainly have an impact on casualty figures in the first year as there will be some 300,000 fewer new drivers on the road. However, in year two, there will be a roll-over effect as these slightly older new drivers qualify.

Perhaps, Rob, you would like to see the driving age raised to 50 to reduce collisions? Perhaps we should go all the way and introduce blanket 20mph limits on every road in the country and satellite in-car speed limiters? Perhaps we should reintroduce the man with the red flag walking in front of every car?

Of course we all want to improve road safety but that does not mean we have to discriminate against 17-year-olds who can go to war but can't even vote. It is not new drivers aged between 17 and 24 who are disproportionately represented in the accident figures.

We must address the problems of new drivers. This proposal discriminates against young women, who have a far better safety record than young men. Drop your opposition on grounds of age and let's work to improve safety for all.

Yours,
Edmund,
Executive director,
RAC Foundation

Dear Edmund,
Perhaps my first response should be that you should never believe everything you read in the papers.

We do need to put road safety into context. Although our roads are supposed to be the safest in Europe, we continue to tolerate 3,420 deaths and 321,000 injuries every year - at a cost to society of around £10bn. A disproportionate number of these are young people, who hold 10% of driving licences yet are involved in 20% of crashes. And every week, we read of the Friday-night car crash involving four or five teenagers.

Something has to be done to help this group be better prepared for driving. In theory, you can apply for your driving licence and receive it on your 17th birthday. You can take the theory test on that day and pay for the "same day results" service. If you pass, you can ring the Driving Standards Agency and book a practical test for the next day anywhere in the country.

On the day after your birthday, you could be holding a full driving licence - but nobody would call you trained or competent. As part of a package of measures, a minimum period of learning is worth considering. It's the rest of the package that we also ought to scrutinise.

Yours,
Robert,
Executive director,
Parliamentary advisory council for transport safety

Dear Robert,
Let's get back to the point. Should the legal driving age be raised? My reply is still no. Of course we need better training and we need to save more young lives but simply raising the age limit could backfire.

The safest young drivers are those with some formal training and long periods of practice, normally with a relative. If you raise the driving age to 18 many teenagers will have left home and will miss out on parental supervision. They will be driving their own cars and will be more prone to peer pressure during those first few months of driving. Seventeen-year-olds are also less likely to drink and drive, as they can't legally buy drinks.

We must help prepare all new drivers. Hazard perception and safety awareness should be included in the school curriculum. Excellent clubs like the "under-17s" pre-driver training in Malmesbury should be encouraged.

There is no evidence to suggest that new drivers need a year between obtaining a provisional licence and taking their test. Many would just take lessons prior to the test. Evidence from abroad doesn't suggest that 18-year-olds are safer than 17-year-olds. Let's educate, not discriminate.

Yours,
Edmund

Dear Edmund,
I think I spy a flaw in your argument. No one is suggesting young people should not start learning at 17. The question is at what age they can pass the test. We have already seen a similar approach taken with motorcycling. You have to pass a compulsory basic training test before going out on the road. The numbers of young motorcyclists killed and injured has fallen dramatically as a result. The real problem now is the 40-plus "born again" biker, who buys a BMW and gets killed through ignorance.

Where I suspect we agree is that age and experience are key factors in learning driving skills. We can help with experience by providing a wide range of environments in which young people try out driving, and by getting them to learn about hazard perception.

There's probably not a lot we can do about the ageing process, except by restricting the circumstances in which people can do unlimited harm. If I may say so, your final sentence is a perfect soundbite, but I don't know that it means anything. The two are surely not incompatible. Can we not find a third way here that emphasises the importance of education but points to the need to restrict in the interest both of society and the individual?

Yours,
Robert

Dear Robert,
A driving instructor has called and confirmed my argument. He says young drivers learn much more from intensive courses than from taking one lesson per week for 12 months (prohibitively expensive, but it may be in the government proposals). For the theory test, he instructs two hours per day for six days and then two hours per day for 10 days for the test.

He also agrees that the combination of intensive professional tuition and practise under parental supervision produces the safest young drivers. Most learners would just wait until they are 18 to take lessons. We should not tar all 17-year-olds with the same brush. If a new driver receives six points on their licence within two years of passing the test, they have to retake the test. We should advertise this fact to the hard-core of dangerous new drivers.

Young people are more likely than any other age group to take calculated risks and to commit deliberate violations such as speeding, undertaking and jumping red lights. While some traffic violations are caused by error of judgment or lapses of concentration, there is a hard core who show a deliberate willingness to flout the rules and take risks which could endanger all on the road. Deliberate risk-takers are more likely to crash than those who sometimes make accidental errors.

Extra driving tuition will not calm the violator, but the threat of losing their wheels and changing behaviour and beliefs before they are 17 will save lives.

Ninety per cent of teenagers want to take the test at 17. Someone needs to stick up for them as they don't have the vote (yet). I'm willing to do it. Let's educate rather than discriminate . I want safer driving for all, rather than getting lost on some third way.

Yours,
Edmund
PS Is this really just a ploy to reduce congestion ?

Dear Edmund,
Talking of ploys, you don't expect me to believe that a driving instructor just called you, do you? If you're reluctant to make policy on the basis of prejudice about age, I'm also reluctant to make it on the views of a single driving instructor about effective training.

We're talking about a national road safety strategy and initiatives within it. We also need to raise the standards of driving instructors. This is at best a "cottage industry". The typical driving instructor is a middle-aged male who has neither the time nor the money to undertake professional development to improve the profession. Of course they want intensive instruction: that ensures their livelihood.

We need to look at the skills and experiences teenagers need to become successful (and crash-free) drivers. If we view the driving test as an educational examination with a mixture of practical and theoretical elements and a mixture of assessment arrangements, we begin to get nearer the level of knowledge required.

The test should be more like an A level; usually taken at 18 rather than at 17. Raising the legal age is not an insurmountable problem. I don't think this is a matter of sticking up for 17-year-olds or any other age group. It's really a matter of life and death for some of them. Let's work together to find a real way of improving their life chances.

Yours,
Robert

Join the debate

This proposal discriminates against young women, who have a far better safety record than young men. Drop your opposition on grounds of age and let's work to improve safety for all. Yours, Edmund, Executive director, RAC Foundation Dear Edmund, Perhaps my first response should be that you should never believe everything you read in the papers. We do need to put road safety into context. Although our roads are supposed to be the safest in Europe, we continue to tolerate 3,420 deaths and 321,000 injuries every year - at a cost to society of around £10bn. A disproportionate number of these are young people, who hold 10% of driving licences yet are involved in 20% of crashes. And every week, we read of the Friday-night car crash involving four or five teenagers. Something has to be done to help this group be better prepared for driving. In theory, you can apply for your driving licence and receive it on your 17th birthday. You can take the theory test on that day and pay for the "same day results" service. If you pass, you can ring the Driving Standards Agency and book a practical test for the next day anywhere in the country. On the day after your birthday, you could be holding a full driving licence - but nobody would call you trained or competent. As part of a package of measures, a minimum period of learning is worth considering. It's the rest of the package that we also ought to scrutinise. Yours, Robert, Executive director, Parliamentary advisory council for transport safety Dear Robert, Let's get back to the point. Should the legal driving age be raised? My reply is still no. Of course we need better training and we need to save more young lives but simply raising the age limit could backfire. The safest young drivers are those with some formal training and long periods of practice, normally with a relative. If you raise the driving age to 18 many teenagers will have left home and will miss out on parental supervision. They will be driving their own cars and will be more prone to peer pressure during those first few months of driving. Seventeen-year-olds are also less likely to drink and drive, as they can't legally buy drinks. We must help prepare all new drivers. Hazard perception and safety awareness should be included in the school curriculum. Excellent clubs like the "under-17s" pre-driver training in Malmesbury should be encouraged. There is no evidence to suggest that new drivers need a year between obtaining a provisional licence and taking their test. Many would just take lessons prior to the test. Evidence from abroad doesn't suggest that 18-year-olds are safer than 17-year-olds. Let's educate, not discriminate. Yours, Edmund Dear Edmund, I think I spy a flaw in your argument. No one is suggesting young people should not start learning at 17. The question is at what age they can pass the test. We have already seen a similar approach taken with motorcycling. You have to pass a compulsory basic training test before going out on the road. The numbers of young motorcyclists killed and injured has fallen dramatically as a result. The real problem now is the 40-plus "born again" biker, who buys a BMW and gets killed through ignorance. Where I suspect we agree is that age and experience are key factors in learning driving skills. We can help with experience by providing a wide range of environments in which young people try out driving, and by getting them to learn about hazard perception. There's probably not a lot we can do about the ageing process, except by restricting the circumstances in which people can do unlimited harm. If I may say so, your final sentence is a perfect soundbite, but I don't know that it means anything. The two are surely not incompatible. Can we not find a third way here that emphasises the importance of education but points to the need to restrict in the interest both of society and the individual? Yours, Robert Dear Robert, A driving instructor has called and confirmed my argument. He says young drivers learn much more from intensive courses than from taking one lesson per week for 12 months (prohibitively expensive, but it may be in the government proposals). For the theory test, he instructs two hours per day for six days and then two hours per day for 10 days for the test. He also agrees that the combination of intensive professional tuition and practise under parental supervision produces the safest young drivers. Most learners would just wait until they are 18 to take lessons. We should not tar all 17-year-olds with the same brush. If a new driver receives six points on their licence within two years of passing the test, they have to retake the test. We should advertise this fact to the hard-core of dangerous new drivers. Young people are more likely than any other age group to take calculated risks and to commit deliberate violations such as speeding, undertaking and jumping red lights. While some traffic violations are caused by error of judgment or lapses of concentration, there is a hard core who show a deliberate willingness to flout the rules and take risks which could endanger all on the road. Deliberate risk-takers are more likely to crash than those who sometimes make accidental errors. Extra driving tuition will not calm the violator, but the threat of losing their wheels and changing behaviour and beliefs before they are 17 will save lives. Ninety per cent of teenagers want to take the test at 17. Someone needs to stick up for them as they don't have the vote (yet). I'm willing to do it. Let's educate rather than discriminate . I want safer driving for all, rather than getting lost on some third way. Yours, Edmund PS Is this really just a ploy to reduce congestion ? Dear Edmund, Talking of ploys, you don't expect me to believe that a driving instructor just called you, do you? If you're reluctant to make policy on the basis of prejudice about age, I'm also reluctant to make it on the views of a single driving instructor about effective training. We're talking about a national road safety strategy and initiatives within it. We also need to raise the standards of driving instructors. This is at best a "cottage industry". The typical driving instructor is a middle-aged male who has neither the time nor the money to undertake professional development to improve the profession. Of course they want intensive instruction: that ensures their livelihood. We need to look at the skills and experiences teenagers need to become successful (and crash-free) drivers. If we view the driving test as an educational examination with a mixture of practical and theoretical elements and a mixture of assessment arrangements, we begin to get nearer the level of knowledge required. The test should be more like an A level; usually taken at 18 rather than at 17. Raising the legal age is not an insurmountable problem. I don't think this is a matter of sticking up for 17-year-olds or any other age group. It's really a matter of life and death for some of them. Let's work together to find a real way of improving their life chances. Yours, Robert Join the debate

webTitle: Introduction: Should the legal age for drivers be raised to 18?

fields.headline: Introduction: Should the legal age for drivers be raised to 18?
fields.trailText: The UK may be second in the overall European road safety league, but when it comes to child deaths on our roads, we are second from the bottom. Lord Whitty's road safety review, published later this month, aims to cut road deaths and injuries down by almost 50%. Learners may have to wait until they're 18 to get their driving licences - like most of their European counterparts. They may also have to train for a year before they qualify. Are teenagers the main culprits? Should they be penalised and the legal driving age be raised? Edmund King and Robert Gifford, respective executive directors of the RAC Foundation and Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety, debate the question in this week's Saturday Review debate. Read it and tell us what you think.

fields.headline: Love and relationships
fields.trailText: Valentine's Day - or, more likely, the day after Valentine's Day - may see a surge in guides to love and relationships. But it's a buoyant market all through the year, with John Gray's Men Are from Mars, Women Are from Venus top of the shop almost since its publication in 1993. Gray has another book in the list, Mars and Venus in the Bedroom, dealing exclusively with sex, as does (in more hydraulic fashion) the Goofy Foot Press's amusing Guide to Getting It On.
fields.body:
Valentine's Day - or, more likely, the day after Valentine's Day - may see a surge in guides to love and relationships. But it's a buoyant market all through the year, with John Gray's Men Are from Mars, Women Are from Venus top of the shop almost since its publication in 1993. Gray has another book in the list, Mars and Venus in the Bedroom, dealing exclusively with sex, as does (in more hydraulic fashion) the Goofy Foot Press's amusing Guide to Getting It On.

But as many of these books are keen to tell you, sex problems are just a symptom of some deeper emotional malaise . . . Perhaps the stars can help, through consultation of Linda Goodman's Love Signs, or maybe the earthbound orders of The Rules, an old-fashioned US guide to dating, could prove more useful. Those in real trouble might have recourse to Isabel Allende's Aphrodite, a collection of sexy recipes, sensuous stories, aphrodisiacs and lovers' spells.

fields.headline: Hard Drives
fields.standfirst: Ros Taylor attempts to navigate the net's car hire sites
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor attempts to navigate the net's car hire sites
fields.body:
Some big car hire companies have some way to go before their online reservation services become a truly attractive option. Navigating one or two of these sites was reminiscent of driving a clapped-out Fiat Punto into the the scrum surrounding the Arc de Triomphe - but a lot less fun.

Europcar
Europcar is particularly bad. You can book cars for hire in Britain, but you can only rent abroad by visiting the international site. My laborious attempt to hire a "compact" car - no other details were available - between Angers and Aix-en-Provence ended in failure. Europcar was unable to process my request, and told me to try again later. This kind of response quite rightly deters many people from buying on the web. Companies would never get away with it elsewhere.

Hertz
Hertz's site is somewhat old-fashioned but functions efficiently. It also provides plenty of detail about the available cars, which is useful if you don't know what a Canadian station wagon looks like. The company also offers a Eurotunnel special called Le Swap (found in the Special Services section), which allows you to hire a car in Britain, take Le Shuttle to Calais and swap the vehicle for a left-hand-drive model to drive on the Continent.

Avis
It may be worth checking Avis, too, especially for US rentals. But why is the substantial 20% discount for online bookings only available to US residents?

Curacao
Similarly, Curacao has some special deals only for North American customers.

Holiday Autos
A much better option is Holiday Autos, which offers a clean, well-designed site and an uncomplicated booking process. Online booking attracts a £15 per week discount on US rentals until November; Italy and Austria are £10 cheaper until March and November respectively. It has also just expanded its range of luxury cars. Perhaps paying £283 for the pleasure of driving a Porsche Boxster around London for a day is a tad excessive, but you could take advantage of Germany's fast autobahns with a Mercedes E class for £469 a week.

Expedia
Holiday Autos is the "preferred partner" of Expedia, although this doesn't mean that you can't book with other companies via the site. In fact, Expedia's car wizard is currently the best price comparison service available on the web.

.

webTitle: Will it give Egg a run and wipe the Smile?

fields.headline: Will it give Egg a run and wipe the Smile?
fields.standfirst:
Rupert Jones previews this week's unveiling of Abbey National's online bank, code-named Aquarius, opening in the spring
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: We've got an Egg and a Smile, and this Thursday could well see the arrival of yet another internet bank with a funny name. That's when Abbey National will unveil more details about its new separately-branded, stand-alone internet bank, due to open for business in May or June.
fields.body:
We've got an Egg and a Smile, and this Thursday could well see the arrival of yet another internet bank with a funny name. That's when Abbey National will unveil more details about its new separately-branded, stand-alone internet bank, due to open for business in May or June.

Its name is a closely guarded secret but the project currently has the working title of "Aquarius" so perhaps we can expect something with a new age flavour.

Abbey National clearly doesn't believe in doing things by halves - as well as pouring money into this separate venture, it is also launching its own internet banking service, which is due to be up and running by the end of April and will operate alongside its branch network and phone banking service.

All this emphasis on feverishly developing net-related services might seem over the top, but the traditional high street banks are terrified about seeing all the money they are looking after disappear into the cyber-coffers of internet upstarts.

All the evidence suggests that thousands of people are switching on to internet banking every day. Barclays has predicted that approaching 10m Britons will be signing up for net banking by the end of this year, and by and large, these are just the sort of people the banks are desperate to woo. One recent survey found that the average household income for those net users who regularly check out personal finance websites is £30,000, compared with just over £26,000 for internet users as a whole.

The latest company to join the online charge is Virgin Direct, which today launches what it claims is one of the most advanced internet banking services yet developed. It will offer many of the usual online facilities such as bill paying and standing or der and direct debit amendments, but, unlike some other services, customers will not have to apply or register to use it or install new software. It is available from Wednesday to all 25,000 people who have the company's Virgin One all-in-one mortgage and current account.

What makes the service unique, says a spokesman, is that customers will also be able to access information about other Virgin Direct products they hold including savings, Peps, Isas and pensions. All Virgin One customers are being sent a credit card carrying a 13-digit number which they will need to access the service.

Meanwhile, NatWest this week revealed that more than 100,000 people have al ready signed up for its internet banking service, even though it only launched at the end of November. Around 1,700 people a day have been joining and the bank says it is on its way to hitting its target of 1m users this year.

At the moment, NatWest's service is fairly plain and simple - you can transfer money, pay bills, check your balance, view recent transactions, and so on. However, it claims it will be the first UK bank to offer instant, low-cost term assurance cover on the net when this is added to its website (www.natwest.com) later this month. Over the next few months NatWest plans to add savings, investments, mortgages, credit cards, loans and other products to its online portfolio.

The level of internet service on offer, and the different functions available, can vary dramatically from bank to bank. Remarkably, HSBC (formerly Midland Bank) still doesn't offer internet banking at all - it says its service will be launched in the second half of this year.

The Halifax's service, which went live in October, is one of the more basic - while you can pay bills and make fund transfers to other Halifax accounts, in both cases these have to be set up offline first. However, the former building society has been concentrating on the launch this coming summer of its own separately-branded, stand-alone internet bank, currently called "Greenfield.co".

Among the most sophisticated of the online services are those offered by Royal Bank of Scotland and Barclays. RBS's allows customers to set up and make person-to-person payments to other UK bank or building society accounts, set up bill payments and standing orders, and diarise payments and money transfers up to 120 days in advance. The Barclays internet banking service - Britain's most popular with around 500,000 users - also allows people to transfer money to any UK bank or building society account and control regular payments, which includes setting up, amending and cancelling standing orders, and paying bills now or at a later date.

Of the internet banking new entrants, the best-known include Smile (www.smile.co.uk) and First-e (www.first-e.com). Smile, set up by the Co-operative Bank in October, has as its flagship product a current account which pays 4.59% gross on credit balances.

First-e, a subsidiary of French bank Banque d'Escompte, currently offers only an online savings account, but later this year will launch a current account offering free banking, a "high" rate of interest, a cheque book, debit card and an instant secured overdraft facility.

fields.headline: Waiting game goes on
fields.standfirst: It's nailbiting time for homeowners who may be told to top up their policies. Patrick Collinson reports
fields.trailText: Are you one of the mortgage endowment shortfall victims? Mailings to 10m homeowners with endowments went out in January, but few people are any wiser about whether they will have to dig into their pockets to top up failing policies.
fields.body:
Are you one of the mortgage endowment shortfall victims? Mailings to 10m homeowners with endowments went out in January, but few people are any wiser about whether they will have to dig into their pockets to top up failing policies.

The good news is that one of the major providers, Legal & General with 700,000 with-profits endowments, is now promising to send policyholders a follow-up letter by the end of March. It will give a detailed re-projection of the endowment, identifying whether it is on target to repay the mortgage and if you need to take action.

The bad news is that the Financial Services Authority estimates that as many as 3m of the 10m policies may be in shortfall, with typical premium hikes likely to be around £50 per month. The scale of the shortfalls was first revealed by the Guardian in October last year and they have arisen because life offices must now project future returns at no more than 6% a year, compared with the 8-12% expectations common when the policies were sold in the late 80s and early 90s.

L&G's re-projection programme is significantly ahead of other life offices, most of which are sticking to FSA guidelines which say that re-projections must start going out by April.

Scottish Amicable, with 850,000 policies, will be sending out its re-projection letters from April, but will not complete the exercise until the end of the year. "It's no mean task to work out the figures out on so many policies," says a spokesman. The first policyholders to get reprojection letters will be people with plans closest to maturity.

Standard Life, the biggest endowment provider with 1.2m policies, declined to give details about when policyholders will receive their re-projections. "We can't be any more specific than the end of the year," said a spokeswoman. She admitted that the life office has received "thousands" of calls from concerned policyholders since the first warning letter was issued in January. Standard Life will also undertake individual re-projections on request from policyholders. The telephone number is 0845-6060076.

All life offices are obliged to send re-projections on request, but are desperate to avoid a flood of requests jamming up their systems. Many are warning that even if you ring now, a re-projection may not be sent for several weeks.

The 750,000 with-profits endowment holders with policies from CGU will not be receiving re-projection letters. It has won an exemption from the FSA because it is promising to make up any shortfalls. It says that no matter what original projection rate used, it will plug the gap as long as investment returns do not drop below an average of 6% a year.

Liverpool Victoria, a relatively small player in the market with just 7,500 policies, has gone a step further. This week it promised that it will pick up the bill for any shortfall, no matter what levels investment returns may fall to.

So what should you do if you receive a re-projection letter which identifies a shortfall on your policy? Do not automatically top up with your existing life office - in some cases it may be simply throwing good money after bad.

What's more, you could be hit with a new round of commissions and charges. Setting up a share Isa is one option, although you are not actually obliged to do anything.

This week a Bath broker, Chartwell Direct, offered another option. It will set up a top-up endowment plan for a flat fee of £35 and rebate all initial and renewal commission to the policyholder. Tel: 01225-446556.

She admitted that the life office has received "thousands" of calls from concerned policyholders since the first warning letter was issued in January. Standard Life will also undertake individual re-projections on request from policyholders. The telephone number is 0845-6060076. All life offices are obliged to send re-projections on request, but are desperate to avoid a flood of requests jamming up their systems. Many are warning that even if you ring now, a re-projection may not be sent for several weeks. The 750,000 with-profits endowment holders with policies from CGU will not be receiving re-projection letters. It has won an exemption from the FSA because it is promising to make up any shortfalls. It says that no matter what original projection rate used, it will plug the gap as long as investment returns do not drop below an average of 6% a year. Liverpool Victoria, a relatively small player in the market with just 7,500 policies, has gone a step further. This week it promised that it will pick up the bill for any shortfall, no matter what levels investment returns may fall to. So what should you do if you receive a re-projection letter which identifies a shortfall on your policy? Do not automatically top up with your existing life office - in some cases it may be simply throwing good money after bad. What's more, you could be hit with a new round of commissions and charges. Setting up a share Isa is one option, although you are not actually obliged to do anything. This week a Bath broker, Chartwell Direct, offered another option. It will set up a top-up endowment plan for a flat fee of £35 and rebate all initial and renewal commission to the policyholder. Tel: 01225-446556.

fields.headline: British designers storm NY catwalk
fields.standfirst: Related special report: London Fashion Week
fields.trailText: Three very different British designers took New York by storm on the penultimate day of its fashion week.
fields.body:
Three very different British designers took New York by storm on the penultimate day of its fashion week.

In his collection for the cashmere company Tse, Hussein Chalayan displayed thick cable-knit sweater dresses in cream, and cashmere-mole skin mix coats with fastenings which interlocked.

He traced map-like outlines on jumpers and skirts, which melded well with "aerial view" jackets and coats featuring green and brown panels, like fields seen from the air.

Vivienne Westwood opened her show with a jumble of clothes spotlit on the catwalk, and the first outfits, especially the bunchy skirts of chintzy curtain fabric, looked as if they belonged on the heap.

Then, however, came asymetric-collared peplum jackets and drop-waisted pleated skirts for a svelte shape. There was sauciness, of course - tiny belt-skirts and towering dominatrix heels - but plenty of desirable, and wearable, clothes.

Wearable, desirable clothes are Nicole Farhi's trademark. This collection, however, was raunchy by her standards: black rubber pencil skirts, suede with silver studs, backless tops with hipster trousers, and shaggy velvet coats.

There was plenty of classic Farhi in the soft colour combinations of claret and blue, or petrol blue worn with black and camel.

webTitle: Teenage culture harming pupils, says Woodhead

fields.headline: Teenage culture harming pupils, says Woodhead
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Chris Woodhead, the chief inspector of schools, yesterday sparked a fresh row about the teaching of morality by blaming the corruption of teenagers on the the pop and fashion industries.
fields.body:
Chris Woodhead, the chief inspector of schools, yesterday sparked a fresh row about the teaching of morality by blaming the corruption of teenagers on the the pop and fashion industries.

Youngsters were more likely to learn bad behaviour beyond the school gates, the head of the Office for Standards in Education (Ofsted) wrote. But the best schools were those which took a pro-active approach to fighting external influences.

Teachers' leaders questioned the wisdom of Mr Woodhead commenting on moral issues, given the controversy which blew up last year over his nine-year relationship with a former pupil. His intervention also came just days after he waded into the debate on section 28 of the local government act, which bans "promotion" of homosexuality, appearing to undermine the government's determination to repeal the legislation.

In an article in yesterday's Church Times, Mr Woodhead stressed the need for schools to have clearly stated values. "The negative values and behaviour sometimes observed in teenagers are more likely to have been learned outside school than within, and the best schools struggle to outdo the influence of peer pressures and the teenage culture created by the pop and fashion industries," he wrote. "But struggle they must. While the teaching of moral standards in schools is not an end in itself, it is a necessary prerequisite for a stable and harmonious community where all can work and achieve to their highest potential".

Last year Mr Woodhead came under pressure to resign after claims that he had lied about the timing of the beginning of his relationship with Amanda Johnston, who was his pupil when he was head of English at Gordano school near Bristol between 1974 and 1976. Mr Woodhead left his wife, Cathy, for Miss Johnston. Earlier, the chief inspector had triggered a row by claiming that affairs between pupils could be "educative", just as the government was preparing legislation criminalising such relationships.

Yesterday Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of School Masters Union of Women Teachers, commented: "It would be best if Mr Woodhead refrained from making public comments about morality and the corruption of teenagers, given his own chequered personal history. At the time, he should have either sued or resigned."

David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, which unsuccessfully sought a criminal investigation into whether Mr Woodhead had lied about his private life, said: "It is dangerous for him to get involved in what are clearly deep political waters."

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, added: "I think it is extremely unwise for the chief inspector to tread in this area. In a society which is increasingly unsure about its values, schools are beacons of clarity in guiding the lives of young people. Ofsted's inspectors repeatedly praise schools for the work they do in this area. Schools do not need to be lectured on this subject, particularly by the chief inspector."

webTitle: How you can learn while you teach

fields.headline: How you can learn while you teach
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Teaching English as a Foreign Language, or Tefl (also known as English language teaching, or ELT), has always been a good bet for graduates who happen to have English as their mother tongue and want to travel, learn another language and put off doing a “proper” job for a couple of years.
fields.body:
It’s easy to spot an ex-Tefl teacher. They will either be the person who is the first up for charades or the one in meetings who always insists that the group splits up into pairs. Oh, and then you get the person who, while the rest of the pub is mouthing the words to an early 90s hit - let’s say, something by Massive Attack - will stare blankly into the distance: a lot of that stuff didn’t make it to Kyoto, which is where she was teaching English at the time.

Teaching English as a Foreign Language, or Tefl (also known as English language teaching, or ELT), has always been a good bet for graduates who happen to have English as their mother tongue and want to travel, learn another language and put off doing a “proper” job for a couple of years. Yet, on their return to Blighty, is the line about “two years’ teaching in Malaga” on their CV actually interpreted by potential employers as: “dossing on a beach while drinking San Miguel and smoking Ducados”?

And if you do find your heart is in teaching English, is it ever possible to make a go of it, settle down and earn decent money, or will you be condemned to living the life of the eternal rootless student? “If you’re prepared to go from Sri Lanka to Spain, you can make a go of it. If you come back and go to Brighton and teach for £8.50 per hour, you’d be better off making cappuccinos,” says Melanie Butler, managing editor of the trade paper EL Gazette. “It’s an industry which 70% of people should leave after a year: they’ve got what they can out of it.”

“There’s no obvious career ladder,” says Chris Graham, director of recruitment agency Saxoncourt English Worldwide. “The drop-out rate is pretty high because the money’s not good. People usually come back to get a ‘proper’ job, and by that I mean proper money.”

Saxoncourt recruits about 600 teachers a year and Mr Graham says you can expect to earn between £500-£600 a month in a language school in Poland. In Italy, the salary would be similar, but the cost of living far higher. According to Mr Graham, people who have taught English abroad are often bad at selling their skills on their return to the UK.

Yet some teachers are good at selling their skills - and are simply good at selling. Monika Lavery taught in a small school in Vic, Cataluna, at the foothills of the Pyrenees, having done the Certificate in English Language Teaching to Adults (Celta) course at International House in Barcelona. She not only learned Catalan in addition to Spanish while living on a farm, but also became interested in the food.

“At Christmas they would be killing pigs and making sausages: as I was the tallest person around I was always asked to hang the sausages from the poles in the cellar,” remembers Ms Lavery. “All the food was local. It was very inspiring. It was the old-style community which we’ve lost so much of here, although it’s coming back.”

On her return to the UK Ms Lavery knew that she wanted to keep up her Spanish and her contact with Spain. “I didn’t feel that there was a fascinating future for me as a Tefl teacher and I didn’t seem to be able to get another job in Spain that wasn’t teaching.” Starting with Spanish cheese, Ms Lavery went through the embarrassing procedure of cold-calling people like the cheese buyer at Fortnums at a time when there was hardly any Spanish cheese being sold in the UK.

While living with her parents and teaching English part-time to keep the wolf from the door, she came across a particular sheep’s cheese, at a trade fair, which was stored in olive oil and sold in a tin.

“It was the most unbelievable cheese,” she recalls, and it prompted her to go back to Spain to meet Ambrosio, the producer, “who put passion and soul into cheesemaking”.

The cheese in the tin got people like celebrity chef Alastair Little and food expert Simon Hopkinson listening to her. She founded Brindisa (from the Spanish word “Brindis”, which means “celebratory toast”) in 1988 and today it is the foremost importer of quality Spanish food and ingredients in the UK.

Now, with 14 staff and based at the Borough Market in London, Ms Lavery still goes to Spain up to six times a year and has fulfilled her post-teaching dream. “I was driven to do something that would link me with Spain forever. I didn’t really think clearly about what I was doing. It was a huge challenge but I think my sales skills came from teaching.

“It’s a combination of an interest in language; of communication in general. You’re always guiding students down a path to learn something or believe something. You also get used to looking people in the eye quite happily: you learn that from standing in front of a class. As for eliciting information - it applies in many other situations.”

At the head office of Scope, the UK’s leading disability charity, press & PR Officer Marcella McEvoy has also found that her experience teaching English in Prague helps her in all areas of her work. “It taught me tenacity,” she explains. “As a Tefl teacher, there are many moments of humiliation. You learn to develop a very thick skin.”

Ms McEvoy believes that determination to make the lessons a success meant that she developed creative skills which she now exercises when devising campaigns for Scope such as Mother, Bump and Baby Month.

Having to constantly dream up entertaining lessons is something that any ex-Tefl teacher will remember with either affection or horror. With most English language teaching done in private language schools, if your classrooms start to empty, you can only take it personally. The ability to wing it helps, and many people have the knack of being able to turn up to a lesson with nothing but a handful of Cuisenaire rods - variously coloured wooden sticks used as a teaching aid - in their pocket and a few jokes, games or songs up their sleeves as preparation.

Stoical, inventive and daring, they can pull off a perfor mance which would make the likes of Eddie Izzard or Marcel Marceau green with envy. But some people have less than pleasant memories: “I find myself becoming nostalgic about tapas but then I remember the pressure,” says Jill Valentine, who taught in Huelva, Andalucia, for a year.

“It was the constant stress; standing up in front of the class and worrying about it all falling apart.” Ms Valentine is now development manager at the University for Industry in Sheffield, where she is nevertheless still involved in education: she’s responsible for national learning centres.

Marcella McEvoy believes that some Tefl techniques always stay with you. “If I run a workshop I find myself grabbing those pens and drawing pictures on the white board,” she says. “And I’m always chopping up lots of bits of paper and making people walk around the room and do silly things.”

At International House in London, Roger Hunt is director of teacher training and has been draw ing on white boards and chopping up bits of paper for quite a while. Proving that you can make a career out of ELT, and a successful one at that, Mr Hunt originally went to an affiliated International House school in Alexandria for three months in 1980 and ended up staying for four years. He’s worked in Madrid and Budapest, has written books and travels widely.

“Language has always been divided up into little bits. It’s a bit like trying to drive a car by learning how to use the accelerator first. In your first driving lesson you’ve got to do everything, even if you don’t do it very well. You’ve got to be immersed in language in an holistic way.”

International House was founded in 1953 and now has 120 affili ated schools in more than 30 countries. “I think some people think it’s a young person’s job,” Mr Hunt says. “But now we get a lot of people applying for our courses who are middle-aged and successful and decided they want to see the world and teach English.”

And it’s something you can always go back to. International House offers a Tefl Update course at £250 for two weeks, should you feel like giving it another go.

The experience of living away from your familiar surroundings and being forced to develop both inner resources and outer communication skills can stay with you for ever.

For those who attempt to integrate and learn a language fluently, their prospects back in Blighty will increase - provided that they can think laterally enough to convey the benefits of their experience in a convincing way.

And if you do get the bug, you can get ahead in ELT. But does it mean that you will always have itchy feet? Mr Hunt has been in London for four years now. “I’m off to Barcelona next month to visit our school there,” he says with a smile. Maybe I’ll just stay.”

The Bell School, 01223-246 644/ www.bell-schools.ac.uk International House, 0171-491 2598/ www. international-house-london.ac.uk; Cambridge EFL exams, 01223-553-355/ www.cambridge-efl.org.uk Saxoncourt, 0171-491-1911/ www.saxon.court.comEL Gazette/ EL Prospects, 0171-255-1969/www.elgazette.com VSO, 020-8780-7500 www.vso.org.uk Brindisa, 0171-403-0282; Scope, 0171- 619-7100.

On course for a new direction

7,000 people do the Celta course each year but 20%-30% of people do the course then decide not to teach.

30%-50% of the people doing Celta at the Bell School are going into ELT as a career change.

Greece has the biggest ELT market in the world while Poland is the fastest growing.

Industry experts predict that the demand for English Language Teaching in China could be “insatiable”.

At International House, if you are over 30, resident in the UK and receiving no other form of funding, you are eligible for a discount of 23% on the tuition fees for the Celta course.

51 UK institutions offer EL-related MAs.

Jobs in ELT are advertised in EL Prospects, the Times Educational Supplement and the Guardian on Tuesdays.

VSO offers yearly renewable ELT contracts in Laos, Cambodia, Kenya, Zambia, Vietnam and Mongolia.

webTitle: Queuing up for the wheel of fortune

fields.headline: Queuing up for the wheel of fortune
fields.standfirst: Is London still seen as the main attraction?
fields.trailText: Alison Ebbage asks whether London still holds the same attraction for graduates as it has in the past.
fields.body:
Wading through the classified job advertisements, you could be forgiven for thinking that jobs outside of London simply don't exist. Combine this with stories of houses selling for 2p in the north and the recent ONS report which forecast an 9.14% increase in the population of London by 2002, and you'd be a brave man or woman if you weren't on that Virgin or GNER train within the hour to join them.

However, geography is becoming less relevant in the new world of work. The regions of the UK are experiencing revival as e-commerce and other IT-related start-ups emerge across the country. Throw in the growing resistance among graduates to the long-hours culture so typical of London, and you roll out a very different map of Britain- one that is not so London-centric.

In a recent survey by property consultant Healey & Baker, Cardiff emerged as the favourite city among British office workers, followed by Glasgow and Edinburgh - a result that may have been prompted by a surge in national pride created by devolution.

The celtic trio won the highest ratings on a range of 'feelgood' factors judged to make an ideal working city. The top English town or city was Reading, which came 4th followed by Leeds, Milton Keynes, Birmingham and Manchester.

In contrast, the City of London came way down in 9th position, while the West End was 10th.

Yet in many quarters, the word is still that the streets of London are paved with gold. Asula Ali, development executive at Reed Graduate Recruitment, says: "The perception is still that you will only get a proper graduate job with the salary to match in London.

"But the fact of the matter is that if you are focused and realistic, then your career opportunities won't be disadvantaged by being elsewhere in the UK."

London has always attracted more than its fair share of bright young things - not just for the abundance of career opportunities, but also because graduates see it as an exciting place to live.

Nick Jagger, research fellow at the Institute for Employment Studies, says: "London still has more professional jobs but there's also a lot of regional specialisation going on." For example Manchester has a booming law centre, Leeds and Edinburgh have always been strong financial centres, Cambridge and the M4 corridor are leading the charge in software and biotech and Brighton is emerging as a multi- media hub. Moreover, IT and engineering, two sectors facing a shortage of quality graduates, have always been well-represented in the "regions".

Changes in communications technology mean that companies in many sectors don't actually need to be in London any more, and while many of the large blue-chips still bring their graduates to the capital for structured training, the growing number of graduates taking jobs with small and medium sized enterprises can find themselves doing on-the-job training anywhere in the country.

Debra Allcock of the Industrial Society says: "The UK economy is now decidedly service-based, with a global not regional outlook, which means that unless you are working in a very specialised area you will pick up certain key skills which can be transferred between sectors and locations more easily." She also thinks graduates in London are disadvantaged because there are more people chasing a finite number of positions.

Clare Brown agrees. She graduated from Manchester University with a 2.1 in English and took her first job in London, after months of hunting, for £12,000. "It was hard" she says. "I was attending interviews for quite menial positions in marketing. The competition was so fierce that I had to lower my salary expectations."

So might you be better off as a big fish in a small pond rather than a tadpole in an ocean?

Lee Mulvaney thinks so. He's now in his second job as a senior analyst programmer in Manchester, following a couple of years with a firm in Liverpool, his university town.

"I could basically pick and choose as far as location is concerned," he says. "Perhaps that's because I'm in a field where there is a skills shortage but friends I know in other sectors feel the same way."

Lee says he would not consider a move to London. "I know I could probably make more money, but to be honest I don't think London has anything that Manchester doesn't - apart from a frenetic lifestyle which is just not my thing. Here my money goes further and I'm near my friends in Liverpool and my family in the north-east."

Indeed, the recent Association of Graduate Recruiters survey reported that more graduates are rejecting the long-hours culture so common in London in favour of a more balanced lifestyle. And you don't have to be too financially-literate to notice the house prices and high cost of living in the capital.

So is a London weighting to a graduate salary no more than fool's gold? In reality, just as sixth formers choose their university town because of the social life as much as the degree course, many graduates choose the location of their first job along the same lines.

Nick Jagger scoffs at suggestions of graduates turning their backs on the capital. "London still has the majority of professional jobs. Despite all the changes we have seen in employment, jobs are not infinitely relocatable."

Asula Ali disagrees. "Companies are moving out of London. We are handling vacancies all over the country and the opportunities are mainly located outside of London."

And Debra Allcock says: "If you're good then it doesn't matter. The right attitude will get you far."
fields.bodyText: Wading through the classified job advertisements, you could be forgiven for thinking that jobs outside of London simply don't exist. Combine this with stories of houses selling for 2p in the north and the recent ONS report which forecast an 9.14% increase in the population of London by 2002, and you'd be a brave man or woman if you weren't on that Virgin or GNER train within the hour to join them. The celtic trio won the highest ratings on a range of 'feelgood' factors judged to make an ideal working city. The top English town or city was Reading, which came 4th followed by Leeds, Milton Keynes, Birmingham and Manchester. fields.headline: Top rung/Bottom rung
fields.trailText: Top Rung
fields.body:
Top Rung

Sue Fletcher
 Aged 49
Deputy MD
Hodder & Stoughton

Like many English graduates, Sue Fletcher knew her career lay in books. "It could only be librarianship or publishing," she says.

On leaving Bristol University, Sue took a secretarial course and moved to London. She gained a variety of experience in publishing houses and with a literary agent before her breakthrough in 1976 as a senior editor with Sphere Books, where she later became managing editor.

She then joined Macdonald Futura as editorial director and went on to become one of the founders of Headline which merged with Hodder in 1993.

Purple passage? "I get a buzz from finding new authors and seeing them sell. It's a hugely exciting feeling getting in on the ground floor of a real talent."

Hodder stats: it publishes around 400 books a year in hardback and paperback - including prizewinners and best-sellers and everything from Alex Ferguson and Michael Hesletine autobiographies to cookery books.

Hot read? "I am involved with Amy Jenkins' first novel Honeymoon which indications show will be a best-seller."

Must-have qualities: graduates need pronounced and confident taste and the ability to communicate that to others.

Final tip? "Have energy, be organised and have a great appetite for fiction."

Bottom rung

Julie Crisp
Aged 24
Editorial assistant
Hodder & Stoughton

Julie Crisp's love of English meant that a publishing career after leaving university was always on the cards. "At school I was interested in languages and thought about working as a translator, " she says. "But publishing is an ideal career for me."

Plot so far: BA in English at the University of Glamorgan and joined Hodder & Stoughton four months ago.

"I got a series of temporary jobs in London while awaiting replies to publishing applications. I went for one job with Hodder and was actually offered another."

Current role: As an editorial assistant, she handles manuscripts from established authors and reads unsolicited material. "My exciting moment do far has been working on the Brian Herbert and Kevin J Anderson book House Atreides ."

Training includes editing copy courses, using author databases. Julie's editor monitors her progress and there is an annual appraisal. "It's a learn-as-you-go approach."

Next chapter? Julie would like to become a commissioning editor - a route taken by two of her predecessors.

Tip for would-be entrants: "Start early with your applications to publishers - but focus on the type of publishing you want to be in."

For more career details, email: annie.wiseman@hodder.co.uk

fields.headline: News
fields.trailText: • Midas touch: You don't have to be smart to be a millionaire, says author Thomas Stanley who has just surveyed 1,300 millionaires. The average millionaire scored only average grades in college. Most were told they weren't smart enough to succeed. Stanley cites as an example Steve Jobs, Apple Computer founder and messiah, who didn't even go to college.
fields.body:
 Midas touch: You don't have to be smart to be a millionaire, says author Thomas Stanley who has just surveyed 1,300 millionaires. The average millionaire scored only average grades in college. Most were told they weren't smart enough to succeed. Stanley cites as an example Steve Jobs, Apple Computer founder and messiah, who didn't even go to college.

 Book of the week: Managing to do your job is only half the battle. Your success depends just as much on how you manage your relationships at work. Steve Gravett offers advice gleaned from 25 years experience as a manager. Managing Your Boss & Colleagues (How To Books) can be ordered at the special price of £7.99 (plus p&p) from our Cultureshop on 0800 316 6102.

 Graduate of the week: Computers were as large as cars when Joaquin Sandoval began his doctoral thesis in chemistry 48 years ago. Now, seven children and nine grandchildren later, he has finished it. Yesterday the 75-year old went before a doctoral panel at the University of Murcia in south-east Spain to finally read his life's work on the subject of oils and fats.

 Bottling it up: You may grumble that your job will drive you to drink. But for some people it literally does -and it isn't just those with stressful jobs. Researchers at the University of Illinois who studied more than 7,000 people found that workers who are under-stretched at work are just as likely to turn to drink and drugs as those who are over-stretched.

 Lift off: The internet is set to come along for a ride in your office lift. Move over Muzak, lift news has arrived. Captivate Network's 10-inch diagonal screens silently display news, sports, stock market data, local weather and traffic and other miscellany, updated as often as every 20 minutes. If you actually enjoy the quiet 'down time' of a lift ride, it's time to take the stairs.

 What is Rise? Each week, we try to offer relevant news and advice to graduates and early career professionals seeking to map out their working lives. But are we scratching where you itch? You tell us. Mail your ideas and suggestions on how we can help you more to rise@theguardian.com.

fields.headline: Tip of the week
fields.standfirst: Have a flutter
fields.trailText: Have a flutter
fields.body:
Appearing soon at an office near you - "Sorry, I just don't have room in next year's budget to give you a rise." But there is a way you can squeeze a few extra pounds from your boss's purse says Jack Chapman, author of Negotiating Your Salary (Ten Speed Press).

"One way to make more money on the job is to gamble. I don't mean running a poker game in the cafeteria. I mean betting your boss that you will meet or exceed a target: construction deadlines, production deadlines, sales quotas, customer satisfaction survey results, cleanliness awards, employee productivity measures, accident-free days, newsletter excellence award recognition - just a few of the things bosses like, and will pay for."

fields.headline: Brief encounter
fields.trailText: Name: Gabrielle Ross
fields.body:
Name: Gabrielle Ross

Status: Founder and owner of Beau Bra label, which includes bespoke lingerie and glow-in-the-dark underwear.

Past:Read archaeology at Durham University. Hit on idea after friends joked they could whisk off a bra with one hand in just four seconds. After law school, landed job with City firm Simmons & Simmons, but couldn't resist the urge to make bras. The firm granted her a 12 month sabbatical.

Present:Beau Bra, which celebrates its first birthday in April, retails its fun and cheeky lingerie in Selfridges and Fenwicks, as well as in outlets in the Far East, Germany, France, Italy and the US.

Future:"I'm definitely going back to corporate law in September. By then I hope to have someone who will run the business for me."

Strengths:"The rag trade is a vicious business, so it has been invaluable knowing the law."

Weaknesses: "I take criticism of the designs very personally."

Wisdom: "Pursue your passion while you're young and free."
