fields.headline: Hotel with reservations
fields.standfirst: Derek Malcolm sees Wim Wenders's latest film open the Berlin festival
fields.trailText: Derek Malcolm sees Wim Wenders's latest film open the Berlin festival
fields.body:
The Million Dollar Hotel, built in LA in 1917 as The Frontier, fell into hard times long before U2's video, Where the Streets have no Name, was shot on its rooftop. Now this downtown fleapit becomes the location for Wim Wenders's 20th film - a "poetic and paradoxical love story wrapped in a murder mystery".

The surprise is that Bono co-wrote the original story and Mel Gibson stars in it. The film, which opened the 50th Berlin festival at its smart new headquarters in Potsdamer Platz, has Gibson as a stoic FBI agent with a strange neck brace that apparently hides the arm growing out of his back (which enables him "to play the violin and wipe my own arse at the same time").

He is detailed to visit the seedy hotel to find out what happened to a junkie named Izzy who fell to his death from the rooftop. Izzy, a painter trying to capture the lost souls of the ghetto, turns out to be the estranged son of a billionaire media magnate and the word goes round that he was probably pushed. The media arrive in droves and every misfit in the hotel is suspect, including Jeremy Davies's lovesick Tom Tom, who has fallen for Milla Jovovich's tarnished street angel, and the old musician who insists he wrote uncredited half the most famous songs of the Beatles.

"Love," says somebody at one point, "can never be portrayed the same way as a tree." And you could say that what is basically a mournful little film noir cannot really be portrayed as a metaphysical treatise on passion and loyalty without a certain amount of portentousness. When Julian Sands's art dealer, looking at Izzy's paintings, says there's a thin line between art and garbage you tend to agree. The Million Dollar Hotel looks good and has a paradoxical atmosphere that's half jokey and half serious. But there simply isn't enough narrative drive to sustain its two-hour length.

Every now and again a spark lights up the screen, as one or other of the derelicts brushes up against Gibson's seriously incapacitated but obstinately determined detective; and a romantic aura surrounds the whole piece. What one wonders, however, is how the public will take this dreamlike fantasy.

As a cross between his previous Hammett and The State of Things, Wenders fans will not find it entirely unfamiliar. But Gibson's may be more puzzled. His is a capable enough performance, but, in the least mainstream film he's made, he occasionally looks like a fish out of water. Maybe the whole film is just that - a cultish art film that could have been made in the 70s with nowhere much to go but the shelves where cinematic curiosities are picked over.

 The Million Dollar Hotel is scheduled for release here in April.

fields.headline: Death of Roger Vadim
fields.standfirst:
Director who will be remembered for launching career of Brigitte Bardot
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Roger Vadim, the French film director who will always be remembered as the man who unleashed a pert and pouting young blonde called Brigitte Bardot on an unsuspecting world, died yesterday after battling cancer for several years.
fields.body:
Roger Vadim, the French film director who will always be remembered as the man who unleashed a pert and pouting young blonde called Brigitte Bardot on an unsuspecting world, died yesterday after battling cancer for several years.

The French president, Jacques Chirac, mourned the passing of a man who "shook up all the prevailing attitudes".

Vadim, who was 72, cast Bardot in the 1956 classic And God Created Woman, launching her as the definitive 1960s sex symbol and inspiring the envy of a generation of men since she was, at the time, his wife.

The film, a daring exploration of sexual freedom, starred "BB" as a young woman who marries an older man, only to fall madly in love with his younger brother. It was denounced by the Vatican and banned in several countries.

Vadim pulled in huge worldwide audiences for works like Barbarella, his 1968 science fiction spoof starring the third of his five wives, Jane Fonda.

Among the other beauties he cast were Catherine Deneuve, his partner between marriages, Angie Dickinson, Jeanne Moreau and Susan Sarandon.

Besides BB and Ms Fonda, he also married the Danish starlet Annette Stroyberg, Catherine Schneider and Marie-Christine Barrault, a French actress.

fields.headline: In for the long haul
fields.trailText: Going to the cinema is fast becoming an endurance test, as movies get longer and longer. Michael Atkinson asks, whatever happened to the quick flick?
fields.body:
Why are movies growing longer? Why has every visit to the cinema become a test of buttock fortitude? Why is our film going patience being stretched liked a bungee cord tied to a bridge-jumper's ankle? Simply to go to a film now, you have to ask a neighbour to water your plants and walk your dog while you're gone. You have to mark it on your calendar, shift meal plans, dress comfortably, as if you were going into a six-month hypersleep.

Sometimes packing a small bag seems appropriate - a change of underwear, canned food, some salt tablets. A movie isn't simply a movie any more; it's a crusade. It's easy to be outraged - one of our pre-eminent forms of public entertainment is being slowly morphed into an ordeal akin to attending all-day lecture seminars or the entire Ring cycle, and so who can blame us for growing resentful?

If I added up the excess time I spent sitting in a movie theatre in 1999, there's about 36 hours I would, if I could, happily tack on to the end of my life. I'd like that time back, frankly, and if I tally up the hours from the last few years' maddening overruns, and the overruns sure to come in the next few, I've got approximately a week and a half coming to me. It'll make a difference when I'm 80, that's for sure, and all I'll have then as recompense are active fantasies about assassinating David Lean.

Of course, Lean is long dead, and Lean's films usually justified their hyper-extended length. (Then again, couldn't you, with a pair of dull scissors, tighten Doctor Zhivago up so it takes less than three hours to endure?)

Lean didn't even pioneer the Long Movie - DW Griffith practically invented feature films by letting The Birth Of A Nation run for over three hours. So the impulse to ravage the audience's gluteus maximus has always been there.

But except for Lean and hothouse berserkers like Gone With The Wind (clocking in at a few minutes shy of four hours), long movies were rare. Extreme length was usually reserved for epics (a genre often hellishly dull at any length) and adaptations of novels so well-read and beloved (ie GWTW), that leaving large chunks of it out would have sparked riots in the streets. It should be noted that the normative length for movies ever since Griffith got over his gigantism in 1916 has been anywhere between 90 minutes and two hours.

There are good reasons for this: after two hours of sitting in the dark, we get hungry (this was solved early on with concessions), our bodies get restless, the clothes we're wearing (unless we went in pyjamas) begin to chafe, our bladders beg for release, our eyes begin to strain. Still, the most vital industry reason why films have always normally adhered to the 90-120 minute spread was booking - theatre-owners could squeeze in more showings of a film per day.

Apparently, these factors don't concern Hollywood any more. Just a cursory glance over the mainstream films released in 1999 is a chilling experience in watching your life's precious minutes disappear into the abyss. The Green Mile and Magnolia both run a brutal three hours, eight minutes, as if the former had been based on Tolstoy instead of Stephen King, and as if the latter didn't need to be winnowed down to the relatively modest length of, say, Nashville. Stanley Kubrick made sure we felt every one of the 159 minutes of Eyes Wide Shut, whereas Topsy-Turvy (160) and The Insider (155) are thoughtfully entertaining despite the fact that both needed to diet off 15 or 20 minutes before seeing the light of day. Titus came in at two hours, 42 minutes, despite the fact that even Anthony Hopkins seemed very aware that the ideal length was exactly zero.

No one could be surprised that Luc Besson's The Messenger and Chen Kaige's The Emperor And The Assassin both ramble on for two hours, 40 minutes, but did Fight Club (139), Random Hearts (133), The Matrix (136), The Cider House Rules (131), Ride With The Devil (138) or The Talented Mr Ripley (139) have to be so damn long? A film-maker would, we'd hope, need a very good reason to breach the two-hour barrier, so what justification could one imagine for 8MM, American Beauty, The Mummy, Limbo, Cradle Will Rock and Snow Falling On Cedars all being well over 120 minutes long? What industry-wide derangement is responsible for the running times of Summer Of Sam (141), Angela's Ashes (145) and Anna And The King (147)? Haven't we had quite enough, before the films were even made, of Spike Lee, Frank McCourt and that stupid white-girl-in-Siam story?

Likewise, 1998 movies as disparate as The General, Pleasantville, Lolita, Enemy Of The State and The Apostle all dipped deep into that third hour. If you wanted to compare and contrast the second world war epics Saving Private Ryan and The Thin Red Line, it meant spending virtually the length of an entire work day, minus lunch, to do so. Shakespeare In Love, which endearingly overshadowed them all, racked up a relatively modest 122 minutes, for which few can hold a grudge. Consider that if we were talking about ages past, every one of these movies would have been hammered into bearable length.

In fact, a number of them were: The Talented Mr Ripley was made with a great deal more wit and suspense, and with 20 less minutes, by the French in 1960. Of course, Angela's Ashes, Eyes Wide Shut, The Insider, Fight Club and Summer Of Sam wouldn't have been made at all.

The reason for this cinerrhoea is probably a combination of the usual suspects: the freedom allotted to film-makers by digital editing, a runaway sense of egomanic self-indulgence, and a misguided marketing notion that audiences paying high ticket prices want a lot of movie for their money. All we can say for certain is that when it comes to movie length, less is indisputably more.

Like all cultural forms with a fixed temporal length, movies are more than just the sum of their materials - they are, as well, the experience of having to endure those materials. The length of that experience is just as vital an aesthetic issue as theme and execution. If it's misjudged, a promising film can become a trial. Even the best of films, and the best of filmic ingredients, can wear on you like a grinder's wheel if they go on for too long. Nowadays, a film that attains depth and breadth and does so in under two hours (like Neil Jordan's The End Of The Affair) are the truffles in the filmgoer's search for delicacies. Movies that come in at 90 minutes or - God forbid - shorter are things of beauty.

fields.headline: Are you talkin' to me?
fields.standfirst: Faced with Mamet laying down the law,  Andrew Rissik  prefers his tough-guy patter
fields.trailText: Faced with Mamet laying down the law, Andrew Rissik prefers his tough-guy patter
fields.body:
Jafsie and John Henry: Essays on Hollywood, Bad Boys and Six Hours of Perfect Poker
David Mamet
Faber, £9.99, 187pp

Wilson: A Consideration of the Sources
David Mamet
Faber, £9.99, 336pp

As his latest collection of essays, Jafsie and John Henry, demonstrates, David Mamet does the higher journalism better than many higher journalists do. When he's content with the role of observer, he writes prose as well as Charles Bukowski or Raymond Carver, with exceptional clarity and lyricism as well as with a strong, communicated sense of the spatial solidity of objects and the clatter and untidiness of people.

Mamet made his name writing plays about small-time urban low-life types inhabiting the no man's land between business and crime. He loved their corrupt, swaggering verbal glitter, their peacock-male sense of being street-smart and wised-up; and he was fascinated by the rules and rituals they lived by, their sense of macho honour and their fear of betrayal.

In his early work the conversations felt as if they'd been overheard in bars or on street corners, transcribed and then somehow heightened. Mamet's skill was to take this material and shape it, to place his characters in contexts where their frustration and anger and sheer vitality had wider dramatic implications - where masculinity crossed the borderline into psychosis. He could elevate the coiled aggressions of people who don't trust each other into a hypnotic verbal poetry, full of violent psychological resonance.

It was a gift Hollywood quickly learnt how to use. Because Mamet possessed a magnetic ability to capture and then unleash the unstable, irregular rhythms of a voice, he wrote rewardingly for big-name heavyweight actors. Jack Nicholson in The Postman Always Rings Twice and Paul Newman in The Verdict both drew a dilating intensity and sense of obsession from his writing; in The Untouchables Sean Connery won an Oscar speaking his lines. Not until Quentin Tarantino came along did anybody write screen dialogue that crackled quite like Mamet's, yet which also had such a lustre of high cultural self-awareness.

Self-consciousness is an essential part of what Mamet does. Even in prose form, his dialogue is a fusion of opposites. It's very pared down, very sculpted; yet it also bursts with life, with a profane energy and speed. You don't read, you hear. As in this, from a piece called "Cops and Cars" in Jafsie and John Henry , where the young Mamet, working as a taxi driver, is hit by a patrol car: "The cop jumped out of his car, all solicitude. 'Jeez', he said, 'are you okay? I wasn't looking. I took the corner too fast, Are you okay? I'm sorry...' " Of course, the words don't really mean what they say. The cop books him anyway.

Mamet has always been fascinated by the structure of language, the way rhythm and repetition can communicate what words themselves don't or can't. There are times when one seriously doubts whether he has a subject other than aesthetics, beyond locating a kind of formal beauty in patterns of speech and the cadences of prose, or, on a larger scale, in the persistent half-sinister, half-predictable symmetry of events.

"Cops and Cars", the brevity of which functions sardonically as an attitude, shows off his sense of patterning. It begins with Mamet at street level, taking the rap. It ends, a lifetime later but only two blocks away, with Mamet, now internationally famous, directing a movie - and, because of a problem with the weather, urgently needing to clear a street of cars several hours earlier than he's asked the police to schedule. "The street had been posted for days with a sign which read, 'Such-and-such-a-date, this street closed from (here, in a blank, was written NOON) - any cars found past this time will be towed.' The head of our police escort listened, as we wrung our hands, took out a magic marker, crossed out the word NOON and wrote in DAWN, and towed the cars."

Mamet's writing finds its meaning through such epiphanies, distilling their significance into an angry, stinging shrewdness. In his world, everything comes down to having the inner dope. It's why one of his most richly achieved screen creations was the seen-it-all Irish cop Malone, played in The Untouchables by Sean Connery: entertainingly dour and trigger-happy in a Howard Hawks Western way, he also spoke in terse, antithetical sentences; we felt we were being addressed by a patriarch.

It's easy, reading Mamet's prose, to see where the crazy, elegised voices in his drama come from. The essays in Jafsie and John Henry show how he loves to put an ancient, almost scriptural spin on the language of observation. In "Six Hours Of Perfect Poker" - most of which is a vividly concrete evocation of the adrenalin addiction of the game - we encounter high-aspiring parentheses such as this: "It is my experience in the analysis of dreams, as in the constructing of Drama (which is nothing other than an inversion of the process), that it is invariably the overlooked, the seemingly innocuous, the dismissed 'connective' term, which is the clue to the mystery."

This attitude, this inflection, is one very familiar from Mamet's dramatic writing - the voice of the old-timer, the One Who Knows, sitting in a bar with a drink or two inside him, imparting nuggets of wisdom to his protégés. It has a dominating authority, a wonderful bright-burning paranoia, but it's hardly surprising that the positions it adopts are contradictory and self-defeating. Objective truth adjusts itself to the flow of rhetoric.

One essay, "Noach", is a baroque but compelling attack on conformity in stacked-up, Mailerish language - "we can see the very exuberance engendered by solidarity as a tool diagnostic of arrogance and the cruelty to which it leads", Mamet thunders. Then, a few pages later, in a piece called "Poor but Happy", he's saying the opposite - suggesting a solution to the disease of American anti-semitism by exhorting his readers to "proclaim and, so, to enjoy one's membership of the group".

You don't read Mamet for wisdom, because he doesn't possess it. When he tries to be wise he just gets tanked up on his own grand metaphysics. "What causes race hatred?" he shouts at us. "It is caused by self-loathing." Does he seriously believe that the Nuremberg rallies were exercises in self-hatred? That the iniquities of the slave trade were caused by low self-esteem?

I like Mamet best when the part of him that sounds like a scolding Freudian rabbi is not in the ascendant. In essays on whisky-tasting, sheath knives, deer hunting, he has a kind of perfect pitch. He writes better about the world of non-sexual sense impressions - the taste of Scotch, the weight of a rifle, the smell of a forest - than anyone since Ian Fleming. He's strongest when he's earthed and practical.

Which is probably why I found his "experimental" novel, Wilson: A Consideration of The Sources, virtually unreadable. The book posits a future internet crash in which the entire collective memory of the 21st century is erased and the past has to be recreated from the textual fragments which survive, some of which are (or appear to be) the memories of the wife of ex-President Woodrow Wilson.

The result is a bombastic patchwork of recondite jokes, verbal games and puns, padded out with slabs of parody or pastiche and governed not by narrative but by an overbearing impenetrability of tone. It has a theme of sorts - "We have been raised to think of the past as 'what happened'. The 'past' is merely our idea of what happened" - and moments of lucidity, when Mamet's disorganised, hectoring style snaps into focus and becomes poetic.

It doesn't matter that it doesn't work. Mamet has never pretended to be a long-haul writer and sees time the way the early Elizabethans did, as a destroyer. His best work points us, often brutally fast, to endings which are not intended to console. As for the grandiose way he sometimes writes - the hard-nosed pontifications - he probably feels it's an authority he's earned. He reminds me a little of the US army officer in Michael Herr's Dispatches, to whose elaborate military schemes the only truthful answer was, "Colonel, you're insane." But his voice - when it's telling us what he feels, not what to think - has enormous power to compel.

fields.headline: All you need is love
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  wallows happily in poetry and hormones in Sheila Sullivan's Falling in Love
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard wallows happily in poetry and hormones in Sheila Sullivan's Falling in Love
fields.body:
Falling in Love
Sheila Sullivan
Papermac, £8
Buy it at BOL

Call me old-fashioned, but there's something romantic about falling for ancient marketing ploys. In other words: it's Valentine's Day on Monday, which gives you two days to do some swotting up on the subject of love. And here is a book which might help, whether you think with Rosalind in As You Like It that romantic love is "merely a madness"; or that it makes the world go round; or that it is simply an invention of troubadours keen to get into milady's chastity belt while hubby was off at the Crusades. (It is, perhaps, a mixture of the three, and none the less real for that.)

Sullivan herself is fairly sure that love has been around for ever, and she summons plenty of evidence. But some of that evidence is sourced from rather odd places. Her technique is largely dependent on quoting those who have written, in fiction, extensively and perceptively on states of love - Philip Roth, Kingsley Amis, Erica Jong, Iris Murdoch and D H Lawrence. Which might lead us to suspect that her reading is not as "sweepingly erudite" - in Kathryn Flett's words - as we might otherwise suppose.

As she says, quoting Freud, we should "turn to the poet" when we wish to learn about women. Here's one poet she quotes: "Father was in the corner / Explaining to the groom / The vagina not the rectum / Was the entrance to the womb" (though strangely, she produces the bowdlerised version of the limerick about the swans at St John's which were reserved for the dons).

Here also is a poetic snippet from Erica Jong: "How hypocritical to go upstairs with a man you don't want to fuck, leave the one you do want sitting there alone... That's called fidelity. That's called civilisation and its discontents." Or here's e.e. cummings's poem "she being Brand", the one which compares coition to driving a car ("cranked her / up, slipped the / clutch (and then somehow got into reverse she / kicked what / the hell)"), etc. Sullivan also quotes the strangely affecting yet undeniably rude magnum opus of Victorian pornography, My Secret Life; indeed, for a book about lurve, there's quite a lot of ludic nookie going on. Which is probably fair enough.

To be less harsh, her non-fiction sources are better chosen: apart from the usual suspects (Plato, Freud, Greer), she picks up on the magisterially perceptive Burton's Anatomy of Melancholy, which seems to be her idealised model for this very book. Of course, nowhere does a mere amateur like Burton rise to the descriptive heights of the 1982 American Conference of Love and Attraction, which finally put the poets out of business by defining love as "a cognitive affective state characterised by obtrusive and obsessive fantasising concerning reciprocity of amorant feelings by the object of the amorance". (Elsewhere, I particularly liked Sullivan's own phrase, "women's breasts have received unstinted praise throughout the ages".)

As you may have guessed, I have my quibbles: when she complains that "the present perfect female shape, displayed in contemporary fashion, is becoming that of a waif-like child", she is forgetting that this is not a shape structured or even desired by the people who normally desire women, it's a weird conspiracy between designers and women themselves.

She expresses a broad contempt for sociobiology, misrepresenting its central platform (she thinks it equates human behaviour with ants'; I thought it was a little more subtle than that). But she does at least do the ethological parallels justice, and confirms what I heard in a pub once - that the initial, thrilling stage of love is largely a matter of being under the influence of naturally generated amphetamines.

To be less harsh, her non-fiction sources are better chosen: apart from the usual suspects (Plato, Freud, Greer), she picks up on the magisterially perceptive Burton's Anatomy of Melancholy, which seems to be her idealised model for this very book. Of course, nowhere does a mere amateur like Burton rise to the descriptive heights of the 1982 American Conference of Love and Attraction, which finally put the poets out of business by defining love as "a cognitive affective state characterised by obtrusive and obsessive fantasising concerning reciprocity of amorant feelings by the object of the amorance". As you may have guessed, I have my quibbles: when she complains that "the present perfect female shape, displayed in contemporary fashion, is becoming that of a waif-like child", she is forgetting that this is not a shape structured or even desired by the people who normally desire women, it's a weird conspiracy between designers and women themselves. She expresses a broad contempt for sociobiology, misrepresenting its central platform (she thinks it equates human behaviour with ants'; I thought it was a little more subtle than that). But she does at least do the ethological parallels justice, and confirms what I heard in a pub once - that the initial, thrilling stage of love is largely a matter of being under the influence of naturally generated amphetamines.

fields.headline: Triumph of the ghost bacteria
fields.standfirst: It's a bug's life, as Giles Foden discovers in Michael Ray Taylor's Dark Life
fields.trailText: It's a bug's life, as Giles Foden discovers in Michael Ray Taylor's Dark Life
fields.body:
Dark Life: Martian Nanobacteria, Rock-eating Cave Bugs, and other Extreme Organisms of Inner Earth and Outer Space
Michael Ray Taylor
Bloomsbury, £16.99, 287pp

As a schoolboy I sometimes found myself deep in the cave structures of the Pennines or the Mendips. Led by a brilliant but irasicible English teacher whose swept-back white hair had earned him the nickname "Drac", we crawled through labyrinthine passageways, abseiled down alabaster-smooth waterfalls and swam across underground lakes till we stood, amazed, in caverns with rock formations weirder than anything out of Star Trek.

Had I been aware, back then, of the microbial richness of the inner earth, I might have thought twice about these expeditions. Well, I did think twice - about the claustrophobia and the danger of floods and explosions, but never about bacteria. So far as we knew - and, until recently, most cave scientists knew - caves were formed by geochemistry, not by biology.

Not so, says Michael Ray Taylor in Dark Life, his exciting (if a touch excitable) guide to some of the most important scientific discoveries of the decade. They concern "a vastly diverse class of previously unknown microbes". Inhabiting the deep subsurface of the earth, this "dark life" has been found not just in caves but in "mid-ocean volcanic vents, salt domes, Antarctic ice cores, mines, and the deepest holes ever drilled". Drawing energy from chemicals or natural radio-activity, they form "complex ecosystems and food chains wholly independent of sunlight, photosynthesis, oxygen, and all the other requirements for 'life as we know it'".

Star Trek indeed - but the real cultural backdrop to these discoveries is Mulder and Scully in The X-Files, playing out our postmodern psychodramas as they battle the sentient fungal growth of underground spores. Or something. Whatever it is, you can be sure it is scary, exploiting the profound ecological unease of our times.

The natural as the new supernatural? Certainly these bugs - some alive, some long dormant - have an element of the ghostly, one that seems to speak to our own troglodyte past. Maybe, when he said that "the truth of nature lieth in certain deep mines and caves", Democritus was talking about human nature as well as nature nature.

Most of the bugs, however, are "nanobacteria" - too small to be seen - and as the root of the prefix suggests (from nanos, Greek for dwarf), they needn't be harmful. In fact, much of the drive to learn more has come from medicine, with the discovery that several cave bugs like to attack cancer cells.

Caving is a strange sport, the hope of finding "virgin passage" one of its primary impulses. Taylor never loses an opportunity to comment on the physical beauty of his fellow explorers: "Strong, young, and skilled in caving and climbing technique, she was from Southern California: black hair, big eyes - the full Malibu."

This is the photographer who accompanies him on a trip to Lechuguilla in New Mexico. One of the most important newly discovered caves, its features include "rows of ghostly human-sized forms" and, more importantly, deep pools never before touched by man. Thought to be sterile, these actually turn out to be teeming with the mysterious nanobacteria - some of which appear to share structural characteristics with bacterial fossils picked up by the Mars probe.

But far from eating us, these bugs are more likely to be destroyed by human contact. Swimming through one of the Lechuguilla lakes, Taylor and his Amazonian photographer go naked -"except for their helmets and attached lamps" - for fear of muddying the waters and bringing in more foreign elements than absolutely necessary.

Again Taylor cannot resist the slide to innuendo, slyly taking in the immense rose-coloured calcite formations, known as mamillaries, that crowd the walls and ceilings. "I noticed that some of those projecting into the water were topped by dark, rigid mineral nipples... Now ripened like massive fruit, each must have weighed tons."

Later he describes geologist Robert Folk stumbling upon Italian film star Ornella Muti on the set of a movie at the hot springs of Viterbo. " 'I've got to get this,' whispered Folk. He lifted the Argus and began snapping photos. He eased closer, turning the camera sideways. Ornella began covering her exposed body with gleaming white aragonite mud."

These guys, you begin to feel, spend too much time down holes. The writing is slightly odd, too. The author wasn't there at Viterbo, but it reads as if he were. This kind of hyper-dramatised, atmospheric notation - de rigueur on American journalism courses - needs deft handling in non-fiction, especially in conjunction with high science.

But it is a fascinating book for all that. Many of these bacteria "had lived happily for billions of years before the first plant cell came along". It is a hardly conceivable span of time, one which - as scientists take in the import of these discoveries - is provoking a reconsideration of the taxonomy of life on earth. And not just on the earth. Underground, undersea - where Taylor chases the plume of bacteria that follows an oceanic eruption - and out in space, bugs are supreme.

fields.headline: The girl who wasn't there
fields.standfirst: Mary Morrissy's attempt to fictionalise Anna Anderson, The Pretender,  fails to convince  Alex Clark
fields.trailText: Mary Morrissy's attempt to fictionalise Anna Anderson, The Pretender, fails to convince Alex Clark
fields.body:
The Pretender
Mary Morrissy
Jonathan Cape, £10, 276pp

A young woman escapes her claustrophobic family in the country and comes to the big city. Riches and romance evade her; disappointed and destitute, she throws herself into a river. When she resurfaces, she is in a lunatic asylum, her identity unknown to herself and those around her. But as she slowly recovers, the necessity of a total reinvention of self begins to seem more appealing than appalling.

So goes the basic premise of Mary Morrissy's second novel. But rather than create an entirely fictional surround for such an intriguing psychodrama, Morrissy has drawn on an extremely well-known, not to say notorious, example of delusion and self-creation. In The Pretender she explores the possible origins of Anna Anderson, the woman who claimed until her death in 1984 to be the Grand Duchess Anastasia.

Whether one supported or dismissed Anderson's claims, the true story is fascinating. It revolves around the possibility that when the Romanov family were shot by their captors in 1918, one or even two of their children survived the gunfire and bayonets. The plot thickened when, a few years later, "Anna Anderson" appeared in the United States and declared herself to be Anastasia. She produced witnesses who recognised her from childhood, waving away her apparent inability to speak Russian. After her death, DNA tests on her hair proved "conclusively" (her acolytes, of course, counter that the tests were rigged) that she wasn't related to the Romanovs.

Who was she, then? One line of investigation suggests that she might have been Franziska Schanzkowska, a Polish country-girl who worked in a munitions factory in Berlin during the first world war, where she sustained injuries consistent with the bullets and bayonet story, and from where she suddenly disappeared. Accepting the likely truth of this theory, Morrissy creates a fictional past for Schanzkowska. Her novel, which touches on Anna Anderson little save for atmospheric first and final chapters, is concerned with creating a set of psychological circumstances disturbing enough to be consistent with the personality of the long-term impostor.

The novel has undoubted strengths and inevitable weaknesses. Perhaps the greatest concern is the most obvious; that the author appears to be constrained by the limits of her ambitious project. She must continually be laying down markers for the attentive reader. Have we, for example, noticed that Franziska's father always called her Princess, at least until her baby brother was born? That, as an impoverished runaway, she dreamed of somehow getting to America? That the existence of the adored younger brother parallels the presumed real-life relationship between Anastasia and Alexei? The themes that interest Morrissy - childhood trauma and dislocation, sibling rivalry, the constant yearning for escape - lack the room to breathe when they are projected onto the larger canvas.

Far-fetched facts do not always demand far-fetched fiction, and Morrissy is at her best when observing and depicting more generalised scenes and atmospheres. Her description of the asylum in which Franziska first finds herself after her suicide attempt is stunningly good, full of vividly realised portraits of the unhinged and dispossessed and infused with a chilling sense of an enclosed world. She is acute, too, on wartime Berlin, and on the attempts of its embattled citizens to survive.

And yet too much of the story is missing, despite Morrissy's valiant efforts to fill in the gaps. We see the beginning of transformation and its sad, lonely end, but very little of what went on in between. What was it like to live in someone else's skin for over 60 years? To be engulfed in a manic delusion so outrageous that it gripped the world? These are tough, if not impossible, questions to answer, but they are the heart of Anna Anderson's story. One can't help feeling, reading this novel, that a vital piece of the jigsaw is absent.

fields.headline: The poet that time forgot
fields.standfirst: Lord Alfred Douglas is remembered as the man who ruined Oscar Wilde. But he was also an accomplished poet, and  Gawain Douglas, his great-nephew, wants to see him get the recognition he deserves
fields.trailText: Lord Alfred Douglas is remembered as the man who ruined Oscar Wilde. But he was also an accomplished poet, and Gawain Douglas, his great-nephew, wants to see him get the recognition he deserves
fields.body:
When I was a boy, my great uncle, Lord Alfred Douglas - or Bosie, as he was known - was just the photograph of a beautiful young man in a dusty old book of his poetry. I loved, and still love, the soaring, Shakespearean line and musical quality to his poems; they beg to be read aloud - which is why I have recorded a CD of them. I felt I had to do something to re-establish his reputation, still completely dominated by his relationship with Oscar Wilde.

As a child I knew nothing of the affair, which started after they met for tea at Wilde's house in Tite Street, Chelsea, in 1891. I doubt if any innocent event has ever had quite such dramatic repercussions, for it was to result in a scandal that rocked Victorian society and ruined both participants. Bosie's father, the ninth Marquess of Queensbury, accused Wilde of sodomy; Wilde sued for libel, lost his case and was himself prosecuted for homosexuality. However Bosie and Wilde's love, for so it was, survived trial, tragedy and disgrace, until Wilde's death in France in 1900.

"Your slim gilt soul walks between passion and poetry", Wilde wrote to Lord Alfred once. Bosie began writing in his undergraduate days in Oxford before he met Wilde, and his first serious poem, Autumn Days, appeared in The Oxford magazine in 1890. His first collection, simply called Poems, was published in France in 1896 during Wilde's imprisonment, and in 1899 an anonymous English edition of his work was a huge success. His poetry remained in print for the rest of his life. He wrote mainly sonnets in the strict Petrarchan style, but also some fine lyrics, satires, and amusing nonsense rhymes, Tails with a Twist, which were a model for Hilaire Belloc's Bad Child's Book of Beasts.

Poetry gleams like a silver thread through the dark history of the Douglas line, a curious distillation of beauty from bloodshed. The poetry comes from Gavin Douglas, the 16th-century bishop, one of Scotland's greatest poets, who translated Virgil's Aeneid from Latin to Gaelic, and William Douglas, who wrote the words to the song Annie Lawrie. Even Bosie's own brutish, thuggish father had poetry in his soul. His will stated that he should be buried "in any place where stars shall ever shed their light, and sun still gild each rising morn_" This from the man who tyrannised his wife (Bosie abhorred the mental cruelty he visited upon her), and cared more about his horses and his dogs than he did his own children. Bosie, when young, had revered his father's manliness - a fine boxer, the marquess devised the Queensbury rules that are still in use today. But the rift between them, fuelled by their famously insolent correspondence (Bosie once sent a telegram to his father calling him "a silly little man") was healed only shortly before Queensbury's death. And nothing could make up for the wasted years.

"The mad, bad line", Wilde had written about us. How right he was. Barbarity runs thick in the Douglas blood. There was William Douglas, one of the two Black Douglases of tradition who died in 1390. "Hush thee hush thee, dinna fret thee lest the Black Douglas come and get thee," was a refrain handed down by lowland Scottish families. James, his cousin, the other Black Douglas, was entrusted to take Robert the Bruce's heart in a silver casket to the Holy Land, to fulfil a vow to visit Jerusalem that the king could not keep while he was alive. James didn't make it either; he was hacked to death defending Christ in Spain. He died with ineffable courage, flinging the casket ahead of him when death was inevitable, with a wild battle cry: "Now pass onward as thou were wont, and Douglas will follow thee or die!"

There could be a predisposition for human flesh in our family. His namesake, James, third Marquess of Queensbury, whose nickname was "the cannibalistic idiot", escaped in 1707 from his cell into the the kitchens of Holyrood Palace, where he seized a cookboy, killed him and roasted him on a spit before the fire. I wonder if poor Wilde had any idea what he was dealing with. Even Bosie's own son Raymond was deranged and spent much of his life in confinement. Once, when released from his institution to come out to lunch with my father, he attempted to throw the chambermaid out of the window.

But along with this daunting heritage came qualities of courage and loyalty. Bosie was the only one to stick with Wilde at the time of his trial, when most upper-class gays were fleeing the country to avoid the scandal.

As I grew older and became a teenager, gradually I learnt more about Bosie. About the bad boy who had ruined Wilde. About the loss of the family's vast Scottish estates and huge fortune, more or less as a result of the bitter family rift between the marquess and his sons over the Wilde affair. Queensbury had been so maddened by Bosie's behaviour and the support given him by Percy, his other son, that he took no care over the settlement of his wealth on future generations. As a result the estates were sold and the entire fortune left to Percy, a hopeless speculator who lost the lot, about £300,000, in one year. My father was fond of remarking that all he had inherited from the whole debacle were the keys to the family graveyard.

Those were the stories. I was more interested in the poetry. I started to learn and recite the poems as my father, Francis Queensbury, had done before me. He was famous for his recitations at such places as Leeds Castle and Blenheim Palace. He had a fabulous voice and a unique style, and delivered Bosie's sonnets with a growling, stentorian grandeur.

Bosie and I connect. I am a pianist and singer and so was he; it is my profession, and was his hobby - though he was asked to play the chapel organ, while serving time in Wormwood Scrubs (he was sentenced to six months for libelling Winston Churchill). Bosie fought his battles not in the fields of Spain, but in the courtrooms of England where he proved a ferocious litigant. He also wrote one of his finest works, In Excelsis, in prison.

The poetry ranges from lines of passion and intensity: ("You were a brute and more than half a knave/ Your mind was seamed with labyrinthine tracks/ Wherein walked crazy moods bending their backs/ Under grim loads" - The Unspeakable Englishman) to delicate fancy and romance ("Alas that Time should war against distress/ And numb the sweet ache of remembered loss/ And give for sorrow's gold the indifferent dross/ Of calm regret or stark forgetfulness_"). The latter comes from a sonnet written about Wilde after his death.

I love Bosie's contrary nature. His rigid adherence to an antique style of sonnet writing and his defiance of convention certainly make him an exceptional 20th-century figure. He was once highly regarded, gaining a place in the Oxford Book of English Verse. His poems, with their rigour and diamond-like strength, as clear and sharp as frost, should fascinate us today.

Perhaps I can put Lord Alfred back on the bookshelf now.

The poetry ranges from lines of passion and intensity: ("You were a brute and more than half a knave/ Your mind was seamed with labyrinthine tracks/ Wherein walked crazy moods bending their backs/ Under grim loads" - The Unspeakable Englishman) to delicate fancy and romance ("Alas that Time should war against distress/ And numb the sweet ache of remembered loss/ And give for sorrow's gold the indifferent dross/ Of calm regret or stark forgetfulness_"). The latter comes from a sonnet written about Wilde after his death. I love Bosie's contrary nature. His rigid adherence to an antique style of sonnet writing and his defiance of convention certainly make him an exceptional 20th-century figure. He was once highly regarded, gaining a place in the Oxford Book of English Verse. His poems, with their rigour and diamond-like strength, as clear and sharp as frost, should fascinate us today. Perhaps I can put Lord Alfred back on the bookshelf now.  To order a copy of the CD Poems of Lord Alfred Douglas Recited by Lord Gawain Douglas, price £12.99, call 01304 375813. fields.headline: Poetry
fields.trailText: Nick Drake's latest collection of poems roams around eastern Europe, plus The Twelfth of Never and The Ballad of HMS Belfast
fields.body:
The Man in the White Suit
Nick Drake
Bloodaxe, £6.95
Buy it at BOL

Nick Drake won the Forward Prize for Best First Collection with this volume, and there is no question that it merited the recognition. These well-travelled and well-read pieces range around eastern Europe (see the creepy "Ceausescu's Daughter's Bedroom"), England, and sundry other places; politics and love are treated with gravity and wit. The poems are extraordinarily rich in accumulated detail, and need to be taken gently. The collection of well-observed minutiae becomes most effective in elegaic remembrance: "In Memory of Vincent Cox" tenderly recalls the gambling father of a friend, "who might forgive - with the ghost of his good luck, / with the ghost of a chance - these words as my low stake".

The Twelfth of Never (Picador, £6.99)
The Ballad of HMS Belfast (Picador, £6.99)
Ciaran Carson
Buy it at BOL

Ciaran Carson's new collection The Twelfth of Never is being intelligently issued alongside an anthology of his specifically Belfast-oriented pieces at a time when that city is under the spotlight as never before. Carson's work sings with passion and vigour; there is a sure music to his phrasing, and nothing listless about his purpose. The Twelfth of Never kicks off with a saint's day that doesn't exist ("we stumble through this paradise... storytellers who convince themselves that truths are lies"), and cheerfully proceeds to elide myth and truth with the enjoyment of a born entertainer. The Belfast poems are giddying with disorientation and detail, long clotted sentences that often enact their meaning, as in the famous "Belfast Confetti": "Suddenly as the riot squad moved in, it was raining exclamation marks,/ Nuts, bolts, car-keys. A fount of broken type..."

webTitle: Poet's last play gets homely opening

fields.headline: Poet's last play gets homely opening
fields.trailText: The last, unexpectedly hopeful play of the dying poet laureate Ted Hughes, which had been seen as a potential catch for the London stage, is to be premiered instead in the Pennine valley where he was born and found lifelong inspiration.
fields.body:
The last, unexpectedly hopeful play of the dying poet laureate Ted Hughes, which had been seen as a potential catch for the London stage, is to be premiered instead in the Pennine valley where he was born and found lifelong inspiration.

Hughes's friend and fellow-Yorkshireman, Barrie Rutter, announced yesterday that Alcestis, the theme of which has tragic parallels with Hughes's relationship with his wife, the poet Sylvia Plath, will be performed this summer, eight miles from where Hughes was born.

At Hughes's request, shortly before he died in 1998, the script of the vivid translation of Euripides's masterpiece was sent to Rutter, who runs the Northern Broadsides theatre company from a converted Halifax carpet mill. The poet had been struck by Broadsides's production of Milton's Samson Agonistes the previous year - delivered, like all the company's work, in strong and rhythmic Yorkshire accents.

The unusual commission nearly failed, Rutter said yesterday, because Hughes misread his initial reaction, possibly because of cancer and the drugs used to dull its pain. The laureate mistakenly thought that his friend did not rate the play, and sent a disappointed card only weeks before he died, saying: "Where shall I place it then?"

Rutter said: "I sent a message back straight away, saying: Ted, Ted, no, no, no. No, because I'd obviously muddled my response and No because he'd got my reaction wrong. Alcestis is a really powerful masterpiece by one of the world's great poets - part of that wonderful, final flourish of Hughes's talent which brought us Tales from Ovid, the Oresteia and the poems of Birthday Letters in the year before he died.

"He used to say that wherever he travelled or lived, his tuning fork was stuck firmly here in the Calder Valley. We're delighted to have the chance to show that we too sing that tune."

The play, which will tour from Halifax to London in September, tells the story of Alcestis, whose royal husband contracts a terminal illness but strikes a bargain with Death. His glorious career is allowed to continue, with ever more success, if he can find someone to die in his place.

"No substitute comes forward apart from his wife Alcestis," said Rutter. "And the story starts on the day that she dies."

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: A gorilla wins the Sydney City to Surf race, plus The Mirror, One Thing Leads To Another, Two Serious Ladies and Quicksand
fields.body:
In The New Country
David Foster
Fourth Estate, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

After a spectacularly hilarious opening involving a mystery gorilla winning the Sydney City to Surf race, Foster's modern Australian pastoral is a delight. He trips lightly and comically over Aborigine land rights, Rupert Murdoch, and the 2000 Olympics. Ad Hock is trying to develop tourism in the Yarrowongamullee outback, as well as organise his class reunion, when his brother Mike, suspected of being the sprinting gorilla, dies. Foster's sense of place has won praise from Annie Proulx. His blackly humorous despair about his pig-headed fellow countrymen makes him a worthy successor to Flann O'Brien.

The Mirror
Lynn Freed
Flamingo, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Agnes arrives in Durban as housekeeper to a Jewish man, his dying wife and hostile daughter.Half-conscious of her sexuality, she soon realises that her power over men can be used to buy her way out of the kitchen. For sheer bravado, hard-nosed business sense and a cunning understanding of human frailty, Agnes deserves admiration. The qualities with which Freed endows her heroine are fundamentally masculine, and through this comes a subtle but inescapable feminist message which makes The Mirror more than a colonial family saga. Moreover, Freed gives Agnes a voice and an indomitable attitude which captivates and mesmerises the reader.

One Thing Leads To Another
Jamie Holland
HarperCollins, £5.99

Buy it at BOL

Transport Dick, Julian and George to a west London flat and you have Enid Blyton for twentysomethings. In this jolly fluffy adventure, Flin, Geordie and Jessica make a pact to find love before the lease on their flat runs out. Along with lashings of heartbreak, sex and the odd ginger beer laced with booze, the sex-starved trio moan about work, growing up and the traffic jams on the M4. The baddies wear business suits and make passes at Jessica, while Flin gets lured into bed by sex-crazed Poppy, last seen in primary school. Lots of super fun is had by all as Holland leads the mildly troubled three to - you've guessed it - contented coupledom.

Two Serious Ladies
Jane Bowles
Penguin, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Miss Goering and her friend Mrs Copperfield are ladies who run away from lunch. One finds salvation among the prostitutes of Panama; the other in daring sexual liaisons. The third lady who wants more than lunch is Bowles herself, who describes their perverse flight from convention in deadpan style. Peculiar and original, Two Serious Ladies is a wonderfully amusing celebration of eccentricity. From the image of Mrs Copperfield paying to take a siesta with a prostitute in a brothel to Miss Goering being delighted at being taken for a prostitute herself, Bowles relishes the contrasts between those who take excursions and those who travel without return tickets.

Quicksand
Junichiro Tanizaki
Vintage, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

Set in pre-war Osaka, Tanizaki's novel is a bleak depiction of middle-class Japanese society. A young married woman takes painting lessons and becomes infatuated with a fellow student. Friendship becomes sexual passion and the two young women are determined that neither "Mr Husband", the girl's family nor convention will prevent their being together. But Sonoko comes to realise that her lover, Mitsuko, demands her husband's subordination too. Through Sonoko's eyes we see Mitsuko - beautiful, captivating and utterly corrupt - manipulate all around her. A gripping and unsettling indictment of the superficial conformity of 1920s Japan.

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: The rational antidote to Valentine's Day, plus Broadway Babies Say Goodnight amd The Medieval Surgery
fields.body:
The Improvised Woman
Marcelle Clements
WW Norton, £10.95
Buy it at BOL

The rational antidote to Valentine's Day: a study of an unnoticed truth - that many American women now live alone, a quiet change in societal structure. This droll writer (her tone is a little like Jane Austen's letters) records what solos from 19 to 90-something say - hardly a word of it psychobabble or victimspeak; no whinges, no self-deprecation, much rude humour. Shrewd, too. We adore her summary of the great American romance with solitude, in which traditionally only a man got to be lonely and free: "Have you ever seen a tumbleweed follow a lone woman rider?"

Broadway Babies Say Goodnight<BRMark Steyn
Faber, £9.99
Buy it at BOL

Steyn loves, too: he loves the Broadway musical; only he doesn't love Stephen Sondheim because Mr S will never unconditionally write "I love you", which refusal makes a lie of all the declarations of love and hope that sustained Broadway. Sometimes the wisecracks crackle too fast, so Steyn sounds like gum-snapping showgirl; but mostly the book (in the musical sense) would stage swell: it's got heart, class, rhythm, a perfect little biotuner of the life of Irving Berlin (or why White Christmas has traditional Jewish connotations and tragic personal ones). And an intermission. Do not read in public places, because you are certain to sing along.

The Medieval Surgery
Tony Hunt
Boydell, £12.99
Buy it at BOL

After all that love, some pain: Roger of Parma's 1180 treatise on surgery, with a crisply professional commentary. The swollen right cheek of a wretch in a tunic is a "an indication of mandibular dislocation"; a grim scene in which a patient clutches the shins of a doctor who, with forceps, is "neutralising the barbs" before extracting an arrow. We suspect medical humour in the line "the patient appears comfortable", describing the wide-eyed face of a medieval man watching as his slit-open belly is stitched up. A foul world: scrofulas, fistulas and cranial fractures - any casualty on a bad Saturday night, except that no doctor here runs by the trolley; he sits on a kingly chair and pronounces.

fields.headline: Small Press Corner
fields.trailText: A gorgeous facsimile edition of the first edition of Ruskin's challenge to capitalists
fields.body:
Unto This Last
John Ruskin
Hendon Publishing, £6.99

The book that Mahatma Gandhi called "impossible to put down". It still has teeth today: an angry, exquisitely argued challenge to capitalists to behave with honour. A company's ethical duty is to distribute its product "at the cheapest possible price where it [is] most needed". Well, they laughed at him in 1860, too. This gorgeous facsimile of the first edition is produced by Lancashire house Hendon Publishing, who started off in 1970 with the As It Was series of photographic books. To mark the centenary of Ruskin's death, they are also republishing Sesame and Lilies at £5.99.

fields.headline: Decommissioning
fields.trailText:
Something to do with precipices
and ice cream
and then nothing at all to do with them
- I'm tracing whatever
- yeah whatever
and want to be rocky ropy
yes claggy even ragged
like the smell of damp newspaper
a smell that's worse than dull
- maybe it's an icecream parlour - Fusco's -
on the Ormeau Road
a gunman with an unused weapon
letting himself softly out the back door?
- I met a son of that family
last winter in Moscow
but here and now
there's no thick innocent snow
to soften things
- their angles
their hard lines
as we watch David Trimble dangle
on a thread
- thread or a wire
a command wire that ends
in a hazel grove
that overlooks an A road
some council houses
a red phone box
in South Armagh
- this is what I'm thinking
as we all make this next trip
to the brink
it's in me as I take the road
past the ice rink
to a house on the river
but the river I see
is a greasy groove
that might just be the Lagan
slipping or sliding
down to the sea
- would one jammed Armalite
a rusty revolver
and a sweaty wad
of Semtex do the trick?
it's not likely
as the fabled pikes and a thousand bits
of new and ancient hardware
stay rammed in the thatch
for the next time
or the time after that
- no way will it hatch
either the oval
or the squared egg of peace
because the Union
- what's left of it
the Union was always a dead end
a painted wee corner
whose two high walls
echo back No Surrender
as a pleading boxed-in command
Surrender

fields.headline: City sickness
fields.standfirst: Steven Poole  sees a utopia crumble in Stephen Amidon's The New City
fields.trailText: Steven Poole sees a utopia crumble in Stephen Amidon's The New City
fields.body:
The New City
Stephen Amidon
Doubleday, £15.99, 445pp
Buy it at BOL

It is man's nature, says Aristotle, to live in a city. A city's grimy, haphazard accretions begin as products of its inhabitants' natures and end up being part of them: bricks become psycho-geography. Does it follow, then, that if you change the city radically enough you can change man's nature? Take a piece of virgin land and design away unhappiness and conflict in a blueprint of lush lawns and sturdy timber houses?

It is 1973, we are in Maryland, and that is exactly the idea behind Newton, this novel's setting. Its civic ambitions run to erasing racial strife. If black and white live together in material comfort, with parks and recreational facilities open to all, they'll get along just fine.

Utopian social engineering, however, has a habit of going awry. Amidon's novel charts the slow poisoning of a friendship between Austin Swope, the white lawyer who has been overseeing the city's completion, and Earl Wooten, the black contractor who has got it built. Wooten's already worried that his son Joel is having an affair with a blonde cutie called Susan: interracial love, he thinks, is "bad medicine". Swope's son Teddy, Joel's best friend, is feeling woefully "ditched" by his compadre in favour of Susan's doubtful charms.

Then Wooten gets a call from head office in Chicago. He thinks they're going to offer him the job of city manager, which everyone thought Swope had sewn up. He doesn't tell his friend. Swope hears the rumour on the grapevine, however, and woundedly plots Wooten's downfall. The rusty machinery of tragedy grinds into life.

Amidon soaks the proceedings in period detail: Watergate on the TV; lounge games of Risk; kids listening to "Stevie" or Led Zeppelin and toking like there's no tomorrow. Teddy is at first the most likeable character, a boy genius who drawls invitations like "Do you want to enter my humble abode and partake of the storied herb?" and regales Joel with episodes from his 2,000-page novel, The Widening Gyre, whose hero boasts "a gift for mind-reading and a massive schlong".

Each chapter unfolds from a different character's point of view, although we are only given to know the minds of Swope, Wooten, Teddy, Susan, and her father, John Truax. Amidon uses this device cunningly, setting up a little crisis at a chapter's end and then rewinding the tape to start a few hours earlier, through different eyes. We know what's coming, but not why: a constant frisson of suspense. Amidon's choice of free indirect style over first-person narration, meanwhile, maintains a distance that allows him to soak sentiments in wrenching irony: he is superb at showing decent men deceiving themselves. "Swope was not vindictive," we are told, as Swope wades ever deeper into a meticulous vengeance.

All right, so this is a big American novel. But is it a Big American Novel? Well, the new city is of course America, the start-from-scratch dream of land, freedom and brotherhood. Then you have race, 'Nam, rock music, teenagers and the law. And Amidon scores his epic with gently tolling symbolism: the fish in the new lake knowingly turn belly-up, and Teddy gives his father a Newton's cradle, which pictures at once a predictable cosmic order and an Old Testament vengeance: knock something and it comes back at you just as hard.

But a BAN ought to teem with plurally imagined life, and the people outside Amidon's privileged circle of quasi-narrators do not seem quite real. Joel is unfathomable: Teddy's devotion to him is something for which we are given excuses rather than reasons. Swope's wife wafts around ethereally to no apparent purpose, and Susan's mother Irma Truax is a nutty Kraut stereotype. There is also a slightly reticent sheen to the prose. The funniest line, "The county magistrate entered the chamber like a small mammal looking for food", sticks out as a rare moment of imaginative levity.

This fascinating novel is perhaps, in the end, too careful. The last 100 pages are horrifically gripping, and yet at the last the novel seems to stop rather than to finish. Amidon's decision to deny readers the most obvious continuation, a courtroom thriller, is a brave one. But a more shameless thriller writer would certainly have reversed the linear narrative, and begun the story with this book's climax of murder and arrest. After all, Amidon spends 450 pages dramatising how cool, deliberate planning can degenerate into atavistic chaos. Maybe he should have gone for the jugular.

Wooten's already worried that his son Joel is having an affair with a blonde cutie called Susan: interracial love, he thinks, is "bad medicine". Swope's son Teddy, Joel's best friend, is feeling woefully "ditched" by his compadre in favour of Susan's doubtful charms. Then Wooten gets a call from head office in Chicago. He thinks they're going to offer him the job of city manager, which everyone thought Swope had sewn up. He doesn't tell his friend. Swope hears the rumour on the grapevine, however, and woundedly plots Wooten's downfall. The rusty machinery of tragedy grinds into life. Amidon soaks the proceedings in period detail: Watergate on the TV; lounge games of Risk; kids listening to "Stevie" or Led Zeppelin and toking like there's no tomorrow. Teddy is at first the most likeable character, a boy genius who drawls invitations like "Do you want to enter my humble abode and partake of the storied herb?" and regales Joel with episodes from his 2,000-page novel, The Widening Gyre, whose hero boasts "a gift for mind-reading and a massive schlong". Each chapter unfolds from a different character's point of view, although we are only given to know the minds of Swope, Wooten, Teddy, Susan, and her father, John Truax. Amidon uses this device cunningly, setting up a little crisis at a chapter's end and then rewinding the tape to start a few hours earlier, through different eyes. We know what's coming, but not why: a constant frisson of suspense. Amidon's choice of free indirect style over first-person narration, meanwhile, maintains a distance that allows him to soak sentiments in wrenching irony: he is superb at showing decent men deceiving themselves. "Swope was not vindictive," we are told, as Swope wades ever deeper into a meticulous vengeance. All right, so this is a big American novel. But is it a Big American Novel? Well, the new city is of course America, the start-from-scratch dream of land, freedom and brotherhood. Then you have race, 'Nam, rock music, teenagers and the law. And Amidon scores his epic with gently tolling symbolism: the fish in the new lake knowingly turn belly-up, and Teddy gives his father a Newton's cradle, which pictures at once a predictable cosmic order and an Old Testament vengeance: knock something and it comes back at you just as hard. But a BAN ought to teem with plurally imagined life, and the people outside Amidon's privileged circle of quasi-narrators do not seem quite real. Joel is unfathomable: Teddy's devotion to him is something for which we are given excuses rather than reasons. Swope's wife wafts around ethereally to no apparent purpose, and Susan's mother Irma Truax is a nutty Kraut stereotype. There is also a slightly reticent sheen to the prose. The funniest line, "The county magistrate entered the chamber like a small mammal looking for food", sticks out as a rare moment of imaginative levity. This fascinating novel is perhaps, in the end, too careful. The last 100 pages are horrifically gripping, and yet at the last the novel seems to stop rather than to finish. Amidon's decision to deny readers the most obvious continuation, a courtroom thriller, is a brave one. But a more shameless thriller writer would certainly have reversed the linear narrative, and begun the story with this book's climax of murder and arrest. After all, Amidon spends 450 pages dramatising how cool, deliberate planning can degenerate into atavistic chaos. Maybe he should have gone for the jugular.

fields.headline: In search of paradise lost
fields.standfirst: Charles Allen tells John Cunningham about his quest for Shangr-La
fields.trailText: Charles Allen tells John Cunningham about his quest for Shangr-La
fields.body:
Life was fine for Charles Allen when he was recording the memories of old colonials in India, Africa and Malaysia. Presented first as BBC radio documentaries, then packaged into books, the series - Plain Tales from the Raj, The Dark Continent and The South China Seas - were based on a simple formula.

It worked for years, made Allen's name as an oral historian and licensed him to poke over the embers of empire. His father was the sixth generation of Allens to serve the Raj. Charles inherited the colonial gene but, as a leftie student, had to find a different, distanced way of using it.

He's had his ups and downs since the 10 good years of the Plain Tales, but now, in his 50s, three constants in his work have come together in his book about Tibet: his addictions to Asia, mountains and unfashionable causes.

The book is about his search for Shangri-La; the name was coined in a 1930s novel, The Lost Horizon, by James Hilton, but it came to be attached to a legendary bit of paradise on earth, hidden away beyond the Himalayas in western Tibet.

Allen's own attempts to get there didn't quite succeed, and now he says he might never be able to go back. From the sanctuary of the British Library, which he uses as research base and semi-club when in London, Allen confides: "I'm an awful traveller. I'm constantly sick; I can't stand Indian food and I've lost part of one lung."

In spite of this, he looks totally robust, and his dogged approach to research is intact - that's why he's in the BL, the London building that, ironically, most resembles a Tibetan temple - working on another book on the sub-continent.

Allen is an amalgam of classic traveller - hoping to discover an unexplored or lost destination - and wayward expert, clinging to a theory that academics revile. It's like being harangued by Coleridge's Ancient Mariner, but thankfully Allen has the redeeming ability to admit the shortcomings of his quest, while maintaining his belief in his basic premise. This, as he explains over a calming cup of Earl Grey in the BL caff, is that underneath Tibet's Buddhist culture lies an older, shadowy religion, known as Bon, which also preceded the Hinduism and Jainism of the region. Allen is keen to point this up because from the heartland of Bon came the idea of a perfect paradise - Shambhala.

He explains that he'd overlooked the Bon civilisation when he wrote an earlier book on the region in 1981. This was A Mountain in Tibet, about Mount Kailas, the fabled site sacred to Hindus, Buddhists and Jains.

"I got it all wrong", he says. However in 1996 and 97, he made return journeys to try to find Shambhala. He was wiser in some ways, but not in others. A meal of rancid buffalo meat nearly scuppered the expedition. He met a Bonbo abbot who said the ancient, abandoned capital city of Kyunglung was only a day's hike off. But it eluded him, and he was cheated again when he returned with a TV crew in 1998.

"I'll always regret not making the extra effort and pushing on, but we had already run out of funds and time," he says. The team was almost on the outskirts of the decayed capital city of the little paradise.

"If we'd been allowed half a day more, we'd have discovered something really radical. We'd have got into the complex of caves and temples. It's like a troglodyte city." He's convinced this belongs to the earliest civilisation in Tibet. "But I can find no other Tibet expert who will back me up on this."

However, the travel chapters of the Shangri-La book alternate with his summaries of what has been discovered about the beliefs and practices of the Bonpo - followers of a creed which, he believes, could have had its origins in Iran.

The hardback wasn't widely reviewed when it appeared last year. Allen reckons that is because other experts don't like him rocking the boat. "There's been a resounding silence," he says. "It's a bit naughty, the way some of the leading Tibetologists here and in America have trotted out the [previous] Dalai Lama's view of history." That gives an essentially seamless account of Buddhism in Tibet. But, Allen reminds them, Buddhists persecuted Bons: "Tibetan Buddhists are not the good guys in this story." Their religion is, he points out, an extraordinary hotch-potch of beliefs, practices, tantric texts, beasties, demons and superstitions.

Western academics don't haven't much interest in Tibet - "it's the poor boy of Asian studies" - nor in sorting out the layered muddle of religion, culture and politics.

Overall, we're too mawkishly sentimental in our attitude to Tibet, Allen concludes. But then he admits that he, too, is just as sentimental; just as hooked on the place. "It is wonderful, this combination of spirituality and harshness; of people living on the edge of existence who smile when they meet you."

webTitle: Winners and losers at the Nibbies

fields.headline: Winners and losers at the Nibbies
fields.trailText: • And so to the Nibbies, where the Vista Computer Services Supply Chain Performer of the Year (winner, HarperCollins) vies for pride of place with the Securicor Omega Express Author of the Year (J K Rowling).
fields.body:
 And so to the Nibbies, where the Vista Computer Services Supply Chain Performer of the Year (winner, HarperCollins) vies for pride of place with the Securicor Omega Express Author of the Year (J K Rowling).

HC also won the Representative of the Year Award (sponsored by Waterstone's, whose recent staffing crises have provoked complaints from some reps that it's easier to get an audience with the Pope), and were represented by Eddie Bell, smiling broadly and looking as if his resignation - which followed the next day - was the furthest thing from his mind.

Meanwhile, Sir Alex Ferguson picked up yet another gong when his autobiography, Managing My Life, won the Book of the Year Award, ahead on points against John Major, Thomas Harris, Frank McCourt (for the widely panned 'Tis - some mistake, surely?), Michael Frayn and the authors of The Year 1000, Robert Lacey and Danny Danziger.

 One publisher not out in full force at the Nibbies was Fourth Estate, unnominated in any category, whose top brass were pointedly celebrating the publication of Carol Shields's new book at MD Victoria Barnsley's house. Barnsley had despatched her underlings for a jolly, winning brownie points with them and thereby not having to go herself.

Quite possibly, she was saving her energies for the hard-fought auction later that week which saw her company acquire a new book from Radio 4's James Naughtie for a vast sum of money.

However, Barnsley may not be invited back to the Nibbies anyway, having never been quite forgiven for leaving her gold statuette in the back of a taxi when Fourth Estate won Publisher of the Year. Sadly, a dutiful cabbie handed it in to Publishing News, under whose auspices the awards take place: they took a dim view of such ingratitude.

 The publishing world eagerly awaits the introduction of rock'n'roll-style gold and platinum discs - well, books - for top-sellers. Track records suggest that Delia Smith and Louis de Bernieres will be among the first recipients: two authors less likely to fill their hotel rooms with coke and teenage girls and chuck the TV out of the window it's hard to imagine.

 By the looks of a press release about Martin Kemp's forthcoming The Oxford History of Art, it's clear that "radical" is where it's at in new-millennium publishing. Oxford themselves declare that "we have something very radical on our hands"; the author describes the moment he first caught sight of the proofs and thought "this is pretty radical"; and the entire project is summed up as not only stimulating but - you've guessed it - radical! Added to which, for all you fusty-dusty old art lovers, the work contains over 750 illustrations! (Exclamation mark not mine!) Got the message?

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: A Valentine's gift that should be used with caution, plus Dad's Army Volume 10
fields.body:
The Nation's Favourite Love Poems
BBC Radio Collection, £8.99, 130 mins
Buy it at BOL

Caution: don't send this one unless you're sure it won't be traced to you, you're not serious about the recipient, or your relationship's rock-solid. As an anthology of familiar romantic verse, it's got all the chocolate creams. And even gushed in the soupiest voices that actors use for love poetry, the greatest lines still make your neck-hairs ping. Paul Rhys wins the soup contest, but Judi Dench makes it a close-run thing.

Dad's Army Volume 10
BBC, £8.99, 120mn

Still they come, episodes from this supreme comedy series, and still they are fresh and funny. Private Walker, the spiv: "I can get you butter - lovely stuff - made from ewe's milk." Corporal Jones: "Oh, I don't want it if it's been used." And the "stupid boy", uttered by the ineffable Captain Mainwaring.
