fields.headline: Elegy for the last amateur
fields.standfirst: DJ Taylor  discovers how much life the workaholic Ruskin gave up for his art
fields.trailText: DJ Taylor discovers how much life the workaholic Ruskin gave up for his art
fields.body:
John Ruskin: No Wealth But Life
John Batchelor
Chatto & Windus, £25, 369pp

John Ruskin: The Later Years
Tim Hilton Yale University Press £20, 544pp
Buy it at BOL

Even by the remorseless standards of the 19th century - the 26 volumes of Thackeray's collected works, Dickens somehow managing to combine writing novels with editing a weekly magazine - Ruskin's fecundity can still come as a shock.

In his mid-50s, 30 years into a career that had begun in 1843 with the first volume of Modern Painters, he continued to file research projects with a raptness that verges on mania. Work in progress in 1875 included a history of 15th-century Florentine art in six volumes, a history of pre-Christian Attic art in three, serial lives of Scott, Xenophon and Hesiod and a "general description of the geology and botany of the Alps, in 24 volumes". Neither of his latest biographers, John Batchelor and Tim Hilton, offers a definitive total, but the final computation can't be much under 250 items.

Equally difficult, too, not to imagine that this extraordinary torrent of print, an endless inky fountain of lectures, reflections and articles, wasn't somehow a replacement for something else - that the fervour with which Ruskin put pen to paper compensated for the dramatic fractures and absences of his emotional life.

As both Batchelor and Hilton show, the latter in relentless detail, Ruskin's acquaintance was a Victorian Who's Who, taking in everyone from Turner to Swinburne, the pre-Raphaelites to William Morris, and yet his solitariness pulses away like a lighthouse beacon. Simultaneously indulged and kept up to the mark by wealthy parents, whose roots in "trade" gave him an edgy provincialism that he never quite shook off, he found it perfectly natural that his mother should follow him to Oxford.

She despatched wonderfully snobbish letters home about his well-born chums: "The only thing that occurred during the lecture that will please you particularly", she informed Ruskin senior, "was that Ld. March and Ld. Desart came and placed themselves by John, and Ld. March having forgot to bring a pencil asked John if he could lend him one."

Other pencils - one pushes the metaphor because it seems so intimately bound up with Ruskin's creative sense - were conspicuously short on lead. The marriage to Effie Gray, first picked out as a pre-pubescent 12-year-old, was never consummated (it says something for Ruskin's detachment that when Effie went off with J E Millais, who she met during the sessions for her husband's portrait, Ruskin insisted that the picture be completed).

Subsequently, he continued to exhibit the trademark Victorian weakness for young girls and even in old age was capable of proposing marriage to the 18-year-old Kathleen Olander (Miss Olander prudently declined). Certainly Ruskin was a passionate man - no one who reads a letter of his could think otherwise - but the passion, as Batchelor notes, was largely reserved for Venetian architecture.

It would be odd if some of the evasions and concealments of the life didn't cross over into the work. Technically he was a mid-period Romantic ("Derwent Water", the poem penned at a precocious 11, is a creditable piece of pastiche Wordsworth) keen on Carlyle, but capable of giving his absorption in art an intensely practical focus.

Naturally enough, this being the 1840s, this process began with a defence of Turner - Ruskin's failure to write Turner's biography must rank as one of his great omissions - but as early as half way through his 17-year stint on Modern Painters he was stressing art's social basis and its function in conveying social truths. As Batchelor points out, this kind of thing had serious implications for the view he took of Victorian culture as a whole. If art had any merit it had to be the product of a "moral" society; at the same it had to reflect a complete world, something that even George Eliot and Balzac - whose narrow realism he deplored - were incapable of achieving.

If all this sometimes makes critic Ruskin sound like the last of the premodernists, vainly holding on to a centre that was fraying at the edges, then it gives social reformer Ruskin a lasting resonance. At the heart of a work like The Political Economy of Art is a simply held belief that art is the expression of human delight in labour. Again this had far-reaching implications for the whole Victorian concept of "betterment". It implied a society that was static, or perhaps organic, rather than linear.

Amid the anthills of Victorian social advancement, "not only is the natural discontentedness of humanity developed to an unheard-of extent, whatever a man's position, but it becomes a veritable shame to him to remain in the state he was born, and everybody thinks it is his duty to be 'a gentleman'". This is a romantic view of work in excelsis. Plenty of writers have laboured the connection between wealth and power: few have done quite so much to set down its effect on the average human spirit.

Thereafter the path led to F D Maurice and his working men's colleges, William Morris, social experiments and even an end-of-century mock-medievalism, steamrollered by the late Victorian machine age - as, of course, it was always bound to be.

Though the extraordinary feats of production were kept up nearly to the end - the autobiographical Praeterita was unfinished at his death - Ruskin's last years were a decline. Hilton offers an awesome recreation of the pressures to which the 60-year-old savant was subject: the relationship with Rose la Touche ending in tragedy ("the woman I hoped would have been my wife is dying"), a defence of the freethinking Bishop Colenso turning into an assault on the whole episcopal hierarchy.

Again, one has the feeling - which is Hilton's point - that Ruskin's real targets go beyond the bench of bishops, and the person being defended is himself. By the final quarter of his life he was becoming out of date, and he knew it. Late-Victorian aesthetics, which in a sense he had helped to create (art for art's sake and the rest of it) were anathema to him.

Whistler's libel suit of 1877 - Ruskin had remarked of "Nocturnes" that he "never expected to hear a coxcomb ask 200 guineas for flinging a pot of paint in the public's face" - was an unhappy symbol of the new aesthetic divides. In the end Whistler was awarded a derisory farthing's damages, but the real loser was Ruskin. Meeting him in 1880, the 18-year-old A C Benson noted that he "seemed to have come from a different century". Worn out and mentally unstable, he still managed to survive a further 20 years.

John Batchelor's book is an excellent short study, keenly alert to the social and political environments in which Ruskin found himself, if sometimes a bit confusing chronologically; Tim Hilton's the second part of a prodigious month-by-month pursuit. Allowing for the differences in scale and treatment, their message is broadly the same.

Critic Ruskin may have been the last premodernist, social-theorist Ruskin the last amateur in an age of specialists, and yet, compared to the social and aesthetic counter-terrorists of the 1880s who supplanted him, he looks bang up-to-date. What, for example, would Ruskin have had to say about the Millennium Dome or the stakeholder economy? Retreating to the narrower world of books, I remember the late Sir Kingsley Amis once claiming that the writer's only duty was to literature. Ruskin, you suspect, would have corrected this to "the rest of humanity". And Ruskin would have been right.

Amid the anthills of Victorian social advancement, "not only is the natural discontentedness of humanity developed to an unheard-of extent, whatever a man's position, but it becomes a veritable shame to him to remain in the state he was born, and everybody thinks it is his duty to be 'a gentleman'". This is a romantic view of work in excelsis. Plenty of writers have laboured the connection between wealth and power: few have done quite so much to set down its effect on the average human spirit. Thereafter the path led to F D Maurice and his working men's colleges, William Morris, social experiments and even an end-of-century mock-medievalism, steamrollered by the late Victorian machine age - as, of course, it was always bound to be. Though the extraordinary feats of production were kept up nearly to the end - the autobiographical Praeterita was unfinished at his death - Ruskin's last years were a decline. Hilton offers an awesome recreation of the pressures to which the 60-year-old savant was subject: the relationship with Rose la Touche ending in tragedy ("the woman I hoped would have been my wife is dying"), a defence of the freethinking Bishop Colenso turning into an assault on the whole episcopal hierarchy. Again, one has the feeling - which is Hilton's point - that Ruskin's real targets go beyond the bench of bishops, and the person being defended is himself. By the final quarter of his life he was becoming out of date, and he knew it. Late-Victorian aesthetics, which in a sense he had helped to create (art for art's sake and the rest of it) were anathema to him. Whistler's libel suit of 1877 - Ruskin had remarked of "Nocturnes" that he "never expected to hear a coxcomb ask 200 guineas for flinging a pot of paint in the public's face" - was an unhappy symbol of the new aesthetic divides. In the end Whistler was awarded a derisory farthing's damages, but the real loser was Ruskin. Meeting him in 1880, the 18-year-old A C Benson noted that he "seemed to have come from a different century". Worn out and mentally unstable, he still managed to survive a further 20 years. John Batchelor's book is an excellent short study, keenly alert to the social and political environments in which Ruskin found himself, if sometimes a bit confusing chronologically; Tim Hilton's the second part of a prodigious month-by-month pursuit. Allowing for the differences in scale and treatment, their message is broadly the same. Critic Ruskin may have been the last premodernist, social-theorist Ruskin the last amateur in an age of specialists, and yet, compared to the social and aesthetic counter-terrorists of the 1880s who supplanted him, he looks bang up-to-date. What, for example, would Ruskin have had to say about the Millennium Dome or the stakeholder economy? Retreating to the narrower world of books, I remember the late Sir Kingsley Amis once claiming that the writer's only duty was to literature. Ruskin, you suspect, would have corrected this to "the rest of humanity". And Ruskin would have been right.

fields.headline: The self and its sins
fields.standfirst: Sean O'Brien  finds echoes of Larkin, Baudelaire and Laforgue in the latest collection by Alan Jenkins, The Drift
fields.trailText: Sean O'Brien finds echoes of Larkin, Baudelaire and Laforgue in the latest collection by Alan Jenkins, The Drift
fields.body:
The Drift
Alan Jenkins
Chatto £8.99, 64pp
Buy it at BOL

Alan Jenkins's fourth, and most interesting book to date, The Drift marks a further stage in the effort of this highly intelligent stylist to divest himself of the comforts of cleverness in order to come at his material more directly - to speak in the voice of feeling in a way which non-readers of poetry sometimes find lacking in contemporary poets.

The process (begun in his previous book, Harm) has a question behind it. When we reach 40 and are forced to grow up, how will the literary ideas and aspirations of our youth sustain us? By continual application, Jenkins suggests. Work is one of the "imperatives" to which the poet's self-knowledge commends him, as - in a book full of maritime metaphor - he tacks urgently to escape the doldrums of middle age.

It seems that work may have to be enough, taking the place of happiness and perhaps of marriage and children: a noble prospect, perhaps, but chilly too. In "Brighton Return" Jenkins aligns himself with the initially unlikely example of Larkin's "Dockery and Son": "For Dockery a son, for me nothing, / Nothing with all a son's harsh patronage". The poem compares Jenkins's biography with that of a friend who drew "the short straw" of early death but none the less made something of life by traditional means, ignoring "the pimps of literature" and the Grouchismo of the media in favour of unglamorous teaching and the satisfactions of family.

So, then, work it is. Baudelaire, one of the gods in Jenkins's firmament, likewise hoped that work might be salvation, and wrote: "I believe that I stake my destiny upon hours of uninterrupted work. All may be redeemed. There is still time." Mind you, look what happened to him. And there's a bind: the given work involves the contemplation of self and its sins, its family, its parents and contemporaries, so that the job, however well done, guarantees no escape from self-loathing or the sorrowful contemplation of a childhood which seems to have been simultaneously paradisal and purgatorial.

The element to which Jenkins commits his material is water - the Thames at Greenwich and the world's oceans beyond, "the all-absolving waters" in which deskbound fact and sea-going dreams can be wedded, at any rate for the duration of a poem.

The romanticism of this is far from simple, however. Jenkins recalls his time at naval school: "While my father sat downstairs and read Lord Jim/ I toiled at mysteries, dead reckoning, latitude/ and longitude; I buffed my shoes for starboard watch,/ saluted on parade and earned the two green stripes/ my mother sewed on my uniform. I was living out his hopes,/ although we both knew I would never go to sea."

In the family portrait that emerges, the poet seems to love his father but feel sorry for his mother - and momentarily worse than sorry in the opening poem, "Chopsticks", set in a restaurant during a trying meeting with her on the tenth anniversary of his father's death. He remembers the extended 50s of his childhood, in which Larkin meets up with Laforgue: "I'll sit and think of 10 years gone and her two cats gone, / gone with the Christmas dinners, my grandmother and great aunt, / with the endless Sunday mornings, Billy Cotton on the radio / and the endless Sunday lunches of roast beef, / gone with half her mind and all her teeth..."

On the book's other shore is the final guilty act of clearing the contents of his mother's house. Larkin doesn't seem to have written on this subject, but he might have done. Jenkins's reaction belongs with "late" Larkin such as "The Old Fools" and "Aubade", poems where the sustaining forces of sympathy and objectivity are routed by horror.

This book represents not simply a makeover but a process of considerable change - bravura self-mutilation turning to a recognition of the rights and dignities of lovers and friends, the verse lowering its youthful self-regard. It's a harsh schooling. If on balance The Drift is more interesting than successful (which has something to do with the residual formal influence of Paul Muldoon, a poet Jenkins admires but does not imaginatively resemble), Jenkins is none the less proving in the act of writing that he has the self-command and appetite for risk needed to see the business through in the long run.

fields.headline: Darkness visible
fields.standfirst: Tim Radford  discovers the story of space and time in Richard Panek's history of the telescope, Seeing And Believing
fields.trailText: Tim Radford discovers the story of space and time in Richard Panek's history of the telescope, Seeing And Believing
fields.body:
Seeing And Believing: The Story of the Telescope, or How We Found our Place in the Universe
Richard Panek
Fourth Estate, £12, 198pp

Buy it at BOL

Two hundred years ago yesterday the musician and astronomer William Herschel shone sunlight through a prism and made a rainbow. Then he placed a thermometer on each of the rainbow colours to take their temperature. Violet light was cooler and red light warmer than any of the others.

But beyond the red, where the light stopped, the temperature was higher still. Herschel had found the infra-red - detected invisible light in the form of radiant heat. He had discovered another way of seeing; confirmed that light wasn't just something to see, or see by. It was something to see with. Light became an instrument with which to measure the whole world.

Galileo Galilei fashioned what others had seen as a fairground toy, a tube with discs of glass at either end, and aimed it at the heavens. What he saw from a garden in Padua in 1609 - moons of Jupiter, mountains on the moon, the rings of Saturn - changed history. Before, in the world view hammered out by Aristotle and the Fathers of the Church, earth had been the imperfect centre while the heavens were perfect and enclosing. After Galileo's stargazing, it became increasingly clear that the earth was just another planet, part of someone else's heavens. The discovery had begun to put humankind in its place.

That bit of the story is well-known. But Galileo also fixed his perspicillum on a tiny little cluster of stars in the constellation of Taurus. These are the Pleiades. Homer sings of them, and so does the prophet Job. On a clear dark night most people can see seven stars, which is why they are called the Seven Sisters. With his lenses, Galileo saw another 40. In 1888, two Frenchmen called Paul and Prosper Henry added a camera to a much better telescope, pointed it at the Pleiades and left the shutter open. They developed the plate and counted 2,326 stars in the Pleiades.

They had, of course, seen the stars behind the stars that were behind the Pleiades. They had added another dimension to astronomy: time. Photons of light, too rare and fleeting to be detected by an eye or recorded as wavelengths by a detector, could be collected a few at a time, stored and assembled to build a bigger picture. The brothers had also demonstrated a way of registering at least some invisible light.

The spectrum of electromagnetic energy extends from radiowaves to gamma rays. Humans can see only a tiny segment of this continuum, but almost all of it can be detected by something - a dish aerial, a fleet of satellites, a light-sensitive plate, a charge-coupled device - and turned into an image to be pored over, to be read like a book.

Richard Panek's eye-popping book - brief enough to be gobbled at one sitting, rich enough to re-open immediately - is a story of ever-expanding horizons. Galileo's perspicillum was a poor thing, but it started a revolution. Newton designed a reflector telescope which collected light in a mirror and focused a much wider area of light for the observer to work with. The technological race had begun. More light, the astronomers cried, and went for it. Herschel, who had already discovered the planet Uranus in 1781, built a 40ft reflector telescope with a 48-inch mirror which was considered "the eighth wonder of the world". With such cumbersome machines he saw further and discovered more.

"I have observed stars", he told the poet Thomas Campbell, "of which the light, it can be proved, must take two million years to reach the earth." He had discovered the telescope as time machine. "A telescope with the power of penetrating into space has also, as it may be called, a power of penetrating into the past," he wrote.

Astronomers now penetrate the past by looking across distances so vast that (astronomical having become an abused adjective) there are no words that fit. At the beginning of the 20th century, astronomers believed that this galaxy, the Milky Way, was the entire universe. The next 100 years was marked by the discovery of an amazing cosmic bestiary: other galaxies, clusters of galaxies and even superclusters; pulsars flashing 1,000 times a second; white dwarfs so densely compacted that a mere spoonful would weigh tons; awesome nebulae studded with new-forming stars; all-devouring black holes at galactic cores; x-ray stars 10 billion times brighter than the sun; the embers of creation itself. All these were revealed by astronomers using light and time.

There are now projects to measure gravity waves - shivers in spacetime that mark the death of stars. There are plans for something astronomers call the Overwhelmingly Large Telescope. There are dreams of an observatory on the dark side of the moon. There is a world network of radio-telescopes. There are x-ray and ultraviolet and radiowave detectors circling the earth, along with infrared instruments painting pictures of the hot, invisible cosmos.

Four years ago, Hubble space telescope scientists tried looking not at light but at dark. Every time Hubble orbited the earth, they pointed its instruments at the same tiny, dark part of the heavens, an area about the size of a grain of sand held at arm's length. This went on for 10 days, 150 orbits, 276 exposures. Then the scientists super-imposed all the light they had collected on to one image. The result was a photograph called the Hubble Deep Field. The tiny patch of dark turned out to be a peephole in space, through which could be seen an undreamed of 2,000 galaxies, the feeble light from which had taken probably 10 billion years to travel to earth across a then much smaller universe.

The astonished researchers worked out the number of such peepholes in the sky, and did the sums. It meant a universe grown fivefold: another 40 billion galaxies had to be out there, waiting to be discovered, yet at the same time racing away in the ever-expanding universe. Some trip - from a garden in Padua almost to the edge of time itself, most of it down a little tube with glass at each end.

fields.headline: Romancing the past
fields.standfirst: John Mullan  finds love in trouble in the Granta 68: Love Stories
fields.trailText: John Mullan finds love in trouble in the Granta 68: Love Stories
fields.body:
Granta 68: Love Stories
Granta, £8.99, 256pp

A novel about love might end in a wedding, but a short story about love seems destined to leave us with separation. The latest Granta begins with a tale by Raymond Carver, recently discovered among his papers, which masterfully uses the stopping short of narration to enact the ending of love. A husband tells of an optimistic yet sad holiday with his wife, a last attempt to repair a finished marriage. Love flickers at the edges of the narrator's clipped sentences, then goes out.

The other love stories in this collection are also about love's failures. Ruth Gershon tells of an affair between a Jewish woman from London visiting Israel and her Arab landlord. Orhan Pamuk, in a narrative translated from the original Turkish, offers us a child's view of his parents' break-up. Both write well of the queer poignancy of memory, the way it catches at irrelevant detail in order to dodge painful feelings. Both pieces feel like fragments of memoir rather than short stories. Giving us everything that can be remembered, they allow themselves to ramble as if recollection were its own justification. Carver's story, in contrast, is a spare, completed fiction, engrossing and satisfying because of all it must leave out.

Other stories also contain elements of autobiography. Aleksander Hemon gives an account of a huge family get-together, the ethnic self-importance of his American-Serbian-Ukranian relations never becoming quite comic enough to justify all the genealogy. Keith Fleming contributes a droll piece on the surrogate parenting skills of his uncle, the writer Edmund White, with whom he lived as a teenager after his parents' terrible divorce (and whom he rather easily forgives for an admittedly polite seduction attempt). James Hamilton-Paterson recalls, in a voice unnerving for its absence of self-pity, the experience of being gang-raped by five Bedouins while living in Libya in the 60s. "Asking For It" is the opposite of fiction: a real secret shared with only one friend until now.

At a border between fiction and autobiography is W G Sebald. Granta gives us a gloomy, ruminative chapter of his latest book of erudite hang-dog reveries, Vertigo. In his 1998 The Rings of Saturn, this melancholy German wandered East Anglia as if it were the heart of a strange continent. His new work has little of this previous book's quirkiness. Austria and northern Italy, the scenes of his latest wanderings, feel all too appropriate as settings for his angst. His digressiveness, which can be engaging idiosyncracy, risks dwindling into self-indulgence.

That fiction has disciplines that memoir need not acknowledge is nicely illustrated in Peter Ho Davies's story "Fit Mother". Written in the character of a white-trash single mother trying to trick social services into giving her back her baby, it brings to life every detail by believing in the unsentimental sharpness of its narrator.

Curiously, it is more convincing than Daniel Meadows's essay in photo-journalism. His portraits of working-class strangers from the early 70s paired with pictures of them today are arresting, yet there is something wrong with the incompleteness of his commentaries, as if he were trying to make his characters' lives appear more impoverished than they might be. Leaving things out is sometimes, as Raymond Carver brilliantly shows, the privilege only of the writer who makes everything up.

fields.headline: Big in thrillers
fields.trailText: John Grisham's still not funny in The Brethren, plus Shame the Devil, Hitman and The Spirit Death
fields.body:
Humour has never been John Grisham's strong point. His books have always read like the equivalent of the family saloon - they're designed to get you there and most of us own one without really wanting to. A Grisham is a convenience vehicle for those who don't actually want or have time to read, and is also essentially, and cleverly, forgettable - handy, for when you see the movie you've forgotten the plot.

The surprise of The Brethren (Century, £16.99) is that its plot is essentially comic. Three no-hope judges doing soft time in an easy-option federal prison ensnare a Presidential candidate in their gay lonelyhearts blackmail scam. Grisham does little to make this, or the complications that follow because the candidate is a CIA puppet on a right-wing rearmament ticket, plausible. His recent beach reading, by my guess, has featured: Elmore Leonard, for his unlikely plot collisions, character jive and laid-back approach; Damon Runyon, in an effort to replace legal briefs with character jive; and Richard Condon, for irreverent political satire and character jive. But Grisham's still not funny.

George P Pelecanos, a cult writer close to kissing stardom, has made a franchise of the Raymond Chandler-Nick Hornby graft. Shame the Devil (Gollancz, £9.99) continues to chart the hopes and disappointments of a Washington DC generation pushing 40, their once youthful enthusiasm now easing towards failure. His stories are functional and TV-plot tight (here a botched robbery ends with the killing of the kid of a regular Pelecanos character, causing big emotional waves), serving to illustrate the capital's beat: its characters, their record collections, natty clothes, cars, movies and bars, all of them known inside out. Pelecanos reworks the classic mean streets to a contemporary soundtrack, and if there is a drift towards sentimentality (and rehab) in recent books he is always a pleasure for his understanding of how a big city works - and doesn't.

Max Kinnings's Hitman (Flame, £10), set in London, covers a similar urban recreational ground to Pelecanos, but very laddishly. A comic crawl through a spliffed-out London clubland is grafted onto a murder plot from some forgotten Ealing comedy (eccentric old banana offers 100 grand for her lover to be hit). Brashness and volume are offered as the main distractions from improbable goings-on, and the endorsement of Howard Marks tells you what to expect: a kippered romp, all cynical veneer and knockabout.

The Spirit Death (Simon and Schuster, £12.99) by David Docherty offers a flatter, less frenetic London, coshed by a heatwave and threatened by a bizarre hybrid virus, a fast-acting combination of CJD and Ebola. Accident or conspiracy? The result is more low-key Casualty than ER, and lacking the slickness of the US strain. Similar material was handled better in The Cobra Event, where it was given the big panic treatment.

fields.bodyText: Humour has never been John Grisham's strong point. His books have always read like the equivalent of the family saloon - they're designed to get you there and most of us own one without really wanting to. A Grisham is a convenience vehicle for those who don't actually want or have time to read, and is also essentially, and cleverly, forgettable - handy, for when you see the movie you've forgotten the plot. The surprise of The Brethren (Century, £16.99) is that its plot is essentially comic. Three no-hope judges doing soft time in an easy-option federal prison ensnare a Presidential candidate in their gay lonelyhearts blackmail scam. fields.headline: Tabloids vent fury
fields.standfirst:
Stansted hijack: special report
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The end of the hijacking siege at Stansted triggered some of the most hostile media coverage of asylum seekers since the clashes in Dover last summer.
fields.body:
The end of the hijacking siege at Stansted triggered some of the most hostile media coverage of asylum seekers since the clashes in Dover last summer.

Yesterday, the Sun claimed that Britain was now the "dustbin of the world" and "a soft touch for every scrounger on the planet".

The Mirror's front page headline ran: "Hi, Jack! Where's the four-star hotel? Send them home."

The Mail complained that the Stansted Hilton was used to put up the hostages: "Home suite home, at £202 for one night". It was prepared to wager that most, if not all, the "victims" of the hijack would still be enjoying life on benefits in this country in five years.

A BBC Radio 5 Live phone-in allowed a woman caller to demand the mass sterilisation of asylum seekers so they could not breed in Britain, and used her clip as a trailer.

The Sun reporter Nick Parker was the only guest to refuse to move from his Hilton hotel room when the third floor was cleared to create security for the Afghan hostages.

He reported: "The needs of paying guests were suddenly deemed as insignificant as those of the British taxpayer, as a flood of freeloaders began piling off the plane."

The fact that the rest of the guests had moved was an indication of the kind of attitude which had made Britain a soft touch, he said.

The Mirror claimed the asylum bill had reached £800m a year, and there were 1.25m illegal immigrants in Britain.

The Daily Express adopted a less hostile approach, with a piece from Kabul saying that at home the hijackers were heroes. Its editorial said the passengers who claim asylum should not be sent back to "face certain execution" but to another country, such as Pakistan.

webTitle: Asylum seekers at risk if they are sent back

fields.headline: Asylum seekers at risk if they are sent back
fields.standfirst:
Stansted hijack: special report
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The Stansted asylum seekers could face great risk if the British government returns them to Kabul. Western aid workers based in the city fear that the act of asking to stay in the UK could provoke the ruling Taliban into retribution.
fields.body:
The Stansted asylum seekers could face great risk if the British government returns them to Kabul. Western aid workers based in the city fear that the act of asking to stay in the UK could provoke the ruling Taliban into retribution.

Christine Johnson, Oxfam's representative who has lived in Kabul for the last four years, said: "The passengers who have asked for asylum could very easily be seen as having turned their backs on their country and being traitors to Islam. They could be in real danger as a result."

The Taliban leadership, which views Afghanistan as the only place on earth to have a pure Islamic government, would be unlikely to tolerate people who had effectively rejected their religion in favour of life in a decadent western country.

As for the hijackers themselves, the authorities have already made it clear that if any of them returns to Afghanistan they will be executed.

There was speculation in Kabul yesterday that some of the freed hostages might have told the British police that they were hijackers when in fact they had no part in the plan to seize the Ariana Airlines Boeing 727. They may have calculated that it would be worth spending a few years in a British jail if at the end of that period they could successfully claim asylum.

Those not charged with hijacking by the British and who have not applied for asylum will probably be interrogated and screened by the Taliban on their return to Afghanistan.

If they can convince the authorities that they had no connection with the hijackers, they should be free to return to their homes.

Many Afghans are desperate to leave their country. The capital, Kabul, lies in ruins. After 20 years of war, thousands of buildings have been destroyed. Rubble and twisted metal litter the roadsides.

"I wish I had been on the plane," said the owner of a shop in central Kabul who did not want to be named for fear of Taliban reprisals.

"There might have been a chance of staying on in London."

He dismissed the idea that the hijack ordeal could have been frightening with a shrug of his shoulders.

"It would have been worth it."

In the past, British immigration officials have given Afghan asylum seekers a relatively sympathetic hearing. Britain has frequently condemned the Taliban regime for its human rights abuses and has taken the lead in seeking its diplomatic isolation.

webTitle: 105 Afghan hostages want to stay in Britain

fields.headline: 105 Afghan hostages want to stay in Britain
fields.standfirst:
Stansted hijack: special report
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Only 37 of the 142 hostages who landed at Stansted airport on Monday aboard the hijacked Afghani Ariana Boeing 727 have indicated that they wish to return home, the home office said last night.
fields.body:
Only 37 of the 142 hostages who landed at Stansted airport on Monday aboard the hijacked Afghani Ariana Boeing 727 have indicated that they wish to return home, the home office said last night.

Some of the 14 crew members are believed to be among those seeking asylum, although one flight engineer has said he wants to join the flight back to Afghanistan. So far 74 of those on the plane have formally applied for asylum to remain in Britain. A further 30 are expected to join them.

Last night, as Essex police continued to question the 22 people arrested for being directly involved in the hijack, a Kampuchea airlines Trident jet, chartered by the International Organisation for Migration on behalf of the foreign office, was on standby at RAF Brize Norton in Oxfordshire, ready to fly to Kandahar those who wish to return home.

The preparations were being made yesterday against a background of Tory and tabloid newspaper hostility towards granting any asylum concession to the remaining hostages. Amnesty International last night wrote to Jack Straw urging him to give proper consideration to the claims for asylum and telling him that Afghanistan's appalling human rights record was a chilling reminder of why Britain's asylum laws existed in the first place. The home secretary is likely to come under more pressure this weekend.

The 142 hostages are to be bussed from the Hilton hotel at Stansted airport to the fire service college at Moreton-in-Marsh, Gloucestershire, at today. A home office fast-track asylum unit has been set up there to process their claims for refugee status.

A translator helping police with the interviewing process at Harlow police station said the majority of the hostages he had spoken to had indicated they wanted to stay in Britain: "Of the 11 people I spoke to only one, and he was a flight engineer anyway, did not say he wanted to stay."

The details emerged during a second day of questioning by police and immigration officials at the Hilton. A police spokesman said they expected charges under the prevention of terrorism act and international hijack law to be brought against the suspects on Monday. It is expected they will then be moved to Belmarsh prison, south London, to await trial. "We are looking to charge them with as many offences as possible," he said.

Of the 142 hostages brought to the Hilton, where they have been housed in 91 rooms without telephones, 122 were interviewed on Thursday and the final 20 yesterday. During the day an ambulance arrived and took a one-year-old girl suffering from abdominal pains to hospital.

After police interviews, each hostage was spoken to for five minutes by immigration officials, during which they had the chance to express their desire to seek asylum.

webTitle: Afghan hijack the toughest test for Straw

fields.headline: Afghan hijack the toughest test for Straw
fields.standfirst:
The home secretary's dilemma: he must show that air piracy does not pay but keep human rights pledge
Stansted hijack: special report
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The dilemma that the home secretary, Jack Straw, faces in the coming weeks over what to do about those aboard the Afghan hijack plane must be rated as the toughest that he has faced since he came to office, for there is no simple, painless solution. As his shadow, Ann Widdecombe, put it yesterday: "It is a horrible decision and it is not one I would want to take."
fields.body:
The dilemma that the home secretary, Jack Straw, faces in the coming weeks over what to do about those aboard the Afghan hijack plane must be rated as the toughest that he has faced since he came to office, for there is no simple, painless solution. As his shadow, Ann Widdecombe, put it yesterday: "It is a horrible decision and it is not one I would want to take."

Mr Straw has to demonstrate that there cannot be any benefit obtained by hijacking and yet fulfil Britain's human rights obligation that nobody with a well-founded fear of persecution is sent back to face torture or death.

The fate of the 74 passengers who have so far claimed asylum will be initially settled by immigration officers with the final decision resting with Mr Straw. It is expected that up to 31 other passengers on the flight may also apply. The outcome will largely be determined by their personal stories and the home office's own assessment of the situation in Afghanistan.

The latest home office assessment says: "Executions or other cruel, inhuman and degrading punishments were believed to be widespread, but were not always reported by the authorities. Of those announced, eight people were flogged, including a woman accused of adultery who was given 100 lashes at the Kabul sports stadium in February, 1998, in front of 30,000 spectators.

"There were at least 14 reports of public amputations carried out by doctors from the ministry of public health, usually in football stadiums in front of thousands of spectators, some of whom said they were forced to attend. At least 10 public executions were also reported. They included five men convicted of sodomy." On that basis it is unlikely that Mr Straw will send them back to Afghanistan. But it is likely that the fact that the hijacking started on an internal flight will be enough to justify the refusal of full refugee status.

However, it will be open to Mr Straw to allow some to stay - as many other Afghans have in the past three years - on compassionate grounds.

But in his statement to the Commons he ruled out that option when he promised that all those aboard the plane would be removed from the country.

This leaves the question of deporting them to a "safe third country". Pakistan, which borders Afghanistan, is the most likely destination. But Pakistan is one of the few countries to recognise the Taliban regime and Taliban forces are active in the Afghan refugee camps in Pakistan. If they are sent to Pakistan the best they can hope for is life in a refugee camp with the threat of ha rassment at best and at worst being handed over to Kabul.

The fate of 22 who have so far been arrested, and the 17 people who are also being questioned by the police, is less of a problem for Mr Straw. He simply lets the law take its course. Most will be charged with hijacking offences and will probably face lengthy sentences.

But this is not without its legal risks as, in line with a previous court of appeal ruling, the defendants will be able to argue that the hijacking was justified so they could flee the Taliban regime.

Perhaps the greatest dilemma for Mr Straw lies in what to do with the relatives of the hijackers who were aboard the plane. To deport them while their relatives serve prison sentences may mean they never see them again.

webTitle: Haider rounds on Turks in Austria

fields.headline: Haider rounds on Turks in Austria
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Turks, the second-biggest immigrant group living in Austria, should make up their minds which country they belong to, the Austrian far-right leader Jörg Haider said in an interview published yesterday.
fields.body:
Turks, the second-biggest immigrant group living in Austria, should make up their minds which country they belong to, the Austrian far-right leader Jörg Haider said in an interview published yesterday.

Meanwhile in Lisbon, an Austrian minister was snubbed by her European Union colleagues in the first meeting since 14 EU member states severed bilateral ties with Vienna.

"Turks do not integrate into society," Mr Haider, whose Freedom party is a junior partner in the new coalition government, told the Turkish daily newspaper Hurriyet.

"They say, 'We don't want to be Austrian, we want to stay Turkish'," he said. "So I say, 'That's your problem, make up your mind'."

There are some 170,000 Turks living in Austria out of a total population of 8m, according to the Turkish embassy in Vienna.

Mr Haider said acquiring dual citizenship should not be easy. "You cannot take citizenship at no cost. The person has to prove that he is worthy of living in that country."

He said Germany and Britain had much tougher anti-immigration policies than Austria, but that immigration was an issue that needed addressing or it could potentially lead to social clashes.

"The number of foreign children in schools is very high. Austrian children cannot learn their own language. For this reason we have proposed that the number of foreign children in classrooms be limited to 30%."

Elisabeth Sickl, a Freedom party member, felt the chill of her country's political isolation yesterday when EU ministers in Lisbon drove home their displeasure at the new coalition government.

Officials cancelled a welcome ceremony and group photograph. Ms Sickl appeared disoriented and later said the Portuguese labour minister, Eduardo Ferro Rodrigues, was the only minister who spoke to her.

Describing the meeting as "a bit cool", she said: "There's a lot of prejudice going on."
Agencies in Istanbul and Lisbon

webTitle: From industrial wreck to dot.com metropolis

fields.headline: From industrial wreck to dot.com metropolis
fields.standfirst:
Pittsburgh Back in the big time after 80s steel crisis
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: By the time you reach the Ikea megastore on the city outskirts, it is already abundantly clear that Pittsburgh has reinvented itself. The erstwhile crucible of US heavy industry, whose crumbling steelworks once embodied the term "rustbelt", has somehow become an urban flagbearer for the "new economy".
fields.body:
By the time you reach the Ikea megastore on the city outskirts, it is already abundantly clear that Pittsburgh has reinvented itself. The erstwhile crucible of US heavy industry, whose crumbling steelworks once embodied the term "rustbelt", has somehow become an urban flagbearer for the "new economy".

The signs of radical change are everywhere. It is not just the Swedish furniture outlets and the other retail icons of middle-class prosperity. Alongside them in the Pittsburgh suburbs is a string of hi-tech firms drawn to the city over the past 10 years.

Within a decade, Pittsburgh has been transformed from an industrial wreck to one of the leading "clusters" of computer-oriented companies considered the engines of long-term US growth.

Pittsburgh is the fifth biggest producer of software in the country and markets itself as a "digital greenhouse", a centre for the emerging "system-on-a-chip" technology which is key to the miniaturisation of computer components.

Driving into the centre from the surrounding Allegheny hills, there is visible proof that this is a new city rising out of the rubble of an older, discarded version. The art-deco skyscrapers erected by Pittsburgh's industrial dynasties - Carnegie, Mellon, Frick, Heinz and Westinghouse - still stand but several are home to management consultancies and "dot.com" firms.

The furnaces which used to burn so brightly that planes travelling from New York to Chicago used them as a navigational aid, have gone cold and the city's air quality is cleaner than most other US cities of comparable size. It is one the city's selling points to the new breed of mountain-biking, hill-climbing internet entrepreneurs moving in.

The old steel plants that remain along the banks of the city's three rivers are shells, used for warehousing vans, or partitioned into cheap floor space for small start-up companies. Sony has taken over an old Volkswagen plant.

Less than 20 years ago, the city seemed consigned to the dustbin of industrial history. The recession of the early 80s destroyed the steel industry almost overnight. More than 80,000 steel jobs disappeared within 12 months in 1983.

"The recession hit Pittsburgh arguably harder than any city in America in terms of percentage of jobs lost. There was a real sense of crisis," Donald Smith, an economist at Carnegie Mellon university, said. "But the severity of the blow galvanised public opinion and public leadership."

Mr Smith, who is director of the university's centre for economic development, believes that part of the reason for the city's renaissance has been the well-aimed intervention of the Pennsylvania state government, which set up organisations to finance and advise entrepreneurs.

The other key to Pittsburgh's salvation lay in its industrial founders, who had endowed a string of universities. These were originally set up to soften Pittsburgh's hard edges, but have taken on the role of powerhouses, supplying skilled workers and new ideas.

Carnegie Mellon has become a leading software research centre, specialising in computer security. Meanwhile, the University of Pittsburgh medical centre has become a world leader in organ transplants.

Tim Parks, head of the Pittsburgh Regional Alliance, an association of local industries, said: "The intellectual capital of the universities and their research capacity gave Pittsburgh the basic tools for creating a 'knowledge economy'."

Unemployment, which was well into double digits for much of the 80s is now about 4.5% - just above the national average. Ranked according to output per worker, the city lies behind only Seattle, Atlanta and San Diego. "The productivity gains are what's keeping growth going," said Mr Smith. "And it's not nearly played out - there is still room for improvement."

Nevertheless, a slump in the hi-tech sector would hit hard.

"I don't think we've built a bullet-proof economy," Mr Smith conceded. "But it is a more stable economy and its a lot more recession-resistant than it was."

The furnaces which used to burn so brightly that planes travelling from New York to Chicago used them as a navigational aid, have gone cold and the city's air quality is cleaner than most other US cities of comparable size. It is one the city's selling points to the new breed of mountain-biking, hill-climbing internet entrepreneurs moving in. The old steel plants that remain along the banks of the city's three rivers are shells, used for warehousing vans, or partitioned into cheap floor space for small start-up companies. Sony has taken over an old Volkswagen plant. Less than 20 years ago, the city seemed consigned to the dustbin of industrial history. The recession of the early 80s destroyed the steel industry almost overnight. More than 80,000 steel jobs disappeared within 12 months in 1983. "The recession hit Pittsburgh arguably harder than any city in America in terms of percentage of jobs lost. There was a real sense of crisis," Donald Smith, an economist at Carnegie Mellon university, said. "But the severity of the blow galvanised public opinion and public leadership." Mr Smith, who is director of the university's centre for economic development, believes that part of the reason for the city's renaissance has been the well-aimed intervention of the Pennsylvania state government, which set up organisations to finance and advise entrepreneurs. The other key to Pittsburgh's salvation lay in its industrial founders, who had endowed a string of universities. These were originally set up to soften Pittsburgh's hard edges, but have taken on the role of powerhouses, supplying skilled workers and new ideas. Carnegie Mellon has become a leading software research centre, specialising in computer security. Meanwhile, the University of Pittsburgh medical centre has become a world leader in organ transplants. Tim Parks, head of the Pittsburgh Regional Alliance, an association of local industries, said: "The intellectual capital of the universities and their research capacity gave Pittsburgh the basic tools for creating a 'knowledge economy'." Unemployment, which was well into double digits for much of the 80s is now about 4.5% - just above the national average. Ranked according to output per worker, the city lies behind only Seattle, Atlanta and San Diego. "The productivity gains are what's keeping growth going," said Mr Smith. "And it's not nearly played out - there is still room for improvement." Nevertheless, a slump in the hi-tech sector would hit hard. "I don't think we've built a bullet-proof economy," Mr Smith conceded. "But it is a more stable economy and its a lot more recession-resistant than it was."

fields.headline: The internet's spine tingler
fields.standfirst:
'Are you educating your students for where the jobs were or where the jobs are going to be in the future?'
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: John Chambers wants to amaze you. Here is a man who doesn't wince or even blush when he is introduced as Mr Internet. He doesn't just drop names - he drops the names of heads of state.
fields.body:
Take a step back. John Chambers wants to amaze you. Here is a man who doesn't wince or even blush when he is introduced as Mr Internet. He doesn't just drop names - he drops the names of heads of state. Jiang Zemin in China, Kim Jong-Pil in Korea, Vincent Siew in Taiwan, John Howard in Australia, oh, and Tony Blair in Britain.

They got it. Ryutaro Hashimoto in Japan didn't get it and now he's the former prime minister. Get what? The internet economy, of course. What Hashimoto did not get specifically was one of Chambers' many presentational charts. This showed US and Japanese economic growth rates more or less tracking each other before the mid-1990s, when America's rate suddenly took off. "Through the 1980s we all thought Japanese industry had all the answers. But while they were still building out for the [first] industrial revolution the US was starting to build out for the internet revolution. I told him to stop investing in building bridges and battery plants." He didn't listen.

The reason Chambers expects to be listened to is that he is chief executive of the second-biggest company on the planet - by stock market value. This week, as Cisco issued another set of quarterly figures showing dramatic revenue growth, this "tech titan" overtook Jack Welch's General Electric. Cisco is 14 years old and capitalised at $430bn (£270bn).

Shovels for miners

Wall Street suggests Cisco will overtake Microsoft around about May and by the end of the year Chambers could be heading the world's first trillion-dollar corporation.

"It's just a tremendous honour," he says, standing in Building Nine, East Tasman, San Jose, clearly enjoying every moment of his new status. You can see it on the fresh face of this 50 year old who, having served his time as a computer industry executive in the fun-free years of the 70s and 80s at Wang Laboratories and IBM, was parachuted in to Cisco by the venture capital industry in 1993. Within two years he was at the helm of a business producing today's equivalent of shovels for the miners during the 19th century gold rush.

Cisco makes the hardware and software that is the internet's backbone: the routers, switches and other gizmos with indigestible acronyms that allow data to move around our networked world. It shipped its first email router in 1986 and went public in 1990 with revenue at $69m. Ten years on, Cisco is set for a $20bn turnover.

Statistics are the punctuation of Cham ber's high-adrenaline presentations. He uses them to puncture each and every traditional notion of adequate business practice. His company has ballooned from 1,000 employees to about 26,000 in less than 10 years, thanks to the internet. Cisco has transformed the very landscape of northern California. A good portion of San Jose is given over to a company with 35 buildings in the city, spread over 5m square feet - excluding car parking.

"Every company, every country is in transition whether it realises it or not," Chambers says. "I'd like to tell you the reason that this is occurring is because of enlightened leadership, because of global competition, because of organisational changes. But the real reason for this change is survival."

The word "survival" gets the full Chambers treatment - the syllables are dragged out by his soft southern drawl, there's plenty of theatre with his hands and then a twist of the head, to make sure his audience has no excuse for not getting it.

"The second industrial revolution. We started saying that five years ago. People said 'nice marketing, never going to happen'." Nowadays, pilgrims to San Jose don't question things when they are told that the first industrial revolution took 200 years but when historians come to write about the "internet economy" it will have happened in the space of three decades.

This vision thing is not just about business and profits and corporate development. This man wants to change everything. Scrub Mr Internet, this man considers himself Mr Globalisation.

"The point I'm making is that this technology levels the playing field between companies and between countries. We have a chance to change the world here. The majority of countries did not participate in the industrial revolution," Chambers notes, going on to explain that second and third division nations have the chance to leapfrog into the internet age.

By way of illustration, Chambers turns to Cisco's short but eventful corporate experience. "We are the most advanced users of the internet anywhere in the world." He details how the use of networked technology in every aspect of Cisco's business has given the company an edge over its competitors.

"With 26,000 employees we have just two people doing travel expenses. Of 32 [manufacturing] plants worldwide, only two are our own. We have a virtual global plant. The majority of our products are built and shipped to customers without a single Cisco person touching them."

In short, this gives Cisco fatter margins, with annual "savings" put at around $500m. Having posted results this week for the three months to end-January, the company's revenues are rolling higher at an annual rate of 50% and Chambers points out that Cisco's technological development enables it to publish figures just days after the quarter-end. Top managers are able to monitor every inch of the business in detail, more or less in real time.

"Competitors who don't do this will not be competitors in the future."

For Chambers there are three "waves" in the internet revolution. The first is investment in technology and "if you're not already into that you're behind". The second is new applications: the new business models, products and procedures that stem from development of the internet. As for the third wave, it is still "out there on the ocean." He calls it "e-learning".

"It's not quite there yet, just like e-commerce, which wasn't there two years ago. E-learning will be the third way. In this new world there will be empowerment. You will see what you want to learn. You will select what elements you want to have.

"People should be paid on skill sets, rather than on a degree mentality. At Cisco we give stock options and raises for productivity and effort, not for degrees. I have a guy in my office who joined at 17. He's now 19, earning $77,000 a year."

"My message as I travel the world is very simple: are you educating your students for where the jobs were or where the jobs are going to be in the future?" Cisco has set up about 300 "network academies" in Europe, half of them in Britain, and that figure should double over the coming year.

The right time

For the moment, however, the old world of business rather than education is feeling the full force of the internet storm. Chambers runs through a few sector examples - Barnes & Noble versus Amazon.com, CBS versus Yahoo!, Merrill Lynch versus E*Trade - showing how the stock market has rated and rerated these companies' attempts to change their mind-sets. "Every industry, every country. As business leaders get this, then you see it change their behaviour.

"You've got to have the right applications at the right time. If you're too early, say, with e-commerce to the consumer or video on demand or home banking, before the population will accept it, you've built out an infrastructure that's not competitive and you waste the money. But if you're too late you get Amazon-ed or Yahoo-ed or E*Trade-d."

With that, Chambers is in transition - out of Building Nine, into a black Lincoln and away.

The CV

Born: August 23 1949

Status: Married, one son and a daughter

Education: Educated at Duke University and West Virginia University where he read law, and studied business at Indiana University

Employment: Previously with Wang and IBM. Joined Cisco in 1993. Became president and chief executive in January 1995.

Enjoys: Jogging. Playing tennis with his wife. Never misses the annual family fishing trip with father and son - both named John.

webTitle: Americans are coming to teach us the net

fields.headline: Americans are coming to teach us the net
fields.standfirst:
Cisco sets up London mission
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: American evangelism has never gone down big in little old England, or Britain, or continental Europe, for that matter. But the latest strain - lets call it e-Gawd - is crossing the Atlantic nevertheless. And both the empirical and anecdotal evidence says this is a particularly virulent variety.
fields.body:
American evangelism has never gone down big in little old England, or Britain, or continental Europe, for that matter. But the latest strain - lets call it e-Gawd - is crossing the Atlantic nevertheless. And both the empirical and anecdotal evidence says this is a particularly virulent variety.

Companies such as Cisco Systems, a $430bn (£270bn) networking colossus, do not just want to change the way we shop or bank or do business.

The plan now is to get involved in running the British government. This is not a joke. In a few weeks time, Cisco will appoint a head of European governmental affairs who will be based in London. His or her mission will not be to flog exotica such as "local area network" kits to hard-pressed Whitehall departments. Instead it will be to make sure that governments across the continent "get" the internet economy.

As far as the new titans of Silicon Valley are concerned, this will involve a revolution in the way that governments communicate with their subjects - a move to e-democracy which will heal what Cisco's head of legal and government affairs, Dan Scheinman, described this week as "this disintermediation thing that's been going on post-cold war".

As far as politics goes, he has no doubt that the internet will prove more important than television.

The immediate plan of action is to get broadband into houses - to make sure that homes are properly wired up with digital subscriber line technology or optical cable so that the country is fully networked.

And Mr Scheinman and his peers around San Jose see it as their job to press governments into making sure that the right regulatory structure is in place to allow this to happen. A basic lack of government intervention is seen as having been critical to Silicon Valley's extraordinary success over the past few years and its business leaders believe they have a good story to sell.

It is claimed that "winning" in Europe as well will not be about money or resources, but about "the power of ideas".

There is an acceptance of the fact that there will always be some scepticism at the sound of an American accent - but there is a determination to "educate people" nevertheless. Britain is seen as an ideal place to start, since our own prime minister, Tony Blair, already "gets" it.

A more cynical view might be to suggest that, instead of altruism, this e-democracy thing has rather more to do with Cisco and other Californian commercial giants making sure that their businesses remain intact.

There is no need to look at stock market ratings - which just make the mind boggle - to see the footprint of these firms. They are too big to be taken over by a competing firm, but they are not too big to be taken apart by an angry regulator.

Cisco itself has actually scarred a good portion of the landscape around San Jose, with acre after acre of identikit buildings surrounded by mile after mile of parking lot. Yet the employee satisfaction count appears extraordinarily high. Annual staff turnover is below 10%, although this probably has more than a little to do with those things called stock options. Any Cisco employee who has been with the company for four years is now a paper dollar millionaire. And Dee Sutton on the reception at building nine, East Tasman, can tell you the current stock price as quick as she can point you to the restroom.

Outside Cisco's offices, the story is the same. Cab drivers plying Highway 101, running all the way south from San Francisco can recite the opening day IPO performance of every office block along the road. The paper fortunes are everywhere.

But this week this "feel wealthy" factor was punctured, albeit for just a moment, by what are being described as "denial of service attacks" - the acts of cyber-vandalism which have put the likes of Yahoo, ETrade and CNN.com out of the action. After three days of anonymous action, it is said that a new threat to the integrity of the internet has emerged in the form of internet chat room users furiously discussing who might be responsible. A virtual finger has been pointed at just about everyone from the corporate victims themselves, to stock market manipulators and even elements of the American government - with the FBI allegedly looking to extend its cyber-powers.

One apparently credible theory points to an underground group called Caps - Californian Pro-Smokers - with all nicotine addicts in the state forced to leave their drinks at the bar and step outside onto the street if they want to light up.

There is little doubt that if evidence does emerge about who is responsible, there will be a public lynching - so long as a tree can still be found standing in San Jose.

webTitle: M. Gerbeau and his dome of doom

fields.headline: M. Gerbeau and his dome of doom
fields.standfirst:
The Guardian's story about his qualifications is far from flattering
The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: Six weeks into the new millennium, and the dome experience has been bleak for New Labour. Jennie Page, the chief executive, has been sacked, the scapegoat for the mistakes of two ministers, Peter Mandelson and Charles Falconer.
fields.body:
Six weeks into the new millennium, and the dome experience has been bleak for New Labour. Jennie Page, the chief executive, has been sacked, the scapegoat for the mistakes of two ministers, Peter Mandelson and Charles Falconer.

The business world has been stunned. Many chief executives are holding their breath, hoping that the idea of firing someone for just one month's bad figures does not catch on.

Just when you thought it couldn't get any worse, the Guardian produces a far from flattering story about the qualifications of the new chief executive, Pierre-Yves Gerbeau.

He's jetted in from Disneyland Paris in a desperate ministerial bid to save some bacon from this pig of a project. He has no wish to change any of the zones, but is considering cutting the entrance prices.

That gives everyone who was thinking of going to the dome an excellent reason to put it off.

Regenerating brownfields in a bend of the river near some of the world's most beautiful buildings at Greenwich was a good idea. The dome itself is an exciting space, full of potential.

But you are not allowed to go by car. At £20 for each adult on top of the train and tube fares, it is a big outlay if you are coming from far away, and difficult to get to even if you are closer. If it is going to cost you more than £200 for a family of four and involve several hours travelling each way, it's got to be worth it.

The dome was over-hyped. A government which has lived on burnished reflections of itself in polished, friendly newspaper stories was suddenly made to look unpopular and foolish.

Some came to see the whole dome story as a political allegory. In advance of the opening there was a bravura performance of presentation and hype. The spirit zone was something of an afterthought and had to be filled up at the last minute. It seemed as if the organisers had to be reminded that the calendar we were celebrating was a Christian one.

At the opening a whole series of politically correct messages were sent of New Britain. Christianity took second place to 60s pop and a new kind of monarchy held hands with the prime minister. It was neither socialist nor traditional.

After the opening people felt let down, disappointed, not sure promises had been delivered, not sure they had enjoyed it all as much as they were told they had. The river of fire, one of the big events, was apparently invisible to those who turned out to watch it. Fortunately it had been captured by a lonely cameraman far away on the Post Office tower, so the fees could be paid.

There were poignant contrasts between the way the cabinet had travelled to and from their party, and the way the rest of us were treated.

Someone of ministerial rank now needs to get a grip and issue new instructions to M. Gerbeau, the Disney arrival, on what they want.

If they want the dome to rival the strap-hanging, stomach-churning excitement of Alton Towers, Blackpool Leisure Beach or Thorpe Park, they need to put in an exciting ride or two. If they want it to rival the information and interest of the Science or Natural History museums, they need to rewrite the scripts and beef up the zones.

If they want to use their man from the magic kingdom to good effect they should tell him to lift the standards of housekeeping and service to those of American Disney. At the moment the dome is not part of the have-a-nice-day culture: it's mired in we've-had-our-day attitudes. It needs to be cleaner, sharper, more fun.

After a few minutes in Disney California or Florida even the most hard-bitten cynics can suspend their disbelief. You just want a bigger ice-cream from the Main Street store. You believe in Peter Pan as you go flying over London. The adrenaline flows as you hurtle in the runaway train.

The dome doesn't suspend the disbelief of many an adult, and it can even bore many a child. It needs some magic, more things to do, more excitement. It would also help if they put in a few more eating places, for if visitor numbers do pick up half of them will starve in the resulting food queues.

It's all too like New Labour at the moment. It lets down its natural supporters, and gives its traditional critics a field day. The new French chief executive has taken on more than the task of reviving a flagging leisure facility. He has also to help rescue the "third way", which has turned out to be all spin, no substance, heavily loss making and a bit of a yawn.

John Redwood has just been sacked from the Conservative frontbench team, after the promotion of Michael Portillo. Mark Lawson returns next week

It seemed as if the organisers had to be reminded that the calendar we were celebrating was a Christian one. At the opening a whole series of politically correct messages were sent of New Britain. Christianity took second place to 60s pop and a new kind of monarchy held hands with the prime minister. It was neither socialist nor traditional. After the opening people felt let down, disappointed, not sure promises had been delivered, not sure they had enjoyed it all as much as they were told they had. The river of fire, one of the big events, was apparently invisible to those who turned out to watch it. Fortunately it had been captured by a lonely cameraman far away on the Post Office tower, so the fees could be paid. There were poignant contrasts between the way the cabinet had travelled to and from their party, and the way the rest of us were treated. Someone of ministerial rank now needs to get a grip and issue new instructions to M. Gerbeau, the Disney arrival, on what they want. If they want the dome to rival the strap-hanging, stomach-churning excitement of Alton Towers, Blackpool Leisure Beach or Thorpe Park, they need to put in an exciting ride or two. If they want it to rival the information and interest of the Science or Natural History museums, they need to rewrite the scripts and beef up the zones. If they want to use their man from the magic kingdom to good effect they should tell him to lift the standards of housekeeping and service to those of American Disney. At the moment the dome is not part of the have-a-nice-day culture: it's mired in we've-had-our-day attitudes. It needs to be cleaner, sharper, more fun. After a few minutes in Disney California or Florida even the most hard-bitten cynics can suspend their disbelief. You just want a bigger ice-cream from the Main Street store. You believe in Peter Pan as you go flying over London. The adrenaline flows as you hurtle in the runaway train. The dome doesn't suspend the disbelief of many an adult, and it can even bore many a child. It needs some magic, more things to do, more excitement. It would also help if they put in a few more eating places, for if visitor numbers do pick up half of them will starve in the resulting food queues. It's all too like New Labour at the moment. It lets down its natural supporters, and gives its traditional critics a field day. The new French chief executive has taken on more than the task of reviving a flagging leisure facility. He has also to help rescue the "third way", which has turned out to be all spin, no substance, heavily loss making and a bit of a yawn. John Redwood has just been sacked from the Conservative frontbench team, after the promotion of Michael Portillo. Mark Lawson returns next week

fields.headline: The Wap phone
fields.standfirst:
What it is and how it will change our lives
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: What it is and how it will change our lives.
fields.body:
Mobile phones linked up to the internet are expected to be the "killer" consumer product of the early part of the century, providing mass access to the world wide web from your pocket. Last year 96% of the devices surfing the internet were attached to personal computers. Within a few years mobile phones based on an internationally agreed standard (Wap - wireless application protocol) are expected to oust PCs to become the most popular way of surfing the web, although PCs will still be first choice for heavy applications such as documents, spreadsheets and video.

Wireless has been rescued from obscurity by technological breakthroughs that will soon give mobile phones enough "bandwidth," or capacity, for two-way transmission of anything from voice to video almost instantaneously.

Four ways they will change your lifestyle

1. Email and its little sister, short messaging system (SMS), will move from a mi nority sport to a way of life, enabling users to communicate anywhere in the world. When practically everyone in the country can email (it has already happened in Finland) the phone becomes an extension of yourself. It will change the way the whole nation communicates.

2. Entertainment you can buy theatre tickets, book restaurants or place bets from anywhere, charged to your telephone account, or have the main news items of the day delivered to you on the hour. Wap will also create another goldmine for the under-reported kings of the web - the porn merchants.

3. Shopping you can order a meal or that nearly forgotten birthday present on the way home or join an online auction from a beach in the south of France.

4. Money you can examine your bank account, buy and sell shares, check stock market prices or make payments online without moving from your armchair. And maybe even make a phone call.

webTitle: Lib Dems tell dome minister to 'come clean on PYgate'

fields.headline: Lib Dems tell dome minister to 'come clean on PYgate'
fields.standfirst: The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrats last night called on Lord Falconer to "come clean" about his role in the appointment of Pierre-Yves Gerbeau to save the Millennium Dome, as the Disney organisation tried to distance itself from its former executive.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats last night called on Lord Falconer to "come clean" about his role in the appointment of Pierre-Yves Gerbeau to save the Millennium Dome, as the Disney organisation tried to distance itself from its former executive.

Norman Baker, the Lib Dem dome spokesman, called for a Commons debate on "PYgate" and the circumstances of the sacking of Jennie Page as the dome's chief executive, after it emerged that Lord Falconer, minister for the dome, told sponsors "the saviour of Disneyland Paris" was taking over.

"Mr Gerbeau is in the merde," Mr Baker said, "and he is dragging everyone else in fast. This is a ridiculous situation and we need answers now. The dome is fast becoming an albatross round the government's neck."

He has tabled Commons questions demanding "who identified Mr Gerbeau as a potential new chief executive, and what checks were undertaken concerning his background and previous employment?"

Lord Falconer's spokeswoman said: "These questions shall be answered in due course."

Disneyland Paris, where Mr Gerbeau, 34, worked from 1991 to 1998 as a manager and later as one of 40 directors of operations, refused to confirm his claims that he was a vice-president of the theme park.

"We do not want to talk about PY any more," its spokeswoman told the Guardian. "He no longer works for the company. Please stop calling us."

A dome spokesman said: "Disney does not want to bring any more unwanted publicity on itself; that's why they seem to be pulling back."

He added that Mr Gerbeau's mentors - Gilles Pelisson, head of the theme park, and his predecessor Philippe Bourguignon - had come in for some flak for their outspoken support of their protege.

"A lot of people within the organisation are asking why they went out on a limb for someone now working for a rival. Well, they did it because they really believe in PY."

Mr Bourguignon had described Mr Gerbeau as "one of the most talented young executives I have ever met".

Despite repeated requests, the New Millennium Experience Company has been unable to provide written confirmation of Mr Gerbeau's appointment as a vice-president. "Disney had a very flat structure," the dome spokesman said. "It may seem confusing to the outside world, but inside the company he was a director and outside he was a vice-president."

Several of his former colleagues at Disneyland insisted he was only a director of operations.

Mr Gerbeau faces the first big test of his new regime today when rival boycotts threaten a hoped-for record turnout of 25,000 visitors at the Greenwich attraction. Several schools are staying away because of an unofficial Gay Day organised by the London Gay Men's Chorus.

The gay rights activist Peter Tatchell has called for a counter-boycott after accusing the NMEC of "blatant bigotry" by warning the schools about the Gay Day.

Meanwhile, a number of dome designers claim they still have not been paid for their work. Park Avenue Productions, which came up with the Planet Zone, said it was owed over £1m, although the dome had made one payment in the past few days.

There was further bad news for the troubled attraction when 93% of the 60,000 viewers who responded to a poll by the BBC's Watchdog programme branded the £790m spent on it "a rip-off". The BBC's telephone system crashed under the pressure of calls.
