webTitle: What the shirt deal is really about

fields.headline: What the shirt deal is really about
fields.standfirst:
United's £30m shirt sponsorship is proof that a revolution in how we will use our mobile phones is on its way
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Manchester United and Vodafone yesterday announced a pioneering sponsorship deal that will allow fans to watch live football matches and buy replica kits through their mobile phones.
fields.body:
Manchester United and Vodafone yesterday gave the clearest indication yet of how technological changes are revolutionising the way the public consumes information and spend its money by announcing a pioneering sponsorship deal that will allow fans to watch live football matches and buy replica kits through their mobile phones. The world's largest mobile phone service provider has agreed a £30m four-year alliance that will see it become United's official shirt sponsor and provide wireless internet services to the club's 12m supporters worldwide.

Although Vodafone believes it will be four years before fans can watch a game live on their mobile, from August fans with Wap (wireless application protocol) phones will be able to receive news and latest scores direct from their handsets.

Analysts say the move is tangible evidence of how mobile internet devices are set to overtake PCs and televisions as the most popular way of accessing information and entertainment.

The first replica kits to bear the Vodafone motif will also be available to buy over the phone.

By the start of the 2002-03 season, when the next generation of mobile phones will be widely available, supporters will be able to watch live footage of the latest Ryan Giggs goals and David Beckham sending-offs. The service will be available worldwide and in dozens of different languages, United's deputy chief executive, Peter Kenyon, said.

"Fans from Stretford to Shanghai will be able to keep up with all the action from Old Trafford 24 hours a day, no matter what language they speak," he said. "All they will have to do is push a button on their phone."

Peter Bamford, chief executive of Vodafone UK, said: "This ground-breaking agreement goes beyond a pure shirt sponsorship and will bring a new range of mobile information services to a loyal massive supporter base."

Shares up

The sponsorship deal is the richest in football history and ends United's 18-year alliance with the Japanese electronics company Sharp. The stock market has long awaited the move - the club's shares have risen by 50% since the start of the year, valuing it at almost £800m.

Analysts predict that it will widen the financial gap between the world's richest football club and its rivals in the UK and overseas. "No other club could have pulled this off," said one analyst. "Only now are we beginning to see the value of the Manchester United brand and its importance as a multi-media asset."

The agreement ends United's 12 month search for a new sponsor. Vodafone beat off competition from Microsoft, Yahoo!, Emirates and British Airways.

The deal is just the latest of a number of new services consumers will have to get used to as mobile phones connect them to the internet. Almost anything that can be digitised into the 1s and 0s of computer code - words, sounds, voices, images and video - can be put on to the internet and downloaded to mobiles in suitably abbreviated form.

The first Wap phones are already on the streets. Swedish giant Ericsson said yesterday there could be 600m mobile phones in use worldwide by 2002, and that may prove to be an underestimate.

Already the new WAP phones can be used to send email, receive news clips, stock market prices or football results, book theatres or restaurants, place bets, check your bank account or to create a direct link to parts of your own website. You can even watch a live mini-map showing traffic jams on the ring road around Paris.

But we have hardly seen anything yet. The technology is about to explode, bringing phones with such huge bandwidth - the amount of data they can receive in a second - that they will be able to send and receive high quality moving pictures and CD-quality sound.

Apart from watching a football match remotely, you could participate in lectures at Harvard from a beach in the south of France, or consult your doctor in his surgery while on holiday. By pointing the miniaturised camera to your open mouth you may be able to give enough data for the doctor to qualm your fears about that mouth ulcer. Or you could check on the babysitter, or an aged relative at home, from a cinema foyer by dialling into the web-camera in your living room. Wap phones will almost certainly make other products redundant, such as the Walkman and the current fad, the MP3 players that download music from the internet. The new mobiles will be able to do more.

The new phones, equipped with tiny global positioning systems, will also know exactly where you are to within a few metres. This will enable restaurants or theatres in the area to win your custom by emailing you special deals (the internet start-up company Lastminute.com is already on some of the new Wap phones). Helsinki is building a virtual model of the city, complete with roads and buildings, one feature of which is that parents will be able to tell exactly where in the city their phone-carrying children are.

For once the digital action is not in the United States but Europe. Finland's Nokia, with 29% of the world mobile phone market, has just rolled out its 7110, to be closely followed by Ericsson, the world's second largest mobile manufacturer, Motorola of the US, and Siemens. Vodafone is British, as is Psion, which is challenging Microsoft to provide the standard operating system for internet phones.

In the end the market will decide which of a bewildering variety of models will win. Some will be light with small screens, able to fit in the pocket, others will have bigger screens and look more like palmtop computers than phones. Others will be worn as part of our clothing. It will be a trade-off between size and convenience.

Why the profitable future of football viewing could be in the hands of fans

webTitle: Shipman struck off GMC doctors' register for 'undermining trust'

fields.headline: Shipman struck off GMC doctors' register for 'undermining trust'
fields.standfirst: Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: Harold Shipman's name was erased from the medical register yesterday, 10 days after the Hyde GP was found guilty of murdering 15 of his patients.
fields.body:
Harold Shipman's name was erased from the medical register yesterday, 10 days after the Hyde GP was found guilty of murdering 15 of his patients. The General Medical Council, which has been criticised for failing to act against him sooner, said he had grossly abused the trust of patients and undermined public trust in doctors.

The speed with which the case was heard by the five-member professional conduct committee was only possible because Shipman's lawyers agreed to waive the usual six week delay between the preliminary hearing and the final public event.

"The committee are appalled by the evidence they have heard. It is abhorrent that Dr Shipman cold-bloodedly murdered 15 of his patients, using his medical skills to do so," said Rodney Yates, who chaired the panel.

"Those patients and their families had placed their trust in him. He grossly abused that trust and in doing so gravely undermined the trust which the public places in the medical profession, in particular their family doctors."

Mr Yates, one of the lay members whose number the GMC has promised to increase in an effort to reassure the public that it intends to protect patients and doctors, said Shipman was "a disgrace to the medical profession and totally unfit to practise medicine".

Shipman's registration was suspended with immediate effect and the erasure will be confirmed in 28 days, unless he appeals. He was placed on interim suspension on Thursday.

Sir Donald Irvine, president of the GMC, said: "Shipman has appalled us with his monstrous crimes. He betrayed his patients and undermined public trust in doctors. Today, I am pleased to say, he has been thrown out of the medical profession."

Presenting the case against Shipman to the committee, Sir James Badenoch QC said: "It is not possible to imagine a more terrible misuse of a doctor's skills and knowledge, nor a worse abuse of the trust placed in a doctor by innocent patients than this practitioner's prolonged and callous campaign of murder.

"It must be obvious that this case very vividly illustrates what is an obvious truth about our society - namely that it is very difficult for anyone to believe that a doctor is deliberately harming the very people whose health and safety his skills and calling are presumed to protect."

Shipman was accused of falsifying prescriptions to feed his own drugs habit in 1975. After evidence from psychiatrists, he was sent a warning letter by the GMC, but no further action was taken. His final employer, the West Pennine health authority, did not know about his conviction and had not asked the GMC whether Shipman had ever come to its notice.

To commit the 15 murders for which he is serving life imprisonment, Shipman again stockpiled drugs, writing illegal prescriptions for morphine. "This suggests a murderer who was studied and efficient in his campaign of death," Sir James said.

A further 160 deaths are now being investigated. "The especially tragic feature of most of his victims' deaths is that without his fatal administrations most or all of them would have gone on to live a good number of years of normal life," Sir James said. "The evidence suggests that he showed a detached indifference to their deaths and to the murderous acts he committed."

Following the Shipman case, the GMC is reviewing its disciplinary procedures and structure in an attempt to bring the regulatory body up to modern standards of efficiency, transparency and openness, in the knowledge that if fundamental changes do not happen fast, the government is likely to intervene.

webTitle: Where the dust from pulverised buildings hangs heavy in the air

fields.headline: Where the dust from pulverised buildings hangs heavy in the air
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: It was the first day of spring in Grozny yesterday. In the middle of Minutka Square, an old Lada drove up and deposited three women on the rubble-strewn street. For several minutes they stood by the car, silenced by their horror. Slowly they turned a full 360 degrees, taking in the damage.
fields.body:
It was the first day of spring in Grozny yesterday. In the middle of Minutka Square, an old Lada drove up and deposited three women on the rubble-strewn street. For several minutes they stood by the car, silenced by their horror. Slowly they turned a full 360 degrees, taking in the damage.

All around, towers of crumbled masonry stood where 12-storey apartment blocks had been, whole chunks of buildings had been tossed into the air and lay abandoned by the roadside. Some structures remained standing, scarred by massive gashes from blasts powerful enough to tear out several floors at once. Other blocks had their facades ripped off, leaving the insides of homes exposed to view.

In every street in every direction, the scene was the same. During a two-hour tour of the city, there was not a single building that remained intact.

Trees had been blown in half, roof rafters snapped in two like matchsticks. Huge potholes along the roads made progress slow. Apart from clusters of soldiers, the streets were almost deserted.

At the heart of the city, the dust from thousands of pulverised buildings hung heavy in the air, glinting in the sunshine.

For those residents who returned yesterday, hoping to see what had become of their homes, there was no escaping the devastation. Bathed in sunlight, Grozny - the glorious trophy seized by Russia last week - lay in total ruins.

For weeks Minutka Square had marked a symbolic landmark in the Russian campaign to seize Chechnya's capital. Seen as a key to the whole city, the square was blasted relentlessly by the Russians.

"If I had been dropped here from the sky, I would never have recognised this place. I've lived here all my life but I can't see anything familiar," Burlyat Altorava said finally.

Pointing to a seven-storey building on one side of the square, Yakha Uspanova identified the flat where she had hoped to find her best friend, Leila, still living. Through the skeleton-like remains of the block, a green flash of paint was visible where the kitchen used to be, a long strip of lino was hanging from the wall at the point where a floor had once been. It was clear that no one could be living there or in any of the buildings that surrounded the square.

The strange sense of calm was broken by the thunderous roar of two passing tanks, driven by young, jubilant soldiers. "Thank you Russia for doing this to us," Ms Uspanova said quietly as they passed.

By the junction of Lenin Avenue and Liberty Square, soldiers in striped T-shirts were manning barricades built from a burned-out car and a strange collection of furniture; one man had brought out his guitar. Others were brandishing cameras as if, slightly dis believing the scale of the devastation they had wrought, they too wanted to record the moment.

One soldier posed next to the bottom half of a statue in the middle of the road. Only the feet and the hemline of a coat remained; it was no longer clear who the monument had been to. A woman, pushing a collection of belongings in a wheelbarrow and clutching her small son by the hand, was crying as she tried to explain something to the soldiers; no one appeared to be taking any notice of her and she walked on through the debris.

It was impossible to estimate how many of Grozny's half a million population had remained through the war. As many as 40,000 were thought to have lived through four months of air strikes and several weeks of virtual siege, sheltering in their cellars. Yesterday some of them took advantage of the relative quiet to collect water from one of the few supply points in the city. Covered in grime after four-months without water, Valery Siderov, 64, said he had been hit on the head by falling masonry in the last intensive assault and was still in shock. "It's been a hellish war," he said. "I wanted to leave but I had no money and nowhere to go.

"The worst thing is that there was nowhere to hide. They kept on bombing the whole city. Nowhere was safe. We were hungry and frightened, but we could do nothing but wait."

Occasionally machine gun fire was audible in the streets. Russian officials say a few hundred rebels remain in the city; the "cleansing" process has begun.

At the police headquarters, officers showed the pile of weapons they had gathered from rebel bases in the city. They were unwilling to display the collection of fighters' corpses, which were brought in at the same time.

Soldiers guarding the doorway to the headquarters stood by a huge panel of graffiti, daubed by a rebel, declaring: "Before, we just slaughtered you. Now we are going to eat you as well."

Yesterday was the first day that a safe corridor was guaranteed to refugees returning to Grozny to search for their relatives. Luisa Tatyeva, 42, a midwife, obtained a pass and drove back to the city with her husband.

Looking at the desolate remains of the city, it is easy to understand why the rebel leaders claimed, as they abandoned the city, that Grozny was no longer worth fighting for. Russia's politicians have already suggested that once Chechnya is fully under their control, the capital will be moved to Gudermes, the next largest city, a few dozen miles to the east.

Ms Tatyeva hoped her family would never return to Grozny. "Why should we?" she asked. "This city has no future."

webTitle: The swan that follows the Leda myth

fields.headline: The swan that follows the Leda myth
fields.trailText: Channel surfing
fields.body:
Poor Reginald Perrin. He cut a sad pin-striped figure as he walked home. Wordsworth Avenue was followed by Tennyson Avenue which was followed by Coleridge Close. A little death at each corner. In The Fall and Rise of Reginald Perrin (BBC2) there was nothing to look forward to, certainly not on television. "In tonight's programme: the reorganisation of British water boards - what does it mean for you? The oil sheikh who's bought Lincolnshire. And polystyrene wine racks - do they cause warts? Next, an award-winning Norwegian comedy about social problems in the tundra."

Reggie turned the off switch. This was before remote controls, and, clearly, at a time when oil sheikh references were topical. It had been a hard day at the office with a crazy boss."I didn't get where I am today," CJ had said earlier, "by wearing underpants decorated with Beethoven." CJ had been conducting an inquest in the office about the underwear of his underlings. The one who comments "Great" in response to everything that CJ says had a big picture of Beethoven on his pants. The one who says "Super" had blue Y-fronts that met with CJ's approval: "Very sensible. A splash of colour but not inconsistent with executive dignity."

Reggie looked benign, trying not to betray his contempt, but with just enough of it peeping through that we could share his real feelings. God, the late Leonard Rossiter was one of the greatest comic actors in British sitcom history. And yet Michael Winner still lives. But enough of such comparisons. What is the point of living when you're a man responsible for an instant puddings sales drive in Schleswig-Holstein?

"I've come about Mr Perrin, doctor," said Reggie's secretary, ogled into a chair by the slimeball behind the desk. "Do you know what's wrong with him?" "Yes I do. Middle-aged exhaustion, boredom, anxiety, self-disgust, misery, insecurity, dislike of industry, dislike of instant pudding, 25-year itch, fear, insecurity, frustration." "What can be done about it?" "I have no idea." Typical: the doctor didn't care about this middle-aged man. Instead he wanted to know if he could examine the secretary to determine if she was "chesty" and asked her to perform some cartwheels for him. But that was the 70s, when sitcom gags that sound like sexual harassment cases waiting to happen were not just tolerable but obligatory.

It's not a surprise, is it, that middle-aged men are so troubled? When they have to stand in the boss's office with their trousers around their ankles. When they have to sell instant puddings for a living. When they have to perform rectal investigations on lower life forms when, frankly, they'd rather not. When they can't sustain meaningful relationships with women for more than a few minutes.

That's right. Rectal investigations. In Beast (BBC1), Simon Nye's unexpectedly delightful sitcom about a veterinary practice, one of the vets had circumscribed the number of species with which he was prepared to work. No more would he deal with ferrets, pythons, yappy or indeed non-yappy dogs. No animals with big stary eyes.

Instead the middle-aged vet decided he would become a pet therapist. It was clean work, involving, so far as he could judge, little more than lying on a couch with a clipboard. "Shouldn't the dog be sitting on the couch?" asked a depressed dog's owner. "I suppose so." They swapped places, but only for a while. What men want, you see, is a little bit of quiet time. Perhaps a doze. "I came in when you were doing a session with the parrot," said the receptionist. "You were asleep." "No I wasn't." "Yes you were."

I wanted the sadly aborted pet therapist storyline to continue for several years. It could have worked, you know. Group sessions with different species, some wild, some tame, some invertebrates, others not.

The problem with pet therapy, though, is that even human psychiatrists are too screwed up to administer the care and attention that animals may well need. In a classically sculpted Frasier (Channel 4), the eponymous hero tried ineptly to woo a gorgeous vet. To do this, Frasier affected to like Eddie, the Jack Russell with the stare and the neat bouncing technique. A difficult task. After all, for six years of TV time Frasier has hated Eddie, partly perhaps because the dog has a lifestyle perfectly well adjusted to his simple needs, something which Frasier, eternally adrift in neurotic mid-life bachelorhood, will never manage.

fields.headline: Eddie's got the answer, Reggie
fields.trailText: Wave riding
fields.body:
Just as I was envisaging the banner headlines about last night's play The Swansong - "Bestiality at the BBC", "Woman Fornicates With Swan On Radio 4" - I remembered the story of Leda and the swan. So this wasn't some surreal attempt to épater les bourgeois, just a reworking of a classical myth. You can get away with anything if it's borrowed from Greek mythology.

There's no doubt that the playwright, David Greig, was having his sport when his Lydia hovered beside an Edinburgh pond with a bottle of gin and plans of suicide only to be befriended by a swan. This swan is immediately distinguished from other swans because it a) swigs from the gin bottle b) takes a drag from her ciggie c) makes love to her, and d) prepares a neat four lines of coke.

The swan sounded remarkably like a secondhand car salesman from Fife. That's because he was a secondhand car salesman from Fife, reincarnated as a swan. If Greig wanted to show how easy it is to suspend disbelief on radio he succeeded, because by the time the two were in a pub on the Lothian Road it was ages before you realised the other drinkers hadn't noticed he was a swan. Maybe they'd suspended disbelief too. It was all without the selfconsciousness we've come to associate with magic realism, so that by the end one accepted it. Greig may have been taking the piss, but he found poetry in the banality of misery.

Elsewhere on Radio 4, in the five short plays celebrating the reopening of the Soho Theatre which made up Soho Stories, there were two ghosts. One ghost might be a tolerable plot device; two suggests a radio cliche. The best of the plays was Tony Marchant's Dinner for Who?, in which a man who'd harassed a young temp at work goes out for a patching-up dinner with his partner only to be served by the aforementioned ex-temp.

But Marchant shaped this less as a tale and more as a series of shifting first person narratives, so that the black driver of an unlicensed cab touting for trade at first seemed menacing but eventually, in a clever ending, was given a personal history. It was a fleet piece of writing about longing and prejudice.

The first play, Sue Townsend's Mr Muscle, about a dead clubber revisiting a friend to remember the night of his death, was broadcast live. Yet though I strained to detect signs of unrecordedness - did the performances have an extra edge of danger? - I could find none. Nowadays you need a glitch to signal live.

On Sunday Service (Radio 5 Live) Charlie Whelan interviewed Malcolm MacLaren in one of the pods of the London Eye. Why were they there, apart from affording the other studio-bound presenters the opportunity to snipe at Whelan (though they manage that perfectly well in the studio) ? All the Eye afforded radio listeners was a background hum, and hearing Whelan extol the views. We, of course, had to imagine them, which we could have done equally well if he'd been in the studio.

Finally, David Mellor's new Classic FM programme, If You Liked That, You'll Like This, is a variant on his old one, Across The Threshold. There he tried to induct celebrities into the world of classical music; here he tries to guide listeners from a popular work towards less familiar parts of the repertoire. It's an admirable aim, and Mellor knows his stuff; it's just that his smug, wooden, humourless style makes you want to hate it. I've already heard some lovely things here - last Sunday, Catalani's opera La Wally - but Mellor being modest isn't one of them.

fields.headline: A sleazy enterprise
fields.standfirst: "The reason people have been abandoning the Lottery in their millions is that they see no prospect of making any money out of it"
fields.trailText: "The reason people have been abandoning the Lottery in their millions is that they see no prospect of making any money out of it
fields.body:
An idol has fallen. Well, not entirely. I work for him. I write a column for his online magazine, Slate, which I don't imagine is widely read in this country, even by enthusiasts for the internet, but which is nevertheless an admirable and entertaining publication. So I still look up to Bill Gates as one tends to look up to anybody who helps with the household bills. And, of course, I am obliged to look up to him as probably the richest person who has ever lived. But as a prophet, as a visionary, as the person who understands the future and will guide us there, Mr Gates suffered a huge blow to his credibility last weekend when he appeared on BBC1's Breakfast With Frost to announce that he was teaming up with Sir Richard Branson to take over the running of the British National Lottery.

I have, by my bed, his book, The Road Ahead, which I haven't actually read but which I keep there, like a holy scripture, for easy reference in a spiritual crisis. But I don't think I will ever consult it now. The man of vision has feet of clay. He has chosen to become part of what the Independent, in a leading article this week, described as "the culture of greed that is seeping through Britain". The Independent rather understated the situation. The culture of greed is not "seeping" through Britain; it is swamping it. The urge to get rich quick without effort has become a national obsession, and its principal manifestation is the National Lottery.

So why should Mr Gates want to be involved in such a sleazy enterprise? He certainly doesn't need the money he will earn if he and Sir Richard manage to wrest the franchise away from Camelot. There has to be some other reason. He told Sir David Frost that it is all part of the vision thing. He intends to improve the technology of the Lottery to make it "a richer experience for the people who want to use it". He explained: "The Lottery terminals in the past have not used PC technology, and there hasn't been a way of leveraging all the things going on with the internet." I don't understand a word of that, but it doesn't sound very visionary to me.

The "richer experience" he promises should probably be understood only in the sense that it will make people literally richer. Sir Richard pledged that a Lottery managed by him and Mr Gates would create a millionaire a day. It would also, he claimed, raise an extra £2 billion for good causes. This, of course, is the entire justification for the Lottery's existence, that it produces money for good causes. Sir Richard says that 12 million people have stopped playing the Lottery under Camelot because they don't think it is sufficiently philanthropic. If people feel that all the profits are going into good causes, then around six million lost customers will return, Sir Richard says.

I wish I could believe that, but I can't say I do. The reason why people have been abandoning the Lottery in their millions is that they see no prospect of making any money out of it. One cannot remain excited forever if one never wins. The advertising slogan "It could be you" was a seductive one to begin with, but most people now feel "It is extremely unlikely to be me". They feel they have a much better chance of getting rich quick by speculating in the shares of internet companies. Sir Richard's promise to create a new millionaire every day will be far more effective in attracting people back to the Lottery than his pledge that all its profits will go to good causes. Gambling is not an altruistic activity. It never has been and it isn't now.

The irony is that Mr Gates did not set out to be fantastically rich. As he explained to Sir David, he had a vision of the future in computer software and singlemindedly pursued it. He didn't have "some number in mind" for the profits he could turn. "I love doing software and, you know, I'm still stunned that it was such a good, good business to be in," he said. He gives away billions of dollars to good causes, such as the vaccination of children against disease. And he has stepped down as chief executive of Microsoft to indulge once again his creative side as the corporation's chief software architect.

So what is he doing messing with the National Lottery? Sir Richard must have charmed him with his vision rhetoric, for Mr Gates is a sucker for visions. I have a vision for him. He should buy the Millennium Dome, which he can easily afford, and turn it into a giant exhibition of the future. He has promised developments in information technology that will "blow people away" in the next couple of years. Let us be blown away now. Let him give the Dome its missing "wow" factor. Then maybe I will believe in him as a prophet again.

Sir Richard's promise to create a new millionaire every day will be far more effective in attracting people back to the Lottery than his pledge that all its profits will go to good causes. Gambling is not an altruistic activity. It never has been and it isn't now. The irony is that Mr Gates did not set out to be fantastically rich. As he explained to Sir David, he had a vision of the future in computer software and singlemindedly pursued it. He didn't have "some number in mind" for the profits he could turn. "I love doing software and, you know, I'm still stunned that it was such a good, good business to be in," he said. He gives away billions of dollars to good causes, such as the vaccination of children against disease. And he has stepped down as chief executive of Microsoft to indulge once again his creative side as the corporation's chief software architect. So what is he doing messing with the National Lottery? Sir Richard must have charmed him with his vision rhetoric, for Mr Gates is a sucker for visions. I have a vision for him. He should buy the Millennium Dome, which he can easily afford, and turn it into a giant exhibition of the future. He has promised developments in information technology that will "blow people away" in the next couple of years. Let us be blown away now. Let him give the Dome its missing "wow" factor. Then maybe I will believe in him as a prophet again.

fields.headline: Underside
fields.trailText: •Something of a seismic shift (© T Blair) has been spotted inside No 11, according to an agent lurking outside the chancellor's official residence a week or so back.
fields.body:
Something of a seismic shift (© T Blair) has been spotted inside No 11, according to an agent lurking outside the chancellor's official residence a week or so back. Without a peep of publicity, Gordon Brown hosted a most agreeable symposium titled Keynes and Full Employment in the 21st Century, seemingly rehabilitating the K-word in polite Labour circles whence it has been banished since 1976.

Rounding up the usual suspects from the Keynesian resistance - Steve Nickell and Richard Layard (LSE), plus Cantab's wholly unreconstructed Bob Rowthorn, Mr Brown then required the entire monetary policy committee to listen to them. This must have been something of an ordeal for most MPC types, given the committee's entire existence is predicated on the conviction that Keynes is a discredited old ninny whose silly ideas caused us no end of trouble.

Charles Bean (also LSE) gave a paper on the difference between Keynesianisms old and new, while the Bank of England's Mervyn King spoke on the differences between the MPC and the US Federal Reserve Board; maybe fed-style semi-laxity is the MPC's fallback position. Anyway, this happy band (we won't describe it as "Gordon Brown's personal think-tank", but you feel free) has promised to meet again at No 11 after the budget.

 Elsewhere in Whitehall, a final, fond farewell to the millennium bug, now destined for the great dustbin of super-scares of yesteryear, along with the "new ice age", the Bermuda triangle and the "doomsday bomb". The office for national statistics tells the world that "because of the low number of companies being affected" it is ending the collection of data on bug-related incidents. The penultimate collection - for the end of January - found 99% of firms suffering no ill-effects whatever. Of those that did, the largest single category was "hotels and restaurants". We thought aeroplanes were supposed to fall from the sky and nuclear plants melt down. Instead, it seems the occasional steak may have been a trifle underdone.

 New technology forges ahead, however, east of Suez, where Hutchison, the mobile telephone company, is making great inroads into the Indian market. Whether it will continue to do so is more doubtful, given that Hutchison has decided to adopt over there the name under which it became famous over here: Orange. Harmless enough in Britain (give or take the occasional chap in a bowler hat) but a potential marketing disaster in the subcontinent, where saffron is the colour of the BJP, the Hindu nationalist party. The future's, er, bright?

 Meanwhile, that bargain-basement Keynesian public works scheme known as the Dome is causing no end of trouble far and wide. Last weekend's resignation by supremo Jennie Page drove her partner in life, Jeremy Orme - ratcatcher-general for the financial services authority - from the house. As the press settled in for a long siege, Mr Orme, who had hoped to catch up on some FSA paperwork, was forced to drive his car way away into open country, where he set up a temporary office.

 Elsewhere in the legal field, the Law Society is getting with the information age. A web page is under construction, but already looks very pretty, carrying the society's imposing crest and a little emblem showing a man at work. Rather, it would look very pretty were it not that an individual who was clearly disgruntled with the society's discharge of its regulatory functions has posted an e-flyer on the page, warning that: "The Law Society is the trade body which represents English solicitors ... You will get little help and a great deal of obfuscation." Surely not?

 Finally, we recommend Ranald Michie's excellent book The London Stock Exchange (Oxford;1999) for the lurid light it throws on the practices of the pre-war City. For instance: "An investigation by the stock exchange ... in 1930 uncovered the fact that a member, Cyril James, was involved in share-pushing, whereby investors were recommended to buy shares through false reports of a company's prospects in newspapers like British Industry and Finance." Furthermore, the Economist of November 10, 1928 warned against "repeated oversubscription of speculative issues, the attraction of whose deferred shares as gambling counters were more regarded by the public than their merits as an investment." None of that sort of thing nowadays, thank heaven.

fields.headline: Commons roll of dishonour
fields.standfirst: Life in parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Four Labour MPs have been suspended from the Commons since the election and Teresa Gorman would be the first Tory.
fields.body:
Four Labour MPs have been suspended from the Commons since the election and Teresa Gorman would be the first Tory.

Islwyn MP Don Touhig was suspended for three days and forced to quit as a parliamentary aide to the chancellor Gordon Brown after receiving a leaked social security committee report.

Kali Mountford, MP for Colne Valley, was suspended for five days for handing the report to Mr Touhig.

Liverpool West Derby MP Robert Wareing was suspended for a week for failing to register payments from an overseas firm with links to Serbia.

And Dundee West MP Ernie Ross was suspended for 10 working days after leaking a confidential draft of a critical committee report on the arms to Africa scandal to the foreign secretary, Robin Cook.

All were also censured by the all-party Commons privileges and standards committee.

Other cases considered in this parliament include Geoffrey Robinson for his business dealing and William Hague's failure to disclose the free use of Lord Archer's gym.

Both were reprimanded but Peter Mandelson escaped without censure despite a highly critical report from Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary standards commissioner, into his £373,000 cheap home loan from Mr Robinson.

The worst case considered was that of Neil Hamilton, the former Tory MP for Tatton, despite the fact that he had lost his seat in the 1997 election.

webTitle: Teresa Gorman faces ban from Commons

fields.headline: Teresa Gorman faces ban from Commons
fields.standfirst:
Tories in opposition: special report

Life in parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Teresa Gorman faces being suspended from the Commons without pay, after it emerged last night that fellow MPs are on the verge of censuring the maverick rightwinger.
fields.body:
Teresa Gorman faces being suspended from the Commons without pay, after it emerged last night that fellow MPs are on the verge of censuring the maverick rightwinger.

The all-party standards and privileges committee is about to finalise a "damning" report on her, said one member.

The outspoken Ms Gorman is accused of failing to register all her business interests, and of misleading Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary standards commissioner.

She was forced to apologise to the Commons last May for failing to register her ownership of two bedsit houses in Streatham, south London.

Ms Filkin had asked, "for the sake of completeness", whether Ms Gorman owned "any land or property, other than any home used for [the Gorman's] personal residential purposes, which has a substantial value or from which substantial income is derived."

Ms Gorman told Ms Filkin that she received no money, but former tenants of the two bed-sit houses have since alleged that they paid rent to the Billericay MP and her husband, Jim.

The committee's report is expected to be finalised by next Tuesday, or on February 22, with publication likely two days after it is agreed. The eight-month inquiry, which began last June, was extended to cover her alleged overseas business interests.

One MP close to the case said: "It's the most serious issue we have dealt with since the election. Teresa is not going to be happy."

Since the general election, Labour MPs Kali Mountford, Don Touhig, Robert Wareing and Ernie Ross have been suspended from the Commons for between three and 10 days on the committee's recommendations. Ms Gorman, who is standing down at the next election, would be the first Tory suspension, though a number of others have been rebuked, including William Hague for failing to declare his free use of Jeffrey Archer's gym for judo practice.

The threat of suspension was one of the reasons she failed to make the Tory shortlist for mayor of London after Lord Archer's resignation.

Ms Gorman, who appeared before the committee with her solicitor last month, has spent a five-figure sum on defence.

Yesterday the Eurosceptic, who has been courted by the UK Independence party, said she would refuse to answer "any more irrelevant questions". She said she had abided by parliamentary rules, but her "innocent explanations" were being ignored.

She said the process would remain unfair until recommendations by Lord Neill's committee on standards in public life, including a right of appeal and financial aid for defence, were implemented.

Mrs Gorman is one of Westminster's most colourful characters but has been dogged by controversy.

In 1994 it emerged that she had bought a house next door to her own, in Lord North Street, from Westminster council and sold it at a profit.

A year later she was accused of altering without permission her listed Tudor constituency home in Orsett. She and her husband were each fined £3,000 and forced to remove a porch and fill in two windows.

webTitle: Self-made maverick who just loathes Europe

fields.headline: Self-made maverick who just loathes Europe
fields.standfirst:
As Teresa Gorman faces a ban from the Commons, the Tory live-wire for Billericay faces another test of her unshakeable self-belief.

Life in parliament: special report

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: As Teresa Gorman faces a ban from the Commons, the Tory live-wire for Billericay faces another test of her unshakeable self-belief.
fields.body:
In an era of increasingly grey Westminster lobby fodder, Teresa Gorman is a true maverick.

A rightwinger who shivers with horror at the mere mention of the word "Europe", the Tory MP is never short of an outrageous quote. She said yesterday: "I hope you're not ringing about asylum seekers or the age of consent. I've already given them."

Whether defending ticket touts or demanding a Christmas boycott of mistletoe, Mrs Gorman has had her say. And besides achieving ubiquity on the TV news, she has appeared on the Mrs Merton Show, Call My Bluff, Through the Keyhole and Have I Got News For You. When she wrote a book on the battle against Europe, Mrs Gorman called it "The Bastards" to revel in John Major's abusive description of the Eurosceptics who tore apart his cabinet.

In the book, the MP for Billericay in Essex tells how, as one of the Westminster Nine fanatics who lost the Tory whip and threatened Mr Major's majority, she was confronted by two male colleagues. "A woman's place is in the home," snarled one, and the other added: "Yes, flat on her back. Do you think Teresa would be any good on her back? I wonder what sort of knickers she wears?"

She complained about the pair to the whips and recorded with satisfaction how they were reprimanded and afterwards would cut her dead.

The daughter of a London labourer who started his own demolition company, she caught diptheria at the age of two and afterwards claimed that her mother kept her alive with fizzy lemonade.

She left school in Fulham at 16, went to teacher training college, got married, taught for 10 years, and then decided to study zoology at London university. Leaving with a first class degree, she was inspired by the enterprise encountered on a holiday in the United States to set up her own firm making teaching aids, reaching a £1m turnover. She also created an alliance of small firms and the self employed, and for four years, until 1986, she served on Westminster city council.

She stood for parliament against the Conservatives in Streatham, London, in 1974 on a Eurosceptic ticket, before joining the party the year after -although it took her a dozen attempts to get a safe seat. Her breakthrough came in 1987, when she won Billericay after the sitting Tory, Harvey Proctor, was forced to step down after being caught in a rent boy spanking scandal.

Mrs Gorman, now aged 68, admitted that her gender, for once, had helped rather than hindered her prospects - though she later confessed to having knocked 10 years off her date of birth to appear fortysomething.

"The average selection committee doesn't want a woman; it wants a man of 35 in a neat business suit with an obedient, attractive wife and two nice children," she said.

Earlier she had helped set up the Amarant Trust to promote hormone replacement therapy and boasted it had rejuvenated her life. Her second Commons speech was on the subject, and she endured the taunt of a Labour backbencher: "She's got more hormones in her than a Christmas turkey."

Yet the outspoken backbencher will be best remembered for her Eurosceptism. She used the Maastricht treaty to launch an assault on everything European. One Christmas she gave up kissing under the mistletoe "even if it does mean a little less intimacy" and called for a boycott because there was none from Britain on sale.

Boundary changes and Essex man's decision to desert the Tories slashed Mrs Gorman's majority at the last election to 1,356 from nearly 20,000.

She recently declared that she would stand down at the next election, proclaiming: "I would like to travel, I love America, and I may want to set up a chain of businesses."

She has described William Hague as a "pre-pubescent marshmallow" in love with himself. However, self-adoration is also a Gorman trait and she described herself as "baffled and bewildered" just before Christmas when blocked from seeking the party's nomination for London mayor.

A connection between her disloyalty and the investigation into her business affairs, and the failure to get on the shortlist, appeared never to cross her mind.

Mrs Gorman's belief in Mrs Gorman is unshakeable.

In her view...

Tory gays...

"Of course the party is full of gay men because they've come up through public school... if you live in an ambience almost entirely male it's inevitable that you get quite a high level of sexual experiment amongst the boys..."

The fire service...

"One of the last of the dinosaur industries clinging to feather bedding...The Algarve is stuffed with healthy young British males living comfortably, their incomes supplemented by disablement pensions."

William Hague's prospects...

"We assume many seats Labour won were Tory marginals we can win back, but I don't think we can bet on that."

Emma Bonino, former European fisheries commissioner...

"Every time I hear her I want to give her a slap round the ear with a wet herring."

fields.headline: Regional pride.
fields.standfirst: "London can't even create the thing it was synonymous with - pop music - any more. When was the last great London sound?"
fields.trailText: "London can't even create the thing it was synonymous with - pop music - any more. When was the last great London sound?"
fields.body:
As time goes on, and as I see more of this country, I often get the feeling that it is less of a "land" than it used to be, and far more of a collection of small countries just waiting to break away. Perhaps the idea of devolution for Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland has made each part of England think about its specialness, too; perhaps it is a fear of being blanded out into one, big, soulless Euro-portion by Brussels that makes us cleave to local custom. And perhaps this is why commentators are having trouble finding the "real" England; perhaps there isn't going to be one for much longer, but just the North, and the South, and the West, and the East.

What exactly does a pig farmer in Cornwall have in common with an estate agent in Cheshire or a night-club dancer in Hammersmith, anyway? Vitally, and unlike almost every other nation, Britain does not have a collective chip on its shoulder holding it together; we had it all, and we let it go. Far from being a so-called "young" country, we are probably the most mature country there is, for good or ill; we don't go around panicking about being dissed like France or the US, and we look back in languor and amazement at our glorious past. It's not the worst way to be at all - but it does mean we lack a set of grievances to rally around.

I'm not immune from this. As I get older, I find that, more and more, I yearn to hear the accent of my calf country, the South-west of England. More than any other, we are the people of England that have never spoken yet, and still do not, unless you count the "Ooo- arr-Ambrosiar!" advert. (Growing up, my only West Country role model was Cadbury's Caramel bunny.)

For years as a London-dweller I kidded myself that The Archers was set in the South-west, but my Sunday-morning fix went the way of all flesh when I could block out no longer the fact that the Aldridges were always "popping into Birmingham" to see a ballet. I always forget how rarely the West Country accent is heard in the media until I go back and am surrounded by its lapping, quizzical sinuousness. I'm amazed when people find it odd or unattractive.

When my Dartington-educated friend recently accompanied me home for my mother's funeral, I noticed she was talking far less than usual, and this is a girl who could talk for England. She admitted she couldn't understand the Bristol accent, and had been terrified of responding to a question the wrong way ("Isn't it awful about Julie's mum?" - "Mmm, yes, super!"). At first I thought this incredible; then I thought, well, where would she hear it?

The broadcasting media is alive with the buzz of Scots and the burble of Irish, but where is the West, or Birmingham, or Newcastle? It's not just that the West Country voices lack the "authority" to read the news; anyone watching Casualty will be surprised to find that Nurse Lisa Duffin, played by Cathy Shipton, started life with a strong Bristol accent, which she was told to lose as viewers couldn't understand it. This would be insulting in any circumstances; considering Casualty is set and filmed in Bristol, it is downright surreal. Imagine the producers of EastEnders telling black or Asian characters to speak proper English because no one could understand them!

It was I who first coined the word Capitalist (big C) to describe one who worships and fetishises London, and I was more than guilty of this myself during the 70s and 80s. But even then, when I went home to Bristol I was struck by the absolute lack of interest in London among even my liveliest and smartest Bristol friends. London was less than two hours on the train but might as well have been in Australia; they weren't frightened of it, but saw it as a place where people went who couldn't make it in Bristol! I got the impression that they considered London to be a city of whores - artistic, financial and sexual, more to be pitied than envied. I don't think they were far wrong.

If anything, it's got worse; London can't even create the thing it was synonymous with - pop music - any more. In the 60s and 70s, London either produced its own great pop groups - the Who, the Kinks, the Small Faces - or drew the best work from those provincials who moved there - the Beatles. When was the last great London sound? And how easily the wild northern boys are ruined by its siren song. The last albums by the once great Pulp and Oasis might just as well both have been called "London", because that is surely what they're like: sound and fury, signifying nothing, all sucked dry.

"Perhaps you'll come home now?" - the neighbours still say that to me, even after 23 years away. For the first time, their question makes more sense than my answer. More and more, I see my whole flight from my hometown to the capital as some sort of disorder, albeit one that plagues young people all over the world the moment hormones and ambition kick in. Politics and media in these islands are dominated by Scots who live in Islington and believe that every place in between doesn't matter a heap of beans; you're not telling me that's healthy.

I don't think I could ever go home for good, but I can carry my home with my voice: better Minnie Mouse from Ooo-Arr country than the Talking Clock lady and gent any day of the week. To people of the regions, the banal pronunciation that passes as the English norm conjures up all the glamour and glory of the drab couple in the weather house. After 23 years in the media, and to some extent the public eye, I'm still amazed that people are so amazed at the way I talk. How is a journalist "meant" to talk - like a cosseted Oxbridge spawn whose Daddy was in the Cabinet and Mummy a minor aristo? Should I have realised while young that my accent was "wrong", as Sue Lawley and Joan Bakewell did, and changed it for something more Sanderson?

Yes, I am from the western English working class. No, my name is not Lawson, Wyatt or Coren. Yes, I made it all by myself, with no old-school network and no trust-fund safety net. No, I have never had to wait for a parent to die or for a spouse to surrender worldly goods in a divorce court, because I made and spent my own first million by the endeavour of my own brain and hands (well, middle finger of right hand) before I was 35. Yes, I love my voice, because it speaks to me of all these things and of someone who is resourceful, unbowed, original and, above all, untamed. Would I swap it for a received pronunciation job, modulated and acceptable and like every other godawful boring journalist's voice? I'd rather have my tongue cut out.

fields.headline: Union of mouse operatives
fields.trailText: Your piece about trade unionists and the internet (Unions signal rise of the cyber picket, February 10) paints a very negative picture, focusing almost entirely on conflict and disputes. You ignore the fact that many unions - mine included - are making far greater use of the internet in a positive way.
fields.body:
Your piece about trade unionists and the internet (Unions signal rise of the cyber picket, February 10) paints a very negative picture, focusing almost entirely on conflict and disputes. You ignore the fact that many unions - mine included - are making far greater use of the internet in a positive way: in 1999 my union concluded what may well have been the first pay deal negotiated entirely over the internet and transatlantic phone lines.

We have a group of members in Aylesbury whose employer is based in New York. After an initial teleconference we used email to negotiate with the employer, consult our members and accept the offer. The five-hour time difference was not a problem, and the deal was settled far more quickly than would otherwise have been possible.

The internet also provides recruitment opportunities - through our website we can tell non-members about the benefits of joining our union, and as a direct result we receive a steady stream of application forms. And we use the internet to improve communication with our members - through the private members-only area of our site we can update them on key issues on a daily basis.

To suggest the internet is only of benefit for unions in industrial disputes is about as accurate as your hackneyed your view that all trade unionists wear donkey jackets.
Paul Noon
General secretary, Institution of Professionals, Managers and Specialists www.ipms.org.uk

fields.headline: Net Nazis
fields.trailText: As I speak German, I understand a fair amount of the Austrian Freedom party's website (Diary, February 11). Most of it is pretty standard stuff, hailing the election victory and so on, but under the links section I was sickened to discover links to other sites like the Ku Klux Klan.
fields.body:
As I speak German, I understand a fair amount of the Austrian Freedom party's website (Diary, February 11). Most of it is pretty standard stuff, hailing the election victory and so on, but under the links section I was sickened to discover links to other sites like the Ku Klux Klan, National Socialist Graphics, the Front National in France and, most shockingly of all, a link to a web site dedicated to neo-Nazi music, with titles like Murdersquad, Holocaust 2000, and White Victory. I can only conclude that this is a spoof website created by someone with a very juvenile sense of humour. But if this is the party's official site, then Europe really does have something to worry about.
Jo Farmer
Strasbourg, France
jo.farmer@coe.int

fields.headline: DVD moves
fields.trailText: You write that "a 16-year-old was arrested for allegedly creating and distributing a programme which enables the piracy of DVD movies" (FBI and multinationals no match for 100,000 hackers, February 10). In fact Jon Johansen's software, DeCSS, does no such thing.
fields.body:
You write that "a 16-year-old was arrested for allegedly creating and distributing a programme which enables the piracy of DVD movies" (FBI and multinationals no match for 100,000 hackers, February 10). In fact Jon Johansen's software, DeCSS, does no such thing. It enables the decryption of encrypted DVDs, but it is not necessary to decrypt a DVD to make a copy of it. DVD piracy is non-existent due to the scarcity of hardware and the price of blank media. What DeCSS does do is prevent the DVD consortium from being uniquely able to sell the ability to produce DVD players, a power they wish to keep since it is a licence to print money.
Gareth Owen
Newcastle-Under-Lyme, Staffs

fields.headline: Heroes and villains
fields.trailText: A heroic bid for freedom, involving the commandeering of a rickety plane from under the noses of armed guards, using the feint of a family wedding and travelling across half the globe to flee from an oppressive, brutal, fundamentalist regime is surely the stuff of a Hollywood movie (Straw hard line on hostages, February 11). Of course if the "heroes" are not western whites, but Afghans, they are afforded no such glamour and instead are heaped with vicious opprobrium by Widdecombe and Straw.
fields.body:
A heroic bid for freedom of biblical ambition, involving the commandeering of a rickety plane from under the noses of armed guards, photogenic children, using the feint of a family wedding and travelling across half the globe to flee from an oppressive, brutal, fundamentalist regime which treats women worse than slaves - is surely the stuff of a Hollywood movie (Straw hard line on hostages, February 11). Of course if the "heroes" are not western whites, but Afghans, they are afforded no such glamour and instead are heaped with vicious opprobrium by Widdecombe and Straw.
Simon Gardner
Leighton Buzzard, Beds

 Is there any chance Mr Straw could accompany the hostages back to Afghanistan? I hear the rulers have some interesting ideas on law and order that he might learn about at first hand. On his way back he might try the treatment we mete out to asylum seekers.
Dr Kimon Roussopoulos
Cambridge
kimon@kimon.demon.co.uk

 Do the asylum seekers know that they would be required to share this small island with Ann Widdecombe?
John Ratty
Llangollen

 I'm tired of hearing scapegoated Jenny Page referred to as "bossy" and schoolmarmish (Rollercoaster ride of Disney whizz kid, February 11). If she had been male, it would have been "decisive and single-minded".
Mary Scott
Aberdeen

 Are the dome sponsors, disappointed they have acquired PY Gerbeau rather than Philippe Bourguignon, entitled to ask "where's the beef?"
Peter Barnes
Milton Keynes

 Is there a person credited with turning the millennium wheel around?
Andy Mash
London

fields.headline: A stake in Hammer's heart
fields.trailText: How disappointing to read that Charles Saatchi has plans for a Hammer horror TV series and a remake of the classic films (Saatchi plans new Hammer horror, February 8). This would not be such a bad thing were it not for the fact that his interest lies in "cashing in" on the current popularity of the horror genre.
fields.body:
How disappointing to read that Charles Saatchi has plans for a Hammer horror TV series and a remake of the classic films (Saatchi plans new Hammer horror, February 8). This would not be such a bad thing were it not for the fact that his interest lies in "cashing in" on the current popularity of the horror genre. Even more disturbingly the American teen horror film is being used as an example.

Had I to choose styles of film broadly within the same genre for comparison, I would be hard pushed to find any two so completely at odds. As Fiachra Gibbons rightly points out, what made the Hammer horrors a success were "creaky sets and creakier scripts"; the teen horror genre, though not necessarily bad, is pure Hollywood, filled with beautiful people and a million-dollar budget: it is not difficult to see where the two differ.

The Hammer horrors were so bad they were good and if Saatchi has plans to remake them in the tone of Hollywood horror then I fear the films will become so good they're bad. To remake these films today seems pointless. When Hammer was in its prime, the genre was new and innovative. Now it is hard to find a film that does not incorporate the horror film or one of its many sub-genres. Saatchi and his consortium should leave well alone.
SJ Hall
London

fields.headline: Pet hate
fields.trailText: Catherine Bennett's story about Barbie, the hamster who was sucked into a vacuum cleaner, is illustrated with a photograph of a guinea pig, not a hamster (G2, February 10). As an expert in this field, I must point out that there is a world of difference between the two.
fields.body:
Catherine Bennett's story about Barbie, the hamster who was sucked into a vacuum cleaner, is illustrated with a photograph of a guinea pig, not a hamster (G2, February 10). As an expert in this field, I must point out that there is a world of difference between the two. The hamster is a nasty, mouse-like thing, not fit to comb a guinea pig's fur; the guinea pig is a proud and noble creature who vacuums up hamsters for breakfast.
Edward Hardy
London

fields.headline: Real world economics
fields.trailText: At last, the real world is starting to question the pseudo- scientific disciplines of the UK monetary authorities. After your encouraging leader (February 11) we would urge you not to ease the pressure on the monetary policy committee.
fields.body:
At last, the real world is starting to question the pseudo- scientific disciplines of the UK monetary authorities. After your encouraging leader (February 11) we would urge you not to ease the pressure on the monetary policy committee.

Working in equity (rather than bond) markets, we are in daily contact with companies who tell us that prices are set by competition and not by costs. Oil prices up ... air fares down. Do we really think that Ford paying its white-collar workers more will enable them to put up the price of a Mondeo? Will spending more on a house mean you become less price-conscious elsewhere?

We have long accepted that the Bank of England set rates and we don't, but they will increasingly have to accept the redundancy of their econometric models and that companies (not econometrics) set prices. Higher volume does not cause higher prices any more; lower prices cause higher volume. Call it the happy-hour effect. Real GDP growth of 1.4% in Q2 1999 had manufacturing output falling 1.3% and telecommunications rising by 13.3% - and guess what's happening to telecom prices?

It's time the MPC looked at the real world. What use is the concept of an output gap when (to quote Greenspan) "there is no meaningful measure of capacity utilisation in the service sector", a mere 75% of the economy? The UK is unique in that our biggest liability (mortgages) are largely based on short-term interest rates, such that we are all affected by the capriciousness of the MPC (who so far have changed rates every other meeting). If we can't change the mindset of the keynesian would-be demand managers at the Bank, then the next best thing is an institutionalised framework of longer-term fixed rate mortgages so that the economic consequences of the MPC are neutered.
Mark Tinker
Head of European equity strategy
Darren Winder
Head of European economics, Warburg Dillon Read

fields.headline: Who's top of the class?
fields.trailText: "It was critical that the impact that teachers had on pupils' progress was measured," says Estelle Morris (Moves to appease teachers over pay, February 10). Where do these ministers live? They don't send their children to my school.
fields.body:
"It was critical that the impact that teachers had on pupils' progress was measured," says Estelle Morris (Moves to appease teachers over pay, February 10). Where do these ministers live? They don't send their children to my school: over half the children on free school meals; over 75% with a language other than English; 40% on the special educational needs register ... Appease teachers!

We set the children for maths and English in years 3 to 6. Children more able to understand the curriculum - ability or fluency in English - tend to be in larger groups with one teacher. Children who need more help are in smaller groups with maybe two teachers (a class teacher and a bilingual support teacher), up to three learning assistants and possibly a support worker assigned to an SEN child.

The children will be in different sets for maths and English and the teacher who takes the larger English set may take the smaller maths set with the various levels of assistance. She or he will then take their class registration group for PE, history, art, music and so on. And these same teachers run dance, football, music and rugby clubs after school.

In addition, the meals supervisors ensure the children are calmly looked after at lunchtime. The school admin staff look after children who are ill, soothing and comforting, and protect teachers from some of the avalanche of paper. The premises officer will have moved equipment and furniture, got footballs off the roof, warded off intruders and supervised the cleaners who play their part by keeping the place clean and safe for lessons.

The special needs coordinator will have discussed individual education plans and behaviour management strategies with the teachers, she will have called in support from the education social workers, occupational therapists, educational psychologists, speech therapists, counsellors and doctors. The bilingual support team will have made learning aids, advised teachers, worked with individual children and groups, obtained the assistance of interpreters and translators, met with parents and run parents' groups.

The deputy head and I take difficult and aggressive children, who have to be out of class because of their behaviour or welfare needs. We talk to parents about their children's attendance, punctuality, behaviour, learning, care, clothing and head lice. We will also have passed on to the teachers the thoughts and wisdom of the local authority advisers and inspectors.

All teachers will have been on training courses and so had to leave notes and plans for supply teachers - who also contribute towards the children's progress.

Who, then, is responsible for the children making progress "as good or better than similar pupils nationally"? Schooling is teamwork. The Tories set school against school with the competition of league tables, this government is setting teacher against teacher.
Barry Cole
London

 The negative effects of judging workers on measures for which they have no control was well reported over 50 years ago. Has nobody in the present government got a history degree?
David Halsall
School of Business, Sheffield Hallam University

 PAT's reaction to the pay rise for teachers was not motivated by a "knee-jerk" dislike of performance-related pay. It was based on the fact that while average settlements are running at 4.6% teachers will receive only 3.3%. This will do nothing to solve the crisis facing a professional service which is critical to the future prosperity of the country but which has serious recruitment problems and an ageing membership.
Kay Driver
Professional Association of Teachers

fields.headline: No hat, no rabbits
fields.standfirst:
But there is still room for hope in Belfast
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: It happened almost simultaneously. Gerry Adams announced what could be a breakthrough. But too late. The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, had 20 minutes earlier set in hand the process which would put the assembly into cold storage.
fields.body:
It happened almost simultaneously. Gerry Adams announced what could be a breakthrough: enough progress on decommissioning to enable General de Chastelain to furnish a fresh report offering substance where his first report offered mere aspirations. The decommissioning issue, Mr Adams maintained - and the Dublin government seemed to share his enthusiasm - had at last been surmounted. But too late. The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, had some 20 minutes earlier set in hand the process which, after little more than 70 days, would put the Northern Ireland assembly and its associated enterprises into cold storage. For him, the initiative was too little, too late. By the time these words are printed this morning, we may have learned what the general thinks of the terms which IRA has offered. The best hope may be that the formula now arrived at may perhaps form the basis for reviving the process later.

This morning will see recriminations which will need to be controlled if they are not to inflame a delicate, perhaps dangerous, situation. The suspension of the institutions should ensure that David Trimble's threat to resign is not carried through, but moves were last night expected at the meeting of his Ulster Unionist Council which could make it near impossible to get negotiations going again: especially the demand that the price to be paid for any further Unionist participation must be the scrapping of Chris Patten's plans for reform of the RUC. The British government, as sensible unionists know, could not possibly meet a demand like that. For such a move to succeed would be a disaster.

Though many of the participants were last night dismayed and depressed, as well as dog tired, this is not by any means the end of the story. Compared with what happened 25 years ago, when the last power-sharing venture collapsed, the portents are truly encouraging. The Sinn Fein leadership may not have swung the IRA round to even token decommissioning soon enough, but they have brought them a very long way. De Chastelain confirms it: he found them resolved not to return to violence and committed to the peace process. These may be dismissed as mere words, but they are words which not so long ago would have seemed quite extraordinary coming from such a source. There is no small irony, as Mr Adams recently observed, in an Irish Republican leader trying to persuade a Unionist leader and the British government not to collapse a partitionist administration at Stormont.

Much of the new mood has to do with the fact that people in Northern Ireland, who dreamed vainly of peace for so many years, have now had a taste of it and do not want to let it go. The power-sharing phase, brief though it was, has been a success. It is in this context that any lingering recalcitrance has to be judged. If they refuse any move towards decommissioning, as the SDLP's wise Seamus Mallon was saying the other day, they are not simply trying their strength against political opponents: they are defying the settled will of the people of Ireland, north and south. That is why, possibly on the formula Mr Adams flourished last night, the process has a good chance of resuming and restoring in time the institutions frozen last night. It is a bleak moment; but there have been many such in Northern Ireland over the past 30 years and the potential for recovery this time looks better than most.

fields.headline: Celtic infringed
fields.standfirst: Heavy-hitters dazzled by northern lights
fields.trailText: For radio listeners of a certain age, it was a melody to match the weather forecasters' song of Biscay, Fair Isle and Dogger. Saturday teatimes the announcer intoned: Heart of Midlothian - Walter Scott's Edinburgh clink become a football club - Dunfermline Athletic, Airdrieonians, Queen of the South, and, unforgettably, Hamilton Academicals.
fields.body:
For radio listeners of a certain age, it was a melody to match the weather forecasters' song of Biscay, Fair Isle and Dogger. Saturday teatimes the announcer intoned: Heart of Midlothian - Walter Scott's Edinburgh clink become a football club - Dunfermline Athletic, Airdrieonians, Queen of the South, and, unforgettably, Hamilton Academicals.

Now here comes a club out of the Highlands to add to the melodious roster: Inverness Caledonian Thistle. The first division club this week brought down mighty Celtic and its coach John Barnes. Kenny Dalglish has been recalled from scouting the Spanish golf courses amid rumblings about foreign imports diluting the green ethos at Parkhead, where Celtic's stands rear over Glasgow's east end. ("Foreign" does not, needless to say, embrace the Republic of Ireland.)

Pedants will point out that Inverness is not in the Highlands, geologically or historically speaking. But it is Scotland's northernmost club with any class and the away victory in the third round of the Scottish cup has brewed a potent mix of home-town and regional pride. Mighty Glasgow has been humbled: Aberdeen, potential next victims a week tomorrow, must be quaking.

webTitle: UN agency failed to meet refugee crisis, says report

fields.headline: UN agency failed to meet refugee crisis, says report
fields.trailText: The United Nations refugee agency UNHCR was badly prepared and undermined by weak management during the flood of Kosovo Albanians from the province which began last March, according to an independent assessment by five academics and aid workers.
fields.body:
The United Nations refugee agency UNHCR was badly prepared and undermined by weak management during the flood of Kosovo Albanians from the province which began last March, according to an independent assessment by five academics and aid workers.

The report, which was commissioned by the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, Sadako Ogata, says that the agency underestimated the demands of a high-profile emergency. It criticises inadequate staffing levels, inappropriate and cumbersome decision-making, and limited financial resources in the crucial first weeks of the crisis when around 850,000 Kosovo Albanians fled to Albania and Macedonia within a month.

While it underlines that the UNHCR was exposed to a politically-charged environment beyond its control, and criticises Nato and several European countries, the report also points out that the agency's weaknesses encouraged governments and other bodies to undermine its accepted international role as the lead refugee organisation.

"The agency was in some respects weaker than it needed to be by not optimally utilising the resources which it did control, or could easily acquire. This applies particularly to management practices and staffing patterns, [and] possibly to diplomacy in the field during the initial phase," the report said.

"We didn't even meet our own emergency stand-by arrangements," Ron Redmond, a UNHCR spokesman, admitted yesterday.

Normally the UNHCR should be able to deliver relief supplies for 250,000 people and deploy emergency response teams within 72 hours, which it failed to do. Decisions were not made soon enough and "junior or inexperienced staff were at times placed in overly demanding positions", making it unable to address critical diplomatic and logistical challenges as Macedonia sought to close its borders, according to the report.

It also depicts a situation where officials came to rely on Nato's assertions that air strikes "would be a solution rather than a problem", mak ing the extent of the impending refugee crisis unpredictable. When thousands of Kosovo Albanians did start to flee, the report speculates that Nato's claims that the exodus was caused by a Serb offensive were an attempt to deflect criticism of the air strikes.

"If not, it raises serious questions about the responsibility of a regional organisation, and its members, to inform UNHCR of likely refugee consequences of military activities," the assessment continues. It also suggests that Nato had known about the Serb plans since December 1998.

Fearing that the exodus would spill over into western Europe, and anxious to subdue domestic public opinion, EU countries are also criticised for unnecessarily bypassing the UNHCR to deliver high-profile assistance directly within Albania and Macedonia. Only 3.5% of the top six EU contributors' funding for the humanitarian crisis went to the refugee agency.

However, the report notes that the UNHCR's shortcomings had minor consequences on the welfare of refugees, and were exacerbated by the exceptional scale of the exodus, as well as its high visibility. UNHCR staff in Macedonia were outnumbered five to one by 450 international journal ists, and were placed under further strain by a "steady stream of high-level politicians who visited the region in the early period requesting briefings and tours and who were often unaccustomed to a certain chaos characteristic of an initial emergency response".

In a statement, the UNHCR said it was taking steps to strengthen its emergency response but emphasised that its operation turned out to be "vital for the beneficiaries and for the international community".

The report points out that the refugee agency's own evaluations indicate that it also performed "well below the mark" in previous emergencies in Sudan, in the former Yugoslavia and the Great Lakes region of Africa, and during the Gulf crisis.
