fields.headline: Taking on the world
fields.standfirst: The web is about to offer small investors global freedom, reports Patrick Sherwen
fields.trailText: This week saw three developments in the world of online investment that will have private investors breathing down the stripey-shirt clad necks of the City slickers.
fields.body:
This week saw three developments in the world of online investment that will have private investors breathing down the stripey-shirt clad necks of the City slickers.

Since the popularity of internet-based investment services started to gather momentum towards the end of 1999, a new broker has sprouted almost every week. The compost for these new blooms has also been thickly and freshly spread in the form of finance-related websites which carry increasingly up to the minute share price and market information. Private investors can now trade on their domestic markets with almost the same freedom and information as their institutional counterparts.

But crossborder trading still costs up to five times as much as staying within the national boundaries. Once this barrier is broken down the advantages of the world wide web will truly become apparent and the arrival of Jiway, Multex and Sharepeople on the retail investment scene this week could go some way towards doing that.

Jiway (rhymes with highway) will open for business in September as a new form of stock exchange constructed with the small private investor in mind. It is the result of a joint project between the Swedish OM Group and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter (MSDW), the US investment bank. The idea of Jiway is to give ordinary retail investors access to more than 6,000 shares from European and US equity markets at half the price they would normally pay when using a high street or internet broker.

The system will be run as a trading platform into which brokers will plug in so that they can buy and sell shares on behalf of their clients with out having to set up costly and cumbersome arrangements with foreign exchanges. Arun Kumar, one of the people behind the project and a vice president of MSDW says that under current arrangements brokers have put off setting themselves up for cross-border trading despite rising demand from investors.

If the Jiway project wins Financial Services Authority approval in the late summer, the problem will be partially alleviated. "Over time I think the private investor will ask questions of his broker: 'Why are you not on Jiway? I want to invest in Italian stocks and Dutch telecom stocks'," says Mr Kumar.

The service may eventually expand to include index-related products that allow investors to buy a whole index as it if were a single share. Mr Kumar says it could even extend into far eastern markets but it is too early to say for sure.

In the meantime, investors can satisfy their wanderlust with Sharepeople. This is the first online broker to allow private individuals to trade more than 12,000 shares in the UK, the US - including smaller markets such as Aim and Nasdaq - and soon European markets such as Easdaq, through a single account.

Rather than switching between dealing services and web pages, traders will be able to view all their holdings in a single portfolio no matter which market the stock was bought in. The portfolio is linked to a high interest account which is used to feed the trading account, both of which are run by Bank of Scotland. A flat fee of £17.50 will be charged for all trades and the service will also offer access to an expanding range of unit trusts.

So far Sharepeople has signed up Global Asset Management, HSBC, Martin Currie, Newton, Perpetual and Save & Prosper. Links to Standard & Poors' Concise fund research provide investors with a respected source of information on which funds to choose. The project is backed by Goldman Sachs and GE Capital among others.

The arrival of this service might be seen as timely by anyone who has tried to register for Halifax's popular ShareXpress dealing service. Calling the registration number on Thursday led to a recorded message saying that "due to volumes" no more customers could be taken on board. Halifax says the phone service will reopen as soon as possible. In the meantime new customers can register on the internet.

The final piece in the cross-border investment jigsaw to be put in place this week was the free availability to private investors for the first time of international equity broker research by Reuters through Multex.com. In the past this research has been available only to institutions.

webTitle: Take a tip - and steer clear of the wide boys

fields.headline: Take a tip - and steer clear of the wide boys
fields.standfirst: As two tabloids accuse each other of dodgy deals involving shares, Tony Levene takes a look at the murky side of the market gurus
fields.trailText: Share tipping has become big business with scores of newsletters, magazines and newspaper columns aimed at experienced investors and first-time punters attracted by rocketing prices in dot.com and hi-tech companies.
fields.body:
Share tipping has become big business with scores of newsletters, magazines and newspaper columns aimed at experienced investors and first-time punters attracted by rocketing prices in dot.com and hi-tech companies.

And that's not counting the financial chat rooms where stock aficionados swap market gossip with one another.

But the battle between the Mirror and the Sun, and their mutual accusations of dirty dealing, have revealed the murky side of share tipping. Both sides in this redtop newspaper war claim journalists on the other tabloid bought shares before they were tipped in the hope that their recommendation would bring in more buyers and send the price soaring.

Tipping comes in all shapes and sizes from the 32p a day Mirror with its two million plus circulation to specialist publications with subscription-only sales amounting to a few hundred. These can charge £500 a year or more.

Marketmakers say newspaper and tipsheet recommendations have no effect on leading Footsie companies such as BT or Glaxo Wellcome. But tips do affect small companies, currently the favourite hunting ground of the new breed of internet investor. It takes only a few buyers, perhaps with no more than a few thousand pounds between them, to push a price sharply higher in a rarely traded share. And that often pulls in other investors.

But tips could be part of a "pump and dump" exercise where holders of a share put out buy recommendations, often suggesting the price will soar - the "pump" - hoping to sucker in others who will buy their unwanted shares - the "dump".

This week, the Financial Services Authority announced the formation of an e-commerce team to monitor tipping on the net.

The Motley Fool (www.fool.co.uk), which has held informal talks with the FSA, has message boards where members can pin up their thoughts. It is unregulated. The Fool's David Berger believes universal access to the net is an important safeguard.

He says: "Our whispers are in public, unlike those of City insiders, so ours can be challenged. We can track messages to e-mail addresses, although we do not demand identity checks or addresses to register as a member. But we encourage members to use our problem post and 'fool alerts' which we think are unique."

The FSA's current rules to prevent conflicts of interest among print media tipsters are confused. It only controls some, as part of its regulation of "investment advice" - a term which includes tips on equities, unit and investment trusts or bonds but not savings accounts with banks and building societies.

Writers on mainstream publications, whose primary purpose is wider than share tipping, do not need authorisation under the "freedom of the press" exemption.

Sara Williams, who publishes the subscription only Growth Company Investor and a number of tipsheets, is covered by regulation. She says: "I had to pass financial and investment planning exams to qualify. I insist that all writers sign a letter pledging to report any conflict of interest, such as holding a share which they tip. This will then be noted in the publication. Writers have to wait 48 hours after readers get the publication before they can deal."

Andrew Griffiths, who publishes three share advice sheets including the AIM Newsletter, spends around £5,000 a year on regulation and compulsory professional indemnity insurance.

He says: "I have to follow the rules. We cannot make exaggerated claims in our marketing. But there is nothing in the Financial Services Act about owning shares you then tip. Our writers are entitled to buy any shares they tip at the same time readers receive the publication. And if they mention them subsequently, they do not have to reveal ownership."

Griffiths reckons tipsheet owners have either to employ writers who own no shares or those who put their money where their mouth is, using their experiences of winning and losing. He prefers the second variety.

Shares, a weekly bookstall magazine, is not regulated. But it warns: "Staff may hold shares in some of the securities written about in this magazine. All shareholdings will be disclosed where it [sic] may represent a conflict of interest." A Shares writer says this does not involve revealing whether the holder has one share or a million. Nor does the Shares code cover writers who suppress stories unfavourable to shares they own.

The Investors Chronicle takes a tougher line. Managing director Michael Murphy says: "You are not allowed to buy a share you have written about and you are not allowed to write about a share you own. Everyone has to register their shareholdings and regularly update them. This rule covers everyone. We also warn printers and distributors that they must not deal ahead of the Friday morning publication."

But tipsheet writers think regulation is toothless. One says: "The authorities are fools. There's a lot of insider trading and front running in small illiquid stocks. There are so many areas of leakage from bankers to secretaries. The FSA is not interested in tipping."

But whatever the source of the tip, it is well to be aware of an old City saying: "Where there's the tip, there's a tap". This means that investors need to check why a share is being recommended before taking action. The motives can range from an honest desire to tell readers something they might not otherwise discover to an illegal attempt to "ramp" the shares by spreading false hopes about a stock in the hope that enough buyers will come in to ensure the price rises. Those connected with the company, including directors, brokers, bankers and public relations agents, may also place stories with tipsters, either to help their clients or to ensure they have a firm price into which they can sell stock.

But some shares jump ahead without a single buyer - marketmakers subscribe to all the tipsheets and share magazines and often mark up the price of shares which are tipped. "If we think there is going to be a lot of demand, we increase the price of the share in the hope of flushing out sellers. We're protecting our own position while making the tipper look clever," says a marketmaker.

Choosing your tipsheet

* Look at the past record. Many sheets boast about successes but forget flops.

* Compare their claimed growth rate against the markets they specialise in. Small companies and AIM stocks did well last year.

* Does the tipster employ a scattergun approach, recommending scores of shares each issue?

* Watch out for boasts based on the middle price between the offer price (at which you buy) and the bid (at which you sell). Ignoring this "spread", dealing costs and stamp duty means claims of bigger than deserved gains.

* Is there a large "free float" - easily available shares to purchase rather those held by directors and their friends? Some tipsheets have boasted of turning £10,000 into £1m when it was not possible to buy even £10,000 worth.

* Does the tipster repeatedly recommend stocks associated with one broker or entrepreneur?

* Is there sensible and regular "sell" advice?

She says: "I had to pass financial and investment planning exams to qualify. I insist that all writers sign a letter pledging to report any conflict of interest, such as holding a share which they tip. This will then be noted in the publication. Writers have to wait 48 hours after readers get the publication before they can deal." Andrew Griffiths, who publishes three share advice sheets including the AIM Newsletter, spends around £5,000 a year on regulation and compulsory professional indemnity insurance. He says: "I have to follow the rules. We cannot make exaggerated claims in our marketing. But there is nothing in the Financial Services Act about owning shares you then tip. Our writers are entitled to buy any shares they tip at the same time readers receive the publication. And if they mention them subsequently, they do not have to reveal ownership." Griffiths reckons tipsheet owners have either to employ writers who own no shares or those who put their money where their mouth is, using their experiences of winning and losing. He prefers the second variety. Shares, a weekly bookstall magazine, is not regulated. But it warns: "Staff may hold shares in some of the securities written about in this magazine. All shareholdings will be disclosed where it [sic] may represent a conflict of interest." A Shares writer says this does not involve revealing whether the holder has one share or a million. Nor does the Shares code cover writers who suppress stories unfavourable to shares they own. The Investors Chronicle takes a tougher line. Managing director Michael Murphy says: "You are not allowed to buy a share you have written about and you are not allowed to write about a share you own. Everyone has to register their shareholdings and regularly update them. This rule covers everyone. We also warn printers and distributors that they must not deal ahead of the Friday morning publication." But tipsheet writers think regulation is toothless. One says: "The authorities are fools. There's a lot of insider trading and front running in small illiquid stocks. There are so many areas of leakage from bankers to secretaries. The FSA is not interested in tipping." But whatever the source of the tip, it is well to be aware of an old City saying: "Where there's the tip, there's a tap". This means that investors need to check why a share is being recommended before taking action. The motives can range from an honest desire to tell readers something they might not otherwise discover to an illegal attempt to "ramp" the shares by spreading false hopes about a stock in the hope that enough buyers will come in to ensure the price rises. Those connected with the company, including directors, brokers, bankers and public relations agents, may also place stories with tipsters, either to help their clients or to ensure they have a firm price into which they can sell stock. But some shares jump ahead without a single buyer - marketmakers subscribe to all the tipsheets and share magazines and often mark up the price of shares which are tipped. "If we think there is going to be a lot of demand, we increase the price of the share in the hope of flushing out sellers. We're protecting our own position while making the tipper look clever," says a marketmaker. Choosing your tipsheet * Look at the past record. Many sheets boast about successes but forget flops. * Compare their claimed growth rate against the markets they specialise in. Small companies and AIM stocks did well last year. * Does the tipster employ a scattergun approach, recommending scores of shares each issue? * Watch out for boasts based on the middle price between the offer price (at which you buy) and the bid (at which you sell). Ignoring this "spread", dealing costs and stamp duty means claims of bigger than deserved gains. * Is there a large "free float" - easily available shares to purchase rather those held by directors and their friends? Some tipsheets have boasted of turning £10,000 into £1m when it was not possible to buy even £10,000 worth. * Does the tipster repeatedly recommend stocks associated with one broker or entrepreneur? * Is there sensible and regular "sell" advice?

webTitle: Switch Peps to raise your gains

fields.headline: Switch Peps to raise your gains
fields.standfirst: Many investors are not aware they can transfer, but it is easy to do and can add hundreds of pounds to your final profit, says Jim Hawkins
fields.trailText: Personal equity plans (Peps) were introduced in 1987 and sold until April 1999, when they were replaced by individual savings accounts (Isas). Both are wrappers which allow the funds within them to grow free of income tax and capital gains tax.
fields.body:
Personal equity plans (Peps) were introduced in 1987 and sold until April 1999, when they were replaced by individual savings accounts (Isas). Both are wrappers which allow the funds within them to grow free of income tax and capital gains tax.

Pep investments need to be reviewed regularly, since Inland Revenue rules allow investors to transfer from one Pep to another if they so wish. It is also possible, of course, to cash in a Pep.

In the eight months to December 1999, transfers of unit trust based Peps aver aged £300m per month, and encashments £338m. However, a Legal & General survey conducted late last year revealed that 41% of Pep holders did not realise that they could switch.

One obvious reason why you might want to switch is dissatisfaction with a Pep's performance. One tool for comparing funds is Standard & Poor's Micropal statistics which appear in the back of each month's Money Management magazine. All the funds that are Pepable have a mark similar to a dollar sign in the margin immediately to the left of their name. On the right half of the page, perfor mance figures show how £1,000 has grown over one, two, three, five and 10 years.

Say you had invested £1,000 in the Baillie Gifford Income A fund three years ago. You will find this in the UK Equity Income sector of the unit trusts and OEICS listings. As at January 2000, you will see your investment has grown to £1,240. Immediately to the right of this figure is the number 84. This means that it is the 84th best performing fund over the three years.

If you let your eye run to the end of the section, you will be nonplussed to discover that there are only 84 funds in it. How much more pleased you would have been had you chosen ABN AMRO UK Equity Income - the best performing fund in the sector, which would have turned your £1,000 into £1,867.

As we are frequently reminded, past performance does not guarantee future performance. A very successful fund manager may have left in the recent past, and a fund may now be living on former glories. However, if it has been a consistently good performer over all periods between one and 10 years that cannot be a bad sign.

Scrutiny of the middle set of columns will show a fund's performance in each year from 1996 to date.

Careful examination of these figures will also indicate if a fund is rising or falling. For those seeking capital growth from UK equities (the UK All Companies sector) ABN AMRO has again been a consistently good performer with its UK Growth fund.

Transferring a Pep to another Pep does not affect your entitlement to an Isa, but if a Pep is transferred to an Isa it will be considered part of your Isa allowance.

It was possible to invest in both a general Pep fund, say unit trust based, and a single- company scheme. When transferring, it is not possible to swap between single and general company Peps.

Investors must move a whole tax year's general Pep, even though the holding may be split between several different investments. A single company Pep from the same year is considered separate and does not necessarily have to be moved.

Most Pep managers "bundle" general Peps for different years into one plan. This means that several years' Peps often have to be moved together. The problem is that if you hold different funds with the same manager, you will probably have to transfer them all, even though you may only want to change one.

Most providers tend not to levy exit charges from their funds. There is usually an exit fee from the Pep itself, though, varying from £29 to £60. Since transfers to a new manager tend to be treated as new business, there will often be a further initial charge to pay. This can be 5%, but is often discounted.

Some providers offer free transfers or special deals for transfers over a certain amount. And some funds, particularly those that deal direct, levy no initial charge.

Besides poor performance, there are other reasons why you might want to rearrange your Pep portfolio. Your investment priorities might have altered and you may wish to change the emphasis from income to capital growth or vice versa. Your attitude to investment risk may have changed. If you have taken out several plans over the years, you may find that your portfolio is unbalanced and wish to correct that.

Having decided to make a transfer, how do you go about it? There are many organisations which offer Pep monitoring and transfer services. These often include access to research, valuation and assessment of portfolios. There is usually no cost as long as you make the company providing them your intermediary. Two such organisations are Allenbridge (www.allenbridge.com) and Barbican Investment Research (www.barbican.invest.co.uk).

Last but not least, when considering a transfer, it is always a good idea to see what else the existing provider has to offer. It will almost certainly be cheaper to make an internal transfer than to change to a new provider - and to do that, you would simply talk to your existing Pep manager.

webTitle: Preparing people for the new world

fields.headline: Preparing people for the new world
fields.standfirst: As the UK's training marketplace prepares to embrace the internet, Jac Peeris looks at the radically changing human resources industry
fields.trailText: As the UK's training marketplace prepares to embrace the internet, Jac Peeris looks at the radically changing human resources industry.
fields.body:
The transformation of the core human resources market and the growth of training services on the internet are both direct results of several major strategic changes.

First, the downsizing and re-engineering of the late 80s and 90s has left many organisations leaner, meaner and keener, and better equipped to deal with a rapidly changing marketplace. In reality, however, the lack of effective re-training and re-skilling of the remaining staff has hampered this process considerably, causing inefficiencies and missed opportunities.

Secondly, the advent of the global marketplace and the introduction of technology designed to reach that marketplace has added even more to the pressures facing modern companies. In today's environment, the workforce must adapt and acquire new skills just to survive. And they have to do so in a world that is changing and developing at a bewilderingly fast pace.

Moreover, the focus of HR's three traditional elements - personnel management, recruitment and training - is changing radically.

A new HR world is coming. And, in this climate, it is no surprise that the importance of high-impact, well chosen training is growing at a massive rate. There are currently more than 10,000 suppliers of training products and services in the UK, serving almost 1.5m customers of varying sizes.

According to the most recent government training statistics, the private sector alone spent more than £15bn on training in 1997, a figure that is growing by an average of 7% every year. However, this situation is not quite as healthy or as buoyant as these figures initially suggest. If one compares the UK's statistics to those of other countries, particularly European countries and the US, a different picture emerges.

In 1997, only 15% of UK workers received some kind of training compared with, for example, 22% in the US and 26% in Germany. More importantly, it's not just about the size of spend or the percentages of employees receiving training. The impact of each training pound spent is critical. There is no question that getting the right training for the right people can be very difficult.

Part of the problem is that in such a fragmented market, it is difficult to respond quickly to new needs as they arise. Buyers are, basically, running to stand still: continuing to use existing suppliers, ad-hoc referrals and time consuming market searches to try to identify suppliers who can fulfil their training requirements.

Often, it is difficult for them to assess their training needs clearly. As a result, individuals with more specific requirements are often passed over in a search for the panacea of large-scale programmes and broad-brush solutions. And, as many companies are finding out, it is hard enough to find the appropriate training without attempting to tailor programmes to individual requirements.

Today a number of initiatives have been developed aimed at helping education and learning across all levels of society. The Investors in People (IIP) accreditation has already been awarded to some 35% of UK firms with between 50 and 200 staff. The goal is to have more than 70% of firms with more than 200 staff accredited by this year. The personal training allowance, Individual Learning Accounts or ILAs, are also set to become law later this year. This will make individual training expenditure tax deductible, and, as a result, will make training more appealing to many people.

Finally, after many years of talk, people are becoming a highly valued part of today's business environment.

More and more businesses are finding that as most other inputs become commodities, people and the knowledge they create are becoming one of the few remaining areas for competitive differentiation. As a result, a number of strategic imperatives are emerging. Cutting-edge companies are investing the right amounts in strategic training initiatives developed to ensure the right staff have the right skills to get the right job done right.

They are also ensuring that individual needs are catered for; ensuring that each employee is performing at their peak. More and more training is being outsourced to the experts.

Companies are beginning to cherry-pick the best training and development available, upgrading these services as required. And, they are getting more out of training, making it a priority, evaluating feedback, providing follow-up and measuring long-term results.

As the merger of AOL and Time Warner illustrates, the internet has become a powerful force which will continue to transform the landscape of most industries.

There are both challenges and opportunities ahead requiring appropriate preparation - the right training and development is a critical part of ensuring that the UK workforce is able to make the most of these challenges and maximise its position in the global marketplace of the 21st century.

Jac Peeris is the founder and chief executive of Skillvest.com which provides buyers and sellers of training with an online marketplace

webTitle: Will estate agents survive web assault?

fields.headline: Will estate agents survive web assault?
fields.standfirst: More people are selling their houses over the net and avoiding shelling out thousands in agency fees. Elizabeth Langton reports
fields.trailText: No fees, no commission, no agency charges, no cost to the customer whatsoever. These are the claims of internet services that hope to put Britain's high street estate agents out of business.
fields.body:
No fees, no commission, no agency charges, no cost to the customer whatsoever. These are the claims of internet services that hope to put Britain's high street estate agents out of business.

The internet property market is buzzing. Increasing numbers of estate agents are using the web as a means of advertising properties for sale. Now new companies are muscling in on their core business. HomeFreeHome, which launched last week, will be joined on Monday by Easier.co.uk. - and both websites offer consumers the chance to save on commission and advertise their property for free.

HomeFreeHome says those who want to sell their home will be able to upload property details and photos and buyers will be e-mailed when a property that fits their requirements appears on the site.

Like other web-based services, HomeFreeHome hopes to make its money not from the consumer but from the advertisers who will pay to appear on its site. It will also join other sites in providing information about finance, moving and goods and services connected with home ownership.

According to research carried out by rival property site HouseWeb.com, set up in 1996, the number of private property sales is almost doubling each year thanks to the internet.

The company says that this year more than 100,000 homeowners will save £1,500 on average by selling their home themselves. A home owner in Somerset sold his £375,000 property through the site and saved about £7,500 in estate agents fees, says managing director Mark Desvaux. He predicts that UK homeowners will follow in the footsteps of their German counterparts, where 50% of sales are private.

Estate agents deny they are rattled by the growth of cheap internet alternatives to high street selling. Hugh Dunsmore-Hardy, spokesman for the National Association of Estate Agents, says his members do much more than market a property.

"The agent uses their interpersonal skills to bring the buyer and seller together. Many agents are refining and expanding their service to such an extent that it is almost the norm for the agent to handle all the viewing too."

He says web sites, by contrast, are no more than "an advanced form of communication that sellers can turn to as an alternative to putting an ad in the evening paper. The only difference being you can include more information on the site".

But critics of estate agents say the trade gets money for old rope. When property shortages mean that in some areas homes are sold even before the For Sale board is up, many sellers question exactly what their agent did to earn their 1%-2% commission (as much as £2,000 on a £100,000 home) other than take a photograph that makes their home look like it's in a police line-up.

Even before the advent of the virtual marketplace, there were entrepreneurial homeowners happy to go it alone and avoid estate agents' fees. Homes have always been sold through word of mouth, the property section of newspapers and magazines and ads in newsagents' windows.

Sasha Newman sold her flat in East Dulwich, London privately to the sister of a neighbour two weeks after marketing the property through an estate agent. The agent had not introduced the buyer and so she didn't feel obliged to refer the private buyer to the agency. She told the agent she'd decided against selling and wanted to take the property off the market, but admits she felt nervous about bending the truth.

Ms Newman found the process more straightforward than she'd expected. "In many ways, negotiating face to face was simpler than doing it through a third party," she says. She is in no doubt that she'd do it again: "I came out of it £3,000 better off."

Ms Newman is one of the lucky ones, argues Mr Dunsmore-Hardy. Many sales fall to pieces along the way and the estate agent is essential to keep the thing stitched together, he claims.

Agents are experienced negotiators, he says. "They can foresee any problems that appear after the sale has been agreed and help overcome them before they become major issues.

"Sales also fall apart when agents handle them. Things are more likely to go wrong in private sales."

HomeFreeHome hopes to appeal to the increasing number of buyers that are happy to go it alone. Other sites offer home sellers the chance to market their property for a fee of anything between £20 and £100.

HouseWeb charges £40 for sellers to advertise their property on the site. Homeowners can either upload photos themselves or send them to the company for scanning. Advertising on Housesearch.uk.com costs £20 including two pictures.

Agents argue that home owners would have difficulty deciding how much their home is worth and many will under or overvalue it. In a property hot spot, the agent is more likely to have their finger on the pulse of the market, says Mr Dunsmore-Hardy.

However, most agents are happy to give free valuations and would-be private sellers could get quotes from a couple of agents and opt for a price that sits between the two figures.

There are pitfalls to private sales. Sellers need to spend time and money on the project if they want to advertise in the press. Those who get a private offer after signing up with an agent need to check the small print - some contracts demand commission even if you go ahead with a private sale.

These days more and more consumers are happy to contract out tedious tasks, such as shopping. Mr Dunsmore-Hardy does not believe that sellers will be falling over themselves to market and sell their own homes. "Most people have a daytime job and are happy to pay the agent to take the has sle of buying and selling off them," he says. "How do you know that the inquiries you are attracting are from serious buyers? It may be people looking out of curiosity."

Sellers should also be wary of giving out personal details until they are certain that the interested party is genuine.

Also, private sellers are not bound by laws that ensure estate agents describe properties accurately. Buyers may be disappointed when they discover the spacious, high-spec bargain they'd spotted on the net is in fact a grim little terrace in need of a complete overhaul.

But the net is increasingly the key to buying and selling property. Many sellers will be tempted to go the private route when they can advertise their home for a few pounds or even nothing. After all, if it fails the estate agent is just a phone call away.

Links:

www.HomeFreeHome.co.uk
www.housenet.co.uk
www.housesearch.uk.com
www.HouseWeb.co
www.loot.com
www.easier.co.uk

There are pitfalls to private sales. Sellers need to spend time and money on the project if they want to advertise in the press. Those who get a private offer after signing up with an agent need to check the small print - some contracts demand commission even if you go ahead with a private sale. These days more and more consumers are happy to contract out tedious tasks, such as shopping. Mr Dunsmore-Hardy does not believe that sellers will be falling over themselves to market and sell their own homes. "Most people have a daytime job and are happy to pay the agent to take the has sle of buying and selling off them," he says. "How do you know that the inquiries you are attracting are from serious buyers? It may be people looking out of curiosity." Sellers should also be wary of giving out personal details until they are certain that the interested party is genuine. Also, private sellers are not bound by laws that ensure estate agents describe properties accurately. Buyers may be disappointed when they discover the spacious, high-spec bargain they'd spotted on the net is in fact a grim little terrace in need of a complete overhaul. But the net is increasingly the key to buying and selling property. Many sellers will be tempted to go the private route when they can advertise their home for a few pounds or even nothing. After all, if it fails the estate agent is just a phone call away. Links: www.HomeFreeHome.co.uk www.housenet.co.uk www.housesearch.uk.com www.HouseWeb.co www.loot.com www.easier.co.uk

webTitle: Sow the seeds of a quick house sale

fields.headline: Sow the seeds of a quick house sale
fields.standfirst: If you're planning to sell your property this spring it will pay you to start getting your garden in shape now, says Richard Simpson
fields.trailText: If you're planning to sell your property this spring it will pay you to start getting your garden in shape now.
fields.body:
We're constantly being told that gardening is the new rock'n'roll, and indeed garden make-over shows like Ground Force regularly attract upwards of 10m viewers. That's a lot of armchair gardeners, so if you're planning to sell your house this spring, what can you do to encourage one of this new breed of green-fingered house-hunters to shout "I must have it" the second they catch sight of your beds and borders?

Damian Gray is a partner at Knight Frank in Beaconsfield. He says that buyers are more knowledgeable about gardens these days - although that doesn't mean they're prepared to do much in the way of hard graft.

"People certainly are taking more of an interest, but what's happening is that more of them are getting their gardens professionally landscaped. Buyers are prepared to sit on a tractor to mow the grass, but that's about all."

The fact that Mr Gray's typical clients mow their grass with a tractor rather than a little electric job gives away the fact that he operates in a somewhat rarefied price range, so what about the more mainstream houses - has the legendary Dimmock effect taken hold there yet?

Lance Trendall runs Premier Move, an estate agency with branches in Harpenden and St Albans, and he reports that although his buyers love watching other people digging on TV, they're not terribly keen on doing it themselves: "The growth in DIY has meant that more people want a house which needs doing up, but no one has yet said to me that they're looking for a house that needs landscaping."

And the story is much the same in the north of England, as John Leigh of Kendal- based Hackney and Leigh explains. "I don't think that all the TV exposure has made any real difference - the people who always used to want huge gardens still do."

However the fact that most house buyers don't really intend to give their new patch a make-over doesn't mean that gardens aren't important; all the agents I spoke to agreed that getting the garden right does make a real difference in how easy your house will be to sell, and in deciding what you'll actually get for it.

"The front garden should look tidy and well kept," insists John Leigh, "because a house has five seconds to make that first impression. And it's especially important that the garden doesn't look unkempt." Lance Trendall agrees, and advises vendors with a shaded patio to ensure that the slabs are moss-free before they try to sell.

So what are the garden features which really turn buyers on? Damian Gray of Knight Frank says that this varies by house type, with country buyers still wanting the traditional cottage garden look. A suburban garden needs to be "manicured and perfect" and if you're in the country house bracket you should be able to offer a well-maintained historic garden, complete with grand vistas and well-planned walks.

It seems that all the garden make-over shows with their shark-fins and decking have actually done little to change our traditional preferences, as Gray confirmed when I asked him to name the most saleable garden features.

"If I see a walled garden it's heaven, because they offer people their own little enclave. A heavily planted border full of old English plants is good, and people like a shed somewhere for writing in - although that's usually where the lawnmower ends up." And Gray warns against creating a feng shui-influenced garden of the raked gravel and three stones type, unless it complements a really with-it house.

Adrian Bishop, editor of Amateur Gardening magazine, agrees that you can't go wrong with "traditional borders and cottage garden plants", because they have a timeless appeal. Bishop admits that he can't tell what will be trendy in garden design over the next few years, although he thinks decking and bright external paint colours may be on their way out.

Getting it right now could make a big difference to your house's eventual value, with Gray estimating that an appealing garden adds at least 10% to the value of a typical country cottage.

That figure suggests that it would be well worth doing some work in your own garden if you're planning to sell this spring, so what does Gray recommend? "There are three things to do. First call in a contractor and get them to clear the garden. Get rid of all the rubbish, prune everything back and make sure the garden's structure is nice and clear. Next, if you've got any views make sure that you take full advantage of them, and finally try to preserve as much privacy as you can."

Lance Trendall adds that "anything which looks like work makes buyers cringe", supporting the view that getting your garden under control now will pay dividends when you sell.

John Leigh emphasises that it's important to make your patch look as sunny as possible, "so if you've got Leylandii on your land get them cut back". And Adrian Bishop suggests that you invest in a few bags of seed for a spot of cheap and almost instant colour.

So if you're selling your house this spring, the key advice is to make sure that the garden's neat and tidy, won't require lots of work, and that it is fairly traditional in design and planting.

Despite the TV gardening gurus, what most of us really like best is the gardening equivalent of magnolia walls. Sorry Charlie and co, but that's just the way it is.

webTitle: A system up for grabs - if you can hack it

fields.headline: A system up for grabs - if you can hack it
fields.trailText: It's the DVD (digital versatile disc) everyone's been anticipating: The Blair Witch Project, which arrives on the new home entertainment format on April 17, priced £19.99. But what the release doesn't mention is that you don't need to wait until April to get your hands on a DVD copy of the film, or pay £19.99.
fields.body:
It's the DVD (digital versatile disc) everyone's been anticipating and desperately wanting to get their hands on," proclaims the press release from movie distributor Pathé. The item in question is low-budget horror hit The Blair Witch Project, which arrives on the new home entertainment format on April 17, priced £19.99.

But what the release doesn't mention is that you don't need to wait until April to get your hands on a DVD copy of the film, or pay £19.99. If you scour the specialist retailers or know where to look on the internet you can pick up The Blair Witch Project in the UK right now for just £16.99.

It's a similar story with the Will Smith blockbuster Wild Wild West. This comes out on DVD in this country on February 21, with a likely recommended retail price of £19.99, but can already be found in a few places for £14.99.

So what's going on? How come a movie that's not yet available is available, and why such a difference in prices?

What's going on is that the long-suffering UK public are once again getting a raw deal. In the wake of the furore over cars, designer goods and CDs, DVD is the latest manifestation of rip-off Britain.

The villain in this saga of greed and global domination is Hollywood itself, which is attempting to control the way we watch its products on DVD. But there are ways of short-circuiting its efforts to restrict our viewing pleasure.

Many experts are predicting that DVD will kill off the video cassette player in just a few years' time. It represents a giant technological leap forward from VHS, with CD-sized discs that can hold up to 266 minutes of digital-quality film and CD-quality sound. There's no more rewinding and you can instantly access different scenes of a movie. DVD, launched in Japan three years ago, arrived in this country in 1998, but has only really taken off during the last few months. Around 90,000 DVD players were snapped up in December alone, lifting the total sold so far in the UK to 250,000.

There have been some teething problems with the new technology - some discs, notably sci-fi hit The Matrix, won't play on some players. But what has really got the goat of many movie fans is "regional coding" - the Hollywood-imposed system specifically designed to prevent UK DVD owners from watching discs from outside their "region".

"The system was set in place by the Hollywood studios, who only agreed to support the DVD format on the condition that they could impose some kind of control over release dates and distribution for the software," explains Chris Jenkins, editor of the monthly magazine Total DVD. "They divided the planet into six regions, or zones - America is Region 1 and Europe is Region 2."

With films usually showing in America months before they arrive in the UK the studios wanted to avoid a situation where people outside the US were able to watch a movie on DVD before they had paid money to see it at the cinema. So discs and players are encoded for a specific region, the aim being that discs from America can't play in places such as the UK, and vice versa.

That would seem fair enough if everyone was able to get access to the same discs - but they're not. Our friends in America have a much larger choice of films than we do - there are currently less than 1,000 Region 2 discs available compared to almost 5,000 Region 1 discs. Region 1 DVDs come out months earlier - Double Jeopardy and Stigmata, both currently playing in UK cinemas, will be available on Region 1 disc from the end of this month, and pre-orders are already being taken for the R1 disc of Oscar-tipped drama American Beauty, which has only just opened here.

And Region 1 films are cheaper too. The Blair Witch Project and Wild Wild West are two examples of this, with R1 discs of these films on sale here for up to 25% less than their belated UK counterparts. To add insult to injury, R1 DVDs often include extra features such as deleted scenes and making-of documentaries not found on their Region 2 equivalents.

So it's no surprise that disgruntled movie fans are finding ways of cracking the regional codes in order to allow some UK players to play American discs.

If you think that hacking into your DVD player in order to alter its settings sounds both illegal and highly technical, you'd be wrong. With some of the players on sale here, rejigging them so they can play R1 discs couldn't be easier - all you have to do is type in a series of numbers or commands using the remote control. It's perfectly legal and, as you're not tampering with the mechanics, it won't invalidate your warranty.

But not every player can be hacked in this way. For the full lowdown, check out the DVD Reviewer website (www.dvd.reviewer.co.uk), which carries details of 25 models and their hacks, including players from Samsung, JVC, Matsui and Grundig.

If your player isn't hackable, don't despair. Many can be upgraded to make them multi-region. There are a number of firms specialising in modifying DVD players. It usually involves adding a chip and costs around £50-£60. One of the leading players in this field is Techtronics (www.techtronics.com) which has an upgrade service costing from £49 and offers do-it-yourself modification kits starting at £25.

You can also buy players that have already been upgraded to multi-region from some retailers. Many of them advertise in DVD magazines.

Once your DVD player is capable of playing non-UK discs, you then have to find them. Many stores only sell Region 2 releases. You can of course order Region 1 movies direct from US retailers, but there are also several UK-based shops and mail-order companies selling them, including Play247 (0845 800 1020/www.play247.com), Absolute DVD (08000 968 967/www.absolutedvd.co.uk) and The Disc Emporium (01438 816688/www.disc emporium.com).

But the British Video Association, which represents video companies, takes a dim view of companies that import and sell R1 discs and has been attempting to clamp down on their activities, claiming they are contravening the Video Recordings Act and infringing copyright laws, says Mr Jenkins. The BVA has attempted to argue that selling modified players is also illegal.

How to play it smart

Rupert JonesSo you're looking for a DVD player, you want to be able to play Region 1 discs but you don't want to spend too much money. Which players are the experts recommending?

Chris Jenkins at Total DVD magazine says you should look for a machine with a simple multi-region hack. One he rates is the new Wharfedale DVD-750, which is on sale at selected Tesco stores for £180. "Wharfedale have got a very good reputation. The machine is a solid performer, very easily hacked and has all the basic functions."

The hack for this machine is the same as for another popular player, the PROline DVD-1000. You have to open the disc tray and place a Region 1 disc on it. Don't close the tray - simply type in 0,1,2,3 on your remote control then press play. To return the player to Region 2 status, place an R2 disc on the tray but don't close it. Press return then play on the remote control.

Another budget machine Mr Jenkins likes is the Matsui DVD-110, on sale at Dixons for £180. Again it comes with a simple hack. For those looking to spend a little more, he is a fan of the Pioneer DV-525, which sells for around £280.

It only tends to be the budget machines that are hackable, he adds - the more expensive ones tend to need modifying, but will usually deliver better performance.

The DVD Reviewer website (www.dvd.reviewer.co.uk) is also keen on the Wharfedale DVD-750, describing it as "the best buy of the cheapies". It praises its simple hack and points out that it plays all the "problem" discs.

webTitle: Collectors will kill for early crime classics

fields.headline: Collectors will kill for early crime classics
fields.standfirst: A first edition of Brighton Rock recently sold for £9,000; now another could fetch £15,000. Stewart Dalby looks at the craze
fields.trailText: A first edition of Brighton Rock recently sold for £9,000; now another could fetch £15,000.
fields.body:
Six months ago, I wrote that a first edition of Graham Greene's book Brighton Rock had sold at auction for £9,000. A reader wrote to me saying that he had a number of Graham Greenes and had checked: prices for firsts, in mint condition, were nothing like this.

I was a bit taken aback myself. I have some Greene first editions, bought long ago for £40 or £50 each and I was used to the idea that they are worth some hundreds of pounds. So I double-checked and, yes, it was £9,000.

Now, at a Sotheby's sale titled English Literature and History on February 24, concentrating on crime and thriller writers of the 20th century, a first edition of Brighton Rock is estimated to fetch between £12,000 to £15,000. At this rate, the book is inflating faster than an internet stock.

Alan Shelley of Bow Windows Bookshop in Lewes, East Sussex explains: "This book is extremely rare; you hardly ever see a copy with an original dust jacket. I would say this kind of price is not typical of Greene's work generally."

Jonathan Gilbert of Adrian Harrington Books says: "It's like buses - you never see them, then two come along at once. Obviously what has happened is that people have read about the price this book fetches and gone scurrying to the shelves to see if they have got one.

"In my opinion this copy is not as good as the one that fetched £9,000. But this is what this particular book can realise. It is a cornerstone book. Graham Greene is popular at the moment - there's the new film of The End of the Affair, from his novel based on his 13-year affair with Catherine Walston."

Other books by Greene in the sale are not expected to fetch anything like the Brighton Rock prices. A first edition of The End of the Affair, inscribed by the author, is expected to fetch £500 to £600. A first edition of the film script for the The Third Man, Greene's only original screenplay, is estimated at £1,000 to £1,500.

Greene was more than a thriller writer; he was arguably one of Britain's finest writers of the 20th century. So perhaps he should not be seen as the norm. But there is a definite collectors' market for crime and thriller writers which is distinct from the modern first editions craze.

There are two trends. First, there is an interest in the crime writers of the 20s and 30s and more interesting, to my mind, is the passion for recent writers like Ellis Peters (of detective monk Cadfael fame). There is also a tendency to buy writers like Colin Dexter, best known for his Inspector Morse books.

At the Sotheby's sale there are some Agatha Christies on offer. Although her mysteries have been translated into 103 languages and have sold more than 2bn copies in hundreds of countries all over the world, first editions of her early books are rare. Her first novel, The Mysterious Affair at Styles, which introduced Hercule Poirot, the Belgian detective who appeared in 25 further novels, is featured in the auction, and has an estimate of £1,200 to £1,300.

Other writers from the 20s and 30s, like Dorothy Sayers, are also collected. A proof copy of her 1930 book Strong Poison is on offer at £1,000.

Perhaps more interestingly, modern writers who are not considered classic are fetching very high prices. Ellis Peters would now see £1,000 for her first book, A Marked Taste for Bones, published in 1977. This compares to around £200 a few years ago. Colin Dexter also fetches good prices. The Last Bus to Woodbridge, published in the 70s, would realise £1,000.

All this is fuelled by TV series. Other popular writers are RD Wingfield, who wrote the Inspector Frost books, and WG Burley of Wycliffe fame. Not all crime writers are avidly collected, though. Ruth Rendell and her Inspector Wexford books were published in such vast numbers that most are not sought by collectors.

For further information, tel: Sotheby's 0171-293-5000

A first edition of The End of the Affair, inscribed by the author, is expected to fetch £500 to £600. A first edition of the film script for the The Third Man, Greene's only original screenplay, is estimated at £1,000 to £1,500. Greene was more than a thriller writer; he was arguably one of Britain's finest writers of the 20th century. So perhaps he should not be seen as the norm. But there is a definite collectors' market for crime and thriller writers which is distinct from the modern first editions craze. There are two trends. First, there is an interest in the crime writers of the 20s and 30s and more interesting, to my mind, is the passion for recent writers like Ellis Peters (of detective monk Cadfael fame). There is also a tendency to buy writers like Colin Dexter, best known for his Inspector Morse books. At the Sotheby's sale there are some Agatha Christies on offer. Although her mysteries have been translated into 103 languages and have sold more than 2bn copies in hundreds of countries all over the world, first editions of her early books are rare. Her first novel, The Mysterious Affair at Styles, which introduced Hercule Poirot, the Belgian detective who appeared in 25 further novels, is featured in the auction, and has an estimate of £1,200 to £1,300. Other writers from the 20s and 30s, like Dorothy Sayers, are also collected. A proof copy of her 1930 book Strong Poison is on offer at £1,000. Perhaps more interestingly, modern writers who are not considered classic are fetching very high prices. Ellis Peters would now see £1,000 for her first book, A Marked Taste for Bones, published in 1977. This compares to around £200 a few years ago. Colin Dexter also fetches good prices. The Last Bus to Woodbridge, published in the 70s, would realise £1,000. All this is fuelled by TV series. Other popular writers are RD Wingfield, who wrote the Inspector Frost books, and WG Burley of Wycliffe fame. Not all crime writers are avidly collected, though. Ruth Rendell and her Inspector Wexford books were published in such vast numbers that most are not sought by collectors. For further information, tel: Sotheby's 0171-293-5000

webTitle: Germany to be sued over beef ban

fields.headline: Germany to be sued over beef ban
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: The European commission yesterday finally ran out of patience with Germany over the ban on British beef. The 20 Brussels commissioners are now almost certain to launch legal proceedings against Berlin next Tuesday.
fields.body:
The European commission yesterday finally ran out of patience with Germany over the ban on British beef. The 20 Brussels commissioners are now almost certain to launch legal proceedings against Berlin next Tuesday.

A spokeswoman for the consumer protection commissioner, David Byrne, said: "The Germans have told us there will be a vote of the regional ministers in the bundesrat on March 17, but we are not prepared to risk any further delays.

"The Germans have given several dates for fulfilling their obligations and lifting the ban and there have been repeated postponements. The commissioners will be asked by Mr Byrne on Tuesday to agree to start legal proceedings."

Germany and France remain the only EU member states which have refused to comply with an EU agreement last August to lift the ban, imposed in March 1996, to ease consumer fears about the spread of mad cow disease.

France, which insists there is still a health risk, is already facing legal proceedings in the European court of justice in Luxembourg.

Germany's reason for retaining the ban is "procedural", according to the government in Berlin. At least five of the country's 17 regional governments want to keep the ban.

If Germany votes to lift the ban the legal proceedings can be halted immediately.

webTitle: Israel walks out of talks as Hizbullah strikes again

fields.headline: Israel walks out of talks as Hizbullah strikes again
fields.trailText: Hizbullah guerrillas yesterday launched a fresh ground assault which killed an Israeli soldier and wounded two others in south Lebanon, wrecking a US-convened meeting of international truce monitors intended to defuse the spiralling violence, and raising fears of further Israeli onslaughts on Lebanon's infrastructure.
fields.body:
Hizbullah guerrillas yesterday launched a fresh ground assault which killed an Israeli soldier and wounded two others in south Lebanon, wrecking a US-convened meeting of international truce monitors intended to defuse the spiralling violence, and raising fears of further Israeli onslaughts on Lebanon's infrastructure.

The United States blamed both Hizbullah and Syria for the setback.

James Rubin, the US state department spokesman, said the attack was a "deliberate disruption" of the international meeting. Syria had influence over Hizbullah, he added, and should have exerted it "more effectively".

The Hizbullah attack targeted an Israeli position at Beaufort castle, a crusader fortress in the central sector of Israel's self-styled "security zone" in south Lebanon.

The latest Israeli fatality - the seventh in less than three weeks - triggered a swift riposte from Israeli aircraft and artillery, which struck at the outskirts of several villages just north of the zone.

It also prompted the Israeli delegation to storm out of the meeting of the monitoring group.

This body, which meets regularly at the headquarters of the UN interim force in Lebanon (Unifil) in the village of Naqoura, in Israeli-occupied Lebanon, comprises representatives of the US and France - its co-founders - Israel, Lebanon and Syria.

It was born out of the US-brokered understandings of April 1996, which prohibit attacks on or from civilian areas - reached after an Israeli blitz in which at least 175 Lebanese were killed.

"The official plenary meeting did not take place," said a Franco-US statement. "The co-chairs were informed by the Israeli delegate that, due to military actions on the ground earlier today, their delegation has been instructed to return to Israel."

The Israeli delegation had been expected to press at the meeting for a change in the "rules" of warfare in south Lebanon, prohibiting Hizbullah attacks on Israeli soldiers in the security zone.

The Lebanese prime minister, Salim al-Hoss, had flatly rejected this proposal, which, as the Lebanese see it, would be tantamount to authorising Israel to launch attacks on civilian infrastructure whenever Hizbullah killed its soldiers.

Mr Hoss also strongly criticised the US for what he described as bias, taking issue with a remark made by the secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, that in destroying Lebanese power stations Israel had merely been sending "a very strong signal" that the Israelis "don't want this escalation".

"How does any country allow itself to send signals through destroying infrastructure and attacking civilians?" Mr Hoss said.

Meanwhile, Hizbullah vowed to fight on, no matter what. It said the "April understandings" enshrined "the full right of the resistance movement to go after enemy troops in the occupied zone", and it would "never accept a change in the rules of the game".

It also reserved the right to launch Katyusha rockets against targets in northern Israel in response to any attacks on Lebanese civilians.

In Jerusalem the army confirmed yesterday's air strikes and Israeli casualties. An announcement said Sergeant Zachi Yitah, 19, was killed and another soldier seriously wounded when a missile hit a combat trench.

Washington is concerned that the fighting in south Lebanon will escalate, complicating US attempts to bring Israel and Syria back to the negotiating table.

Israeli and Syrian delegations spent more than a week at peace talks in west Virginia last month but left without progress on the Golan heights, Syrian territory captured by Israel in the 1967 war.

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum
fields.standfirst: 'I''ve been feeling all my life that I have been rounded up and incriminated'
fields.trailText: 'I''ve been feeling all my life that I have been rounded up and incriminated'
fields.body:
Return from Centerparcs to pre-Utopian life in the cold, cruel real world, and sit down to deal with large pile of bills. Harriet rushes in. "Quick! Quick! Tell me the difference between Stalin and Lenin," she demands. "It's got to be in tomorrow and I haven't even started yet!"

"Stalin," I ponder, "had a moustache and was a monster. Lenin had a beard and was probably not such a bad chap, but don't quote me on that."

I don't know whether Lenin is still lying in state in the Kremlin or if he's been moved to a less prominent position (perhaps by Charlie Dimmock in a new show: Changing Tombs). Red is no longer quite so fashionable. Feel fairly sure, however, that Stalin will never be rehabilitated.

"Ask Daddy - he is a historian after all."

Ex-Spouse is lying in state in front of the TV. He will never be rehabilitated either.

Although feckless father-figures can be transformed into heroes. On EastEnders, Terry, erstwhile boozer and gambler, forgave his straying wife with saintly delicacy. I am distracted, however, by Terry's resemblance to George Bush Junior. Another George Bush! At least there wasn't another Stalin. Bush has the hair for it, though. American politicians all have big hair. If Lenin was running for Congress, he'd never get past the first committee.

Gaze moodily out of window at bird-table. A mind on the birds is worth two on the Bush. A greater spotted woodpecker, attracted by Great-Aunt Elspeth's fat balls, arrives in a flash of red. Sweet birds! You know where you are with them.

Turn reluctantly to my paperwork. I've opened two new bank accounts. Spread your overdrafts out, is my advice, burying them here and there, like squirrels before winter. However, all my insurance companies have written in indignation because I've moved from the Bollocking Bank to the Listening Bank without telling them, and their direct debits have stalled.

"Unless payment is made of your overdue premium," warns a friendly society, "your policy will be cancelled and you will be unprotected. You owe us £176 and it's five minutes overdue, okay? So pay up yesterday or we'll charge you £15 for the major concession of not ripping your lights out; we know which schools your kids go to so pay up or else, scum!" Or at least that's the gist. Stalin would be proud of them.

Unprotected! My babies exposed in a roofless ruin as earthquake, wind and fire sweep through Wiltshire! I ring the company immediately and a friendly girl tells me my premium isn't late at all; it's just a frightening letter they send out to shock people into action, and if I just put a cheque in the post it'll all be fine.

Begin to recall that Lenin wasn't completely wonderful. Something about "round up the Anarchists and incriminate them". I have been feeling all my life that I have been rounded up and incriminated. Wonder if there is a warm and leafy corner of the globe where a penniless female anarchist could spend her declining years, safe from the assaults of friendly societies, frosts and father-figures.

Hear Harriet pounding furiously up the stairs, so I escape into loo. "Mum!" "Wait! Can't I have a few seconds' peace even in here?" "Dad's like useless! He just mumbled something about losing interest in history in 1802, and when I asked him about the Russian Revolution he just said, 'Not enough wigs.'"

"All right. I'll help you with the Russian Revolution in a minute."

First, five minutes' peace with last summer's Birds magazine. Tony Soper! A young man when I was a child and still young, bless him, like David Attenborough. Birds and animals! Pure souls! Spend a lifetime studying them and end up younger than you started!

"We prize the great spotted woodpecker which visits for suet in winter," writes Tony, "but conveniently forget that it becomes a thug in the summer, when it chisels its way into a tit box for the meaty nestlings."

Oh shit! Not the bloody woodpecker - literally.

"Mum?"

Coming! Insurance premium paid. Glance out of window, dreading to see in sky the eye of the terrible woodpecker and the blood on his terrible head. Stalin in a nutshell.
