fields.headline: The End of innocence
fields.standfirst: Nearly half the sexual abuse suffered by children is inflicted on them by other children, it is now reckoned. What was once considered horseplay or youthful experiment has come to be viewed in a much more sinister light. Does a game of Kiss Chase really amount to harassment, or are we indulging in a moral panic? Is it possible to define 'appropriate' behaviour for the very young? Dea Birkett investigates the case of 10-year-old Johnny R , once accused of molesting a little girl with whom he played football
fields.trailText: Nearly half the sexual abuse suffered by children is inflicted on them by other children, it is now reckoned. What was once considered horseplay or youthful experiment has come to be viewed in a much more sinister light. Does a game of Kiss Chase really amount to harassment, or are we indulging in a moral panic? Is it possible to define 'appropriate' behaviour for the very young?
fields.body:
Once upon a time, not so very long ago, there lived little girls and little boys who skipped and jumped and hopped and laughed and played together. Snails, sugar, spice and all things nice, that's what these little children were made of. We told them stories and tucked them up in bed at night, warmed by the certainty that the only monsters were in their storybooks. Childhood was an enchanted place that we all believed in. But this story doesn't have a happy ending: our cherubs aren't gently sent to the Land of Nod with a soft lullaby. In this story, our children become changelings, their chubby faces distorted and menacing. The little boy tucked in bed is no longer to be trusted. He's a harasser, an abuser, a sexual predator. He indecently assaults, masturbates, rapes and buggers other children. Childhood is no longer a fairy-tale haven. We are being asked to believe in something far worse than any wicked fairy - that there's a silent, violent epidemic of children sexually abusing other children.

The NSPCC calculates that 40% of abuse on children is committed by other children, "and the true scale is much deeper than that". Kids just aren't kids any more. Boys won't just be boys; they'll be mini monstrous men. The NSPCC warns that "too many young abusers are slipping through the net. There has got to be a major education campaign to make sure that professionals - social workers, the teaching and medical professions, and others - are properly informed about the abuse of children by other children so that their behaviour is not dismissed as 'horseplay' or 'natural experimentation'."

These abusive acts are not confined to teenage tearaways, overcome by a surge of pubescent testosterone. Last weekend an 11-year-old was arrested in Lincolnshire on suspicion of raping a 12-year-old girl. "There are more and more referrals from younger children - six-, seven-, eight-year-olds are not uncommon. Our experience tells us that children as young as five are sexually abusing," says the NSPCC, listing sadism, fetishism, cross-dressing, masturbation, exhibitionism, voyeurism, zoophilia (sex with animals) and "digital and object penetration" as the types of activities that even kindergarten kids engage in. In an adult attempt at a remedy, there are almost 50 centres throughout the country dedicated to the new field of tackling "sexually inappropriate behaviour" in adolescents and young people. And every week, another child is taken to court charged with rape or indecent assault on another child. In 1997, the last available statistics, more than 1,000 young people were found guilty of or cautioned for sexual offences. There is no way of calculating how many are currently on the Sex Offenders Register; there are probably around 200.

In this new, unsettling moral universe, is our children's normal sexual development being criminalised? Does touching your sister's genitals, once, become an abusive act? Is experimentation between children being unnecessarily seen as a mighty problem that needs to be tackled? Is an over-zealous interest in Postman's Knock really the signature of an apprentice paedophile? Is French kissing another six-year-old assault? Is "show me yours and I'll show you mine" a sexually inappropriate request? Is the unimaginable really happening in the enchanted land? Is this the end of innocence?

Johnny R is 10 years old. He supports Manchester United, plays midfield for the local under-11s, watches snooker on TV and wants a Sega Dreamcast for his birthday. He has also been on the Sex Offenders Register. Last August, Johnny was convicted of indecent assault. His alleged victim was a neighbour who lived opposite him in their wide suburban street, where all the houses have front and back gardens. They were in the same class at primary school. She liked to play goalie to his midfield, using a bike as a goalpost.

Then, one day, when they were playing football together on a local building site, up past the smart new show-homes, she ran home to her Mum. "I asked her what was wrong, and she burst into tears," says her mother, Mrs S. "She went on to say that Johnny had pulled down her pants and touched her. I asked her again what was wrong, what happened. She said Johnny had touched her where she wees."

The "victim", Nicky S, was eight years old. Johnny, small and blond, was first charged with rape - the youngest person ever to be so - though this was later reduced to indecent assault. It took until November to clear his name.

It was Cup Final day last May. Johnny's story is this: "We were watching United, and Eric [his best friend] knocked on the door and said, 'Do you want a game of football?' and I said, 'Yes'. And Nicky was playing on her bike. And Nicky came up to us and said, 'Can I play football?' I said, 'No, you can't.' I just said no. Then Eric said, 'Go on, then, let her.' We went up to the building site and just played a game of football until Nicky came and she put her bike down. I was sweating and I lied on the floor for about five minutes. She jumped on me, just jumped on me, playing. She bounced on me. When Eric got on the floor, he was sweating and all, she jumped on top of him. I said, 'Get off him. Get off him.' And Eric said, 'Get off me.' And she went up to the fence and she climbed over the top, it was all pointy, and when she got to the top she ripped her knickers, and when she got down she looked at her knickers, and she went home to her Mum crying. She blamed it all on me. I was her friend for a very long time, but she's not my friend any more."

I met this Lilliputian sex offender in his grandmother's spick-and-span house. There was a constant burr from the washing machine. Nana R was endlessly wiping smudges of chocolate from her grandchildren's faces and her pea-green, velveteen three-piece suite. Although the house was full of children, it was an obsessively clean home. She hasn't been back to work at the supermarket since her grandson's arrest, and now spends her days dusting and polishing. "I didn't used to be like this," she says. Johnny was feeding his baby sister a bottle filled with Coca-Cola and pulling funny faces, making her gurgle. He has one of those young boy mouths that are always slightly open, giving him the appearance of being in permanent shock. And he was dressed in a 10-year-old's kit of football top, track-suit bottoms with poppers up the sides, and trainers, not the cheap kind, but a proper brand name.

Mrs R, Johnny's mother, is chain-smoking, her hands shaking with anxiety and anger. She has cut and dyed her hair into a blond bob since the trial, in the hope that fewer people will recognise her. "He was arrested, read his rights, and led down to the cells, like an animal, for rape," she says. I asked Johnny, "Did you know what rape was?" He looks bemused, confused: "No." His mother interrupts: "They asked him in the first interview if he got an erection. He just looked at me and said, 'What's that?' They asked him questions, and sometimes they had to rearrange them because he didn't understand. They finger-printed him. They even had to stand him on a box for the photograph, because he wasn't tall enough."

Johnny was bailed to his grandparents'. "He wanted to know why he couldn't go home to his mum," says Nana R. "He cried to go home. We had to explain to him that he must never leave this house and go home, even if he wants to. It's only about 10 minutes away, walking, only two roads, five minutes on his bike. He can't go out unless there's a grown-up with him. We found it a bit hard, really. Because the children he was used to around here - there was about eight of them - they'd all play football together. I don't want the children knocking on the door asking if he can go out and play. There's only so many excuses you can make. And then they start saying, 'Why can't he play?' We had to have a social worker here for two hours on a Sunday, so he could mix with his brother and sister. And if he went upstairs to play on his Play Station, this social worker had to go up and follow him."

At his trial three months later, Johnny R was found guilty of indecent assault on Nicky S. He was placed under a three-year supervision order. He hadn't been at lessons since the Cup Final, as he would have had to share a classroom with his former friend. Johnny passed his days watching snooker on TV and waiting for the normal pattern of his life to resume - school, football, playing in the street with his mates.

On the R family's tight, neat estate, gossip inevitably flies as freely as the kids' footballs. "This is a very small town, so everything goes round," says Mrs R. "Every child in that school knows. You'd be able to see that doubt in them." I ask Johnny to show me his Sex Offenders Register form; he called it "that list, sex offenders thing", and obviously had no idea what it meant. He found it quickly, by the mock-antique phone; everything is so ordered at Nana's. His name was written on it, and the simple words "Indecent Assault on Female Under 16". Then he put "that list" back in its registered envelope and went off to play on the Fischer Price "Talk to Teddy" phone. "It's Granddad! It's Granddad!" he pretends to his little sister.

Johnny R was only 10, but that didn't stop him being categorised as an abuser. In the language of the sex-offender treatment-practitioners, Johnny was a "denier". Such children, it is believed, simply refuse to admit the true extent of the harm that they have caused. However hard a child protests the innocence of their actions, that they were just mucking around, it's not accepted. "You expect people to deny at first," says Mark Dalton, team manager of the NSPCC's Midlands Project for Young People With Inappropriate Sexual Behaviour. "Why would they admit? People deny the intent or seriousness of it, or aspects of the responsibility. They say he was leading me on. You only admit to get it over and done with. And it's not a question of simply going, 'It's a fair cop, Guv. I did it.' We want the emotion that goes with that."

Projects have been established throughout Britain, by probation services, children's services and young-offender units, to enable young abusers to come to terms with what they have done, to have that "emotion". There are 18 NSPCC young-abuser projects throughout the country, with 12 more planned, "to stop young abusers becoming the serial paedophiles in the future". They provide sessions of individual or group therapy, over a period of three months to a year, designed to make the children "address their abusive behaviour", increase "victim empathy" (ie understand how hurtful it is to be abused by them) and motivate them to change, "to replace anti-social thoughts and behaviour with more positive ones".

This is a new and burgeoning professional field. At a recent National Organisation for the Treatment of Abusers (NOTA) conference on Effective Research And Protective Practice, in York, there were more than 400 participants who work with sex offenders. Twelve workshops focused on young abusers, from Family Therapy with Incarcerated Young Sex Offenders to Focused Group Treatment for Sexually Acting Out Boys Aged 10-15 Years. The consensus among the participants was that "sexually inappropriate behaviour" generally begins between the ages of six and seven, and that it will have happened many times before it is detected, usually years later. The orthodoxy goes that, for each reported incident, there are scores more unreported. This is the model that would be applied to Johnny R.

In this messy landscape of children's sexual development, measuring what is inappropriate is not a simple task. A recent referral to Dalton's Project For Young People With Inappropriate Sexual Behaviour is a seven-year-old who rubbed Smarties on his penis and fed them to a younger child. There is still no benchmark of "appropriate" behaviour against which such actions can be assessed. Health trust ethical committees are understandably reluctant for any research on children's sexual development to be carried out on their patch. Children's emerging sexuality remains an area of which we adults are simply ignorant. John Coleman, director of the Trust for the Study of Adolescents, says, "What is normal? We don't know. We don't have the research to tell us. It's absurd how little concrete information we've got when it's so important and has so many implications. We don't know what is actually happening out there."

Of course, there are indisputable cases of abuse. The Sex Offender Unit at Middlesex Probation Service has worked with gang rapists, abductors and stalkers, all in their early teens. Marcus Erooga, an NSPCC team manager and co-editor of the recently published Children And Young People Who Sexually Abuse Others: Challenges And Responses, argues that the area of what counts as abuse is not as fuzzy as it might seem. "There's a very tight definition," he says. "Inappropriate and non-consensual. It's quite explicit, deliberate, sexual acts."

Our confusion arises from our refusal to take abuse by children seriously. What would count as clear abuse if perpetrated on a child by an adult is often not seen as such when the perpetrator is a child themselves. "There's a myth that goes around that if a child has been abused by another child, it's not that bad," says Anne Blues, team manager of the NSPCC/Barnado's project Kaleidoscope, which specialises in treating very young children "whose sexual behaviour harms others". Kaleidoscope is "pro-active" in trying to get girl abusers, in particular, referred to them. "Girls are defined as promiscuous when they're actually abusive," says Blues. "And the boys won't tell you, because the overriding feeling is, 'Aren't they lucky'."

But beyond obvious examples, there lies a hinterland of sexual activity where such certainties founder. Last March, Cheynes Infant School in Luton banned the playground game Kiss Chase because it involved "unwanted physical attention" and the "exchange of bodily fluids" (ie saliva). Headteacher Maureen Fitzgerald wrote a letter to parents explaining that she considered the game, with small children putting their tongues in each other's mouths, "inappropriate behaviour". Some believe that Doctors And Nurses will be next.

Ann Furedi, columnist and director of communications at the British Pregnancy Advisory Service, says that adults are unnecessarily proscribing childish actions. "I believe children will explore their body, their genitals, and ask questions in an entirely unembarrassed and unawkward way, without really placing it in a sexual context. We then look at this through a particular prism. Increasingly, there's a tendency to interpret what would have been seen as quite innocent activities as being loaded with a sexual context."

When is an act by a child sexual at all, rather than plain, old-fashioned bad behaviour? Marcus Erooga insists that, even if the child doesn't understand the notion of sexual and gets no sexual gratification from their actions, it should still be seen as sexual abuse. "The reason that it's important that the word sexual remains there, whatever the motivation, is because the behaviour still has a sexual component and is likely to continue to effect their sexual development if not addressed," he says. In one recent case, an 11-year-old boy was convicted of assaulting a two-year-old relative. Her mother had called the police when she found him lying naked with her daughter. Although the boy pleaded guilty, a doctor's report was accepted by the judge that concluded he suffered from Attention Deficit Disorder and there was "no clear evidence that sexual motivation was a part of this incident". Nevertheless, the 11-year-old was placed on the Sex Offenders Register for 30 months.

Increasingly, younger and younger children are being defined as sexual abusers. Anne Blues's youngest client was three years old. "She was excluded from nursery for masturbating and for using implements on other children - pencils and things. She obviously didn't understand what she was doing, but she was doing things to other children and they did not want her to. It's important not to label children, but we have to describe the behaviour." But, unlike other childish crimes - pick-pocketing, shoplifting, joyriding - the argument is not simply whether the young person did it or not. The argument is whether what they did actually caused harm and was morally wrong. Once, God and Mother provided signposts through this murky emotional landscape. That job is being increasingly handed over to the young abuser professionals who decide what is acceptable and what is not. There's an understandable desire among these experts to get to grips with the grey area of nascent sexual development. They want to draw up some harder and faster rules.

Attempts to codify "appropriate sexual behaviour" in children began in the US where, just 15 years ago, there was no such thing as a treatment programme for sexually-abusive kids. By 1996, there were 50 residential and 396 non-residential programmes for sex offenders under the age of 12. These centres needed clear-cut categories applied to the emotional mess of children's emerging sexuality.

A plethora of handbooks were published, advising parents, teachers, health-care workers and children themselves what was "appropriate sexual behaviour". The most popular was Flirting Or Hurting?, first published in 1994 and selling more than 20,000 copies. This book charts the differences between flirting and harassment. Flirting, it suggests, includes comments such as, "Like your hair" and "You look nice". Harassment might be lip-licking and the very same phrase that might, with another tone of voice or facial expression, be appropriate: "You look nice."

But even in a society that believes it is having some success in codifying "normal" sexual behaviour, there is furious debate. In the autumn of 1996 in Lexington, North Carolina, first-grader Johnathan Prevette was punished for giving a classmate a peck on the cheek. The boy's defence - that the girl had asked for a kiss - was not accepted. His punishment included being forced to miss an ice-cream party for children with good attendance records.

The six-year-old Prevette became a cause célèbre, and members of his family were invited on to TV chatshows as honoured guests. Jane Martin, a spokesperson for the school district, declared, "A six-year-old kissing another six-year-old is inappropriate behaviour. Unwelcome is unwelcome at any age." She went on to point out that the rules on sexual harassment were clearly set out in a handbook.

Few adults share this clear-cut sense of boundaries beyond which a child must not tread. The recent collapse of a case against 11-year-old Swiss boy Raoul Wuthrich, accused by a neighbour in Colorado of touching his five-year-old sister "in an inappropriate way" while helping her pee in the garden, demonstrates how difficult it is to set clear guidelines. Yet, whatever the uncertainties, it inevitably and rightly falls on us adults to guide and police children's sexual development. According to former teacher Neil Duncan, senior lecturer in education at the University of Wolverhampton and author of Sexual Bullying, we are seeing a teenage world through the prism of adult eyes: "Staff have come to me to report 'disgusting' things they've heard about bodily fluids [semen] - the last taboo. You go along and speak to the kids, who say it was 'just a laugh'. That's all it meant. We're so uptight about the sexual behaviour of children that any contact can be reconstituted in terms of peer child abuse."

Once the decision is reached that an act of abuse has occurred, the child is then judged a deviant. The NSPCC believes that he or she may well be an adult sex offender in the making. "Paedophiles don't wake up at 23," they argue. "We know adult paedophiles start fantasising sexual interest in children as adolescents."

But not all young abuser professionals believe that there is an inevitable slippery slope from teenage groping to adult offending. "The received wisdom 10 years ago was that if you didn't help people stop, they would never stop, and that juvenile abusers were just adult abusers in training. But that just doesn't stand up," says Mark Dalton. "The most usual experience we get is a young teenage boy who is in a caring role with a child he knows and it's a grope, it's a fondle, it's that sort of thing. We can't say that that 15-year-old is going to become the next Fred West." Alison Hadley, national policy officer at Brooks Advisory Service, makes a plea for adult tolerance of our adolescents. "We have to remember that they're children, and are needing guidance and support. People forget that it's a steep learning curve in your teens, and you do make mistakes."

Mistakes can be costly for today's teenagers. One Monday morning in June, Pete K's mother received a phone call from his Catholic secondary school asking her to come and take her son back home. A girl, 14, had reported that, while she was sitting next to him in class the previous Wednesday, Pete, also 14, had taken hold of her hand and put it on his crotch. She then said that he had placed his hand on her leg and moved it towards her crotch. Pete admitted taking her hand, but denied placing his hand on her leg. This was said to have happened during a French lesson, with 28 other children and a teacher present.

The girl's father reported the incident and Mrs K was asked to take her son down to the police station, where he was arrested for indecent assault and cautioned. "Fair enough, he did act inappropriately," she says. "He signed the caution, and then out came the Sex Offenders Register." Even those who have simply accepted a caution are required to be registered for two-and-a-half years. The police did not make the K family or their solicitor aware of this requirement before they accepted the caution. "When we were asked to sign the register, we refused," says Mrs K. "First, they were going to arrest me for not compelling him to sign. Then him, for not signing."

Two weeks later, Pete was permanently excluded from school, just over a year before he was due to sit his GCSEs. His younger sister was sent away to live with her father, out of the district, as a condition of him returning home. He was allowed supervised visits to see her once a week. "To me as a normal person, he's done nothing different from what millions of teenagers do," says Mrs K. "That's why I wouldn't sign it. If they put all these adolescents on the register, it will be a very big one. They want to put children by the side of paedophiles. There's something wrong."

Johnny R's appeal date was set in early November, three months after his conviction. There were no wigs, few formalities, and the grey-haired judge leaned over his bench and said, "If Johnny wants to break off to go to the loo or to stretch his legs, just let me know." But courtrooms are not child-friendly, and the ceiling, as high as a church, made Johnny, in a blue fleece jacket and jogging pants, seem even smaller. His mouth was still hanging open a little, perhaps wondering what this was all about. The R family were all dressed ferociously neatly, with oiled-back hair and fiercely ironed suits, as if the slightest crease would somehow make them crumble. Only a courtroom away, a woman was being convicted for murdering her children.

The tape of the initial police interview with Nicky S was played. The woman police officer was very gentle with her, constantly reassuring, "You're doing very well," and muttering a soft, "Okay, Okay." (In contrast, when Johnny started crying, he was told sharply by the same police officer, "I don't want you snivelling all through the interview.") "He's very fond of me, he does love me, but I don't love him," Nicky told the kind police lady. As this declaration played in court, the prosecuting solicitor took a pen out of her Winnie the Pooh pencil case. In this strange arena, what counted as childish and adult seemed to have become confused. When we watched the tape of Johnny's best friend, Eric, trying to describe what went on, he said Johnny "fancied her . . . they've been dating each other". His words trespassed into dangerous territory. To the grown-ups, they sounded far too adult for his age. Eric was nine.

Nicky, a tiny Nike fashion plate, was cross-examined by video link. At one point, she buried her head entirely inside her T-shirt, so all we could see on the screen was a giant Nike tick. She began to cry, "It's not my fault I can't remember things when I was little." Six months, when she was eight-and-three-quarters rather than nine, is an age ago for a small child.

There were moments when the moral nature of this trial was all too clear. The police interrogated Johnny for a second time: "What's a snog?" asked the officer.

"I didn't ask her," whimpers Johnny.

"You didn't ask her for a snog?"

"No."

"You don't know what that word means? Does it mean kiss?"

"Yes."

"But you didn't ask her for a snog?"

"No."

And I can't help thinking, so what if he did. It's not a crime - and surely not "inappropriate sexual behaviour" - for a 10-year-old to ask a girl he works with in maths group for a snog. Ask for a snog, not force one on her. The prosecuting barrister pursued the suggestion that Johnny "fancied" Nicky, imputing adult desires and intentions to these young children. He questioned Johnny: "You like Nicky very much, don't you?" (Yes) "You thought she was nice?" (Yes). "Did you love her?" (No) "You wanted to be her boyfriend?" (No). It was as if this, this fumbling for adolescence, had itself become a crime.

My impression was that all the children were terrified of all the adults - whether the softly-spoken police woman in the interview room, the barking barristers, or even their own families. All the little interviewees seemed to be desperately trying to give answers that wouldn't get them in trouble. They knew they'd done something that grown-ups didn't like. The words used by the adults in court to describe the children's genitals was "rude bits", and their alleged actions were "messing with" and "naughty". The message was clear: whatever these children were doing, if anything at all, the grown-ups thought it was dirty.

But the grey-haired judge decided otherwise. It took him less than four minutes to decide: "They had all played together on numerous occasions, and on some of these occasions there had been horseplay," he said. "Are we sure the conduct was indecent? We've come to the conclusion that we cannot be sure." The case against the 10-year-old was overturned. Johnny R won his appeal. He's started going to a new school, making new friends to play football with. He's just had his 11th birthday party. He got his Sega Dreamcast.

Marcus Erooga, an NSPCC team manager and co-editor of the recently published Children And Young People Who Sexually Abuse Others: Challenges And Responses, argues that the area of what counts as abuse is not as fuzzy as it might seem. "There's a very tight definition," he says. "Inappropriate and non-consensual. It's quite explicit, deliberate, sexual acts." Our confusion arises from our refusal to take abuse by children seriously. What would count as clear abuse if perpetrated on a child by an adult is often not seen as such when the perpetrator is a child themselves. "There's a myth that goes around that if a child has been abused by another child, it's not that bad," says Anne Blues, team manager of the NSPCC/Barnado's project Kaleidoscope, which specialises in treating very young children "whose sexual behaviour harms others". Kaleidoscope is "pro-active" in trying to get girl abusers, in particular, referred to them. "Girls are defined as promiscuous when they're actually abusive," says Blues. "And the boys won't tell you, because the overriding feeling is, 'Aren't they lucky'." But beyond obvious examples, there lies a hinterland of sexual activity where such certainties founder. Last March, Cheynes Infant School in Luton banned the playground game Kiss Chase because it involved "unwanted physical attention" and the "exchange of bodily fluids" (ie saliva). Headteacher Maureen Fitzgerald wrote a letter to parents explaining that she considered the game, with small children putting their tongues in each other's mouths, "inappropriate behaviour". Some believe that Doctors And Nurses will be next. Ann Furedi, columnist and director of communications at the British Pregnancy Advisory Service, says that adults are unnecessarily proscribing childish actions. "I believe children will explore their body, their genitals, and ask questions in an entirely unembarrassed and unawkward way, without really placing it in a sexual context. We then look at this through a particular prism. Increasingly, there's a tendency to interpret what would have been seen as quite innocent activities as being loaded with a sexual context." When is an act by a child sexual at all, rather than plain, old-fashioned bad behaviour? Marcus Erooga insists that, even if the child doesn't understand the notion of sexual and gets no sexual gratification from their actions, it should still be seen as sexual abuse. "The reason that it's important that the word sexual remains there, whatever the motivation, is because the behaviour still has a sexual component and is likely to continue to effect their sexual development if not addressed," he says. In one recent case, an 11-year-old boy was convicted of assaulting a two-year-old relative. Her mother had called the police when she found him lying naked with her daughter. Although the boy pleaded guilty, a doctor's report was accepted by the judge that concluded he suffered from Attention Deficit Disorder and there was "no clear evidence that sexual motivation was a part of this incident". Nevertheless, the 11-year-old was placed on the Sex Offenders Register for 30 months. Increasingly, younger and younger children are being defined as sexual abusers. Anne Blues's youngest client was three years old. "She was excluded from nursery for masturbating and for using implements on other children - pencils and things. She obviously didn't understand what she was doing, but she was doing things to other children and they did not want her to. It's important not to label children, but we have to describe the behaviour." But, unlike other childish crimes - pick-pocketing, shoplifting, joyriding - the argument is not simply whether the young person did it or not. The argument is whether what they did actually caused harm and was morally wrong. Once, God and Mother provided signposts through this murky emotional landscape. That job is being increasingly handed over to the young abuser professionals who decide what is acceptable and what is not. There's an understandable desire among these experts to get to grips with the grey area of nascent sexual development. They want to draw up some harder and faster rules. Attempts to codify "appropriate sexual behaviour" in children began in the US where, just 15 years ago, there was no such thing as a treatment programme for sexually-abusive kids. By 1996, there were 50 residential and 396 non-residential programmes for sex offenders under the age of 12. These centres needed clear-cut categories applied to the emotional mess of children's emerging sexuality. A plethora of handbooks were published, advising parents, teachers, health-care workers and children themselves what was "appropriate sexual behaviour". The most popular was Flirting Or Hurting?, first published in 1994 and selling more than 20,000 copies. This book charts the differences between flirting and harassment. Flirting, it suggests, includes comments such as, "Like your hair" and "You look nice". Harassment might be lip-licking and the very same phrase that might, with another tone of voice or facial expression, be appropriate: "You look nice." But even in a society that believes it is having some success in codifying "normal" sexual behaviour, there is furious debate. In the autumn of 1996 in Lexington, North Carolina, first-grader Johnathan Prevette was punished for giving a classmate a peck on the cheek. The boy's defence - that the girl had asked for a kiss - was not accepted. His punishment included being forced to miss an ice-cream party for children with good attendance records. The six-year-old Prevette became a cause célèbre, and members of his family were invited on to TV chatshows as honoured guests. Jane Martin, a spokesperson for the school district, declared, "A six-year-old kissing another six-year-old is inappropriate behaviour. Unwelcome is unwelcome at any age." She went on to point out that the rules on sexual harassment were clearly set out in a handbook. Few adults share this clear-cut sense of boundaries beyond which a child must not tread. The recent collapse of a case against 11-year-old Swiss boy Raoul Wuthrich, accused by a neighbour in Colorado of touching his five-year-old sister "in an inappropriate way" while helping her pee in the garden, demonstrates how difficult it is to set clear guidelines. Yet, whatever the uncertainties, it inevitably and rightly falls on us adults to guide and police children's sexual development. According to former teacher Neil Duncan, senior lecturer in education at the University of Wolverhampton and author of Sexual Bullying, we are seeing a teenage world through the prism of adult eyes: "Staff have come to me to report 'disgusting' things they've heard about bodily fluids [semen] - the last taboo. You go along and speak to the kids, who say it was 'just a laugh'. That's all it meant. We're so uptight about the sexual behaviour of children that any contact can be reconstituted in terms of peer child abuse." Once the decision is reached that an act of abuse has occurred, the child is then judged a deviant. The NSPCC believes that he or she may well be an adult sex offender in the making. "Paedophiles don't wake up at 23," they argue. "We know adult paedophiles start fantasising sexual interest in children as adolescents." But not all young abuser professionals believe that there is an inevitable slippery slope from teenage groping to adult offending. "The received wisdom 10 years ago was that if you didn't help people stop, they would never stop, and that juvenile abusers were just adult abusers in training. But that just doesn't stand up," says Mark Dalton. "The most usual experience we get is a young teenage boy who is in a caring role with a child he knows and it's a grope, it's a fondle, it's that sort of thing. We can't say that that 15-year-old is going to become the next Fred West." Alison Hadley, national policy officer at Brooks Advisory Service, makes a plea for adult tolerance of our adolescents. "We have to remember that they're children, and are needing guidance and support. People forget that it's a steep learning curve in your teens, and you do make mistakes." Mistakes can be costly for today's teenagers. One Monday morning in June, Pete K's mother received a phone call from his Catholic secondary school asking her to come and take her son back home. A girl, 14, had reported that, while she was sitting next to him in class the previous Wednesday, Pete, also 14, had taken hold of her hand and put it on his crotch. She then said that he had placed his hand on her leg and moved it towards her crotch. Pete admitted taking her hand, but denied placing his hand on her leg. This was said to have happened during a French lesson, with 28 other children and a teacher present. The girl's father reported the incident and Mrs K was asked to take her son down to the police station, where he was arrested for indecent assault and cautioned. "Fair enough, he did act inappropriately," she says. "He signed the caution, and then out came the Sex Offenders Register." Even those who have simply accepted a caution are required to be registered for two-and-a-half years. The police did not make the K family or their solicitor aware of this requirement before they accepted the caution. "When we were asked to sign the register, we refused," says Mrs K. "First, they were going to arrest me for not compelling him to sign. Then him, for not signing." Two weeks later, Pete was permanently excluded from school, just over a year before he was due to sit his GCSEs. His younger sister was sent away to live with her father, out of the district, as a condition of him returning home. He was allowed supervised visits to see her once a week. "To me as a normal person, he's done nothing different from what millions of teenagers do," says Mrs K. "That's why I wouldn't sign it. If they put all these adolescents on the register, it will be a very big one. They want to put children by the side of paedophiles. There's something wrong." Johnny R's appeal date was set in early November, three months after his conviction. There were no wigs, few formalities, and the grey-haired judge leaned over his bench and said, "If Johnny wants to break off to go to the loo or to stretch his legs, just let me know." But courtrooms are not child-friendly, and the ceiling, as high as a church, made Johnny, in a blue fleece jacket and jogging pants, seem even smaller. His mouth was still hanging open a little, perhaps wondering what this was all about. The R family were all dressed ferociously neatly, with oiled-back hair and fiercely ironed suits, as if the slightest crease would somehow make them crumble. Only a courtroom away, a woman was being convicted for murdering her children. The tape of the initial police interview with Nicky S was played. The woman police officer was very gentle with her, constantly reassuring, "You're doing very well," and muttering a soft, "Okay, Okay." (In contrast, when Johnny started crying, he was told sharply by the same police officer, "I don't want you snivelling all through the interview.") "He's very fond of me, he does love me, but I don't love him," Nicky told the kind police lady. As this declaration played in court, the prosecuting solicitor took a pen out of her Winnie the Pooh pencil case. In this strange arena, what counted as childish and adult seemed to have become confused. When we watched the tape of Johnny's best friend, Eric, trying to describe what went on, he said Johnny "fancied her . . . they've been dating each other". His words trespassed into dangerous territory. To the grown-ups, they sounded far too adult for his age. Eric was nine. Nicky, a tiny Nike fashion plate, was cross-examined by video link. At one point, she buried her head entirely inside her T-shirt, so all we could see on the screen was a giant Nike tick. She began to cry, "It's not my fault I can't remember things when I was little." Six months, when she was eight-and-three-quarters rather than nine, is an age ago for a small child. There were moments when the moral nature of this trial was all too clear. The police interrogated Johnny for a second time: "What's a snog?" asked the officer. "I didn't ask her," whimpers Johnny. "You didn't ask her for a snog?" "No." "You don't know what that word means? Does it mean kiss?" "Yes." "But you didn't ask her for a snog?" "No." And I can't help thinking, so what if he did. It's not a crime - and surely not "inappropriate sexual behaviour" - for a 10-year-old to ask a girl he works with in maths group for a snog. Ask for a snog, not force one on her. The prosecuting barrister pursued the suggestion that Johnny "fancied" Nicky, imputing adult desires and intentions to these young children. He questioned Johnny: "You like Nicky very much, don't you?" (Yes) "You thought she was nice?" (Yes). "Did you love her?" (No) "You wanted to be her boyfriend?" (No). It was as if this, this fumbling for adolescence, had itself become a crime. My impression was that all the children were terrified of all the adults - whether the softly-spoken police woman in the interview room, the barking barristers, or even their own families. All the little interviewees seemed to be desperately trying to give answers that wouldn't get them in trouble. They knew they'd done something that grown-ups didn't like. The words used by the adults in court to describe the children's genitals was "rude bits", and their alleged actions were "messing with" and "naughty". The message was clear: whatever these children were doing, if anything at all, the grown-ups thought it was dirty. But the grey-haired judge decided otherwise. It took him less than four minutes to decide: "They had all played together on numerous occasions, and on some of these occasions there had been horseplay," he said. "Are we sure the conduct was indecent? We've come to the conclusion that we cannot be sure." The case against the 10-year-old was overturned. Johnny R won his appeal. He's started going to a new school, making new friends to play football with. He's just had his 11th birthday party. He got his Sega Dreamcast.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: One of the bêtes noires that seizes the often febrile, regularly addled, incorrigibly elitist minds of the denizens of the world of wine concerns brands. Certain critics, particularly, find the presence of wine brands intolerable because they can see in them their own irrelevance, if not their complete doom. The so-called connoisseur regards them as anathema. What both these categories of snob fail to appreciate is that they buy into brands every bit as much as the drinker who has Don Darias with his Sunday lunch - the only difference being that the latter usually gets much better value. Chteau D'Yquem, Chteau Lafite et al are also brands, but they are ones that meet the wine snob's ache for rarity. Their performance can miserably fail to live up to their perceived status, but it is difficult to discern these things if one's nose is toffee.
fields.body:
One of the bêtes noires that seizes the often febrile, regularly addled, incorrigibly elitist minds of the denizens of the world of wine concerns brands. Certain critics, particularly, find the presence of wine brands intolerable because they can see in them their own irrelevance, if not their complete doom. The so-called connoisseur regards them as anathema. What both these categories of snob fail to appreciate is that they buy into brands every bit as much as the drinker who has Don Darias with his Sunday lunch - the only difference being that the latter usually gets much better value. Chteau D'Yquem, Chteau Lafite et al are also brands, but they are ones that meet the wine snob's ache for rarity. Their performance can miserably fail to live up to their perceived status, but it is difficult to discern these things if one's nose is toffee.

A wine brand need not be a particular product. France is a wine brand; so is Australia. Both satisfy the conditions of brand-dom in that they represent perception rather than reality - a perception encouraged by marketeers - and both offer reassurance. Chile is some years from reaching brand status, but it is getting there. Palmeria, formerly La Palma, is a wine range under the brand umbrella of Chile and it represents, to this drinker, an exemplar of what the subject under discussion is about: the creation of consistency, excellence, good value and, above all, reassurance, which is not betrayed by any gap between perception and reality. In other words, the perfect brand.

Sainsbury's has La Palmeria Chardonnay Gran Reserva 1998 (16 points, out of 20, £7.99), and it is infinitely preferable to any number of jejune Montrachets (another regional brand). It is excitingly fruity without being so exuberant that you cannot compose sonnets while you sip. Oddbins has La Palmeria Merlot Cabernet Gran Reserva 1998 (16.5 points, £7.99), and here there is a measure of fullness and mouth-filling sensuality that cannot be compared with the wine brand that has made this grape recipe famous (Bordeaux), because to do so insults the wine. Oddbins also has, as do Fullers and the CWS, La Palmeria Cabernet Sauvignon 1998 (16 points, £3.99), which is not as textured as its pricier sister, nor so complex. It's more like a merlot in its leathery odiferousness and soft, utterly delicious, civilised tannins - but, for the money, it is a steal. Oddbins and Sainsbury have La Palmeria Reserva Cabernet Sauvignon/ Merlot 1998 (16.5 points, £5.49), which has some juiciness but is judiciously dry to finish - between these contrasting textural features, there is a rippling river of cassis-tinged richness.

Sainsbury's, Fullers (now sold to Unwins) and the CWS also have the pinnacle of the range: La Palmeria Merlot Gran Reserva 1998 (17 points, £7.99). 'Lushly classy for the classy lush,' one is tempted to say, but then you will have to include me in that because I drank a bottle of this wine's engagingly aromatic, crumpled-velvet fruit over the New Year weekend, while my head was in one of my hardback Christmas presents. And I can tell you that it beat any number of putative Rivers of Fire hollow. A substantial wine of elegance and power, it offers much better value than Chteau Petrus (the perceived ultimate merlot brand, of which the last bottle I confronted retailed at £800).

Somerfield, alas, has failed to become a brand among supermarkets, except where wine and readers of this column are concerned, and three splendid reds recently caught my eye. They are Piccini Chianti Classico 1996 (16 points, £6.49), South African Bush Vines Pinotage 1998 (16 points, £4.99), and Castano Monastrell Merlot 1998 (15.5 points, £3.99), from Spain. The Chianti offers mature, earthy cherries and spicy plums. Gruff-voiced, but avuncular, this wine is great for quaffing and good with robust food. The Cape wine parades tobacco- edged fruit with a handsome texture and savoury finishing tannins. These are also in evidence with the Spaniard, which has the loveliness but not gawkiness of youth to its fruit. It does not taste as if it came over with the Armada, as is often the case with certain mouldy Riojas (once a brand to be reckoned with).

fields.headline: How to...dance
fields.trailText: How to shake your thang at raves, clubs, weddings and family parties
fields.body:
In clubs, men have a very formal dance that involves getting another beer and slumping in their chair. Eventually, he'll get up and dance with/ obstruct/tackle the woman of his choice. This movement is designed to get women off the dancefloor quickly, to somewhere where the man is not quite so vulnerable.

Some women get up on the floor and dance alone with their arms above their heads. On no account try to dance with them, as they are obviously doing something intensely sensuous and won't want you suddenly grabbing them and spinning them.

Rave dancing is pretty straightforward: you just take a little pill and the music tells you what to do. When you've finished dancing, you realise that you've been doing exactly the same movement for three hours, you're two stone lighter and you've forgotten where you live.

At weddings and family parties, all generations can display their dancing skills. You can put on the Sex Pistols, and the over- 60s will immediately start a nice little quick-step that they perfected during the Blitz. Then, all parents who were alive in the 60s will re-create some of the groovy moves with which they attempted to cash in on free love. These get the same kind of response that they did back then.

Most people who are forced on to the floor opt for the traditional shuffling-haddock routine, in which you step gingerly from one foot to the other and look intently at the floor as if you've just dropped 2p. Sadly, the people who look most ridiculous on the dancefloor are those people who really enjoy dancing and are just full of an insane urge to move their body to Gloria Gaynor. They may be enjoying themselves, but to everyone else they look like Rumpelstiltskin.

Often you'll get an ugly couple who've been to dance classes. While everyone else is gently shimmying around, they're chucking each other over their heads and swinging each other around as if they were in a hammer-throwing competition.

The only group that won't dance at all are the youngsters, for whom the disco was specifically arranged. They are completely paralysed by coolness and the songs played are never quite hip enough to overcome this.

There's always one sad young man who has got it into his head that dancing involves barging into people. Nothing clears the dancefloor faster than he does, and within seconds the old couple will be back doing their neat little quick-step.

fields.headline: Vernie Bennett
fields.trailText: Vernie Bennett was born in 1971, and brought up in Croydon. She began singing with her sister, Easther, in a gospel choir. In 1993, they formed Eternal with Louise Nurding and Kelle Bryan (who have now left the group), and have had 13 hits. Their new single is released next month. She lives in Surrey.
fields.body:
Vernie Bennett was born in 1971, and brought up in Croydon. She began singing with her sister, Easther, in a gospel choir. In 1993, they formed Eternal with Louise Nurding and Kelle Bryan (who have now left the group), and have had 13 hits. Their new single is released next month. She lives in Surrey.

What's your idea of perfect happiness?
Being in an environment where failure doesn't exist. What is your greatest fear?
Drowning - I never learned to swim. With which historical figure do you most identify?
Malcolm X: he struggled to further the cause he believed in. Which living person do you most admire?
My mother - strong woman with high values, taught me everything I know. What is the trait you most deplore in others?
Malicious gossip. What has been your most embarrassing moment?
Falling off stage in Germany. What's your greatest extravagance?
Chocolates. Where would you like to live?
New York - great city. What is your favourite smell?
Burning logs on a fire. What is your favourite book?
Flowers In The Attic. What is your favourite fantasy?
Bathing in chocolate. How did you vote in the election?
I didn't - I was working abroad. How will you vote in the next one?
It will depend on my political views at the time. Should the Royal Family be scrapped?
No, but they should be self-sufficient. Do you support capital punishment?
No, but life should mean life. For what cause would you die?
My religion. Do you believe in monogamy?
Yes, as I also believe in true love. What or who is the greatest love of your life?
God and my mum. Which person do you most despise?
Saddam Hussein - too many lives have been lost because of him. What do you consider the most overrated virtue?
Innocence. Knowledge is power. Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?
No - that's sad and dishonest. Which words or phrases do you most overuse?
'What's meant to be, will be.' When were you happiest?
Still looking for complete happiness. How do you relax?
Sitting in front of the fire with candles lit, drinking hot chocolate. What is the most important lesson that life has taught you?
Listen to your heart.

Still looking for complete happiness. How do you relax? Sitting in front of the fire with candles lit, drinking hot chocolate. What is the most important lesson that life has taught you? Listen to your heart.

fields.headline: Shell out on...oysters
fields.trailText: To their devotees: one of the great delicacies. To their detractors: something 'fishy and slimy and cold'.
fields.body:
The subject
To their devotees: one of the great delicacies. To their detractors: something 'fishy and slimy and cold'. To the Valentine's Day wishful-thinker: an aphrodisiac. To everyone: various edible bivalves, principally (in Europe) Ostrea edulis and Crassostrea angulata . The basics
A breeding oyster squirts out 800,000 tiny eggs, called spats (good thing they don't have to remember birthdays, then). The spats find something hard to cling to. Those that survive will then just sit there for years, feeding on nutriment-rich sea water, and can grow up to 25cm long. But modern oyster farming doesn't let them sit - they're removed from the seabed to protected 'parks', and from there to a prime spot (often an estuary) for final fattening before harvest at three to five years of age. Our principal suppliers: France (two billion of the little critters a year), UK and Ireland. The details
More numerous than an oyster's offspring. Ostrea edulis (called 'natives' here) has a rounded shell and unsurpassed flavour. But the longer, craggier Crassostrea angulata ('rock') will cause nearly equal ecstasy if it's been bred, raised and finished in super-fine brine. A tasting at the Selfridges' Oyster Bar (tough work) showed incontrovertibly that French oysters had far more complexity and finesse than English or Irish. In short: provenance rules, okay. In England, Colchester oysters triumph, albeit at a huge price. But then, great oysters are always expensive. The easy way out
Opening oysters is simple, once you've done it a hundred times or so. Buy an oyster knife, a dozen rock oysters and a box of plasters. Or go to a restaurant or oyster bar, and let the experts take the strain. Where to buy
Top people's stores such as Selfridges, or fancy fishmongers. Mail-order: Loch Fyne Oysters (01499 600236) sells rocks from £4.80 for half-a-dozen. Supermarkets don't often help out, though I've spotted small rocks at Waitrose. Final plea: any condiment other than a tiny squeeze of lemon is an oyster injustice.

fields.headline: No sweat
fields.standfirst: 'The principal advantage of steaming over boiling is that steaming is easier to control'
fields.trailText: 'The principal advantage of steaming over boiling is that steaming is easier to control'
fields.body:
Steaming was introduced to many post-war families via the pressure cooker. One of us remembers well the occasion when his mother chose to use the treasured new cooker to make some spinach: unfortunately, the jiggling weight on the pan's lid that controls the steam pressure came adrift and the spinach was expelled as a high-velocity green jet. With her kitchen ceiling festooned with stalactites of spinach, mother never repeated the experiment and from then on only boiled spinach was served.

This was a pity. Steaming - whether under pressure or not - is an excellent way of cooking, especially vegetables. This is because it preserves texture that is more easily lost when the vegetables are boiled. (Steaming is also claimed to preserve water-soluble nutrients that are lost by boiling, but this is largely a myth.) The principal advantage of steaming over boiling is that steaming is easier to control, because it is a less efficient way of transferring heat. This means that it takes longer, so that small errors in the timing make less difference to the final product.

In the roster of cooking efficiency, steaming occupies a place midway between boiling in water and roasting in the dry air of a hot oven. It is more efficient than roasting in dry air for two reasons. First, the steam condenses to form liquid droplets when it contacts the comparatively cool food surface, dumping its load of heat in a burst in the process. This load of latent heat is enormous - as hot, in fact, as the plate needed to boil the water in the first place. Moist air can also carry around three times as much heat as the same volume of dry air, which explains in part why we cook some foods in a bain-marie (that is, in a shallow dish of water in a hot oven).

The efficiency of the steaming can be increased by raising the temperature of the steam. Of course, the easiest way to do this is in a pressure cooker, where the higher pressures raise the boiling point of the water. The increased pressure itself doesn't make much difference to cooking efficiency - it is the increased temperature of the steam that does it. The uniformity of the cooking is also improved, since the steam is contained within a closed vessel that maintains a uniform temperature throughout.

There is considerable scope for using the imagination when it comes to steaming. One is to arrange for a gradient of cooking efficiency. Chefs do just this when cooking asparagus, by standing the spears vertically in an open steamer, so that the tender tips - being further away from the surface of the boiling water - are in a cooler environment than the bases and hence cook more slowly.

For the more adventurous cooks among us, there is also room to experiment with steaming over wine or other alcohol. Wine boils at around 97C, while stronger alcoholic drinks such as vodka have a boiling point of around 90C, so both should give longer cooking times and enhanced flavours. One tip: keep the lid on, and preferably cooled with a moistened cloth. That way, you won't set fire to your kitchen (alcohol vapour is inflammable). Equally importantly, you won't waste the alcohol by cooking this way: it will condense on the inside of the cooled lid and run back down. So, if the food doesn't work out, you can always drink the juice.

All recipes serve six.

Potato pancakes
I love these simple names for brilliant and delicious foods. This recipe, in fact, uses two cooking methods, because once you've steamed the potatoes to go into the mix, you need to fry the resultant batter to make the pancakes

450g good mashing potato
3 whole eggs and 2 egg whites
3 heaped tbsp self-raising flour
150ml milk
150ml double cream
1 tsp freshly-grated nutmeg
Sea salt
Black pepper

Peel and eye the potatoes. Cut them into small pieces and rinse under cold water. Set them in a steamer over furiously boiling water, and leave until cooked through. Once done, mash the potatoes until quite smooth, then set aside to cool. Place the mash in a food processor, add all the other ingredients and whizz until you have smooth, silky, and quite thick batter. Cover, and refrigerate for at least an hour. Cook the batter as you would pancakes - portion size depends on the size of pan you use, and whether you'd rather make individual pancakes or just a single large communal one. Serve with goodies such as smoked eel, crispy bacon, horseradish cream, chives, whatever takes your fancy.

Steamed scallops in the shell
A gorgeous Cantonese recipe, simple and elegant, from Yan-Kit So.

20 large scallops
Groundnut oil for frying
6-8 cloves garlic, peeled and diced
6 large spring onions, green parts only, cut into rounds

For the sauce

6 large spring onions, white parts only, cut into very fine threads
60ml groundnut oil
2cm fresh ginger root, peeled and cut into very fine threads
3 fresh green chillies, seeded and cut into rounds
30ml thick soy sauce
30ml thin soy sauce
30ml water

Ask the fishmonger to open the scallops on the cup side of the shells, rather than on the flat side. Remove the frills, black impurities, muscles and corals (use these latter in a soup, say), leaving only the white meat. Rinse the meat and pat dry, leaving it on the shells.

Prepare the sauce. Divide the spring onions into two serving bowls. Heat a wok until smoky, add the oil and swirl it around, lower the heat, then add the ginger and chilli. Remove from the heat. After a few seconds, add the soy sauces and water, bring to a simmer, then pour over the onion in the two bowls.

Fill a wok or deep fryer with enough oil to cover the base of a small wire sieve in which you will cook the garlic, and heat to 180C. Put the garlic into the sieve, and dip briefly into the hot oil three or four times, until it has taken on colour. Sprinkle the fried garlic and the same amount of green spring onion over each scallop, then place the scallops in a steamer. Cook over boiling water for seven to 10 minutes, until the meat has turned opaque. Remove the shells from the steamer with care, as you do not want to spill the juice. Serve at once, with the sauce bowls alongside: the idea is to pour a little over each scallop, then fork up lightly so the shellfish absorbs the liquor - and don't forget to drink the juice in the shells, too.

Steak and kidney pudding
A great dish to relieve the ennui of the long winter months.

For the filling 1 kg rump steak
250g veal kidneys
250g button mushrooms
Vegetable oil, for frying
1 glass red wine
2 medium onions, finely chopped
1 bayleaf
1 sprig thyme
290ml red wine
290ml water
Sea salt and black pepper

For the suet crust

250g self-raising flour
75g suet
50g unsalted butter
Zest of 1 lemon, finely grated
Salt and pepper
Water to mix

First make the braise - it will be all the better for being made the day before. Trim the excess fat from the beef, and cut the meat into 2.5cm cubes. Remove the fat and veins from the kidneys, cut them in half, then into slices, though not too thin. Wipe the mushrooms with a damp cloth.

Liberally season the meat, then fry it in batches in a wide, heavy-bottomed, cast-iron pan, until brown and crusted all over. Put the cooked meat in a colander over a bowl, to collect the juices. Repeat until all the meat is browned. Pour the wine into the hot pan, scrape up any residue adhering to the base with a wooden spoon, pour into a bowl and reserve.

In a large braising pot, first brown the onions in a little oil, then add the mushrooms and allow to colour lightly. Add the meat, the liquid from both the draining bowl and the pan, the herbs and the seasonings. Pour in the wine and water, bring to a gentle simmer, then bake in a preheated oven (16OC/ 325F/gas mark 3) for two hours.

Lightly butter a 1.5-litre pudding bowl and lay a small circle of greaseproof paper on the bottom of the mould. Put a big pan of water on to simmer, ready to receive the pudding bowl. Now you're ready to make the suet crust. Sift the flour into a bowl, along with the seasoning, add the suet and lemon zest, and mix. Add a few tablespoons of cold water to make a soft dough, wrap well in cling-film, and refrigerate for half an hour. Cut the dough into two pieces, one smaller than the other. Roll out the larger piece so that it will line the pudding bowl, and the smaller one to act as the lid. Tip the steak and kidney into the crust, and pop on the lid.

Seal the bowl with foil - absolutely no steam or liquid must come into contact with the crust. Place the package in the pan of water, cover and leave to simmer for an hour-and-a-half. Serve straight from the bowl.

The steaming of vegetables
Not so much a recipe as a guide -reading Joy Larkcom's words on the subject is a real treat, so I put them down here, not least because they're so good.

Steaming is a fast, efficient method of cooking vegetables. It preserves their delicate flavour, conserving more nutrients than when boiled. It is suitable for all leafy vegetables, and for root vegetables and beans, which should be sliced finely if they are large. Vegetables with a high moisture content, such as cucumber, are not generally very suited to steaming.

If available, use a metal steamer or a Chinese bamboo steamer, which can be set into a wok. Or improvise with a wire sieve on top of a saucepan, covered with some sort of lid or cooking foil.

Method

A) Boil the water. Put the vegetables into the upper part of the steamer, making sure they don't touch the water but are permeated by the steam.
B) Cover and steam for a few minutes.
C) Test for readiness by breaking off a little piece of the vegetable and tasting.
D) Season after steaming with salt, pepper, lemon, fresh herbs etc (lemon and salt help to bring out other flavours). Fresh herbs tossed through freshly steamed vegetables are very good. Try it with chervil, Chinese chives, basil, mint or any fresh herbs to hand. Serve with sliced raw radishes on top, allowing them just to absorb the warmth of the vegetables

fields.headline: A light less ordinary
fields.standfirst: Lighting is the medium of the moment - sculptural, industrial, even playful, but never, Lesley Gillilan discovers, merely functional.
fields.trailText: Lighting is the medium of the moment - sculptural, industrial, even playful, but never, Lesley Gillilan discovers, merely functional.
fields.body:
Charlie Dossett's back-room studio in is a rather gloomy, claustrophobic sort of space. As I recall, it doesn't even have windows, but that's possibly because I was too dazzled by his "skyscraper lights" to notice. There was a least a dozen of them, each standing about 1m tall from ground floor to penthouse, and arranged in a group like a miniature Chicago streetscape.

They looked impressive enough in the raw, but when the power was switched on they instantly turned Dossett's workaday west London studio into a magical place.

A Dossett skyscraper, however, is not an easy thing to categorise: he is happy to describe it as "a kind of lampshade", but could he call it "lighting"? I think not. Not, at least, at the serious end of the interior-design profession, where the word pertains to a bewildering world of dimmers, filters and tungsten filaments. Designers in this field would take one look at Dossett's studio and recommend a bit of "task lighting" or wall washing (among other techniques beyond the scope of an average 60-watt bulb). Indeed, religious modernists among them would interpret the word "lampshade" as a form of blasphemy.

"Good lighting should not really be noticed," insists lighting designer Sally Storey in her forthcoming book, Lighting. "It should enhance your interiors without obviously doing so . . . it's only bad lighting that is noticed." So, needless to say, her book has little room for skyscraper lights, nor for any of the emerging generation of decorative lamps and illuminated products that positively demand to be noticed.

Still, Dossett's light-up architecture is currently making its first public appearance as part of the Contemporary Decorative Arts exhibition at Sotheby's, London. And it's in good company: according to the show's curator, Rachael Barraclough, artificial light is the medium of the moment.

When trawling Europe for the bright young things of 21st-century design, she was amazed by the number of people who are marrying novel materials and mains electricity to create playful lamps. "There is a growing trend for non-essential lights that go beyond the little table lamp, and the functionality of illuminating a space," she says. "Each piece is something that exists in its own right and sets out to create a real impact."

Among brilliant exhibits at the Sotheby's show, there are neon-lit textiles, flashing-light necklaces and chandeliers made of cast plastic beakers. There is Georg Baldele's pendant lamps and electric "candles" made of spirals of layered paper wrapped like stalactites around tiny halogen spots. There are German craftsman Bodo Sperlein's wall-mounted ceramic pieces, which, says Barraclough, are more like gallery installations than homeware products.

There are Jacopo Foggini's luminous sculptures (octopussy tendrils of plastic tubing made to look like Venetian glass). And there's Jeremy Lord: "I could look at his lights for hours," sighs Barraclough. "They ooze colour and life . . ."

Lord is a classic example of the contemporary "lighting sculptor", whose work can be loosely categorised as art, design or technology. His signature piece, for which his Colour Light Company is now well known, is the Chromawall: a mosaic of polycarbonate hemispheres mounted on aluminium to form a large, luminous wall-hanging. Inside each module there are four different coloured lamps and, with the aid of electronics, the whole thing is programmed to radiate an orchestrated but unpredictable display of polychromatic light.

The notion of making functional lamps is, says Lord, "desperately boring": the Chromawall is intended to provide an experience (both "relaxing and mesmerising"), rather than a means to see in the dark. "For me, it's like playing with an optical paint palette," he says. It must also have something in common with putting on a light show (Lord has done a few of those in his time), and the sophisticated Chromawall is fitted with controls for varying brightness and adjusting the speed of the colour changes. "You can jazz it up for a party, or slow it down to chill out," says Lord, whose works have ended up in environment's as varied as a music promoter's bedroom, a family kitchen and a clinic waiting room.

His relatively new Orbit (Chromawall's "baby brother": a single colour- changing cell designed to sit on a shelf) is accessibly priced - £65, compared with £2,000-plus for some of his other work). This is partly because the making of Orbit has moved out of Lord's Worcestershire workshop and into a factory in China.

The relationship between art, design and industry, says Barraclough, is an underlying theme of the Sotheby's show. "A lot of the contributing designers have taken an existing product or a material, reinvented its use and worked with a manufacturer to create an entirely new thing." In the lighting field, that includes Arik Levy, whose "griddled" metal lights are made from adapted insulating piping, usually used in deep freezes.

Jacopo Foggini's light sculptures, meanwhile, are made of methacrylate, an industrial material used in the automobile industry to make car tail lights. He discovered its properties while playing around in his family's Italian plastics factory and, years later, developed a machine that transforms the material into "a support of light itself".

Georg Baldele's soft-glowing lamps are produced as ready-glued, factory-made rolls of paper, which, says Baldele, "I pull out by hand to make a shape, but not always the same shape - it's mass production with a bit of handicraft."

Ceramicist Bodo Sperlein also combines industrial manufacturing with traditional skills. He claims, too, to be the first to experiment with bone china. And, to date, he's the only designer to work with VPP, a vitreous china strengthened with polyurethene resin, making it possible to produce large, durable, ceramic sheets as fine as paper.

"When I started at Camberwell School of Art in the early 90s, ceramics was very 'brown rice'," he says. "It had about as much street cred as needlework." But he was determined to demonstrate the material's versatility (tough, heat-resistant, textural, with good "light-carrying" qualities etc), and his contemporary collection of crisp, clean porcelain ware is as far as you can get from the "brown, blobby" pottery that he fought to forget.

His ceramic lamps include delicate cups of light, sculptured floor lights, a "sheet sculptural tablelamp" (in which a cylinder of light is thrown up on to the surface of a rectangle of bone china) and hand-textured VPP wall lights (another rectangle, but larger and lit from behind).

The latter look, at first glance, as if they are perforated with rows of tiny holes, but it is a trick of the light - the panel simply, and beautifully, glows brighter where the material is thinner. "My aim was to make lamps that have visual impact even when they are turned off," says Sperlein. "A functional product that works equally well as a sculpture."

His sleek, industrially-crafted pieces couldn't be more different from Charlie Dossett's enchantingly low-tech tower blocks - they are, he says, "three-dimensional cartoons". And though they are inspired by the landmarks of down-town-American skylines, they are caricatures of buildings rather than architectural models.

Thus far, his clients are few (they include an estate agent in Whitehall and "people who like tower blocks"). But though currently produced by hand, it can only be matter of time before Dossett's skyscraper lampshade comes in factory-made form

Contemporary Decorative Arts is at Sotheby's, New Bond Street, London W1, until Thursday February 17; details on 020-7293 5000. Lighting, by Sally Storey (Quadrille/ John Cullen Lighting, £12.99), is published in April. Jeremy Lord's Chromawalls and Orbits, from 2021, 020-7837 1900, and the Colour Light Company, 01386 861086.
