fields.bodyText: Charlie Dossett's back-room studio in is a rather gloomy, claustrophobic sort of space. As I recall, it doesn't even have windows, but that's possibly because I was too dazzled by his "skyscraper lights" to notice. There was a least a dozen of them, each standing about 1m tall from ground floor to penthouse, and arranged in a group like a miniature Chicago streetscape. They looked impressive enough in the raw, but when the power was switched on they instantly turned Dossett's workaday west London studio into a magical place. A Dossett skyscraper, however, is not an easy thing to categorise: he is happy to describe it as "a kind of lampshade", but could he call it "lighting"? I think not. Not, at least, at the serious end of the interior-design profession, where the word pertains to a bewildering world of dimmers, filters and tungsten filaments. Designers in this field would take one look at Dossett's studio and recommend a bit of "task lighting" or wall washing (among other techniques beyond the scope of an average 60-watt bulb). Indeed, religious modernists among them would interpret the word "lampshade" as a form of blasphemy. "Good lighting should not really be noticed," insists lighting designer Sally Storey in her forthcoming book, Lighting. "It should enhance your interiors without obviously doing so . . . it's only bad lighting that is noticed." So, needless to say, her book has little room for skyscraper lights, nor for any of the emerging generation of decorative lamps and illuminated products that positively demand to be noticed. Still, Dossett's light-up architecture is currently making its first public appearance as part of the Contemporary Decorative Arts exhibition at Sotheby's, London. And it's in good company: according to the show's curator, Rachael Barraclough, artificial light is the medium of the moment. When trawling Europe for the bright young things of 21st-century design, she was amazed by the number of people who are marrying novel materials and mains electricity to create playful lamps. "There is a growing trend for non-essential lights that go beyond the little table lamp, and the functionality of illuminating a space," she says. "Each piece is something that exists in its own right and sets out to create a real impact." Among brilliant exhibits at the Sotheby's show, there are neon-lit textiles, flashing-light necklaces and chandeliers made of cast plastic beakers. There is Georg Baldele's pendant lamps and electric "candles" made of spirals of layered paper wrapped like stalactites around tiny halogen spots. There are German craftsman Bodo Sperlein's wall-mounted ceramic pieces, which, says Barraclough, are more like gallery installations than homeware products. There are Jacopo Foggini's luminous sculptures (octopussy tendrils of plastic tubing made to look like Venetian glass). And there's Jeremy Lord: "I could look at his lights for hours," sighs Barraclough. "They ooze colour and life . . ." Lord is a classic example of the contemporary "lighting sculptor", whose work can be loosely categorised as art, design or technology. His signature piece, for which his Colour Light Company is now well known, is the Chromawall: a mosaic of polycarbonate hemispheres mounted on aluminium to form a large, luminous wall-hanging. Inside each module there are four different coloured lamps and, with the aid of electronics, the whole thing is programmed to radiate an orchestrated but unpredictable display of polychromatic light. The notion of making functional lamps is, says Lord, "desperately boring": the Chromawall is intended to provide an experience (both "relaxing and mesmerising"), rather than a means to see in the dark. "For me, it's like playing with an optical paint palette," he says. It must also have something in common with putting on a light show (Lord has done a few of those in his time), and the sophisticated Chromawall is fitted with controls for varying brightness and adjusting the speed of the colour changes. "You can jazz it up for a party, or slow it down to chill out," says Lord, whose works have ended up in environment's as varied as a music promoter's bedroom, a family kitchen and a clinic waiting room. His relatively new Orbit (Chromawall's "baby brother": a single colour- changing cell designed to sit on a shelf) is accessibly priced - £65, compared with £2,000-plus for some of his other work). This is partly because the making of Orbit has moved out of Lord's Worcestershire workshop and into a factory in China. The relationship between art, design and industry, says Barraclough, is an underlying theme of the Sotheby's show. "A lot of the contributing designers have taken an existing product or a material, reinvented its use and worked with a manufacturer to create an entirely new thing." In the lighting field, that includes Arik Levy, whose "griddled" metal lights are made from adapted insulating piping, usually used in deep freezes. Jacopo Foggini's light sculptures, meanwhile, are made of methacrylate, an industrial material used in the automobile industry to make car tail lights. He discovered its properties while playing around in his family's Italian plastics factory and, years later, developed a machine that transforms the material into "a support of light itself". Georg Baldele's soft-glowing lamps are produced as ready-glued, factory-made rolls of paper, which, says Baldele, "I pull out by hand to make a shape, but not always the same shape - it's mass production with a bit of handicraft." Ceramicist Bodo Sperlein also combines industrial manufacturing with traditional skills. He claims, too, to be the first to experiment with bone china. And, to date, he's the only designer to work with VPP, a vitreous china strengthened with polyurethene resin, making it possible to produce large, durable, ceramic sheets as fine as paper. "When I started at Camberwell School of Art in the early 90s, ceramics was very 'brown rice'," he says. "It had about as much street cred as needlework." But he was determined to demonstrate the material's versatility (tough, heat-resistant, textural, with good "light-carrying" qualities etc), and his contemporary collection of crisp, clean porcelain ware is as far as you can get from the "brown, blobby" pottery that he fought to forget. His ceramic lamps include delicate cups of light, sculptured floor lights, a "sheet sculptural tablelamp" (in which a cylinder of light is thrown up on to the surface of a rectangle of bone china) and hand-textured VPP wall lights (another rectangle, but larger and lit from behind). The latter look, at first glance, as if they are perforated with rows of tiny holes, but it is a trick of the light - the panel simply, and beautifully, glows brighter where the material is thinner. "My aim was to make lamps that have visual impact even when they are turned off," says Sperlein. "A functional product that works equally well as a sculpture." His sleek, industrially-crafted pieces couldn't be more different from Charlie Dossett's enchantingly low-tech tower blocks - they are, he says, "three-dimensional cartoons". And though they are inspired by the landmarks of down-town-American skylines, they are caricatures of buildings rather than architectural models. Thus far, his clients are few (they include an estate agent in Whitehall and "people who like tower blocks"). But though currently produced by hand, it can only be matter of time before Dossett's skyscraper lampshade comes in factory-made form Contemporary Decorative Arts is at Sotheby's, New Bond Street, London W1, until Thursday February 17; details on 020-7293 5000. fields.headline: Top quality, terrific value
fields.standfirst: ...so why's it available only in Paris, asks Matthew Fort
fields.trailText: L'Opportun doesn't immediately catch the eye. It's a bit scruffy and, to be honest, small - just a couple of back rooms seating maybe 20 people. But there's a queue at the bar awaiting tables, and another queue that reaches out of the door and on to the boulevard Edgar Quinet.
fields.body:
L'Opportun doesn't immediately catch the eye. It's a bit scruffy and, to be honest, small - just a couple of back rooms seating maybe 20 people. But there's a queue at the bar awaiting tables, and another queue that reaches out of the door and on to the boulevard Edgar Quinet. It makes you think, hey ho, there must be something a bit special going on here. And so there is. My friend, Jean-Pierre, tells me that L'Opportun is the hottest table in Paris at the moment, and Jean-Pierre knows, because he decides which is the hottest table in Paris at any given moment. That's his job, or one of them at any rate.

The Parisien gourmet bon ton , on the other hand, are not queuing up at L'Opportun looking for the rarified heights of creative cookery, for palatal pyrotechnics and for plate poetry. All that, according to Jean-Pierre, is a thing of the past. Oh, all right, Alain Ducasse, Pierre Gagnaire and Guy Savoy still weave their magic, but the great mass movement of the culinary arts has moved on, or rather, back - back to the plain, the hale, the hearty and the unashamedly provincial.

Here are a few items off the ordonnance du jour (the chef/prop of L'Opportun and self-styled Beaujolothérapeute, Serge Alzerat, a man who bears the unmistakeable mark of his own cooking, is rather given to jokes along the lines of "Centre de Beaujolothérapie - Dépistage de la Pépie, Prophylaxie de la Soif"): la salade de groin d' âne (âne is donkey, to save you reaching for a dictionary), la tête de veau façon gribiche, la fricasse d'escargots et pleurotes, and le coq au vin du beaujolais. All these bear the hallmarks of a return to the regional roots of French cooking, earthy in both the sense that it is of a specific terroir - Lyons, in this case - and in its gastronomic characteristics.

Such culinary simplicity depends for its impact of the quality of the raw materials, and this is the mast to which Alzerat has pinned his colours. The beef, declares the menu, comes from Pierrefort in the Cantal. Jean-Pierre Dutrévis, "artisan boucher", selects the animals and prepares the meat. The cheeses are brought to perfect maturity by affineur Hervé Mons. These are not the gestures of your average beaten-up bistrot.

The value of such careful sourcing was immediately evident in the dinner through which Jean-Pierre, his wife Albertine, Jean-Claude and I worked our way: a plate of foie gras, plain on the plate, but for a few squares of meat jelly; oeufs cocotte aux truffes (eggs baked in cream with truffles); a plate of kidneys and sweetbreads for Albertine and myself, and a fillet steak the size of a small tree trunk with a kind of cheesy sauce for J-P and J-C; a plate of cheeses and a slab of fondant chocolate for me, and a tarte tatin for Albertine. The foie gras was good, the baked eggs outstanding, the kidneys and sweetbreads excellent, the steak fabulous (and the curious, creamy-cheesy sauce very good); the cheeses the finest I have eaten in France; and the fondant chocolate the definition of Keats's suggestion about "ceasing upon the midnight with no pain". (I have no idea what the tarte tatin tasted like, because by that time I was past it.)

You could cavil that the vegetables weren't sourced with the same degree of fanaticism as the other elements (but then, L'Opportun doesn't seem to cater for vegetarians in any sense of the word), and they get fairly cavalier treatment on the menu, with the exception of some splendid pommes de terre lyonnaises. But when you're paying Ff95 (around £9) for top-dog foie gras, Ff90 for the baked eggs and truffles, Ff1,330 for all our food, two bottles of old-fashioned light Gamay, two bottles of Beaune Marconnets 1994 and sundry other odds and ends (J-P picked up the tab, as is his generous wont), to nit-pick over vegetables seems pretty small-minded. I cannot think of a restaurant in this country that serves such stupendous food at such unstupendous prices

fields.headline: The end of innocence [II]
fields.standfirst: Nearly half the sexual abuse suffered by children is inflicted on them by other children, it is now reckoned. What was once considered horseplay or youthful experiment has come to be viewed in a much more sinister light. Does a game of Kiss Chase really amount to harassment, or are we indulging in a moral panic? Is it possible to define 'appropriate' behaviour for the very young? Dea Birkett investigates the case of 10-year-old Johnny R , once accused of molesting a little girl with whom he played football
fields.trailText: Nearly half the sexual abuse suffered by children is inflicted on them by other children, it is now reckoned. What was once considered horseplay or youthful experiment has come to be viewed in a much more sinister light. Does a game of Kiss Chase really amount to harassment, or are we indulging in a moral panic? Is it possible to define 'appropriate' behaviour for the very young? Dea Birkett investigates the case of 10-year-old Johnny R , once accused of molesting a little girl with whom he played football
fields.body:
How did Johnny R's case, amounting to mucking around, horseplay, kids' stuff, perhaps natural experimentation, get all the way to a crown court? The police refuse to comment. The Crown Prosecution Service says that it thought there was enough evidence to bring a case; it doesn't take into account that the defendant and complainant are children. But Johnny's solicitor, Martin Ryan, believes that other factors come into play. "In other offences - drugs, violence - they avoid court proceedings. But, from a prosecution point of view, this was not the case you would drop. It's political. There are pressures to deal with sex offenders and young kids. The temptation is to put them before the courts."

There are plenty of precedents to show that this is indeed the case. In February 1998, in a highly-publicised case at the Old Bailey, four boys, three aged 10 and one 11, were cleared of indecent assault on a nine-year-old girl in the toilets of their west London school, after three of them had earlier been cleared of rape. Like Robert Thompson and Jon Venables in the James Bulger murder trial in 1993, these boys were subjected to the rigours of a legal procedure that was lost on them. "I thought the whole thing was entirely inappropriate," says Robin Grey QC, who defended one of the boys. "It was a bit farcical that you had children and the spectacle of a three-week trial. They tried to make it look like a schoolroom. One of them was sucking his thumb. I spent most of my time teaching my boy maths - adding and subtracting. He even asked me to set him homework and brought it back into court the next day. He couldn't follow the proceedings, but he was getting all his sums right by the end of the trial." When one of the boys was asked if he had any questions, he said, "Can I now go and see Star Trek?"

As in all similar cases, the privilege of examination by video link given to the nine-year-old girl was not extended to the young boys she had accused. "The paramount consideration is supposed to be the welfare of the child - but which child?" says Peter Carter QC, another member of the defence team. "Two of the boys were interviewed by members of the robbery squad. The way that the child complainant was interviewed was completely different, by two specially-trained women police officers. She was treated with kid gloves. But our defendants were no less vulnerable."

Nor is their word given equal weight: the orthodoxy among sex-offender treatment practitioners is that the difficulties of and hurdles in reporting sexual abuse means only the truthful take the trouble. "It's very unusual for young people to lie about being abused," says Mark Dalton of the NSPCC's Midlands Project for Young People With Inappropriate Sexual Behaviour. "If you're questioning is good, they can't lie. It's an adult construct to say, if you offer a service like our project, young people will lie to drop other young people in it."

But Grey believes that there are attractions in being the one who points the finger. "They're always told by police and social workers, 'Well done', and 'Oh, you're very brave', so they think they'll tell these lies and get a pat on the back and be told they're wonderful. There's very much the culture at the moment in sex cases - the complainant said it happened, therefore it happened. But when it's a child on the other side, it seems very wrong."

The case against the boys collapsed; the judge said that the girl had a history of fantasies and making up stories. Horseplay had again found its way into a crown court. "It's the system failing to cater for the natural inquisitiveness of the young, experimenting with their bodies and curious about the bodies of members of the opposite sex," says Steven Kay QC, who defended another of the boys. "The decision to bring a prosecution based on these kinds of circumstances is completely baffling. It's as if the lobby groups - the victims groups, the social services - make those in positions of responsibility too frightened to say, 'No'."

I asked Kevin McGowan, solicitor for one of the boys (whose mother said the family was emigrating after the ordeal), if we had learned anything from this case. He paused. "No - if another allegation was made in the same way, it would probably be dealt with in the same way."

It was in the case of Johnny R. "We kept saying to him, tell the truth, just always tell the truth, and if you tell the truth, truth will out," says Nana R. "Well, when he was convicted we were just numb. Johnny was devastated, because he had told the truth. He just couldn't imagine why his Mum and Nana couldn't put it right." Johnny still wets the bed now and again. "He won't go near girls", says Nana R. "He doesn't trust anyone now, not like he used to." He's being offered therapy.

"His schooling has been interrupted, his family life has been interrupted," says Martin Ryan. "Even though he's been acquitted on appeal, he isn't automatically de-registered. There is no requirement for police to delete him form the Sex Offenders' Register." As it happens, the police have agreed to take Johnny's name from "that list, sex offenders thing". But Ryan intends to take Johnny's case to the European Court of Human Rights anyway. It is his contention that Johnny's name should never have been put on the register in the first place, since it is not intended for children.

Once upon a time, we believed in and trusted our children. Can we ever return to this enchanted land? Can childhood be reclaimed? Or are our little angels forever branded little devils? Even those involved in sex offender treatment programmes for young children are beginnning to become concerned that childrens' emerging sexuality is policed with too heavy a hand. "The more I do this, and the more cases we get, the more we are aware that we could be a millstone around the neck of young people" says Mark Dalton. "An assessment report from us can be a heavy number. If we label someone as high risk when they're 12, that report will still be dragged up when they're 17." The European ruling in the Thompson and Venables case will stop many of these cases being brought all the way to the crown court in the future, as happened in the abortive west London trial, but it will not stop young children such as Johnny R being stigmatised, criminalised and put on the Sex Offenders' Register.

What should have happened in the case of Johnny R? Perhaps we ought to have looked at it not throught the prism of adult rights and wrongs - the language of "naughty", "messing with" and "rude bits" - but through more innocent, childish eyes. "We may over react to quite normal expressions of childrens' behaviour, and misinterpret them," says Ann Furedi. "If a 35-year old man puts his hand up your skirt, it means something entirely different from a 10-year old behaving in that way. Yet young lads playing Kiss Chase with young girls at school are somehow evaluated as if they were adults stalking or harrassing."

We seem to have forgotten that we were once young, and lived in a messy emotional world, where we struggled to find out what we wanted to do and what we wanted to have done to us. We have forgotten what it is like to trespass gingerly into a place that we hadn't yet charted, whose rules we hadn't yet learned - the grown up world of adult sexuality.

Some of the names of the children and their families in this report have been changed.

webTitle: Sri Lanka's tea growers have gone organic

fields.headline: Sri Lanka's tea growers have gone organic
fields.standfirst: ...and the taste is quite amazing, says Joanna Blythma
fields.trailText: Until quite recently, Sri Lanka had disappeared from the British tea connoisseur's map now, it is  set on a course that is making its teas some of the most exciting in the world
fields.body:
Until quite recently, Sri Lanka had disappeared from the British tea connoisseur's map. While European tea lovers have always rated top Ceylon estates highly, here the 60s Ceylon Tea centres - which served up a cup of heartburn-inducing tannic brew alongside some vaguely curried veg in cold pastry - did nothing to endear it to consumers. During the same period, UK tea brokers deserted Sri Lanka as the industry was nationalised, quality took a nosedive and the colonial planters either headed for home or for Kenya. To cap all that, the island's extensive tea plantations were hit by an outbreak of worms that were resistant to pesticides: a frightening development, as a similar outbreak had wiped out Ceylon's coffee production in perpetuity. A one-off, low-tech solution was found: children were paid manually to pick off the worms from the leaves.

This salutary demonstration of the limitations of pesticides, however, set Sri Lanka on a course that is now making the country's teas some of the most exciting in the world. Since the crisis, the national policy has been to use pesticides only in extremis , never preventatively, and to encourage beneficial insect species as a mechanism for predator control. In the past few years, as the government has introduced the partial re-privatisation of the tea plantations, some of the best estates have taken pesticide-avoidance to its logical conclusion and converted to organic. And not just any old organic: many have adopted the most rigorous and sophisticated type of organic production possible, the biodynamic method of the Austrian philosopher, Rudolf Steiner.

Steiner advocated the use of natural "preparations" (of which more below) and a lunar calendar to plot the optimum time for all operations in the growing cycle. Like homeopathy, the Steiner approach was once widely mocked as cranky mumbo jumbo, but today - and although the science behind it is still not fully understood - it is increasingly accepted that his methods can achieve remarkable results.

The application of these biodynamic methods to Sri Lanka's tea production would have passed me by were it not for the efforts of Robert Wilson, a retired Ceylon tea planter, who is now importing into the UK a fabulous portfolio of "Ceylon" Teas - both organic and conventional - from top estates such as Brunswick, St James and Mahagastotte. Wilson's teas are bought in the most desirable dry season, when they are, in Ceylon tea-speak, at their most "flavoury".

One of the most exceptional comes from the biodynamic Iddalgashinna Estate, which sits 6,500ft up in the Beragala Hills of Uva, and whose presence is announced at the lower levels with whitewashed road signs that declare the area a "Toxic-Free Zone". Iddalgashinna's natural environment shares much with the virgin rainforest on which it borders - superficially, it looks like a beautiful green jumble. While many tea plantations consist of concentric lines of tea bushes, here they are interspersed with diverse trees and plants, which produce not only vital shade but also beneficial green manures that are then supplemented with worm compost.

The only spray the tea bushes get is a Steiner-style "preparation". Fresh dung from a lactating cow is mixed with rock phosphate and crushed eggshell, then packed into shallow brick trenches, covered with sacking and left for 30 days. The resultant mixture is then turned with a fork and left for a further 30 days, before being mixed with water and sprayed on the tea bushes. It has proven a remarkably effective alternative to pesticides, and aids the production of teas of supreme quality.

I worked my way through all of Iddalgashinna's tea grades. The tea, which is always hand-picked, is manufactured in the traditional, skilled, "orthodox" manner. Among the stars on parade was a green orange pekoe that would cause a stampede of Japan's most devoted tea collectors - its large leaf unfurls beautifully on infusion, producing a pale-green liquor with an ultra-fresh, cut-grass bouquet and distinct peatiness - while even the most committed, first-flush Darjeeling lover would be left weak-kneed by "silvery tips", the newest growth, which produces a light, subtly smoky liquor. The other large-leaf black grades on offer are amazing, too, with pleasant bitterness and a nose of freshly-peeled oranges, caramel and cut flowers.

And yet Iddalgashinna is not some inconsequential little tea garden. This "bio-tea" estate has a workforce of 1,400 and production to match. It is currently owned by a local company, has its own nursery school, house-building schemes and no less than three medical centres. This kind of infrastructure is standard in the traditional plantation system, but here the ethos is more egalitarian. On most estates, the workers stay respectfully outside the manager's office window. At Iddalgashinna, they are inside, working out the plantation's transition to community ownership.

Many of Wilson's other Ceylon teas have an equally fascinating pedigree, and the sheer selection is paradise for anyone who likes to explore the intriguing nuances of a fine specialist product. Like malt whiskies, each estate has a unique style, as does each district, from the pungent, almost astringent Nuwara Eliyas to the more mellow Dimbulas or the delicate Uvas. Just one word of warning, however: dip your nose into these amazing teas and expect to get hooked 

Robert Wilson's Ceylon Teas, 01460 77508.

fields.headline: Ventura quits Perot's Reform party
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: The Minnesota governor, Jesse Ventura, threw American third party politics into a bout of election-year confusion yesterday by announcing that he is quitting the Reform party after a row with the party founder, Ross Perot.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle in St Paul, Minnesota
fields.body:
The Minnesota governor, Jesse Ventura, threw American third party politics into a bout of election-year confusion yesterday by announcing that he is quitting the Reform party after a row with the party founder, Ross Perot.

The man they call "the body politic" told reporters that he is planning to set up a new organisation. "I am disaffiliating myself from the national Reform party completely as of this day," Mr Ventura announced in St Paul. He said he would urge the Minnesota Reform party to to reconstitute itself to fight state elections as the Independence party.

Mr Ventura, who defeated Republicans and Democrats to win the Minnesota governorship in 1998, has been easily the most important and most publicised elected official of the Reform party, which was founded by Dallas oil tycoon Mr Perot to support his presidential bids in 1992 and 1996.

"Let me go completely on the record. The national Reform party did virtually nothing - zero - to get me elected," Mr Ventura said.

Mr Ventura has been locked in a battle to wrest control of the party from Mr Perot's supporters, who want the former Republican Pat Buchanan to be their presidential candidate.

Mr Ventura, who is a liberal on many social issues and a supporter of free trade, said: "I can't stay within a national party that could well have Pat Buchanan as its presidential nominee, and now the latest word I hear is he's getting support from David Duke [the former Ku Klux Klan leader]. Well I can't be part of that, and I won't be part of that."

Mr Perot's supporters had called an emergency meeting of the party's 162-strong national committee in Nashville, Tennessee, this weekend, to try to oust Ventura loyalists.

The real battle between the two wings concerns control of the $12.6m of federal election spending money to which the party's nominee is entitled in the presidential race by virtue of Mr Perot's 8.4% of the national vote in 1996.

fields.headline: Looking for the human woman
fields.standfirst: The psychologist who reads behind people's stories to find out how they actually think
fields.trailText: As Valentine's Day approaches it seemed sensible to talk to a psychologist who has asked the important question "Are Women Human"? Helen Haste, professor of psychology at Bath, says it is not a simple feminist question.
fields.body:
As Valentine's Day approaches it seemed sensible to talk to a psychologist who has asked the important question "Are Women Human"? Helen Haste, professor of psychology at Bath, says it is not a simple feminist question.

"We've had 20 years of saying that women have been oppressed, excluded and denied their status. What I want to ask is whether we have found a way to redefine the human without genders and humanness excluding each other. How do we define what it means to be a fully human being?

"It's not irrelevant that I went to university to read English: at the time I wanted to be a journalist. For a variety of reasons, I abandoned both journalism and English.

"It wasn't a dislike of journalism. I liked ideas. Philosophy is full of ideas, but the ideas in psychology are more accessible and you can play around with them more. They're less entrenched in 2,000 years of orthodoxy.

"But the interesting thing about working in a field like metaphor is that it all has roots in looking at language: if you took the language away, there's not all that much of interest about people's minds."

The central point of her investigations is the idea that the kind of rational thought involved in scientific experiments, while it tells us a great deal about the world, represents only a small part of how humans of either gender actually think. "We don't most of the time think logically and analytically. We actually tell stories the whole time. We are very skilful at telling narratives, the sort of narratives that give you a clear picture of why things happen and what the consequences will be."

As a kind of practical demonstration of this belief, her own conversation is a continual skein of stories, ranging from the detail of her own life into the Cretaceous past. She is fascinated by the importance of dinosaurs in modern life and their changing symbolic roles. This is partly because she lived until his tragic early death with the palaeontologist, Beverley Halstead. But it is also because they offered such a wonderful example of the complex interplay between scientific results and the popular imagination. There is hardly anything that cannot be illustrated with a dinosaur metaphor, all backed by science of one kind or another.

"The shift of things like dinosaurs first as warm-blooded and very active and fast-moving may have changed the slow lumbering blundering great huge crea tures. Then there are dinosaurs as good mothers; and dinosaurs as co-operative. But what actually happened was the warm-blooded fast-moving ones brought back the macho story of dinosaurs as hunters."

Helen Haste's interest is in the way in which our ability to change the world is conditioned by our understanding. "In about 1971 I became politically involved in feminism for all the reasons that people normally did. I had spent my life being patronised, being told that bright girls didn't get husbands and so on. But after a few years of the usual sort of activism, which I was involved in, I realised I could do far more by doing decent research."

She is, I think, one of the people she identified in a study of the psychology of the peace movement, as the small minority who actually get things done. Other personality types might deny a threat, or worry about it silently. But there is one group who found the situation intolerable and acted. "What fuelled them was not fear but anger. They come from the sort of background where their families expect competence. If something is wrong, you just go out and fix it." Including the confusions between being masculine, feminine or human.

fields.headline: MP's life and death struggle
fields.standfirst: The doctor who told the Commons he let a boy die. Now he faces a murder inquiry
fields.trailText: The first thing you notice about Peter Brand, hurrying across the central lobby at Westminster, is that he is more confident than most MPs, even those not being investigated by the police for murder. He is authoritative, preoccupied, a little brusque.
fields.body:
The first thing you notice about Peter Brand, hurrying across the central lobby at Westminster, is that he is more confident than most MPs, even those not being investigated by the police for murder. He is authoritative, preoccupied, a little brusque.

Since the Liberal Democrat MP for the Isle of Wight told the house in a debate on euthanasia that he had allowed a two-year-old child with leukaemia to die in 1972 he has been the centre of increasing controversy with overtones of real danger.

"The General Medical Council has today come out with a statement saying that doctors being investigated by the police should be suspended, but I haven't yet heard from the Hampshire CID so I don't know what they are up to," he says.

Police announced on Tuesday that they were investigating him for murder after a complaint from a member of the public. He knew about this "nonsense" only when he read it in the paper, so he has formally inquired whether Hampshire police normally issue press releases to say they are investigating someone for murder without telling the person in question. One paper, he says, ran a headline saying "MP Kills Tiny Tot". "I really think that was unreasonable," he says, with surprisingly little passion.

What makes him unusual is not that he was prepared to allow a dying patient to die - doctors must do this every day around the country - but that he was prepared to talk about it in public. So what spurred him to act? "During the euthanasia debate I had prepared a low-key speech pointing out that what was being proposed didn't match the aspirations of the explanatory memorandum, but when [the Tory MP] Ann Winterton started talking about 'medical murder' I really felt I ought to share a bit of the real world."

Though he does not say this straight out, he talks as if the bill were a fundamentalist Christian coup aimed at the autonomy of the medical profession. "The thing that worried me about the promotion of this bill is that I started getting dozens of letters days or weeks before the bill was even printed. It was clearly an organised write-in.

"There probably is a profound difference in attitude to the concept of the sanctity of life. They apparently believe that suffering in this world just shortens your time in purgatory and may be a good thing. I respect their views. It is right that they should exercise their views in relation to themselves and their relatives. But I'm not sure it is for parliament to impose aspects of personal ethical codes on people."

He adds that this is really rather a classical liberal point of view. But his motivation was clearly anti-political. He believes that since all these cases are hard, a law to regulate them too closely must be bad.

"I have spent 30 years of my life as a GP explaining that life and medicine are full of uncertainties. But this place wants everything in black and white and is very bad at risk evaluation. Sometimes black and white clarity is simply wrong and dangerous."

This is why he is strongly opposed to legalised euthanasia. "If you look at what has happened in the Netherlands, it is creating unreasonable pressure on clinical judgment because there is now a law that allows it."

But that is not to say death is always the worst possible outcome. "Lots of doctors actually see someone's death as failure, whereas, as I said in the speech, it can be very sat isfying if someone who has been very unwell for a long time can die with dignity surrounded by people who have cared for them.

"In theory we could now put everyone on a life support machine. But one of the consequences of the Winterton bill, which would make it illegal to withdraw care from people in such a situation, is that people would be very worried to do it. Large numbers of patients would not be given the chance."

fields.headline: National Roundup
fields.trailText: Pilot jailed for £1m kidnap plot
fields.body:
Pilot jailed for £1m kidnap plot

A pilot was jailed for two-and-a-half years yesterday after demanding a £1m ransom for the son of Anwar Pervez, the multi-millionaire owner of the Bestway cash-and-carry group.

At Reading crown court, Peter Shadwell, 29, at one time the youngest airline captain in the country, admitted blackmail - though the kidnap never took place because he had been double-crossed by his co-defendant, David James, a private detective, who was earlier acquitted of blackmail.

Shadwell, of Alderley Edge in Cheshire, claimed that after his home and car were repossessed he had hatched the plot with James to kidnap Dawood Pervez, an Oxford student whose elder brother he had known at public school. Shadwell said he paid £50,000 to James after the detective had called and falsely said he had kidnapped Dawood.

Sentencing Shadwell, Judge Stanley Spence commented: "You were abused by a thoroughly dishonest co-defendant into believing the kidnap had taken place."

James was earlier acquitted on the judge's order. He had claimed he was paid by Shadwell to follow relatives of Virgin boss Sir Richard Branson and BA chief executive Bob Ayling, which Shadwell denied. Shadwell, who had been employed by a BA subsidiary on £40,000, sent Mr Pervez letters demanding £1m. He was picked up by police after collecting a planted briefcase of money.

Peter Nightingale, defending, said Shadwell was gay and had lived in a "false world", finding it difficult to admit his true feelings and becoming a binge spender; despite his £100,000 debts, he had put down £500 on a £75,000 Mercedes.

Police seek email date conwoman

Police are looking for an internet temptress who calls herself Kirsty and cons her dates out of money.

Her latest victim, Jamie Darlington, 17, a computer worker from Waltham Abbey in Essex, had an email romance for a month before being persuaded to travel more than 250 miles for a date on New Year's Eve.

When the two met in Southampton, where he had booked five nights at a hotel, "Kirsty" asked him for £105 for some party tickets she said she had bought them, then got out of their taxi.

The teenager was still waiting in the taxi when he got a message on his mobile: "You are the most gullible person in the world. Thanks for the money - it will come in handy... Ha ha ha."

Police in Southampton think many other men have also been tricked but are embarrassed to come forward.

The teenager said yesterday: "We used to exchange regular emails. In the middle of one internet conversation, she asked me what I was doing on New Year's Eve.

"I said that I was thinking about going into work to earn some extra money. At that point, she invited me to Southampton and said we could go to some nightclubs. She wanted me to send some money in advance but I was a bit wary and said 'no'."

"Kirsty" used the email address luckgirlSO15, suggesting by the postcode reference that she was from Southampton. She was ginger-blonde and possibly in her late teens, told her victim she was a hairdresser and left a black leather handbag containing an empty Barbie doll box in the taxi.

Police yesterday released a photo of a woman wanted in connection with the fraud.

Cannabis smuggler, 76, jailed

A great-grandfather was jailed yesterday for six years for his part in a cannabis smuggling ring.

Joseph Causton, 76, appeared to run a respectable business, ABC Canned Fruit Wholesale, importing cans of Spanish plum tomatoes. But a consignment concealed high-grade cannabis resin, worth up to £5m on the streets, for distribution across Britain, Snaresbrook crown court in London was told.

Judge Peter Ader told Causton: "You lent to the operation an air of credibility and respectability. Your role was to give an appearance of legitimacy to the business."

If it had not been for his age he could have expected a sentence of about 10 years, the judge said.

Causton, of Dagenham, Essex, who had claimed he was an innocent dupe, had been convicted of possessing 2,061kg of cannabis resin with intent to supply.

The court had heard how police uncovered a drug trail which saw the cannabis shipped from North Africa to Marbella, Spain, where it was packed into 4kg cans. Labelled as tomatoes, they joined genuine tins for shipment to Britain.

Det Con Lloyd Hales said he believed Causton was Britain's oldest drug-dealer.

His son-in-law, Alan Wheeler, 49, is in jail in Spain after being charged in connection with a separate 550kg cannabis haul.

The judge said Causton would have to spend at least four years in prison before his sentence could be suspended. He was ordered to pay back £10,492, his total benefit from the drugs operation.

The court heard that Causton had a 50-year record of convictions for crimes including receiving stolen goods.

School head downloaded child porn

A headteacher was yesterday found guilty of possessing indecent pictures of youths under 16, downloaded from the internet on a school computer and his home PC.

Robert Shepherd, 52, the suspended head of Holy Trinity Church of England primary school in Cuckfield, West Sussex, was also convicted by Haywards Heath magistrates of misusing a school computer.

Shepherd, who is married with four children and lives in Cuckfield, had told the court he accessed the gay porn sites as a "cry for help" over having been raped at 18.

The case was adjourned for psychological reports before sentencing on March 14, when Shepherd faces being put on the sex offenders' list.

Nuclear fuel row 'may cost jobs'

British Nuclear Fuels Limited last night admitted that a mistake which led to plutonium-based nuclear fuel being shipped to Japan with part-fabricated paperwork could cost jobs at the £300m Sellafield reprocessing plant, which has not yet opened.

The Japanese government wants the suspect mixed oxide fuel to be returned to Britain after ignoring a British trade delegation's efforts to calm fears this week.

Britain has apologised to Hirofumi Kawano, Japan's director-general of the agency of natural resources and energy, and the three BNFL workers blamed for falsifying data on the fuel pellets have been sacked, but a ban on imports of British Mox fuel imposed in December still stands.

Tokyo's intransigence is a potential blow to BNFL, which is reported to count on Japan for 60% of its operating profits.

Japan is also the biggest potential customer for the new Sellafield reprocessing plant, sparking fears of job losses and that the plant could be in serious trouble even before it goes into full operation.

BNFL are to send their own delegation of senior managers to the customer, Kansai Electric Power, but last night, after GMB union bosses had warned that the problem could have an impact on the workforce, a BNFL spokeswoman said: "The GMB obviously have got their members' concerns at heart but, yes, the worst case scenario would be job losses."

The nuclear installations inspectorate is due to publish a report on the falsification incident next week. It is understood to recommend "radical measures" to ensure there is no repeat.

fields.headline: Glenn Miller 'victim of RAF'
fields.standfirst: Airman's logbook points to jettisoned bomb causing band leader's plane crash
fields.trailText: Glenn Miller, the legendary American band leader, could well have been killed by British airmen in a Lancaster bomber during the chaos of the second world war, according to new evidence made public yesterday.
fields.body:
Glenn Miller, the legendary American band leader, could well have been killed by British airmen in a Lancaster bomber during the chaos of the second world war, according to new evidence made public yesterday.

An RAF veteran said his fellow crewmen were convinced that 4,000lb bombs which they dumped in the Channel on the day of Miller's death hit a light aircraft or caught it in their blast. They saw the plane "flip over" and crash into the sea. One of them saw "the sea bubbling and blistering with exploded bombs".

Miller's Norseman aircraft vanished in December 1944, while it was taking him from Cambridgeshire to entertain allied troops in Paris. No wreckage was found.

Other evidence indicates that the plane's timing, speed and flight plan roughly fit the bomb incident. However, it should not have been in an area reserved for the ditching of bombs by warplanes returning from aborted missions.

According to one theory, the Norseman went off course in fog. Glenn Miller - whose big band arrangements are still played around the world - said before take-off: "It's so foggy even the birds are grounded."

Yesterday's account came from Deryck Thurman, of Derby, an ex-RAF flight engineer who was on the Lancaster. Mr Thurman's flight logbook is up for sale at Sotheby's.

He told Radio 4's Today programme: "The raid was aborted when we were south of Brussels, because our fighter escort couldn't get airborne. We had to jettison our bomb load before we could land. We went to an area that was specifically set aside for that purpose.

"Nobody anticipated there being an aircraft there at all. There was a shout that there was someone there. The navigator shot out of his seat to look and saw it whip by, then the rear gunner said: 'It's gone in, flipped over and gone in'."

Mr Thurman's logbook entry reads only, "Ops. Siegen. Recalled. Bombs jettisoned in the sea". As the mission was aborted, crewmen were not debriefed after landing.

Last April a logbook kept by the Lancaster's navigator, Fred Shaw, was sold at auction. Mr Shaw, who has since died, said at the time: "It was obvious to me that the aeroplane below was in trouble, so I watched intently. "Just before it went out of sight, I saw it flick over to what looked like an incipient spin. I saw it disappear into the Channel."

Mr Thurman said that in 1987 he and Mr Shaw held a reunion with the captain, Victor Gregory, and the rear gunner, Harry Fellows. All of them believed the Lancaster had killed Glenn Miller.

Officials in the ministry of defence's air history branch have indicated that they regard the theory as the most plausible explanation of Miller's death. But a spokesman said: "I don't think anyone is sure what happened that day."

Sotheby's aviation specialist, Stephen Maycock, said: "It hangs together as a theory. But the mystery is still unresolved and probably always will be."

At the time Miller was playing 35 troop concerts and doing 40 radio broadcasts a month. He was on the Norseman flight because he had moved his band headquarters outside London. He did so because their accommodation in Chelsea was in the path of flying bombs. The day after they left, a bomb destroyed the building.

On the 50th anniversary of his death, when a memorial to him was unveiled in the US military cemetery at Madingley, near Cambridge, an army chaplain quoted the German philosopher Friedrich Nietzsche's "The universe without music would be madness".

The chaplain added: "For those young people fighting Nazism 50 years ago, certainly their world would have been madness without the music of Glenn Miller."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Man 'harassed Anna Ford'
fields.body:
Man 'harassed Anna Ford'

A man appeared in court yesterday charged with sending newsreader Anna Ford letters of a grossly offensive or indecent nature with the aim of causing her distress or anxiety. Terence Lawton, 46, of Chelsea, west London, was also accused at Feltham magistrates of harassing Ms Ford at her home in Brentford, west London. The case was adjourned.

Art robber gets 15 years

A robber who held art gallery staff at gunpoint and stole 20 paintings valued at £700,000 was jailed for 15 years in York yesterday. Craig Townend's haul from York city art gallery a year ago included an early Turner. Judge Tom Cracknell described Townend, 29, of Rotherham, South Yorkshire, as ruthless and dangerous.

Celebrity chef 'pushed out'

Celebrity TV chef Phil Vickery was "pushed out" of his post at a top hotel in Taunton, Somerset, last June after nine years, he told an employment tribunal in Exeter yesterday, where he claimed unfair dismissal.

Christopher Chapman, proprietor of the Castle Hotel, said the Ready, Steady, Cook chef had agreed to resign after he failed to give up other work.

Judgment was reserved.

Vicar running into trouble

A vicar is threatening to halt the London Marathon because he thinks it will interrupt his Sunday service.

Rector Alan Wynne says his congregation could be jostled by runners as they attend All Saints church in Poplar, east London, on April 16, and argues that a 180-year law gives the worshippers right of way.

He said: "I hope that this will not be necessary. It is not something I want."

webTitle: MP kindest man, wife tells court

fields.headline: MP kindest man, wife tells court
fields.trailText: The new wife of a Labour MP whose former wife claimed he beat her told a court yesterday: "He is the kindest person I have ever met."
fields.body:
The new wife of a Labour MP whose former wife claimed he beat her told a court yesterday: "He is the kindest person I have ever met."

Laura Wray, a solicitor, who married Jimmy Wray last July, said the only flaws in his character were untidiness and an obsession with DIY "which he doesn't get round to finishing".

His former wife, Catherine Wray, claims that the MP for Glasgow Baillieston "battered and abused" her during their marriage, that he punched her, held a knife to her neck and grabbed her by the throat.

Mr Wray, 64, who contests her claims, is suing Associated Newspapers for £1.5m in the court of session in Edinburgh for defamation over an account of their marriage in the Mail on Sunday in 1998. The paper says its story is true.

Catherine Wray, 50, of Milngavie, Glasgow, became the second wife of Mr Wray, a former boxer, in 1985. They separated 10 years later.

Yesterday Laura Wray, 38, told the court that the portrayal of her husband in the newspaper was not one she recognised "at all".

She said she met him in the House of Commons in 1994 through her work, and lobbied his support for a campaign over tobacco-related illness. They married when their divorces came through. They had a son, Frankie, in summer 1998.

She told the court: "He is the most easy-going, even-tempered person I have ever met. I don't think he has ever lost his temper. We have had the odd argument over domestic matters."

She said he hated bad language. "If somebody so much as swears, he objects and says he doesn't like to hear that kind of thing in front of a woman, especially his wife."

Mrs Wray disputed his former wife's claim that he was possessive. "I wouldn't describe him as possessive so much as caring," she said.

When he learned of the Mail on Sunday story, her husband was "shocked and visibly white. We both felt completely deflated and upset".

In the following weeks, she said, "he was very ill looking. He had heart palpitations at one point. He became depressed and withdrawn. He needed constant reassurance that I wasn't going to up and leave him.

"I still think he seems to lack the kind of ebullience he once had _ he is much less willing to put his head above the parapet."

He was a "very caring father" to Frankie, who has development problems.

webTitle: Labourer charged with killing MP's niece

fields.headline: Labourer charged with killing MP's niece
fields.trailText: A 33-year-old farm labourer was remanded in custody yesterday charged with murdering Julie Hamill, an MP's niece.
fields.body:
A 33-year-old farm labourer was remanded in custody yesterday charged with murdering Julie Hamill, an MP's niece.

Alastair Clifford Leighton appeared before North Antrim magistrate's court in Coleraine, Co Londonderry, charged with killing Ms Hamill, whose body was found on a beach in the neighbouring town of Portstewart eight days ago.

A detective inspector said Leighton, from Drumadragh, Coleraine, replied "just guilty" when the murder charge was put to him.

Under questioning from a defence solicitor, the officer said Leighton had come forward voluntarily with his father.

Three of the dead woman's brothers - Gregory, Martin and Eamon - were in court to see Leighton remanded in custody to appear on March 10.

Miss Hamill, 28, a niece of South Down MP and SDLP chief whip Eddie McGrady, was a careers guidance counsellor, from Saul near Downpatrick, Co Down.

fields.headline: Ex-Spice had 'mixed feelings' on quitting
fields.trailText: Quitting the Spice Girls was "like leaving a marriage", Geri Halliwell told the high court in London yesterday.
fields.body:
Quitting the Spice Girls was "like leaving a marriage", Geri Halliwell told the high court in London yesterday.

Ms Halliwell, 27, known as Ginger Spice before she left in May 1998, was giving evidence in support of the pop group in a two-way legal action with Aprilia, official sponsor of their 1998 world tour.

She told Mrs Justice Arden: "What one wants to do and what one does are two different things. At the back of my mind I wanted to leave, but I didn't know whether I was brave enough to do that - leave the security of such a big band."

Explaining the build-up to her leaving, she said: "I was drip, drip feeding the idea to the others and myself to see if I was brave enough. So there wasn't one defining moment when I consciously made that decision.

"It was like leaving a marriage. You get such mixed feelings: one part of me wanted to stay, but the other half said it was time to go."

Ms Halliwell spent an hour in the witness box of court 19.

Aprilia, an Italian motor cycle manufacturer, had a £500,000 deal with the group to promote its products (including a Spice Sonic scooter featuring a picture of all five singers), and claims that Ms Halliwell's departure cost it £1.6m in lost profits.

The company claims that the Spice Girls were aware of her plans to leave when they signed the contract. The group have launched a counter-suit for £212,000 in unpaid sponsorship and royalty fees.

Relaxed and smiling, Ms Halliwell said she had wanted "a little bit of breathing space" before making new plans. She has since pursued a successful solo career and become a goodwill ambassador for the United Nations.

She told the court she remembered telling the others on their tour coach in Frankfurt in early March 1998 - before the Aprilia deal was signed - that she planned to leave at the end of September. But she added: "I do not think they took me seriously."

Later in the tour, in Milan, she "reiterated the fact that I was going to leave". Asked by Andrew Sutcliffe, for Aprilia, how the others reacted, she replied: "I think it was possibly disbelief, a mixed reaction, and still not taking it seriously."

When one asked why she wanted to leave, she told them that she had had enough and wanted to finish with a big finale at Wembley.

Ms Halliwell said the decision to keep her departure secret was not because of a fear of adverse publicity but was more "quite an emotional thing among the band".

"We wanted private time to possibly resolve it," she said. "We wanted to come to terms with it first, and then make it public. It felt kind of better to do it at the end of the tour."

She agreed that she was aware, while filming a commercial shoot for Aprilia early in May, that the company was investing a lot of money in its association with the band; but it would not have been uppermost in her mind during the shoot - "when you are an artist, you are an artist".

She said "it did not even cross my mind at the time" that the scooters' logo of the five would be out of date if she left, adding that she thought they had become "more of a collector's item" as a result.

"It didn't concern me because I felt that the Spice Girls were strong enough and had momentum to go on as a four-piece. The whole concept of it was there."

After Ms Halliwell left court, her spokesman stressed that she was not a party to the proceedings but had come voluntarily as a witness "to help out the girls".

Earlier this week, Emma Bunton - Baby Spice - told the court that the group had never believed Ms Halliwell would leave.

The hearing continues on Monday.

After Ms Halliwell left court, her spokesman stressed that she was not a party to the proceedings but had come voluntarily as a witness "to help out the girls". webTitle: Street name chimes with its station

fields.headline: Street name chimes with its station
fields.trailText: One of the safest streets in Britain has ended up with a highly appropriate name, after planners and mapmakers turned a blind eye to a property developer's quip.
fields.body:
One of the safest streets in Britain has ended up with a highly appropriate name, after planners and mapmakers turned a blind eye to a property developer's quip.

There were no objections from local residents either, to the choice of Letsby Avenue for the quarter-mile road in which the only building is a police station.

Senior officers in the South Yorkshire force gave the nod to the name - familiar from comedians' routines and children's games - after Sheffield council sent them a straight-faced consultation form for comments.

The Ordnance Survey also had a brief look for any nearby Evenin Hall or Onyer Way, before double checking by post and getting approval on official police notepaper.

"We're not quite sure who sent the letter - it's all a bit might-and-maybe at the moment," said PC Keith Scruton of the police air support unit, whose helicopter flies from a pad on the new road. "Pilots checked for the address when the new Sheffield maps came out, and we couldn't believe it at first. But it's certainly appropriate."

The road was built 18 months ago to connect the M1 with Sheffield's new airport. It is the only Letsby Avenue on the long and colourful list of names for Britain's 800,000-odd roads.

"We looked into it very seriously," said Philip Round of the Ordnance Survey, which does not name roads or streets itself but enlists suggestions from local councils and others.

The name is thought to have been put forward in an office discussion at the Tinsley Park development company, which built the road and other infrastructure for the airport.

A police spokeswoman said: "It seems to fit. We've not had to arrest anybody there yet."

Lie of the land

Sluts Hole Lane in Besthorpe, Norfolk, survived a residents' petition for a change last year. Historically unsmutty, it comes from the Dutch word for sluice, used in draining the fens.

Nuding Close in Wanstead, east London, has long lost its signs. Souvenir hunters couldn't resist them and local residents, tired of endless quips, don't want them back.

Grape Lane in York was renamed by staid Victorians who found the original Grope - historically related to local prostitution - too blatant.

Nice View in Leeds, named after the French resort, looks out on a red brick wall and the back of a shop. Perfect View in Bath has just that.

webTitle: BBC programmes fail to make TV top 10

fields.headline: BBC programmes fail to make TV top 10
fields.standfirst:
ITV fills 66 of the 100 places in poll of most watched shows
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC yesterday suffered another blow in its campaign for extra funding after new figures showed that none of its programmes made the 10 most watched shows in 1999.
fields.body:
The BBC yesterday suffered another blow in its campaign for extra funding after new figures showed that none of its programmes made the 10 most watched shows in 1999.

The research by the Royal Television Society comes as the government considers the corporation's claim for increased funding to compete in the world of digital television.

The figures will provide ammunition to the BBC's critics who say it should not receive any extra money because too few people find its programmes appealing.

The RTS study of last year's most popular programmes showed that ITV trounced the BBC, securing 66 of the top 100 places. It was the commercial channel's best showing since the chart started in 1993.

Coronation Street was the most watched show, winning 19.82m viewers for an episode in which salesman Ian Bentley married Sharon Gaskell.

ITV's dominance of the top 10 was cemented by two further episodes of the soap opera and Who Wants To Be A Millionaire?, which proved its status as a television phenomenon with one edition attracting 19.21m viewers and three gaining audiences of more than 16m.

The BBC's only presence in the top 20 were episodes of EastEnders and the Vicar of Dibley, in 20th place.

William Phillip, who compiled the chart, said: "Take away EastEnders and a handful of specials and little remains in the top 50 to justify the corporation's pretensions as a convenor of the whole nation for shared amusement."

ITV produced the most watched shows in almost every programming genre.

It had the best audiences for drama, with Heartbeat and a Touch of Frost winning 17.01m and 16.85m viewers respectively.

ITV's decision to secure sports rights has paid off. Its coverage of the European Champions League final featuring Manchester United's win over Bayern Munich was the top rated sporting event with 15.62m. The England v Scotland Euro 2000 play-off match with 14.6m was the second most watched sports event.

The BBC lost out in feature films with ITV's showing of the Bond film Goldeneye getting 13.23m viewers and securing 26th place.

ITV's success is partly due to a reinvigorated Saturday night performance, which accounted for 13 of its top 100 entries.

But the report contained bad news for the two mainstream channels, with increased competition eating into their audiences. On average, the top 100 programmes last year were viewed by 12.4m people, less than a quarter of the maximum potential audience, whereas in 1993 the equivalent figure was 14.3m.

Carlton's inability to produce hit programmes continued with Carlton and Central, which it owns, contributing seven shows compared with the Granada group's 31.

Despite BBC1 spending £558m and ITV £670m on shows, little fresh programming impacted on the top 100, with soaps, game shows and light dramas dominating.

A BBC spokesperson said: "We don't judge ourselves by pure numbers, we have different barometers of our success The BBC is here to do different things from ITV. We aim to give all licence fee payers a nourishing schedule filled with quality and diversity."

An ITV spokeswoman said: "1999 was a terrific year because we grew our share in peak time by 1% which was our target. ITV is a commercial channel which has a very simple ambition, which is to appeal to the largest possible audience."

But the ratings boom for ITV may be ending. Last month its peak time share fell by 2% compared with January 1999, meaning that on average 500,000 fewer viewers see the programmes it relies on most to generate advertising revenues.

Last year saw BBC1 record its lowest audience figures for the second year running, falling to 28.3%.

fields.headline: De Chastelain's report to governments
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The following is the full text of General John de Chastelain's report given to the British and Irish governments on January 31, 2000.
fields.body:
The following is the full text of General John de Chastelain's report given to the British and Irish governments on January 31, 2000.

1 In our report of December 10, the commission undertook to report further on decommissioning in January. That is this report. Since December, the commission has held further discussions with representatives of the IRA, the UVF and the UFF.

2 Our previous report stated our belief that the results of the Mitchell review and the designation of IRA and UFF contacts, in addition to the UVF contact already in place, gave the basis for an assessment that decommissioning will happen.

While we believe that conclusion was well founded we await further evidence to substantiate it.

3 The IRA contact has assured us of the unequivocal continuing support of his organisation for the current political process. We have been made aware of, and recognise, the difficulties facing the IRA leadership in moving on decommissioning at this time. We are also conscious that the maintenance of the ceasefire, and of those of the UVF and UFF, have played and continue to play, an important part in the political advances that have been achieved to date and that are progressing.

Further, our contact has very recently emphasised that there is no threat to the peace process from the IRA. All of these factors are significant. But our sole task is decommissioning and to date we have received no information from the IRA as to when decommissioning will start.

4 In our most recent discussion with the UVF contact, he reminded us of the discussions he held with the commission over a long period, including the UVF's early engagement on the issues of modalities.

He has also reiterated the UVF stance that while it is prepared to consider moving on decommissioning, it will not do so until it has received an unequivocal statement from the IRA that the war is over.

5 Similarly, our most recent discussion with the representatives of the UFF has confirmed their position stated during our earlier meeting, to the effect that while that group too is prepared to consider moving on decommissioning, it will not do so until it is clear the IRA will decommission.

6 We will continue our efforts to continue the commission's role in the manner and within the time-frame approved by the political parties and the two governments. However, given our understanding of the quantity of arms held by the paramilitary groups, and the dispersed nature of their locations. we believe a time will soon be reached beyond which it will be logistically impossible for us to complete our task by 22 May. We remain prepared to state, at an appropriate date, when we believe decommissioning must start and how it must proceed if our mandate is to be fulfilled within the required period. But decommissioning is a voluntary act; any schedule we produce will only be of value if those who have the arms agree to follow it.

7 The foregoing noted, intensive negotiations have taken place during the past few days. The commission will report further to the governments in the event that ongoing negotiations lead to concrete results.

8 If it becomes clear to us that decommissioning is not to happen the commission will recommend to the governments that it be disbanded."

Signed

Tauno Nieminen

John de Chastelain

Andrew D Sens

webTitle: How Ulster went back to the brink

fields.headline: How Ulster went back to the brink
fields.standfirst:
Arms poser that will not go away haunts the deal-makers

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: In the old days Sinn Fein was happy to be described as the IRA's politicial wing. Republicans back then keenly asserted all parties to the conflict must be involved in negotiations, and the corollary was that Sinn Fein would speak for the IRA at any such talks.
fields.body:
In the old days Sinn Fein was happy to be described as the IRA's politicial wing. Republicans back then keenly asserted all parties to the conflict must be involved in negotiations, and the corollary was that Sinn Fein would speak for the IRA at any such talks.

That, though, was long ago, and Sinn Fein has since embarked on the smartest of strategies: emphasising that it draws its mandate solely from votes at the ballot box and that it cannot speak for the IRA. That allows it to claim that, contrary to earlier demands, the IRA remains outside the political negotiations.

Although Sinn Fein's Gerry Adams, Martin McGuinness, Pat Doherty and Martin Ferris are believed to be on the IRA army council, the approach allows republicans, often elusive in public pronouncements, an even freer hand in deal-making. It is, believe Ulster Unionists, a recipe for uncertainty.

British and Irish sources concede that Sinn Fein and the IRA are not identical, but say they are inextricably linked. As one senior government figure put it this week: "Together, they are a multi-faceted, multi-tiered, urban-rural, political movement."

Several pundits believe this approach made it possible for republicans, through Sinn Fein, to back the Good Friday Agreement, vowing simply to do all it could do to secure paramilitary decommissioning by May 2000. But they think it has also led to the current impasse.

Backlash

Some Ulster Unionists are so frustrated they have even considered approaching the IRA directly, desisting only because of the likely backlash. One senior figure said: "We are now slowly realising that if we make a deal with Sinn Fein, it appears not to bind in the IRA."

This is crystallising because Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble is convinced he won an "understanding" at ex-US senator George Mitchell's review of the agreement. There was no explicit deal of actual IRA decommissioning by the end of January, but he is convinced Mr Adams and Mr McGuinness led him to believe that.

One senior government player said: "There was an implicit understanding that if the Ulster Unionists agreed to devolution in November, they would be unable to sustain membership of the power-sharing executive if there was no progress by the end of January. There was no guarantee, but there was no ambiguity."

After Mr Mitchell's review Mr Trimble knew from his 18 constituency branches ahead of November's critical meeting of his 860-strong Ulster Unionist Council that he was in trouble. He was seeking backing for a switch in his 'no guns no government' policy to jumping first, providing for immediate devolution with Sinn Fein.

So he played what appeared to be his trump: switching the demand for outright backing for devolution without prior IRA weapons to a conditional approach. He would go ahead and join the unique power-sharing government with Sinn Fein that week, but would return to a reconvened council in February so it could take a final decision.

It came with a promise: that if there were no IRA decommissioning before the end of January, he would quit, along with the three Ulster Unionist ministers in the 12-member Cabinet. To underline that, he handed a letter of resignation to party president Josias Cunningham, post-dated to February 4.

John Taylor, deputy of the Ulster Unionist parliamentary party, had also rowed to Mr Trimble's rescue just before the meeting got underway at the showpiece Waterfront Hall, announcing his latest volte-face. He would, after all, support immediate devolution.

Infuriated

So Mr Trimble might have squeezed through without opting for the conditional move, but there was little enough safety margin in his 58 per cent support.

Republicans concede he had difficulties. But they were infuriated at his brief press conference afterwards. Mr Trimble sounded positively belligerent as he said: "We've done our bit, Mr Adams. It's over to you. We've jumped. You follow."

Mr Adams did. He raged that there was no January deadline and railed against Mr Trimble for introducing it. So even as the peace process leapt forward, the seeds of yesterday's suspension were sprouting.

Government sources say they were confident three months ago Sinn Fein would be able to deliver IRA arms by the end of January. Now they think its leadership was chancing its arm. One official said: "They were like Mr Micawber, hoping something turns up."

They pointed to comments in the United States earlier in November from Mr Doherty and Mr Ferris as evidence of Sinn Fein complacency, that once the institutions were formed Ulster Unionsists would not dare to pull out for fear of getting the blame. Nor did Sinn Fein appear to believe Mr Mandelson would suspend.

Mr Trimble's wrong-footing move threw that analysis into disarray. But the Sunday newspapers continued to publish details of how and when decommissioning was about to take place, much to the bemusement of General John de Chastelain, chairman of the Independent Commission on Decommissioning.

British and Irish officials believe Mr Adams and Mr McGuinness would like to see IRA decommissioning. It would open up electoral possibilities for Sinn Fein both sides of the Irish border. But they agree Mr Adams and Mr McGuinness face a delicate task, with dissident republicans, like those responsible for last Sunday's bomb attack in Co Fermanagh, trying to entice disenchanted IRA members. They believe the dynamic within republicanism has changed in the past two months, and think Mr Trimble's move to put in public the nods and winks in private were a key.

It will be hard to avoid the blame game over the next few weeks. Republicans will berate Mr Trimble and Mr Mandleson, and there is little doubt the pendulum currently so heavily against them could come roaring back to smash Mr Trimble.

Today's meeting of the Ulster Unionist Council may threaten to be a damp squib after yesterday's suspension. But it could be crucial. Trimble loyalists are less likely to turn up, and the council's complexion will be more hardline than in November. Some delegates will seek to force motions linking any fresh attempt at government with guarantees on decommissioning and on RUC reform. That would make picking up the agreement even more difficult.

Hollow

Mr Mandelson will signal an all-important breathing space before a second review of the agreement. Sinn Fein's veiled threats about boycotting it are likely to prove hollow. It is bound to stick in there to prove its strategy can work.

As this crisis reached a climax, the focus has been on deputy first minister Seamus Mallon's two key questions. He wants clear responses to: "Is the IRA going to decommission? If so, when?"

Only once the answers are known can any attempt be made to rescue the 22-month-old agreement. Nationalists and the Irish government now agree it is time, one way or another, for the IRA to stop hiding behind ambiguous statements and Sinn Fein and come clean.

The end of direct rule - and its return

April 10 1998: Good Friday agreement signed.

May 22: Backing for deal in referendums on both sides of border.

June 25: Elections to new Northern Ireland assembly. Supporters of deal won 80 seats and opponents 28.

August 15: Car bomb blast in Omagh kills 29 people. Real IRA claims responsibility.

Sept 1: Sinn Fein says it considers violence to be a thing of the past.

Sept 14: Power-sharing assembly starts proceedings.

Dec 10: John Hume and David Trimble receive Nobel Peace prize in Oslo.

Dec 18: Loyalist Volunteer Force first paramilitary group to start handing over weapons for decommissioning.

April 1 1999: Hillsborough declaration seeks to ensure IRA decommissioning.

June 28: Protestant march banned from entering Catholic enclave in Drumcree.

Sept 6: George Mitchell begins review of peace process.

Oct 11: Peter Mandelson replaces Mo Mowlam as Northern Ireland secretary.

Nov 16: Sinn Fein and Ulster Unionists issue conciliatory statements.

Nov 17: IRA says it is ready to discuss decommissioning.

Nov 18: Mitchell says basis exists for decommissioning and coalition government.

Nov 22: Gerry Adams says his party committed to decommissioning and peace accord.

Nov 27: Ulster Unionists vote to accept compromise paving way for assembly.

Nov 29: Ten ministers appointed (two from Sinn Fein).

Dec 1 midnight: Devolution restored.

Dec 2: Irish government signs away articles of constitution laying claim to Northern Ireland. IRA appoints interlocutor to decommissioning body.

Jan 31 2000: De Chastelain report on IRA disarmament handed over to British and Irish governments.

Feb 1: IRA says it remains "totally committed" to peace process.

Thursday Feb 3: Mandelson signals introduction of bill to suspend executive and reimpose direct rule. Tony Blair in crisis talks with Bertie Ahern.

Sunday Feb 6: Continuity IRA bomb a Co Fermanagh hotel. No one hurt.

Friday Feb 11: Mandelson suspends devolved government and reimposes direct rule.

fields.headline: Sky-surfer's parachute fails to open
fields.standfirst: British champion killed in Spain
fields.trailText: Chris Gauge, the British sky-surfing champion, was killed when his parachute failed to open during a jump in Spain on Wednesday.
fields.body:
Chris Gauge, the British sky-surfing champion, was killed when his parachute failed to open during a jump in Spain on Wednesday.

The 31-year-old was making a training jump from a plane over Seville. His parachute should have opened automatically, but he fell 15,000 feet. Spanish officials are investigating what went wrong, and why a reserve parachute he was believed to have been wearing also did not open.

The death of Mr Gauge, from Trevellas in Cornwall, was confirmed yesterday by the foreign office. Ten years ago he hit power lines during a free-fall contest in the United States, and he had planned to retire next year. His wife, Toni, whom he married in November, was with him in Spain and was travelling home last night. His body will not been released by the Spanish authorities until after an inquiry ends next week.

Mr Gauge's mother, Joan, said: "This is so catastrophic. He was very experienced, it was his life."

Her son had gone to Spain on Saturday for three months to run a sky-surfing school.

He won the British championship last August, and finished eighth in the world in October. He had been full-time since 1987, learning at 18 from someone who himself was later killed in a jump.
