webTitle: Success finds no room for the poor

fields.headline: Success finds no room for the poor
fields.trailText: The internet gurus and venture capital investors who drive from Pittsburgh's newly refurbished international airport to the "Golden Triangle" commercial district pass right by The Hill, but rarely catch a glimpse of it.
fields.body:
The internet gurus and venture capital investors who drive from Pittsburgh's newly refurbished international airport to the "Golden Triangle" commercial district pass right by The Hill, but rarely catch a glimpse of it.

The Hill is Pittsburgh's woeful secret, a dark inversion of the city's loudly hailed prosperity which has sunk to new depths of poverty even as the suburbs around it have grown rich. A secret that reflects a wider, national failure.

The old district used to be Pittsburgh's hallway, inhabited by successive waves of immigrants - Russians, Poles and Jews. Tradition has it that Trotsky made speeches there to raise support for permanent revolution. He would doubtless point to it now as proof of the inequities of unbridled capitalism.

The Hill's residents these days are almost all black and the black unemployment rate, at 12%, is almost three times the white rate.

In the days of "big steel", the district boomed along side white Pittsburgh. There were rows of bars and restaurants where Lena Horne, Art Blakey and Erroll Garner performed.

Now it looks like a war zone. Howard Jackson grew up in The Hill, but escaped before it plunged into its present despair. "Things are changing all around and The Hill is just stagnating. The city is developing. On The Hill it's just being left to die," he said.

But The Hill's problems are more or less the same as impoverished districts across the country. American towns and cities have failed to take these areas on their journey from old economy to new, and the gap in family incomes between the rich and poor across the US is growing.

Jeanne Berdik of Pittsburgh technology council said: "If you're moving to a system which requires a higher level of skills and knowledge and the state is not able to retrain people, there is going to be a bigger gap between those who have the right kind of knowledge and those who don't."

webTitle: US crash prompts air safety checks

fields.headline: US crash prompts air safety checks
fields.trailText: British Airways is inspecting 10 planes owned by a subsidiary, after US authorities ordered an immediate investigation of 1,100 McDonnell Douglas aircraft in service in the US following the Alaska Airlines crash in which 88 people died.
fields.body:
British Airways is inspecting 10 planes owned by a subsidiary, after US authorities ordered an immediate investigation of 1,100 McDonnell Douglas aircraft in service in the US following the Alaska Airlines crash in which 88 people died.

BA, which has started to inspect 10 MD-89 single-aisle planes operated by Air Liberté on the Heathrow to Orly-Paris route, said the checks would be finished over the weekend.

The US inspection of all MD-80 series aircraft was ordered by the Federal Aviation Administration after two Alaska Airlines aircraft were found to have tail section damage similar to that found in the wreckage of Flight 261, which plunged into the Pacific near Los Angeles on January 31.

The FAA, which has not grounded the fleet for the inspections, said it was issuing a directive with immediate effect and was working with other countries, including Britain, to ensure the inspection of aircraft outside the US.

Sources close to the investigation of the crash have found preliminary evidence of extreme wear on parts of the stabiliser control system in the tail of the doomed MD-83 aircraft. They discovered a faulty jackscrew, a rod which moves the stabiliser up and down.

Before the plane dived 17,900ft, the crew reported that a stabiliser had jammed in a position that pushed the aircraft downward.

webTitle: No,the old business cycle has not yet been licked

fields.headline: No,the old business cycle has not yet been licked
fields.trailText: Only time will tell if the US is now experiencing the birth of a new economy or the dying days of a stock market-fuelled economic bubble.
fields.body:
Only time will tell if the US is now experiencing the birth of a new economy or the dying days of a stock market-fuelled economic bubble.

US economic performance since 1996 - about the midpoint of this record-breaking expansion - does makes a strong case for a "new economy".

Gross domestic product (GDP) adjusted for inflation has grown 4.4% per year. Productivity - an index of how much the economy produces in an hour of work - has risen at an impressive 2.7% annual rate. And, after nearly two decades of decline, the inflation-adjusted wages of the typical worker have risen about 2.5% per year.

The early days of this expansion, however, were particularly disappointing - remember the "jobless recovery"?. Over the entire expansion, which began in March 1991, GDP has grown at a slower, 3.6% annual rate - tying as the slowest rate in the eight expansions since 1949. Productivity growth has averaged 2.2% per year - better than the late 1970s and 1980s, but slower than every other postwar expansion. Despite strong growth since 1996, real wages are today barely 2% better than they were at the peak of the last business cycle in 1990 and are still about 1% below their 1973 level.

Without more data - particularly on how the economy fares through the next recession - economists would probably do best withholding final judgment on the roaring 90s.

Meanwhile, the main lessons from the "new economy" may turn out to be decidedly old-fashioned.

First, low unemployment is good for workers. Wages for the typical worker showed no signs of recovery until unemployment fell below 6% in March 1996. Workers at the bottom have benefited disproportionately from low unemployment - and the 1996-97 increases in the federal minimum wage - with wages up almost 10% since 1996. (Meanwhile, a huge untapped supply of labour and the burst in productivity prevented wage rises from translating into higher prices.)

Second, the distribution of economic growth matters. While wages have become somewhat more equal since 1996, income inequality (which includes nonwage income) and wealth inequality (driven by the stock market) have worsened considerably over the full business cycle.

Third, markets can con tribute only so much to solving social problems. The average low-wage worker made about $5.37 (£3.37) in 1996. The 10% real-wage growth since then translates into an extra 54 cents an hour. These market-driven gains fall far short of what is necessary to put health care within the reach of the 45m Americans still lacking even basic cover. Nor will these gains provide safe, affordable child care for working mothers, or decent housing and quality public education for the 12.7% of the population below the official poverty line.

The overvalued stock market, the yawning trade deficit and consumer spending far ahead of income growth - all key ingredients of the boom - point to what may be the hardest lesson from our prosperity: we haven't licked the business cycle yet.

John Schmitt is an economist with the Economic Policy Institute in Washington

webTitle: The dream that became global reality

fields.headline: The dream that became global reality
fields.standfirst: This month American history is made. Powered by new technology, the country has never had it so good for so long
fields.trailText: The history of America in the 90s has been that of the comeback kid and the comeback economy. While Bill Clinton has managed, Houdini-like, to cheat political death with staggering regularity, the battered US economy of 15 years ago has witnessed a rebirth.
fields.body:
The history of America in the 90s has been that of the comeback kid and the comeback economy. While Bill Clinton has managed, Houdini-like, to cheat political death with staggering regularity, the battered US economy of 15 years ago has witnessed a rebirth.

Not that Mr Clinton is receiving much of the credit; most Americans believe that while the president was indulging in his Oval Office hanky panky with Monica Lewinsky, it was Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, who was delivering the good times.

Today the boom has hit 107 months - the longest in the US since records began.

Aided by a new breed of entrepreneurs in the growing hitech sector, Mr Greenspan, the world's most powerful central banker, is seen as the man who turned round the US economy in the 90s.

America has enjoyed the fastest growth of all the major developed countries, accounts for nine out of 10 of the world's biggest companies, and is exporting its free-market model to the rest of the globe.

Whereas 15 years ago a post-Watergate, post-Vietnam America was fearful of a Japanese takeover and envious of the German social market capitalism, now the boot is on the other foot. Japan has endured a decade of economic turmoil since its stock market bubble burst in the late 80s, while it is Germany's turn to grow introspective and look to the free-market Anglo-Saxon model as the way forward for its unemployment-dogged economy.

Despite the setback to trade liberalisation in Seattle two months ago, globalisation is an American-driven phenomenon. It is the Washington-dominated International Monetary Fund that has been pressing for further dismantling of barriers to capital, US financial institutions which have taken the creed to the far-flung corners of the globe and US companies like Microsoft, Dell and Intel which have pioneered the hi-tech revolution. From Moscow to Mozambique, the globe is in thrall to US cultural hegemony: Disney, Coca-Cola, McDonald's.

It is all a far cry from eight years ago, when Mr Clinton was struggling against his first sexual scandal to be the Democratic nominee to fight the incumbent Republican president, George Bush.

After the blue-collar recession at the start of the 80s, which left scars across the traditional industrial heartland of the midwest, the US received another sudden jolt at the time of the Gulf war in 1991. Unemployment rose as growth fell, making US voters susceptible to the classic Clinton soundbite: "It's the economy, stupid."

As it happens, the economy had already started to recover by the time of the 1992 election. The 107 consecutive months of growth - longer than the roaring 20s, longer than the Eisenhower or great society booms of the post-war era - began around the time that the comeback kid was hailing his second place in the New Hampshire primary as a great triumph. With job insecurity rife, wage rates falling and taxes - contrary to Mr Bush's read-my-lips promise - rising, voters were in the mood for change.

Confidence boost

It was President Clinton's good fortune to arrive at the White House just as a number of factors had combined to put the US economy on the mend. Mr Greenspan had cut interest rates rapidly and aggressively in 1991 and the availability of cheap money helped boost confidence. At the same time, the lavish cold war defence spending, culminating in Ronald Reagan's star wars project, had delivered a range of civil spin-offs in computers, telecommunications and biotechnology.

As with New Labour, Clinton's New Democrats were studiously friendly to the great god of the market, so much so that the president was more popular on Wall Street than Main Street. Steps were taken to pay the burgeoning budget deficit - the legacy of Mr Reagan's profligacy - and today the US is again running a healthy surplus.

Moreover, nothing was done to prevent a widening gap between the earnings of those in the boardroom from those on the shopfloor. For most Americans, the two decades from the mid-70s onwards were a time when they had to work harder to stand still. Falling earnings meant people worked longer hours, often double jobbing in order to pay the bills. At the top, however, executives enjoyed staggering increases in pay. For example, between 1978 and 1998 the earnings of the country's highest paid corporate executive are reported to have risen from $5m to $576m - an 11,400% increase.

Only in the past three years have the effects of the boom started to translate into rising real earnings for the bulk of Americans. Although the unemployment figures are flattered by a penal regime that has 2m men behind bars, the labour market is tight, allowing workers to press for higher pay. But the US remains a deeply divided society - with a privileged elite at one end of the spectrum and ghettoes at the other.

But the boom looks set to continue for some time yet. Recent figures have shown the economy still surging, with productivity improving at an annual rate of 5% and the strong dollar helping to keep inflation low by reducing the cost of imports.

There was a serious wobble in the autumn of 1998 when it seemed that the debt default in Russia and the threatened collapse of Long Term Capital Management might bring down the western financial system, but Mr Greenspan rode to the rescue with emergency cuts in interest rates and a hastily organised bail-out for LTCM. Shares rallied, investors piled back into the stock market and Mr Greenspan's already glowing reputation was enhanced further.

However, the Federal Reserve chairman is aware that there could be trouble ahead. It is far from clear whether the especially rapid growth over the past four years represents a fundamental improvement in America's economic potential or is merely another example - like Japan and Britain in the late 80s - of an economy that is growing too fast for its own good.

Mr Greenspan warned more than three years ago of the "irrational exuberance" of the stock market, since when it has continued on its merry way upwards. Some are saying that the Dow Jones index, currently just below 11,000, could hit 36,000.

Mr Greenspan, through gradual rises in interest rates, is hoping that he can let air out of the bubble gradually rather than see it burst. It is he, rather than Al Gore or Bill Bradley, George W Bush or John McCain, who holds the future in his hands.

webTitle: Long walk to freedom Mandela marks 10 years out of jail at his birthplace

fields.headline: Long walk to freedom Mandela marks 10 years out of jail at his birthplace
fields.trailText: South Africa's former president Nelson Mandela has marked the 10th anniversary of his release from apartheid jails in a ceremony at his birthplace in rural Transkei.
fields.body:
South Africa's former president Nelson Mandela has marked the 10th anniversary of his release from apartheid jails in a ceremony at his birthplace in rural Transkei.

"Into this world a young boy was born. He has gone from the world's most famous political prisoner to the world's most loved political leader," Bridgette Mabandla, the deputy minister of arts and culture, said in the village of Mvezo.

Mr Mandela, 81, reflected on his childhood in the tiny village and the day he stole a pig to prove his manhood before ritual circumcision.

He also said returning reminded him his father had beaten his four wives, including his mother. "Just remember, if we beat you it is because we love you," he said, to nervous laughter.

He then unveiled a plaque at a new monument near the mud hut where he was born on July 18 1918, the son of a chief's adviser.

The monument is part of a three-site Nelson Mandela museum, including a planned youth and heritage centre in Qunu village, where he grew up, and an exhibition centre in the regional capital Umtata.

"This project is going to bring tourists here, create employment," Mr Mandela said.

He walked free from Victor Verster prison near Cape Town on February 11 1990, with a clenched fist held high and his then wife Winnie at his side. Reuters

webTitle: Aids threat to gene therapy volunteers

fields.headline: Aids threat to gene therapy volunteers
fields.trailText: Fresh concerns over the conduct of gene therapy research were raised in the United States yesterday when it emerged that a group of young cancer patients acting as guinea pigs had not been told that they could have been accidentally exposed to the virus which causes Aids.
fields.body:
Fresh concerns over the conduct of gene therapy research were raised in the United States yesterday when it emerged that a group of young cancer patients acting as guinea pigs had not been told that they could have been accidentally exposed to the virus which causes Aids.

Researchers at the St Jude children's research hospital in Memphis, Tennessee, discovered in December that genetically modified cells implanted in more than a score of patients could have been contaminated.

But according to yesterday's Washington Post, the scientists only decided to warn patients and their families on Thursday, when the newspaper told them it had learned of the problem.

The hospital was last night expected to make a statement on the issue.

The Memphis revelations come at a time of intense anxiety over the pace and style of gene therapy research in the US.

The death last year of the teenage gene therapy trial volunteer Jesse Gelsinger; the subsequent government shutdown of all gene therapy trials at the respected Pennsylvania institute where Gelsinger was being treated; and the discovery that gene therapy research teams nationwide had failed to properly report deaths and complications among trial patients have all contributed to a widespread fear in the US that researchers are putting the interests of science and commerce before the interests of patients.

The Memphis trials, run jointly with a smaller study at the Baylor college of medicine in Houston, Texas, began in 1995 and involved patients aged under 26 who were dying of cancer. Samples of their tumour cells were removed, modified with a gene carried by a specially tailored virus and reinjected in the hope of provoking the patients' immune system to attack the tumour. On Thursday Laura Bowman, who headed the study at St Jude, admitted that some of the cells used to grow the engineered viruses did not appear to have been screened properly for contamination.

Tests late last year showed that some of the engineered viruses could have been contaminated with HIV-1, which causes Aids, and HCV, which causes hepatitis C.

Researchers and federal officials point out that the initial test results could prove wrong. But the episode casts fresh doubts over the tightness of procedures to care for patient welfare in this frontier medical technology.

Fears have been expressed in the US that pressure for results from biotech companies plugging their stocks on Wall Street could have led to the scientists they sponsor cutting regulatory corners.

Gene therapy has yet to produce a proven clinical treatment, let alone a cure. But some commentators argue that its past reputation as being relatively harmless in trials may have led researchers to become too relaxed about reporting problems - particularly when so many patient volunteers are fatally ill anyway.

Dr Bowman said that only four of the 20 patients she had treated in the trials were still alive; two out of six patients in the Houston study had died. All died from cancer, she said.

Earlier this week President Bill Clinton said that federal health agencies would have to speed up their review of US gene therapy rules and guidelines to see whether patients who volunteered to be guinea pigs needed better protection.

The agencies responsible for licensing gene therapy tests in Britain, which have given permission for 40 trials since 1992, argue that procedures here are already tighter than in the US.

Despite the slow pace of gene therapy research, the scientific community remains optimistic that it will, eventually, start to produce results.

webTitle: Resentment at state's daylight robbery dwarfs anger at crime

fields.headline: Resentment at state's daylight robbery dwarfs anger at crime
fields.trailText: The most surprising thing about the dwarf who jumped out of the box and robbed the post office was the reaction. Not of the staff, who had a gun waved in their faces and understandably handed over the £45,000, but of other Romans.
fields.body:
The most surprising thing about the dwarf who jumped out of the box and robbed the post office was the reaction. Not of the staff, who had a gun waved in their faces and understandably handed over the £45,000, but of other Romans.

At first there was curiosity. The robber had packed himself into a carton and had himself delivered to the post office. It was too big to fit through security scanners, so the carton was carried through a service door, whereupon he burst out and roared: "It's a hold up!"

In a city with many armed robberies, this one was unusual enough to get people talking. They wanted to know details, such as the size of the box, the width of the door, the calibre of gun, the type of swag bag.

Next came anger. My affable newsagent, Luca, was incandescent. The thief had to be hunted down, taught a lesson, keys had to be thrown away. Others expressed the same venom.

This was puzzling. No one had been injured. The amount taken was not large. The dwarf would probably be caught before long. And everyone had a story about rude, oafish post office staff.

Luca couldn't explain it, but a neighbour tried. The queues in post offices take forever and the staff are arrogant, she said; but it is where we meet friends, it belongs to us. It's our space.

This was news to me. Romans are not known as fans of collectivism and at the post office all I ever see are humbled, late, infuriated customers. But maybe it was true. The dwarf was said to have robbed "us".

Satisfied that spleen had been vented, friends then proceeded to admire the daring and cunning, the style.

The robber, it seemed, could be praised - but only for outwitting the authorities. It was difficult to see how the state could in this instance be blamed, but it was.

It is a recurring theme. Incompetence, waste, fraud and avarice, agree my neigh bours in Prati, are bedfellows of government. Having been governed by crooks for 50 years, they have a point.

It took two days of meeting potential landladies to detect self-justification in the anti-government diatribes.

"You must understand that the rent cannot be declared for tax," said one grand dame, dripping jewellery. "They will take 50% and throw it away. Waste it all."

That was the first thing she said. Others were more subtle. They warmed me up with horror stories of bureaucracy gone mad before saying the same thing.

There was one exception. Thin, seventysomething; she tried, she really tried, but she was never cut out for crime.

She stared at her shoes and mumbled about not being able to afford the tax. The phone call came the next day. Was it all right if we declared half the tax?

The rest of her nerves had evaporated by evening, when she phoned again. On reflection the tax was affordable, just about. Was that all right?

Perhaps she secretly longs to have his daring and cunning, but my landlady is the one neighbour yet to praise the dwarf.

It was too big to fit through security scanners, so the carton was carried through a service door, whereupon he burst out and roared: "It's a hold up!" fields.headline: £20m sweetener for Esser in defeat
fields.trailText: Institutional investors in the world's largest telecom company, Vodafone, heaped praise on Mannesmann's chief executive Klaus Esser yesterday after he pocketed a 60.5m marks (£20m) package as part of conceding defeat in the take over with the British group, writes Anne Hyland .
fields.body:
Institutional investors in the world's largest telecom company, Vodafone, heaped praise on Mannesmann's chief executive Klaus Esser yesterday after he pocketed a 60.5m marks (£20m) package as part of conceding defeat in the take over with the British group, writes Anne Hyland .

"He's earned the money many times over - he's made his shareholders a fortune," said one Vodafone investor. "It was in his contract and he's entitled to it. Compared with fees earned by the investment banks involved its small beer."

Another added: "There has been an element of sweetening to the deal. His payment is not outrageous. He has delivered a lot of shareholder value."

It was agreed in December that Mr Esser would receive full salary and bonuses until 2004 when his contract expired.

His annual salary was 1.4m marks plus bonuses of 2.8m marks and a medium term performance bonus of 12.6m marks. He will also receive 31.1m marks from Vodafone afer completion of the acquisition.

It is understood, however, that Vodafone did not have a role in the negotiation of Mr Esser's "appreciation" package.

Mr Esser will remain in an executive role to oversee the integration of the two businesses and the spin-off of the engineering and automotive businesses until June. After that he will take up the non-executive deputy chairman role at Vodafone.

The deadline for acceptances of the 170bn euro (£105bn) deal by German shareholders was also extended from February 17 to March 27 after a request by Vodafone. Vodafone holds about 67% of Mannessmann stock and its shares rose 8.25p to 351.75p. Today, Vodafone's chief executive Chris Gent is expected to reveal that it is likely the head of the supervisory board of Mannesmann, Joachim Funk, will step down.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Taroudant, Morocco
fields.trailText: Taroudant, Morocco
fields.body:
Colour and movement struck us at once.

A small bird darted down from the top of a thorn hedge, caught a fat insect and returned to its perch to gobble. With its rosehip-red throat, chest and underparts, a white stripe running over its dark head from above its beak, over the eyes and down to its neck and the white flashes on its wings - it was clearly a Moussier's redstart, out hunting around a small farm in the foothills of the Atlas mountains.

A field of broad beans in flower filled the warm air with a sweet scent rarely experienced in Britain. The village houses are made of pise , a mixture of soil and vegetation which makes them look like natural rectangular features of the landscape.

There was a man seated outside one such house with a carefully respected wooden box and a breakfast tray. He was the local snake catcher, to be called in when a householder discovers he has a dangerous snake in residence.

It has been unusually warm and snakes are waking up. Itinerant snake charmers turn up. One carries a snake box, another plays a drum, another a trumpet, while a man leans on a rifle to expound the pleasures of the snake and another carries a steaming kettle attached to a charcoal heater.

If the snake sleeps on, hot water is sucked up by one of the gang and sprayed over it.

From the roof garden we can watch storks elegantly gliding with the thermals. While they turn and wheel, their colour changes from white to black as the light catches the different feathers. Some have started to house-build on palm trees where a great platform is established to hold the sticks of the nest. One pair is mating already.

Another pleasure is the return of a flock of little egrets to their roost on certain trees in the city. Naturally there are house sparrows, but they are outnumbered by house buntings with their warm grey, almost blue streaked heads and pouting chests. They dash and squabble and enjoy themselves.

fields.headline: Advisers prepare bills for millions
fields.trailText: Royal Bank of Scotland will hand out £265m in fees and taxes to pay for the takeover of NatWest, which itself faces a £60m bill for its unsuccessful defence.
fields.body:
Royal Bank of Scotland will hand out £265m in fees and taxes to pay for the takeover of NatWest, which itself faces a £60m bill for its unsuccessful defence.

Royal Bank also faces a hefty bill to remove the top executives at NatWest, who can each demand at least £1m to leave.

For Gordon Pell, lured by NatWest from Lloyds TSB last month, it could be a case of £1m for a fortnight's work if Royal Bank decides not to retain him.

Ron Sandler, parachuted in as chief operating officer, will also cost as much as £1m to get rid of, while Sir David Rowland, the chairman and chief executive, can expect to be able to command a similar package.

Royal Bank's financial advisers at Goldman Sachs, Merrill Lynch and Warburg along with lawyers and public relations firms, will share in a £143m bonanza. NatWest's payout will go to its financial advisers and lawyers.

Unlike its predators, NatWest has not disclosed its fees although it is estimated that JP Morgan and Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, the investment banking advisers to NatWest, can expect a flat fee of £17.5m each, while the broker Cazenove is estimated to receive £10m. The rest will go on lawyers fees and sundries associated with the bid, such as printing costs.

BoS, which has thrown in the towel, will still face a bill from its financial advisers at CSFB, Morgan Stanley and lawyers who had expected to receive £171m if the bid was successful.

They will now have to take a much smaller slice. At least BoS will not have to incur the £129m stamp duty it faced if successful.

BoS will admit the official cost of the bid when it publishes its figures next month but talk in City yesterday still focused on a healthy reward for the unsuccessful advisers after four months of gruelling work.

webTitle: The contest that made soap stars out of dour bankers

fields.headline: The contest that made soap stars out of dour bankers
fields.trailText: It was a battle of personalities: the braveheart Scots against the "public school boy" image of NatWest, literally in the shadow of the Bank of England in the City.
fields.body:
It was a battle of personalities: the braveheart Scots against the "public school boy" image of NatWest, literally in the shadow of the Bank of England in the City.

It was also a staggering reversal in the fortunes of Peter Burt, the chief executive of Bank of Scotland who received a standing ovation when he made his bid for NatWest last September. That might have been his one consolation as he flew back to Edinburgh on Wednesday, realising that he had won the argument that NatWest needed to change - but lost the battle for the London bank.

He became renowned for his "Burtisms" during the four-month fight, such as "you don't need to own the cow to sell the milk" to explain his belief that NatWest's takeover for Legal & General had to be stopped.

Mr Burt, who has worked at BoS for 25 years, stopped that deal in its tracks, depriving David Prosser, the chief executive of L&G, the prospect of a much bigger job. While Mr Burt faces speculation about his future, friends say he is a resilient career banker who survived the debacle over the American evangelist Pat Robertson debacle last year. He relished the verbal jousts with Fred Goodwin, the Royal Bank of Scotland chief executive, and often referred to his rival as "Fred the Shred".

The 41-year-old accountant earned the title when he axed jobs and costs at Clydesdale Bank, and he will be doing that again at Royal-NatWest. He is due to become chief executive of Royal Bank at the start of next year when his mentor, Sir George Mathewson, steps up into the chairman's seat.

Sir George, made the plush Savoy Hotel on the Strand his home during this furious fight for NatWest. He spent the best part of four months there, chomping on his large cigar in the company of his expensive advisers from Goldman Sachs. When he joined Royal Bank of Scotland 10 years ago, one of his first acts was to make every one of the bank's employees reapply for their jobs. Seen as brash and arrogant, he had little choice but to charge into the fight for NatWest after his Mr Burt made the first move.

Sir George will enjoy his victory over Sir David Rowland (below), "gentleman" chairman and chief executive of NatWest, who might have put NatWest into its predicament when he misjudged the bank's reputation in the City after it tried to take over Legal & General. In defence against the Scots, Sir David wasted little time in fighting back, firing his chief executive, Derek Wanless, and bringing in close allies such as his right-hand man Ron Sandler. Sir David will be remembered as a man who put up a creditable fight when all seemed lost.

fields.headline: Corporate sloths on borrowed time
fields.standfirst: World markets
fields.trailText: So, farewell then NatWest. We shall miss the opportunities you gave us to marvel at your strategic blunders, to berate you for your profligacy, to splutter at your head office excess. You belonged to a bygone era whose passing is a reason for celebration for all those who cherish progress.
fields.body:
So, farewell then NatWest. We shall miss the opportunities you gave us to marvel at your strategic blunders, to berate you for your profligacy, to splutter at your head office excess. You belonged to a bygone era whose passing is a reason for celebration for all those who cherish progress.

After months of playground squabbling, NatWest's board of directors must now pull their white handkerchiefs from the depths of their pockets and wave them in capitulation to the Scottish bullies who, between them, have brought a generation of mismanagement to a close. The fight has been noisy but insubstantial - wholly appropriate, one might say.

Last week the board of Mannesmann, after an obdurate, spirited defence, managed to extract for its shareholders a substantial improvement in takeover terms from Vodafone. By contrast, NatWest shares have slid 27% from their high as shareholders juggled the offers from Bank of Scotland and Royal Bank of Scotland.

NatWest directors proved to have no rabbits in their hat. Their defence was a mirror of the predators' plans - in essence an appeal to investors to back incumbent management to deliver on an agenda of disposals and cost reductions.

It is no surprise that institutional investors were unprepared to allow an opportunity for management change to pass them by. Indeed one, PDFM, was reported to have switched its backing from the BoS bid to the RBoS bid because it did not want to run the risk of a stalemate leaving the incumbents in place against the majority wishes of shareholders.

There have been some complaints about the lack of beef in the offers made for NatWest by the Scottish banks. Their bids were primarily in paper rather than cash, and many arbitrageurs have no doubt been burned by the failure of a European bank to emerge prepared to pay hard cash to enter the British market.

Blame for this cannot lie with Royal Bank. Indeed it should be congratulated for toughing out this scrap with such parsimony. The blame must really lie with the NatWest board. It had every opportunity to seek out a European "white knight". One can only assume the directors either chose not to or tried to and failed. A poor show either way.

The challenges for the new owners of NatWest will be to bring focus to its portfolio of business assets, to wring efficiencies from core operations and to re-energise the brand image with retail customers. These requirements are not unique to NatWest - they apply to many of Britain's corporate giant sloths.

One such sloth achieved a small victory this week in facing down a potential predator. Marks and Spencer, the NatWest of the retail sector, saw its shares slump to a nine-year low as Philip Green backed away from a possible bid. Whether or not the publicity about share dealings in M&S by Mrs Green had anything to do with the decision, this was a defeat for focus, efficiency and brand energisation.

There can be no doubt that M&S shares are cheap. The problem is that cheap shares often get cheaper. Investors have lost faith in the management finding the necessary catalyst for change. There has been much talk of possible predators, but the drifting share price reveals a growing fear that nothing of substance will emerge.

Anyone doubting the latent value in M&S should weigh the group's market capitalisation against both revenues and a guesstimate of its sustainable customer base. In broad numbers Marks is capitalised at £7bn and has revenues of £8bn. Its customer base is anyone's guess - perhaps 15-20m in Britain. This stab at a customer base translates to spending per customer per annum in the range of £400 to £533, and a group valued at £350 to £466 per customer.

Contrast this with Lastminute.com, which this week announced flotation plans that could value the group at around £400m. It has a website that has struggled to accommodate 800,000 registered customers, many of whom might be assumed to be registering so as to punt the shares on flotation. Value per customer: £500. Revenue, needless to say, is thus far negligible.

Lastminute.com may prove a roaring success over the coming years. However, right now I'd rather have one M&S than 20 fledgling consumer internet ventures, many of whose products have yet to leave the drawing board. For every success there will be dozens of failures.

Final test: fire up your PC and try shopping online on the M&S website. You'll find it a good deal easier than on many of the one-man-and-a-dream sites. What price M&S as a store of brand value and a net stock rolled into one?

 Edmond Warner is the chief executive of Albert E Sharp Securities

Anyone doubting the latent value in M&S should weigh the group's market capitalisation against both revenues and a guesstimate of its sustainable customer base. In broad numbers Marks is capitalised at £7bn and has revenues of £8bn. Its customer base is anyone's guess - perhaps 15-20m in Britain. This stab at a customer base translates to spending per customer per annum in the range of £400 to £533, and a group valued at £350 to £466 per customer. Contrast this with Lastminute.com, which this week announced flotation plans that could value the group at around £400m. It has a website that has struggled to accommodate 800,000 registered customers, many of whom might be assumed to be registering so as to punt the shares on flotation. Value per customer: £500. Revenue, needless to say, is thus far negligible. Lastminute.com may prove a roaring success over the coming years. However, right now I'd rather have one M&S than 20 fledgling consumer internet ventures, many of whose products have yet to leave the drawing board. For every success there will be dozens of failures. Final test: fire up your PC and try shopping online on the M&S website. You'll find it a good deal easier than on many of the one-man-and-a-dream sites. What price M&S as a store of brand value and a net stock rolled into one?  Edmond Warner is the chief executive of Albert E Sharp Securities

fields.headline: Saving lives and loves
fields.standfirst: Pfizer
fields.trailText: Pfizer, founded by cousins Charles Pfizer and Charles Erhart, is better known now for selling the anti-impotence drug Viagra. But back in 1942, the firm made a breakthrough when it discovered how to mass produce penicillin.
fields.body:
When the Allied troops hurled themselves ashore on D-Day in 1944, almost all the life-saving penicillin wonder drug they carried was made by an American firm set up 100 years earlier by two German emigrants. Pfizer, founded by cousins Charles Pfizer and Charles Erhart, is better known now for selling the anti-impotence drug Viagra. But back in 1942, the firm made a breakthrough when it discovered how to mass produce penicillin. Until then, the anti-infection drug discovered by Alexander Fleming in 1928 had only been produced in very small quantities.

Pfizer had responded to the US government's 1941 appeal for a way to mass produce the drug. Jasper Kane, a Pfizer scientist, suggested using the techniques the company had developed to mass produce citric acid, its main product. The top management backed his idea. The company bought a disused ice-making plant and spent several million dollars equipping it. The technique worked.

Pfizer's founders had a fortuitous mix of talents. Charles Pfizer was a chemist who had learned his trade as an apothecary's apprentice. Charles Erhart was a confectioner who had been trained by his uncle. They set up their chemical business in Brooklyn in 1849. Its first product was santonin, a bitter treatment for parasitic worms.

The company's initial policy of making chemicals not produced in the US came unstuck when the first world war halted imports from Europe of citric acid. But Pfizer chemists developed a process for making citric acid from readily available sugar. By 1929 it had come up with a deep-tank fermentation process to make it from molasses - the very process it was to use later to mass produce penicillin.

All Pfizer's early products were sold by other companies under their own name. But this changed in 1950 when Pfizer launched the antibiotic Terramycin, its first branded drug. Terramycin, as the "terra" in its name implies, was discovered in earth. In the search for new anti-bacteria organisms, Pfizer scientists carried out about 20m tests on 135,000 soil samples from around the world. Terramycin was the result.

The same year Pfizer started an overseas expansion programme with a goal of international sales of $60m (£37.5m) a year. This was achieved within seven years. The firm matched its overseas growth with a huge research programme to produce a string of new products. It is now one of the top five suppliers of medicines to the national health service.

It spends $3.2bn a year on research and development, seeking new treatments for medical problems including arthritis, asthma, cancer, diabetes, migraine, obesity, osteoporosis, pain, and strokes. Four of its top 10 pharmaceutical products were discovered by scientists at its British research centre at Sandwich, Kent.

It employs about 7,500 researchers, many of whom will now be worried about their job prospects after Monday's announcement of Pfizer's $90bn takeover of fellow American pharmaceuticals company Warner-Lambert.

Probably the most widely talked about product to emerge from Pfizer's research labs is sildenafil citrate, more commonly known as Viagra. Demand for Viagra in the weeks after its launch set a record for a new drug in the United States.

Back in 1943 the US government dealt with record demand for penicillin by ruling that all production be devoted to the war effort. This posed a problem for Pfizer's chairman, John Smith, who had been asked to supply the drug to treat a dying girl at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital.

He bent the rules and supplied the hospital from the small amount the company was allowed to keep for research purposes. The girl recovered, unlike Mr Smith's own daughter who had died of infection before penicillin was available.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: France Telecom targets Orange
fields.body:
France Telecom targets Orange

France Telecom said it would join in the bidding for Orange, which Vodafone Airtouch must sell under the terms of its takeover of Mannesmann.

"We confirm declarations made yesterday to financial analysts by finance director Jean-Louis Vinciguerra," a France Telecom spokesman said.

Mr Vinciguerra had noted that the acquisition of Orange would complement France Telecom's investment in cable operator NTL.

Manufacturing recovery stalls

The recovery in manufacturing industry is showing signs of faltering, according to official figures published yesterday.

The office for national statistics reported that manufacturing output in December was down 0.3% on the previous month, while industrial production fell back 0.5%.

The falls follow six months of uninterrupted growth in manufacturing output.

Compared to a year ago, manufacturing was up 2.1% and total industrial production grew by 1.8% - considerably weaker than the City was expecting.

But the ONS also revised down estimates for month-on-month growth in November from 0.6% to 0.3% for manufacturing while overall production was flat compared to a previous estimate of 0.4% growth.

Clinton tackles hacker attacks

President Bill Clinton will meet next Tuesday with executives from some of America's largest internet companies to discuss ways of preventing hacker attacks against websites.

White House spokesman Joe Lockhart said the president called the meeting to "talk about what our overall long-term plan is and to work through whether we're doing everything we can now".

The move follows several attacks by hackers against popular websites this week that halted service at Yahoo, Buy.com, EBay, Amazon.com, and CNN.com.

The attacks are also being looked into by the FBI.

1,500 new rail cars ordered

A rail regulatory chief yesterday submitted his own order for new train carriages to speed up the replacement of old slam-door rolling stock.

Rail franchising director Mike Grant wants 1,500 new carriages to replace the slam-door trains, beginning with those run on the busy south-east England commuter routes operated by Connex South Central and South West Trains.

The unusual move is an attempt to put pressure on Connex and SWT to replace all their slam-door carriages, known as Mk 1 stock.

Kelda shuffles top positions

Kelda Group announced that John Napier will be succeeding Brandon Gough as non-executive chairman when he retires on March 31.

Also with effect from March 31, Jonson Cox will step down from his executive position as managing director of Yorkshire Water Services.

He will complete a period of handover and leave the group on July 31.

His replacement will be Kevin Whiteman, formerly of the environment agency and now a director of YWS and head of the waste water business unit.

fields.headline: Wassall succumbs to takeover
fields.trailText: Wassall, the lighting business unsuccessfully courted by Archie Norman's Knutsford bid vehicle earlier this year, has sold out to American takeover specialist, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, in a £627m deal announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Wassall, the lighting business unsuccessfully courted by Archie Norman's Knutsford bid vehicle earlier this year, has sold out to American takeover specialist, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, in a £627m deal announced yesterday.

KKR plans to merge Wassall's main operations with those of Zumtobel, a privately owned Austrian company, to create a lighting business capable of mounting a serious challenge to Philip's domination of the sector in Europe.

The combined business will have a turnover of about £1bn. KKR will end up with 34% of the enlarged group, with the Zumtobel family owning the rest of the shares. The combined business will have a turnover of about £1bn.

KKR made its name in the 1980s with a spectacular series of leveraged buyouts, including the then record-breaking $26bn hostile takeover of RJR Nabisco, the US tobacco and food group.

Johannes Huth, a managing director of KKR, said consolidation of the large but fragmented European light fittings market was long overdue.

The deal would create "a new group in the international lighting industry" and allow Thorn Lighting, Wassall's main subsidiary, and Zumtobel to build on their respective strengths, he said.

The Wassall board is recommending the agreed 400p-a-share cash offer from Wengen Acquisition, a bid vehicle set up by KKR, though it is advising shareholders not to accept an unsecured and unguaranteed loan note alternative, which would rank below Wengen's substantial borrowings.

fields.headline: Porsche chief attacks Rover aid
fields.trailText: Porsche chairman Wendelin Wiedeking yesterday fired another salvo in his company's protest campaign against British government aid for the Rover plant at Longbridge.
fields.body:
Porsche chairman Wendelin Wiedeking yesterday fired another salvo in his company's protest campaign against British government aid for the Rover plant at Longbridge.

Lawyers for the German sports car maker have already filed a complaint against the aid package under which the British government will contribute £150m to BMW's £1.7bn redevelopment of the Rover plant.

Mr Wiedeking told shareholders that state aid distorted market competition. "We have never received any form of aid in the past and therefore we feel we are clearly put at a disadvantage," he told the firm's annual meeting in Stuttgart.

Mr Wiedeking said the company expected to match last year's record breaking perfor mance which saw sales reach 6.18bn marks (£1.94bn) though analysts believe it could do even better, helped by strong demand from America.

"Porsche has a history of giving very conservative preliminary results so the likelihood is that the official first-half result will be higher," said Sabine Blumel at IMI in London.

Yesterday Porsche said that first-half sales rose 12.4% to 21,103 units and the group is expecting to sell a total of 46,000 cars in the financial year which ends on July 31.

Sales of the company's cheaper model, the Boxster, rose more than a quarter to 10,668, more than half the total, with the balance coming from the classic 911 model.

The group is spending around 1bn marks on the development of a sports utility vehicle, which it hopes will boost annual sales by a third.

fields.headline: Fears that customers will suffer
fields.trailText: Consumer groups have expressed fears that customer service will suffer as a result of the takeover, despite assurances from Royal Bank of Scotland that it will not close any NatWest branches and will retain its name.
fields.body:
Consumer groups have expressed fears that customer service will suffer as a result of the takeover, despite assurances from Royal Bank of Scotland that it will not close any NatWest branches and will retain its name.

Royal Bank of Scotland is stressing the business as usual message, but if thousands of jobs are cut, that inevitably means less staff serving the public, and the result will be longer queues in branches, said the National Association of Bank Customers. It also believes the deal could herald a long spell of disruption for customers as the two banking groups are slowly welded together.

"The Lloyds-TSB merger caused a great deal of aggravation," said NABC chief executive Stuart Cliffe. "The computer systems were not compatible. Also, people assumed they could go into a Lloyds branch to do TSB business and vice versa."

Mr Cliffe said it would be "unwise" for customers of either NatWest or Royal Bank of Scotland to assume they will almost immediately have access to a whole string of new bank branches. "It may take some months or even years before the organisations have properly merged into one."

From a consumer perspective, the combining of NatWest and Royal Bank of Scotland makes for an intriguing concoction. Royal Bank of Scotland has been a prime mover on the home banking front, and makes much of its technological innovations - it was the first high-street bank to offer internet banking, and its online service is one of the most sophisticated available. One of NatWest's big claims to fame, meanwhile, is that it is Britain's leading small business bank.

The deal could see the rapid building-up of NatWest's fledgling internet banking service, which was only launched in late November. However, one customer organisation said it was worried the deal could result in less competition in the small business banking sector. The Independent Banking Advisory Service said there were already relatively few banks that operate small business services, and NatWest and RBS merging would give the banks even greater control.

Meanwhile, many observers doubted whether the combined bank would be able to resist the cost savings of closing branches. "We are very suspicious of suggestions that they would not close branches. The NatWest record has been particularly bad, over 500 branches closed since 1996," said Derek French at the Campaign for Community Banking Services.

webTitle: Ice cream wars  Roddick fancies Ben & Jerry's

fields.headline: Ice cream wars  Roddick fancies Ben & Jerry's
fields.standfirst: Anita Roddick, founder and co-chairman of Body Shop has been linked to a potential $268m (£165m) takeover of American ice cream company Ben & Jerry's,  writes Julia Finch
fields.trailText: Speculation suggests that Mrs Roddick is working on plans with other investors for a $32-a-share offer.
fields.body:
Speculation suggests that Mrs Roddick is working on plans with other investors for a $32-a-share offer.

The ice cream company is a crusader for social change and environmental protection. It gives 7.5% of its profits to causes ranging from rainforest protection to childcare charities.

However, any socially-conscious bidding consortium will face competition from more traditional commercial operators who view Ben & Jerry's as a potential global brand. Yesterday Unilever, the food company whose brands include Wall's - and which was recently ordered by competition watchdogs to give its smaller rivals a fairer chance -admitted it was also interested in the Vermont-based company.

But Unilever denied a report in the New York Times that it was ready to bid some $40-a-share. "We are interested, certainly, but the financial details given in the New York Times article are false," a spokesman said.

Yesterday Body Shop refused to comment on whether the company's co-chairman was involved in the bid. Mrs Roddick was said to be abroad on business.

fields.headline: Axe over 21,000 jobs
fields.trailText: Another 21,000 banking jobs faced the axe last night after Lloyds TSB announced job cuts and Royal Bank of Scotland took over NatWest.
fields.body:
Another 21,000 banking jobs faced the axe last night after Lloyds TSB announced job cuts and Royal Bank of Scotland took over NatWest.

Lloyds TSB surprised Unifi, the finance union, with its announcement of 3,000 job cuts this year and branch closures in a new thrust for greater efficiency.

NatWest's surrender to the £21bn Royal Bank bid sets the scene for 18,000 job cuts, a fifth of their combined workforces.

The job cuts at Lloyds, which has not yet given the union a pledge of no compulsory redundancies, do not include any cuts which might result from completion of the takeover of Scottish Widows next month.

Peter Ellwood, chief executive of Lloyds TSB, said the job cuts were necessary as it continued to automate back office functions and shift "paper" transactions from branches to centralised centres.

Mr Ellwood admitted that customers appeared to be using the outlets more. "Some 70% of our customers use our branches once a month, a figure which has increased over the last 12 months."

The job cuts and branch closures will require Lloyds TSB to take a £200m charge this year. As a result of the merger between Lloyds and TSB, the combined bank still has 800 branches within half a mile of each other and Mr Ellwood stressed the bank still had 400 more branches than its closest rival.

fields.headline: Takeover speculation surrounds Liberty
fields.trailText: Regent Street's Liberty department store could be about to change hands, more than a century after it first opened its doors for business.
fields.body:
Regent Street's Liberty department store could be about to change hands, more than a century after it first opened its doors for business.

The shop, which specialises in fashion and homewares confirmed in a statement to the stock exchange yesterday that it had "received approaches leading to very preliminary discussions but has not received any firm proposals".

The company said the approaches "may or may not lead to an offer being made for the whole of the issued share capital of Liberty".

Liberty's statement was prompted by a sharp rise in the group's share price. At the turn of this year they were changing hands at around 150p, but in recent days they have shot up to 217p. At yesterday's close they were up 12p at 230p, valuing the company at £52m.

Last night a company official said: "These really are extremely preliminary discussions".

She refused to say whether the approach had been made by a British or overseas organisation and analysts were at a loss to suggest possible suitors.

In addition to its flagship Regent Street store in London, the Liberty group includes a concession at Heathrow, a store in Windsor and a Japanese wholesale business.

The store is still 20% owned by the founding Stewart-Liberty family, which three years ago joined another major investor to oust the store's then chairman, Denis Cassidy, who had planned a £40m expansion of the store. But the new management - led by chairman Philip Bowman and new managing director Michele Jobling - swiftly axed the plan.

But the store has since been dogged by tough trading conditions. Last September it an nounced flat like-for-like sales at its Regent Street store for the half-year, as competition on the high street took its toll. In the six months to last August the store made a loss of £893,000, although that was an improvement on the £1.7m dive into the red a year earlier.

Mr Bowman - who has since also taken over as chief executive of drinks group Allied Domecq - and Ms Jobling are leading the Liberty takeover discussions.

fields.headline: Li crashes telecoms party
fields.standfirst: Entrepreneur's overtures disrupt C&W's planned exit from Hong Kong
fields.trailText: Entrepreneur Richard Li yesterday threatened to disrupt the proposed telecoms merger of Cable & Wireless's 54%-owned Hong Kong operations with SingTel.
fields.body:
Entrepreneur Richard Li yesterday threatened to disrupt the proposed telecoms merger of Cable & Wireless's 54%-owned Hong Kong operations with SingTel.

Mr Li announced that his $30bn (£19bn) Pacific Century CyberWorks, the 10-month-old technology arm of Pacific Century Group, "intends to propose a merger with Cable & Wireless HKT".

C&W shares rose 64p to £13.58 yesterday. Last month, C&W announced plans to merge its Hong Kong business with SingTel, 80% owned by the Singapore government, potentially creating a £37bn group.

That was considered to be the start of C&W's exit strategy from the Hong Kong operation which no longer fits with its target of a global data network.

Richard Li is chairman of PCCW - 60%-owned by Mr Li's main investment vehicle, Pacific Century Regional Developments. He established that company in 1993 after selling Star TV, then valued at $950.5m, to News Corp. Mr Li is the son of the Hong Kong businessman Li Ka-shing.

PCCW is an investment vehicle in Asia for digital and internet technology and has a market capitalisation of about $29bn on the Hong Kong market. A merger with HKT would give it a digital broadband net work in Hong Kong and access to half a million local internet subscribers - and cashflow.

It was unclear yesterday whether PCCW would be part of a wider consortium courting HKT which could include Vodafone and Hutchison Whampoa, the latter controlled by Li Ka-shing.

A wealthy partner such as Hutchison Whampoa would give C&W a more tempting mix of cash and shares. Vodafone declined to comment.

Peter Allen, chief financial officer and director of Pacific Century, said: "Whilst it is too early to determine whether any proposal will be formulated for presentation to the board of HKT, PCCW has retained the investment bank Warburg Dillon Read and Bank of China International to assist in assessing all alternatives including possible investment in HKT."

The view of the Chinese authorities might also shape the outcome, analysts said, because the government is likely to favour a local buyer.

"From HKT's point of view a home turf deal is probably better for its chances of getting into China," said Tressan MacCarthy, analyst at Credit Lyonnais Securities in London.

However, some analysts suggested PCCW might take only a small stake in the company to gain access to a sales outlet for its broadband internet service.

C&W yesterday maintained its talks with SingTel were "constructive" and continuing. Observers had expected a deal to be concluded by the end of March. SingTel agreed that talks were ongoing but declined to comment further.

A Credit Lyonnais Asia report this week said Chris Gent, Vodafone's chief executive, would be talking to Li Ka-Shing about setting up a venture in China.

fields.headline: Lord Kitchener
fields.standfirst: Master of Trinidadian music who introduced the calypso to Britain
fields.trailText: The arrival, in 1948 at Tilbury docks, of "Lord Kitchener", who has died aged 77, is preserved on film. He had his guitar with him, and Kitchener, one of the great calypsonians - and the trailblazer responsible for the growth of Trinidadian music's popularity in Britain - appears as one of those dignified representatives of first-generation Caribbean immigrants. He was exotic, immaculately dressed and, as is the calypsonian's wont, ready with a line in topical verse.
fields.body:
The arrival, in 1948 at Tilbury docks, of "Lord Kitchener", who has died aged 77, is preserved on film. He had his guitar with him, and Kitchener, one of the great calypsonians - and the trailblazer responsible for the growth of Trinidadian music's popularity in Britain - appears as one of those dignified representatives of first-generation Caribbean immigrants. He was exotic, immaculately dressed and, as is the calypsonian's wont, ready with a line in topical verse.

Kitchener arrived on the Empire Windrush, the vessel that brought the first substantial group of postwar West Indian immigrants to Britain. He was one of the few Trinidadians on the ship - the majority were Jamaican - and he stayed for 14 years.

In 1951 he was on film again, leading the pitch invasion at Lords which followed the West Indies cricket team's first victory over England. By then, he was a chronicler of the Caribbean experience in Britain. There were calypsos like I Can't Stand The Cold In Winter, If You're Brown, My Landlady, and, more positively, London Is The Place For Me.

Calypso was shaped in Trinidad, where its blend of Latin American and African rhythms has long been a hugely popular vehicle for social and political commentary, witty insult, sexual innuendo and - as "the people's newspaper" - a way of analysing topical events.

Kitchener's first weeks in England were spent singing to bemused audiences in pubs, but within six months he had broken into the London nightclub circuit with his own band. The key to his success was an ability to reach beyond the Caribbean diaspora - indeed, Princess Margaret reputedly bought 100 copies of his Ah Bernice to send to friends.

With his earnings, he opened his own club in Manchester in 1958. But he retained his links with home. Throughout his stay, he sent songs back to Trinidad for its annual carnival; and, in London, he was part of the milieu which gave birth to the Notting Hill carnival in the late 1960s. By the time he moved back to Trinidad in late 1962 - after that country's independence - he had become a revered link with the prewar calypsonian tradition. He took his homeland by storm.

Aldwyn Roberts had taken the stage name "Kitchener" as a teenager. Born in Arima, he had resolved that, despite a lifelong stammer, he was going to make his fortune as a calypso singer. "Lord" was a title awarded by his fans.

Back home after England, he won Trinidad's road march title - awarded to the singer whose calypso is most played on the streets at each year's carnival - a staggering 10 times between 1963 and 1976, more than anyone else ever achieved. Crowned "Road March King of the World", he dominated the carnival: "Somebody going to frighten bad/ Because Kitchener come back to Trinidad." Thus wrote Tiny Terror in his Tribute To Kitchener calypso.

Mighty Sparrow was his only rival. In 1975, after Kitch won the carnival's annual calypso monarch competition, he and Sparrow retired from the event to open the field for other contenders.

Kitch recorded up to his death, performing with a vitality that put younger calypsonians to shame. He ran his own calypso tent for more than 30 years in Port of Spain, nurturing talent such as David Rudder and Black Stalin. He also composed for steel bands, having loved the steel pan since its emergence in the 1940s.

His style, concentrating on humour, double entendre and the quirks of everyday life, was sometimes criticised for its frivolity. But he did contribute to calypso's tradition of political commentary - speaking out against the government when other calypsonians kept quiet during Trinidad's 1970 black-power revolution. He supported pan-Africanism with his song Africa My Home (1957), and some of his early songs, including Yankee Sufferers (1945), were banned by the British colonial authorities.

Twice married, Kitch only left Trinidad for occasional tours in later life, cultivating a lifestyle that fitted his essential shyness. The people of Trinidad loved him. Latterly, his face appeared on a postage stamp, and there is a statue of him outside Port of Spain. He turned down a Chaconia medal, insulted that he was not thought worthy of Trinidad's highest honour, the Trinity Cross.

Kitch proclaimed himself the "grandmaster of calypso". He was.

webTitle: Lacey's guide to the men who matter

fields.headline: Lacey's guide to the men who matter
fields.trailText: Three to shine
fields.body:
Three to shine

Sol Campbell Tottenham Hotspur
Always important at the back, Campbell's presence will now be even more important given Tony Adams's injury problems. His pace, judgment and the timing of his tackles are among England's strongest assets. If only his passing would improve. Then comparisons with Marcel Desailly might not seem so far-fetched.

David Beckham Manchester United
Still the one attacking player approaching genuine world class available to Kevin Keegan, who will be tempted to use him in a central role if no one else emerges to claim the position in midfield. Yet Beckham's biggest strength is the consistent accuracy of his centres,which might become diluted if he had to play other than wide.

Paul Scholes Manchester United
An established match-winner, he will surely be increasingly important to England, especially if Alan Shearer goes broody again. Against tight-marking defences his ability to find scoring positions with well-timed runs from midfield could mean the difference between success and failure.

Three to emerge

Joe Cole West Ham United
The most exciting prospect England have had in midfield since Paul Gascoigne. At 18 he ought to see the 2002 World Cup qualifiers as his best chance of gaining a regular place. But Kevin Keegan is so short of players who can keep possession and pass the ball imaginatively that he will surely give Cole his chance in the warm-ups.

Steven Gerrard Liverpool
The consistency with which the 19-year-old has been bringing the ball out of defence and using it intelligently should give him a chance of making England's squad. Certainly, if Keegan is looking beyond the summer to the sort of team he wants for the next World Cup, young players of this quality should be given tournament experience.

Frank Lampard West Ham United
Jamie Redknapp's injury problems alone ought to have enhanced Lampard's chances of going to Euro 2000. Keegan is not so well off for creative talent that he can ignore a player who can start and finish with such aplomb. He is one of those players who needs a run in an England side; surely Keegan will at least offer him a jog.

Three to fade

David Seaman Arsenal
He may prove the doubters wrong and is still capable of making outstanding saves but recently he has looked heavy-legged and flat-footed. On occasions he has not stayed on his feet as he once would have done and England goalkeepers who forget to keep their legs together, as Seaman did at Bradford last weekend, can be a burden.

Paul Ince Middlesbrough
The Guv'nor made it back to the England side when Kevin Keegan began to run out of options in midfield but he is clearly no longer the Ince who helped to inspire Glenn Hoddle's team in the qualifiers for the last World Cup, most notably in Chorzow and Rome. Too much of the football in Euro 2000 might pass him by.

Alan Shearer Newcastle United
Of course Shearer will be in Kevin Keegan's squad for the European Championship and England captain to boot. But Keegan has already made it clear that he will not hesitate to drop him if he feels that the player can no longer perform effectively at this level, and he may use the warm-ups to experiment with alternative strikers.

The finals countdown

fields.headline: Wrong number
fields.standfirst: The Readers' Editor on... things that don't add up
fields.trailText: The Readers' Editor on... things that don't add up
fields.body:
Icalled the doctor in this week. Well, not actually the doctor, but a professor of journalism who includes in his courses classes in remedial maths for journalists. I passed him the file containing all the case notes in the form of the many letters of complaint you have written about our wayward way with figures. "Tell me," I asked anxiously, "is it innumeracy?"

Innumeracy would, perhaps, be a bit strong. To be innumerate, according to Collins, is to have neither knowledge nor understanding of mathematics or science. Things are not quite that bad. However, you do not have to have been reading a newspaper, any newspaper, over a very long period to detect a certain unease with figures. We mix metric and imperial, we have lots of trouble with square and cubic measures, we sometimes distort our graphs by scaling them at irregular intervals, we score quite poorly in calculating percentages, we do almost everything you should not do, except perhaps - or only very rarely - succumb to the silliest journalistic naivety, that big numbers are preferable to little ones.

This has its most distasteful expression in the tendency to compete in casualty figures after a disaster, something that we deliberately try to ensure we do not do. Its more common and, can I suggest, its most idiotic expression is in the totting up of prison sentences, as in "the defendants were jailed for a total of 100 years". This figure is quite meaningless, although an attempt to justify it might be made by contending that it was a flag to attract our attention to something significantly out of the ordinary (which it rarely proves to be).

I can only think of one example of this kind of totting up that seemed to have some purpose, and that was not in a newspaper but in Brecht's Threepenny Novel where he is talking about the forlorn experience of dealing with two bankers: "Together they were more than 150 years old, and when one had to deal with them one had to deal with one and a half centuries."

Let me give a few examples of the things that we do do, before we see what the doctor has to say.

In a front page story a few months ago we offered the following calculation: "It would take 12 working years to view each of the 56,000 pictures at the rate of one a minute." A reader writes, "56,000 minutes is, to the nearest hour, 933. Divided by 12 this gives, to the nearest whole number, 78." Who, he wondered, was working a 78-hour year?

Statistics are a danger area. Recently we said, "In 1900 the standard rate of income tax was 8 old pence in the pound (2%)." Several readers were quickly on the phone to say that there were 240 (old) pence in the pound and therefore the rate should have been 3.333% and not 2%.

When we said that the lift in the Empire State building fell 400 feet in four seconds we had a flurry of calls saying, "Come off it." Here is one that I will quote in full since it ends with a very pertinent point: "Is it really too much to hope that when you deal with matters of science or engineering, a little care be taken? It is simply not possible for a lift to fall 400 feet in four seconds, at least on earth. The acceleration due to gravity is 32 feet per second per second: a free falling object will travel a distance of 256 feet in four seconds. Friction and air resistance will reduce this figure in real life. You would not," he charitably suggests, "attribute Hamlet to Molière or Gordon Brown to the Conservative party: why do you tolerate equivalent ignorance in the numeric arts?"

It is time to return to the doctor: "I think it is a cultural problem, not just confined to journalists. It's acceptable to say - in fact you can say it almost with pride - that you are no good at figures. I do a little test with the post-graduate journalism students. I give them a text with all sorts of spelling and grammatical errors and some outrageous statement such as the population of China is, say, 100 billion. They pick up the language errors but very rarely spot the mistakes in figures."

Readers go mad when we seem blind to the beauties of precision. "Surely 1cm is almost 0.4 inches rather than 0.3? It is 0.3937 to be precise." We tend to get confused when calculating the time it takes to microwave a potato; we happily mix imperial and metric measurements when calculating the length of a dinosaur's cervical vertebrae (3.94 feet), suggesting something, one reader protested, that was neither fish nor fowl; and we bring the horizon deceptively nearer when converting from miles to kilometres (making 20 miles 12km instead of 32km).

These are not symptoms of an incurable condition, the doctor says. He and another professor of journalism from whom I sought a second opinion are both prepared to help out with remedial action. We may take them up on it. We do not want to be numbered among those we called, in a felicitous error a little while ago, the "unrenumerated".

webTitle: Dalglish walks into the seething dens

fields.headline: Dalglish walks into the seething dens
fields.standfirst: The reluctant Celtic coach has to go back on trial in Dundee
fields.trailText: Kenny Dalglish must take Celtic to Dundee today and Dens Park is precisely the kind of place that managers do not like to visit. The configuration of the ground means he will have to walk 50 yards from the tunnel to the dug-out and fans can say a lot of harsh things during that time.
fields.body:
Kenny Dalglish must take Celtic to Dundee today and Dens Park is precisely the kind of place that managers do not like to visit. The configuration of the ground means he will have to walk 50 yards from the tunnel to the dug-out and fans can say a lot of harsh things during that time.

Nobody knows what reception he will receive at the end of a traumatic eight days in which Celtic have lost a league game, a Scottish Cup tie and a manager. At best it is likely to be cool but friendly; at worst he might receive what is called in these parts a sherraking.

This most singular of men yesterday continued to give out conflicting messages, while the fans remain undecided whether his switch from an office chair back to the training ground is good news. Such is the complexity of the man that he will not inspire the idolatry usually reserved for someone of his status.

Dalglish held his first press conference yesterday, but he would only tell people what they needed to know and there were to be no questions. His version of events at Celtic was revealing though.

He is still patently furious at the players he considers cost his pal John Barnes the job and he is going to spend not one minute longer in the managerial tracksuit than he needs. It all hardly amounted to a stirring call to arms.

The business of exactly what happened at half-time during the Cup defeat by Inverness Caledonian Thistle still remains a mystery. Mark Viduka clashed with the assistant manager Eric Black and objects were hurled about. At the same time the goalkeeper Jonathan Gould and Eyal Berkovic were not exactly seeing eye to eye.

"I wasn't there so I can't say," Dalglish said, "but if I had been I wouldn't have sent out Viduka for the second half, which was the decision John made. He was not in the right frame of mind. I'm drawing a line under that.

"Jonathan and Eyal have kissed and made friends. These things happen in dressing rooms but at Celtic we always seem to have a problem keeping things like this in house. I know you lads have a job to do, but it's my job to make sure it doesn't get out." Gould, however, is dropped for today's game.

Dalglish was quite specific that he was not going to be a long-term manager. "I was in La Manga where six teams were playing 10 matches [in the Nordic Cup] and the club needed to look at players. That is a job that now needs filling but I would go back there myself if I needed to.

"Who comes in will be decided by the quality of people who are available and there is no timescale," he added, leaving the impression that if a suitable manager appeared on Monday, it would not be a day too soon.

He has pulled in Marc Rieper, the Dane so injured that retirement is imminent, to help with the coaching and is looking for a new chief scout.

The problem is that Barnes came to Celtic at the wish of Dalglish and some supporters believe that the captain should go down with the ship. Events suggest that Celtic might have plotted their way out of one crisis but have done little to instil confidence that a fresh disaster is not on the horizon.
