webTitle: A dark voice of the soul

fields.headline: A dark voice of the soul
fields.standfirst: Hvorostovsky/Arkadiev, Barbican Hall, London *****
fields.trailText: Hvorostovsky/Arkadiev Barbican Hall, London *****
fields.body:
Dmitri Hvorostovsky has a polished stage presence - almost too much so. Though by his own admission he's a nervous performer, he doesn't so much give to the audience as assume that they will take whatever he offers. But behind the "because I'm worth it" looks there's a true musician with a remarkable voice, and to hear a really fine Russian singer perform Russian music is something special. Hvorostovsky has a seemingly bottomless depth of tone and he glides up and down his extensive range betraying no weak points of technique. Though in this challenging recital we had to wait until the very end to hear him at his magical best, there was plenty to intrigue the audience along the way.

Three songs by Glinka, regarded as the father of Russian composition, made an interesting start. Doubt, a setting of a poem by Kukolnik, found Hvorostovsky on expressive, lyrical form, though the atmosphere was jolted a little by his too-audible gasps for breath.

After the hailstorm of consonants that was Glinka's Travelling Song, Mahler's Kindertotenlieder called for a swift change of mood. Hvorostovsky put some new colours onto his palette, opening the cycle with a flatter, resigned tone and moving to a barely-there, floated sound for the close. These songs are usually heard with orchestra, and the sparser sound of the solo piano highlighted the mournful, slender counterpoint. Mikhail Arkadiev, the accompanist, couldn't quite get around the piano fast enough to come near reproducing the orchestral depiction of a storm in the final song, but the eerie music-box accompaniment in the last verse was haunting.

Shostakovich's Suite on Verses of Michelangelo, written 25 years ago in the composer's penultimate year, comes from the same dark world. This is an intensely moving work, and Hvorostovsky will do it full justice when he no longer needs to read it from a music stand. His communication with the audience lost its edge because of this obstacle, leaving room for Arkadiev to come into his own, thundering, hanging back, holding tension and, at times, violently reminding the audience that the piano is indeed a percussion instrument. The tick-tock of chords that closed the final song, Immortality, was followed by the first real silence of the evening from a previously restless audience.

The lengthy applause that broke it brought Hvorostovsky back to more familiar territory, in true performing mode. His encores were both by Tchaikovsky - the wistful In the Din of the Ball followed by a real treat, Yeletsky's aria from Queen of Spades, sung as lovingly and sincerely as it should be, sending the audience home on air.

webTitle: All the best deals have been snapped up

fields.headline: All the best deals have been snapped up
fields.trailText: Thinking of bagging thousands of pounds in windfalls from a demutualising life office? Think again - the juiciest opportunities have already passed you by. That's the advice from Chartwell Investment Management, which says it has stopped publishing its Carpetbagger's Guide to Life Companies because there are so few tempting companies left.
fields.body:
Thinking of bagging thousands of pounds in windfalls from a demutualising life office? Think again - the juiciest opportunities have already passed you by. That's the advice from Chartwell Investment Management, which says it has stopped publishing its Carpetbagger's Guide to Life Companies because there are so few tempting companies left.

Norwich Union, Scottish Amicable and Scottish Widows have already demutualised, while Standard Life has closed its doors to new members, although it continues to sell policies. Getting into the remaining smaller life offices has also become tougher, as most have raised the minimum investment on policies which give you membership.

Membership of the with-profits fund is the key, as they are the owners of the life office. For example, anyone who has a unit trust will not qualify for a windfall, as they are not invested in the with-profits fund. This leaves with-profits savings schemes - the much maligned endowment policies - and with-profit bonds as the cheapest route in.

Friends Provident's minimum is £35 on monthly savings or £3,000 as a lump sum in its with profits bond. MGM Assurance has raised its minimum savings to £75 from £25 per month, while its bond minimum is £5,000. Both Scottish Provident and Scottish Life offered £10 per month savings scheme, but these are now £50 per month, and Scottish Provident requires a minimum term of 16 years.

Chartwell director Patrick Connolly says: "You have to ask if it is an efficient and cost-effective thing to do. On a 10-year policy it's £6,000 in savings on what are high-charging products, and you may only get a £500 windfall. And if you quit the policy early, the returns are very poor."

fields.headline: Sixty seconds in: Ergonomics
fields.standfirst: Chris Reeves, an interaction designer with Philips Design in Le Mans talks to Miles Brignall
fields.trailText: The exciting thing about mobile phones is that the technology is developing so fast. My job is to make sure that however advanced it gets, it's still easy to use. The time it takes to get a mobile phone designed and built is falling all the time and the pressure is on the big companies to get the next generation of phones on to the market.
fields.body:
The exciting thing about mobile phones is that the technology is developing so fast. My job is to make sure that however advanced it gets, it's still easy to use. The time it takes to get a mobile phone designed and built is falling all the time and the pressure is on the big companies to get the next generation of phones on to the market.

In general, ergonomics is the study of how man fits into his environment. For me, that means making sure the phone will make sense to its target audience.

At Philips, every potential phone user fits into one of five categories depending on age, income etc and that will determine what they want out of the phone. A business user will more likely be looking for a large, easily accessed database of numbers, while teenagers are looking to send text messages or receive e-mail.

The interactive department gets involved in the design process at quite an early stage. Once the target audience is identified and the phone's basic functions selected, we take it away to a workshop and brainstorm ideas to decide how it will work. The sorts of things we are designing include displays, both text and graphics, the look and feel of it - everything right down to way it rings. When we've narrowed it down we produce storyboards for the project leader. From there more detailed images of how it will look start to appear on computer screens or as models, and we produce an official document defining the technical specification of the phone.

Once a prototype is produced, the testing starts. Often we trial the phone internally - and then on to the general public. Typically we'll give an overview of how it works and then ask them to perform some tasks and examine with what degree of ease they manage it.

After a lot of testing, we know whether we've got it right and if its easy to use. If it's not as clear as it should be, we change it. If it needs a major re-working we have to go back to the project leader and explain why. All the way through we are signing-off each stage of development.

Working in France has been a culture shock. Although our staff from all over the world are expected to speak English, I'm having French lessons. The other surprise is the meetings which are far more heated than I've experienced.

After a degree in behavioural science and a MSc in ergonomics, I joined the RNIB where I worked on making products more accessible to the visually impaired. One of the things I want to do while I'm here is a to help design a phone for the blind. Philips is at the forefront of voice activated technology, so I may yet get my chance.

webTitle: Employment expert to rule on interest rates

fields.headline: Employment expert to rule on interest rates
fields.standfirst: Buiter to be replaced at monetary policy committee
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's desire to keep Britain's jobless rate on a downward trend was highlighted yesterday when he chose one of the country's leading labour market experts to join the Bank of England's interest-rate setting body.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's desire to keep Britain's jobless rate on a downward trend was highlighted yesterday when he chose one of the country's leading labour market experts to join the Bank of England's interest-rate setting body.

With the number of people out of work and claiming benefit set to tumble below the 1m mark over the next year, the chancellor announced that Professor Steve Nickell was moving onto the bank's nine-strong monetary policy committee.

Prof Nickell, co-author of one of the key textbooks on the link between inflation and unemployment, has been hand-picked to advise on how low the jobless rate can go without stoking up price pressure in the economy.

He will replace the Dutch Professor Willem Buiter on the MPC.

Prof Buiter, one of the four external members of the committee, is stepping down at the end of his three-year term to become chief economist at the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

In a letter to the chancellor, he said the independence of external members was best preserved by serving no more than one term.

"Having reached the conclusion that, as a matter of principle, external members should be appointed for a single term only, I cannot in good faith claim special circumstances for myself," said Prof Buiter, describing his time on the MPC as the high point of his professional career.

Prof Nickell, 55, has a chair at the London School of Economics, which he will retain. He will work at the bank four days a week, taking a pro-rata share of the £128,000 a year salary. He is a colleague of Richard Layard, academic mastermind of the new deal, the government's policy for getting young people off welfare and into work. He is also associated with the concept of the Nairu - the non-accelerating rate of unemployment - which contends that there are limits to which you can use monetary and fiscal policy to stimulate demand without igniting inflation.

With inflation remaining subdued despite rapidly falling unemployment, Prof Nickell's insights into the workings of the labour market will be particularly valuable, said observers.

Nickell's other areas of interest include productivity growth and competition, both preoccupations of the chancellor.

Prof Buiter has been a colourful member of the committee, noted for his sense of humour, quick temper and activist approach which has seen him vote for a rate rise one month and for a cut the next.

The three-year term of Charles Goodhart, 63, a colleague of Prof Nickell's at the LSE, also ends in May but the treasury refused to discuss whether he would be reappointed.

fields.headline: Houses and feelings
fields.standfirst: Home, Tron Theatre, Glasgow ***
fields.trailText: Home, Tron Theatre, Glasgow ***
fields.body:
"Being at home is also about being not at home," one of the four women in Nicola McCartney's new play notes. And so it is in this dark, tangled vision of life in the family homestead: claustrophobic as soon as you step in the door, even if it has been years; stifling, dusty and instantly familiar.

Like a matriarchal update of Pinter's The Homecoming, this one-act play has a similar structure and nearly as dark a mood. Jen (Gillian Kerr), a successful Edinburgh lawyer with the chance of a job abroad, comes to visit her mother and sister. What she finds is bleak dysfunction: an alcoholic mother, walking with a stick after her "accident" and stuck in a fantasy world of country songs and sad lyrics of broken lives; and her sister, the bird-like Jo (Kate Dickie), an Asperger's Syndrome sufferer almost entirely removed from social interaction. Jo is obsessed with time and routine, and can't cope with questions. Providing a rather heavy-handed symbol for what is wrong with all these women's lives, she is initially the play's tragic figure but by the end brings its only note of optimism.

On narrative, character and emotional truth, McCartney is a true talent, especially in the way she draws the two older women, Annie and her sister Kath. Mary McCusker and Hope Ross's performances in these roles are just the right blend of self-knowledge and delusion. McCartney has a deft touch too in portraying the deeper, darker side of family life; the layers of resentment and disappointment waiting to spill out across the generations.

The set, designed by Minty Donald, underlines this sense of a flood of emotional bile bubbling under the surface. It's like a scene from the children's programme, Haunted House: a dusty corner of a neglected pile, a house but emphatically not a home.

The play is less successful in its attempts to portray what the women are going through psychologically. Sometimes they speak individually in staccato fragments ("just-enough-room-to-move-my-arms"), at other times they talk in a round, building a sentence between them. This device drags the play away from its strong and convincing emotional core and feels forced, pretentious. "Wave wave wave waves," Jo says twice. The play already has currents and characters overwhelming enough to sweep us away; such linguistic play feels as out of place as the four women do in their home.

Touring Scotland until 5 March

fields.headline: Standard Life faces conversion threat
fields.standfirst: The largest mutual society in Europe is under siege from a Monaco-based investor: Patrick Sherwen reports
fields.trailText: Carpetbaggers are all a-quiver this week after a hitherto unknown Monaco-based investor took on the ultimate bagging challenge and launched an attack against the largest mutual society in Europe - Standard Life.
fields.body:
Carpetbaggers are all a-quiver this week after a hitherto unknown Monaco-based investor took on the ultimate bagging challenge and launched an attack against the largest mutual society in Europe - Standard Life.

If his proposal to convert is successful, Fred Woollard stands to benefit from windfall payouts worth tens of thousands of pounds. The company's 2.5m existing with-profits policy holders could make an average £6,300 each and the firm's 11,000 employees could find an extra £20,000 in their paypackets.

All this depends on whether Mr Woollard's estimate that Standard Life would be worth £12-15bn on the stockmarket is correct. Standard Life will not comment on the figures. Gordon Arthur, a spokesman, says: "We have no idea. We don't do the numbers because we are committed to our mutual status." And so, he says, are Standard Life's employees to whom Mr Woollard has thrown a rather juicy bone in the promise that if they were among the voters for a successful conversion, 1.5% of any free shares would go in their direction.

Mr Arthur admits this is a tempting offer but says that in a recent review Standard Life's employees were staunchly in favour of remaining mutual. Mr Woollard "is putting forward some populist proposals and let's not forget why he's doing that - because he's going to make a lot of money out of this", says Mr Arthur.

Mr Woollard, a former fund manager for a wealthy Aus tralian family, says: "I would have made more money if I'd stayed a fund manager, but then I wouldn't be doing something I believe in and I wouldn't be doing something that was so much fun.

"Giving something to employees is not simply a charitable gesture. We're approaching this from the point of view of owners. I believe it's good for us, as future shareholders, to have considerable employee share ownership."

Also likely to gain if Standard Life converts are the more than 7,000 shareholders of Dresdner RCM's four endowment investment trusts. Between them these trusts own more of Standard Life's policies than any other single investor with 20% of the trusts invested in the life office. This means they are not only potentially the biggest beneficiaries but also the most powerful voters if the resolutions are found to be legally valid.

Mr Woollard says he is confident that Standard Life's lawyers will not be able to find fault with the resolutions since his own lawyers have already gone over them in detail. The full details of the resolutions are available at www.slmag.com, the website of the Standard Life Members Action Group, as Mr Woollard calls his organisation.

The resolutions state: "That this meeting calls on the directors of the company to take steps to convert to PLC status, and to distribute free shares to participating policy holders and employees on the following basis: firstly, the company shall distribute up to 1% of the free shares to The Standard Life Anniversary Appeal." This deals with the distribution of a portion of the shares to a charitable organisation set up by Standard Life to support various health related causes including Great Ormond Street, Guide Dogs for the Blind and Imperial Cancer Research. "Secondly, the Company shall distribute up to 1.5% of the free shares to employees of the Standard Life group of companies, the basis of distribution to be decided by the directors." This section is explained above.

The final section deals with the payouts to policyholders: "Thirdly, each participating policyholder (regardless of the number, size or type of participating policies held) shall receive free shares worth (in the opinion of the directors) approximately £500; fourthly, the company shall distribute the balance of the free shares to participating policy holders in proportion to the asset share of the policy or policies held by each participating policy holder; and the directors shall determine all other aspects of the demutualisation including the cut off date for qualification to participate in the distribution."

But the argument remains as to whether demutualisation is in the best long term interests of the company and its owners, the policy holders.

Mr Arthur says that the only reason to convert is to get access to more capital with which to expand the business. This is not necessary, he reasons, since the company already has more than enough to grow the business organically and spurns the notion that to acquire is to improve.

"If we have all the capital we need to grow the business the way we want to grow it, we know our policyholders will be better off if we remain mutual," says Mr Arthur.

Mr Woollard concedes that Standard Life needs no new capital and says the benefits of conversion lie in the increased accountability that a public listing would bring and the payouts to policyholders.

webTitle: Turning the screw on house buyers

fields.headline: Turning the screw on house buyers
fields.standfirst: The base rate rise has yet to filter through to borrowers and savers but is likely to impact adversely on both. Tony Levene explains
fields.trailText: The Bank of England's quarter of a point increase on its base rate - the fourth interest rise in six months - obviously means more of the same for homebuyers, a drip-drip torture that puts extra pressure on the monthly mortgage bill.
fields.body:
The Bank of England's quarter of a point increase on its base rate - the fourth interest rise in six months - obviously means more of the same for homebuyers, a drip-drip torture that puts extra pressure on the monthly mortgage bill.

Although most home loan companies have yet to announce their rises, it is clear that variable rate loans are virtually sure to go up. Those with tracker mortgages, such as Virgin customers, will see rates jump automatically.

Increases will bite immediately for new borrowers and take effect from March 1 for existing home loan customers.

And whatever the Bank of England's next move, all mortgages, including the 30% of home loan customers with fixed or capped loans, will rise in April when the tax rebate Miras - Mortgage Interest Relief at Source - finally moves into history. The Miras loss varies between around £15 and £20 depending on the interest level of the individual mortgage. A £100,000 interest-only borrower is likely to be paying nearly £100 a month more by April after the Miras loss if this week's rate is passed on in to borrowers in full.

And the current rate rise may not be the last. Ray Boulger of mortgage brokers John Charcol warns: "The Bank of England is looking to control the housing market and inflation. But rates are going to have to rise significantly to have the desired impact."

Higher interest rates should mean that the other side of the equation, the savers, should rejoice. There are typically seven savings accounts for each home loan. But the reality is that savers are likely to emerge with as nearly as much misery as borrowers. On previous experence, they will have to wait longer before they are told what increases will emerge on their accounts. One of the few banks to raise rates to savers is Investec, which increased its Base Plus tracker account by 0.25% to 6.75%. But savers need £2,001 to access this.

And when other savers find out their new rates, they will almost certainly be unhappy. For the banks and building societies have managed for some time to disappoint all their customers by squeezing their borrowers at one end and their savers at the other.

Analysts say it is all in the name of building up margins, perhaps to give existing players a layer of profit fat to protect them against new net-based banking players.

Whatever the reason, customers of demutualised banks such as Abbey National, Halifax, Northern Rock and Woolwich who have held on to their free shares are probably not happy either. This week these stocks hit new lows. Base rates now stand at 6%. And assuming mortgage lenders pass on the base rate gain in full the variable interest rate at market leader Halifax will be 7.74%, or 1.74% above base rate.

Figures from Moneyfacts magazine show that mortgages were only higher than that on one of the previous four occasions when the base rate was 6%. In January 1993, base rates fell from 7% to 6%. The mortgage rate fell to 7.99% in March 1993. The next time rates were at 6% was again on the way down in March 1996. This converted into a 7.25% variable Halifax rate or 1.25% above base rate.

In October of the same year the Bank's base rate was again 6% .This time the Halifax did not respond immediately, but held its interest levels at 6.99% before raising them to 7.25% in early 1997. And when interest rates fell to 6% in January 1999, the mortgage cost 7.45%. Now it looks like a 1.74% margin over base rates.

But the Halifax argues that its margins over all products did not widen in 1998 compared with 1997. It does not yet have figures for 1999.

Savers have not fared better. In January 1993 the Abbey National instant access rate on a £5,000 deposit stood at 4.5% before tax, or 1.5% below base rates. In March 1996 the gap had doubled to 3.1% to produce a gross 2.9%. By October of that year the Abbey had cut their rate to 2.7%, despite base rates standing again at 6%.

The reaction to the January 1999 6% base rate was to slash the instant-access rate to just 1.65%, or little more than a third of the 1993 level despite the same underlying base rate. And now, in the unlikely - on past performance - case that the Abbey passes on the whole of the increase to savers, they would still receive no more than 1.55% on £5,000 before tax.

Savings banks argue that it is fairer to quote 90-day notice accounts for savings at the £5,000 level. Here, thanks to competition from newcomers such as Standard Life Bank, Scottish Widows Bank and, more recently, the Prudential's online Egg, whose instant access accounts beat most 90-day schemes, average rates quoted in Moneyfacts have held up better.

Most lenders are reluctant to discuss rate rises until they announce them. The Abbey National, contented itself with a "reviewing options" statement although it seems set to raise costs for borrowers. But the Nationwide, the biggest remaining building society which has kept its variable rates around 0.5% below the stockmarket quoted lenders, has more ominous views.

It says: " We have to consider our position carefully bearing in mind we believe in the strong possibility that base rates may continue to rise over the next few months. We also have to balance the needs of borrowers and savers."

This could mean an above average increase for Nationwide borrowers next month. Mutuality is no guarantee against margin building. Its current variable mortgage rate is unchanged on a year ago, although base rates have fallen from 6% to 5.75%. And its rates to savers are nothing to get excited about. Its Cashbuilder instant access account is down 0.35% on £5,000 to 2.9%, although it has gone up from 1% to 1.2% on sums from £1 to £500.

Mr Boulger at John Charcol believes that the latest base rate increase "is highly unlikely to deter those who have made the decision to move home". And he forecasts that: "Rates are not going to rocket out of control. I would not be surprised to see an increase in stamp duty at the next budget to help take the heat out of home prices."

He is also optimistic for borrowers. "It is generally predicted that 2001 will see interest rates falling as the UK begins to move in line with Europe," he says.

But a year ago the experts were forecasting exactly the same - for 1999-2000. And rates moved in the opposite direction to their predictions.

webTitle: How to ... bounce back right after the break

fields.headline: How to ... bounce back right after the break
fields.standfirst: You've had your fun in the sun - now it's time to re-skill
fields.trailText: Are you about to return to work after a long break? Perhaps you have been working or travelling abroad during your time off. Whatever you've been doing your return to work is likely to be both a daunting and exciting prospect as you face a new world of work where voicemails, emails and the latest hand-held computers have taken over the office.
fields.body:
Are you about to return to work after a long break? Perhaps you have been working or travelling abroad during your time off. Whatever you've been doing your return to work is likely to be both a daunting and exciting prospect as you face a new world of work where voicemails, emails and the latest hand-held computers have taken over the office.

Peter Richards, who taught in a secondary school in London before setting off to teach school children in Namibia for two years, describes his return to the UK in 1997 as a culture shock. "It took me time to readapt," admits Peter who read economics at York University. "In the time that I was abroad the internet was just taking off, and it was something I knew very little about." Peter was also unfamiliar with PCs as he had used an Apple Mac at his previous school in London. But thanks to the help of friends in the know Peter learnt how to use the internet, send emails and familiarise himself with a PC in no more than a couple of days.

So, if your knowledge of the latest technology is somewhat limited don't panic.

A refresher course or the help of a friend will put you on track in no time. It's far more beneficial to plan how you are going to acquire the knowledge you don't have while focusing on the invaluable skills you have acquired while abroad.

These skills, coupled with the experience that you have gained while abroad, mean that you will have an edge over your peers who have worked only in the UK.

Jim Grassick a development manager responsible for the recruitment of expatriates for Cussons International in Africa and Asia, is a firm believer in the value of experience abroad. He says: "One of the difficulties we have recruiting from the UK is that most people have no idea of the difficulties associated with working in Africa. Many believe it is one big safari park. The result is a culture shock when they get there, and often an early departure."

Going abroad will have given you a chance to sharpen your planning, problem solving and communication skills. "When you go out to a developing country you find yourself with more responsibilities than you imagined, whereas here, your job description is usually very clearly defined and you stick to it," says Carol Milner, head of return volunteer services at VSO.

Peter Richards is certain he has boosted his skills portfolio considerably by going abroad.

"I've developed the ability to reach a different type of student and became more resourceful because I taught in a classroom with fewer facilities - all I had was a black board, a few chairs and some desks. Yet despite the lack of resources Peter describes the experience as "the best two years of my life. I'm a far better teacher as a result".

Once you are fully aware of what you have to offer you can begin to take steps to ensure a smooth transition back to work. Try to return to work you know well in a place you know well, as this will ensure you don't have too many adjustments to make. But if you decide that you don't want to go back to the same job, consider a skills updating course and even shadowing someone who is pursuing the career path you want.

If you travelled abroad with an organisation like VSO or Raleigh International, make the most of the career days they offer. These often include guidance on CVs and interviews.

Revive contacts with old col leagues and get hold of the latest industry journals.

Peter reckons he would have found the transition back to work in the UK much harder without the latter. "During my last six months in Namibia, VSO sent me out newspapers, so that I was able to keep abreast of current issues."

If you don't remember anything else, remember this...

Overcome any self-doubt by reminding yourself of the skills and talents honed abroad. You might want to consider going freelance initially as you ease your way back into the workforce. This may also help you make an informed decision about where exactly you want to work. And prepare thoroughly for interviews, thinking through the kind of questions you're likely to be asked, such as "why did you choose to take a career break?"

webTitle: Have you got the vital spark?

fields.headline: Have you got the vital spark?
fields.standfirst: Or is your interview style enough to make hair stand on end?
fields.trailText: Projecting your enthusiasm and energy at an interview can tip the scales in your favour when competing with similarly skilled candidates. Ian Wylie gives tips on how to energise your interview technique.
fields.body:
Suppose you're competing for a job against several other candidates with similar relevant experience and excellent CVs. Each of you dresses appropriately for the meeting, shakes hands firmly and maintains eye contact with the interviewer, then answers the questions articulately.

Who'll get the job? While a great CV and interview demeanor can help land an offer, the deciding factor often is the amount of energy or enthusiasm you project during the meeting.

You may think you have every qualification that a company is looking for, yet still fail to arouse its interest. Why?

Even though a company will list specific requirements for the position, an equal number of other areas will influence its decision - a hidden agenda, if you like. This list is more emotional than the first, but its impact on the interview cannot be overlooked.

Items on the forgotten agenda tend to include first impression, personal chemistry, advancement potential, motivation, competence - and energy. Interveiwers like a candidate with 'spar'" - one whose interests and enthusiasm are evident to everyone with whom they speak.

But demonstrating this spark or "energy" isn't easy for many of us. Introverts are often uncomfortable about displaying enthusiasm. Likewise, if you've been unemployed since you graduated last summer, you may not be feeling that enthusiastic about anything. Yet, even quiet candidates who don't normally show energy can learn to demonstrate this quality to interviewers.

Interviewing skills are learned, not innate, so you can teach yourself how to project confidence and enthusiasm during meetings with employers. They only want you to prove to them during this 30-minute session that, if employed, you'll work tirelessly, achieve goals and connect well with others.

Even if you don't have a naturally enthusiastic personality, you can verbally and visually relate how you'll attack assigned projects.

To show vigour, strength and vitality during interviews, start by having the right mind-set. Realise that interviewers want you to convey how you'd approach the available job, not what your personality is like.

To project enthusiasm, think about a cause you're passionate about or an especially enjoyable experience or adventure. It might be a student outing, field trip or volunteer activity you were involved in. Now describe the event and the feeling it gave you.

When you describe such an experience, your enthusiasm and resulting energy will always be apparent because of several verbal and visual cues. For example, your voice level may rise or fall as you describe an exciting event. You may also gesture to convey a strong feeling or action.

You don't have to go over the top, but you do need to show enthusiasm in a way that is natural for you. Employers want to see that you are really involved in the conversation. If you tend to speak in a monotone and have low voice energy, you should try to use more non-verbal behaviors, including smiling.

Work on varying the inflections in your voice, especially when you are emphasizing a point.

Having a more alert, active body posture is another good tip. Sitting up straight or on the edge of a chair and leaning slightly forward shows that you're vitally interested in and excited about what you're discussing.

It's hard to be enthusiastic about another person's experience if he or she doesn't seem interested in it. In other words, if you don't show enthusiasm about your background, interviewers won't be interested, either. They'll have trouble seeing you as a vital achiever who takes pride in reaching job and career goals.

By describing an accomplishment or work project with the same tones and gestures you'd use for an exciting adventure, though, you'll convey your commitment to interviewers. Suddenly your energy, interest and passion for your job will emerge, separating you from candidates who depend on their CVs to speak for them.

You can also demonstrate your energy by showing just how much you want the job. Display your initiative by talking about what functions you could perform that would benefit the organisation, and by giving specific details of how you have helped past employers. You might also ask about specific details of the job position, such as functions, responsibilities, who you would work with, and who you would report to.

No one likes phony enthusiasm. On the other hand, no company recruits graduates who come across as critical or negative - that is one of the most often-heard comments about candidates who are not hired.

Remember that in many cases, companies are run by ambitions entrepreneurs who have given up security and an easier pace for the thrill of seeing their ideas come to fruition.

Approaching an interview in these circumstances without honest enthusiasm for their work will certainly not earn you a job offer.

Sitting up straight or on the edge of a chair and leaning slightly forward shows that you're vitally interested in and excited about what you're discussing. It's hard to be enthusiastic about another person's experience if he or she doesn't seem interested in it. In other words, if you don't show enthusiasm about your background, interviewers won't be interested, either. They'll have trouble seeing you as a vital achiever who takes pride in reaching job and career goals. By describing an accomplishment or work project with the same tones and gestures you'd use for an exciting adventure, though, you'll convey your commitment to interviewers. Suddenly your energy, interest and passion for your job will emerge, separating you from candidates who depend on their CVs to speak for them. You can also demonstrate your energy by showing just how much you want the job. Display your initiative by talking about what functions you could perform that would benefit the organisation, and by giving specific details of how you have helped past employers. You might also ask about specific details of the job position, such as functions, responsibilities, who you would work with, and who you would report to. No one likes phony enthusiasm. On the other hand, no company recruits graduates who come across as critical or negative - that is one of the most often-heard comments about candidates who are not hired. Remember that in many cases, companies are run by ambitions entrepreneurs who have given up security and an easier pace for the thrill of seeing their ideas come to fruition. Approaching an interview in these circumstances without honest enthusiasm for their work will certainly not earn you a job offer.

webTitle: Moving on up: An ABC guide to learning emotional intelligence

fields.headline: Moving on up: An ABC guide to learning emotional intelligence
fields.trailText: It's never too late too improve your emotional IQ
fields.body:
A. Natural selection

You're intelligent - that's good. You're emotional - that's bad, or is it? Depends what you pair it with. Being tired and emotional is not going to enhance your career prospects, but being emotional and intelligent is. Even better, unlike most things that help make you a success, emotional intelligence can be learned and improved upon. So, if you're not tall, handsome, gifted or endowed with good hair, you can compensate by developing a high emotional IQ. It's recognised by many employers as the best predictor of success in managerial roles.

B. Get better soon

If you can pick up cues from others, deal tactfully with difficult people and situations, build rapport and engineer win-win solutions, you're emotionally intelligent. If not, there's still time to learn. It's all to do with how well you're able to understand and deal with others and how you understand and deal with yourself. Intelligence without an emotional angle to it explains the behaviour of many clever but inadequate people.

C. The perfect mix

The emotionally intelligent individual is a blend of common sense and considerate personality with a dash of self control and maturity thrown in. Try an online test at www.queendom.com to see where you are and what you could improve on. Get your boss to try it too. Individuals with even a small degree of emotional intelligence are a dream to work for. Perhaps you should select your next employer on the basis of their EIQ.

webTitle: Help: I've really dropped myself in it now!

fields.headline: Help: I've really dropped myself in it now!
fields.trailText: Advice on what to do when your new employers announce redundancies
fields.body:
I've accepted a job with a company that has subsequently announced redundancies. I have already handed in my notice, but am wondering whether to try to back out and ask to keep my old job.
Alex B, engineer, Northampton

It's quite likely that your prospective employer knew about impending redundancies when they interviewed you. It would be interesting to find out why they didn't tell you. Maybe they thought their plans were not relevant to your post, perhaps they are cautious or secretive.

Whatever, they owe you an explanation. If they didn't know they had problems that's an indication of real trouble and may mean your job offer no longer exists.

Major restructuring exercises can leave employers hiring and firing at the same time. Such measures, although often portrayed as essential pruning to promote new growth and prosperity, mean the company is not healthy right now. Contributing to recovery can be rewarding - if your job is in a new or profitable area you could benefit substantially. However, being a new recruit in a company where others are angry or afraid can be uncomfortable, particularly if they regard you as displacing them.

Get all the facts, including reasons why you weren't told about these changes at the interview. Look at how the company is treating people who are being made redundant, it will give valuable insight into their culture.

If you don't like what you find and have phrased your resignation letter politely, try withdrawing it. Your current employer might forgo the bother of filling a post. Perhaps having nearly lost you they'll appreciate you all the more.

fields.headline: Lloyds to chop and shop
fields.trailText: Lloyds TSB is rebuilding its acquisitions warchest after buying Scottish Widows, ready for a fresh assault on rivals in Britain and mainland Europe.
fields.body:
Lloyds TSB is rebuilding its acquisitions warchest after buying Scottish Widows, ready for a fresh assault on rivals in Britain and mainland Europe.

Peter Ellwood, the bank's chief executive, stressed yesterday he was still looking for deals to accelerate the bank's growth but refused to indicate when or where he might pounce.

His comments came against a further fall in the bank's share price to 626p, even though it reported a 20% rise in pre-tax profits to £3.6bn in 1999.

The bank acknowledged that the movement in its shares, which traded at more than £10 eight months ago, was causing some anguish.

"There's not much doubt somebody thinks we're going to fall off a cliff," Sir Brian Pitman, chairman of Lloyds TSB, said.

The bank, which has been the star performer in the sector through a series of highly regarded mergers, tried to woo investors yesterday by announcing plans to cut jobs and launch a separately branded internet bank spanning continental Europe and Britain.

It also set a target to cut its cost-income ratio - a measure of its efficiency - to 35% by 2002 which Mr Ellwood hoped would become a tough benchmark for the rest of the sector.

However, even that target, which would put Lloyds TSB among the most efficient banks in the world, disappointed some analysts who said they had been expecting more.

Mr Ellwood said the bank's focus was on "revenue growth" generated by selling its customers more products, including life insurance after the takeover of Scottish Widows is completed next month.

He also made it clear the bank had ambition and scope for another acquisition in the UK, although he admitted that competition concerns would prevent it tying up with Barclays or NatWest, which last night surrendered to Royal Bank of Scotland.

While the bank had also spent most of is much-heralded stash of surplus capital, he insisted the pile would build up rapidly to help fund further deals.

"We spent the warchest when we spent £5.5bn on Scottish Widows but each year it goes up [again]," Mr Ellwood said. He estimated the surplus capital would increase by £1bn a year.

Sir Brian also hinted at expansion in Europe to diversify its revenues, 90% of which are derived in Britain.

The bank outlined its strategy to set up a new internet bank in Spain this year, likely to be called e-bank, which would also be rolled out to cus tomers at home later in the year.

In the meantime, customers in Britain are already signing up to the domestic Lloyds TSB internet bank which has set its sights on winning 1m customers by the end of the year, a 20% share of the market.

While the bank has been criticised for taking too long to develop an internet presence, Hugh Pye, banking analyst at Robert Fleming, said Lloyds had a "robust and credible" internet venture.

"They could blow new entrants out of the water," Mr Pye said.

Lloyds TSB's profit figures showed that its share of the mortgage market had dropped during the year and that growth in its core retail banking business had slowed in the second half of the financial year.

The bank will pay a final dividend of 18.5p a share, taking it to a total of 26.6p, a rise of 20%.

fields.headline: Pop Boy with a future
fields.standfirst: Matthew Jay Heavenly Social, London ***
fields.trailText: Matthew Jay, Heavenly Social, London ***
fields.body:
All eyes are on Matthew Jay, Food Records' latest signing. His debut single, Please Don't Send Me Away, was recently Mark and Lard's record of the week on Radio 1, and the assured, alternative folk of his Four Songs EP has already garnered favourable reviews.

Here the 21-year-old from Abergavenny is understandably nervous. The place is packed with a "look and see" crowd who have been contentedly chattering throughout the previous act (a group of men enthusiastically strumming acoustic guitars). Jay perches uncomfortably on a high chair on the tiny stage, says: "Phew, it's fucking hot in here," in dulcet tones, and launches into Four Minute Rebellion, a song that packs a punch with its intricate guitar work and an engaging mix of vulnerability and braggadocio. "You're breaking my nose from 25 feet," he sings and, for the moment, holds the crowd's attention.

Then the band come on - the bassist, drummer and keyboard player - to normalise the proceedings. Jay's wavery, gentle voice doesn't match the power of his guitar-playing, and the band submerges his quirky style. He races through a smoothly melodic Please Don't Send Me Away and a driving, upbeat I Hope She's All Right. By now, though, the crowd are discussing what they had for dinner. Jay wins them back for the slower-paced, more intriguing song Meteorology, with its laid-back 70s feel and metaphorical references to the weather, but shifts again into cheery and chirpy for the penultimate number, sounding like a cross between The La's and Elliot Smith.

The short set leaves little time for Jay to overcome his nerves and get into his stride. It isn't until the end, when the band leave the stage and Jay performs the last song alone, that you feel the strong, subtle force of his music. He finishes with a percussive strum, murmurs "thank you" and disappears through the exit as fast as possible. This boy has burning potential and an ear for McCartney-esque melody. He just has to learn how to project it.

Matthew Jay plays The Social, Nottingham (0115-950 5078), on February 15
